‘Yes, I want a little air. It’s very hot in here.’ And she opened the door. The driving snow and the wind rushed to meet her and struggled with her over the door. But she enjoyed the struggle.
“是的，我想要一点空气。”这里很热。”然后她打开了门。狂风大雪迎面扑来，拖着她翻过门。但她很享受这种挣扎。

She opened the door and went out. The wind seemed as though lying in wait for her; with gleeful whistle it tried to snatch her up and bear her off, but she clung to the cold door post, and holding her skirt got down onto the platform and under the shelter of the carriages. The wind had been powerful on the steps, but on the platform, under the lee of the carriages, there was a lull. With enjoyment she drew deep breaths of the frozen, snowy air, and standing near the carriage looked about the platform and the lighted station.
她打开门走了出去。风似乎在等待着她。它欢快地吹着口哨，想把她抓起来，把她拖走，但她紧紧抓住冰冷的门柱，抓着裙子下了月台，到了车厢的遮蔽处。台阶上的风很大，但月台上，在车厢的背风处，风很平静。她高兴地深深地吸了一口冰冷的雪空气，站在车厢附近环顾站台和灯火通明的车站。

Chapter 30
第30章

The raging tempest rushed whistling between the wheels of the carriages, about the scaffolding, and round the corner of the station. The carriages, posts, people, everything that was to be seen was covered with snow on one side, and was getting more and more thickly covered. For a moment there would come a lull in the storm, but then it would swoop down again with such onslaughts that it seemed impossible to stand against it. Meanwhile men ran to and fro, talking merrily together, their steps crackling on the platform as they continually opened and closed the big doors. The bent shadow of a man glided by at her feet, and she heard sounds of a hammer upon iron. ‘Hand over that telegram!’ came an angry voice out of the stormy darkness on the other side. ‘This way! No. 28!’ several different voices shouted again, and muffled figures ran by covered with snow. Two gentlemen with lighted cigarettes passed by her. She drew one more deep breath of the fresh air, and had just put her hand out of her muff to take hold of the door post and get back into the carriage, when another man in a military overcoat, quite close beside her, stepped between her and the flickering light of the lamp post. She looked round, and the same instant recognized Vronsky’s face. Putting his hand to the peak of his cap, he bowed to her and asked, Was there anything she wanted? Could he be of any service to her? She gazed rather a long while at him without answering, and, in spite of the shadow in which he was standing, she saw, or fancied she saw, both the expression of his face and his eyes. It was again that expression of reverential ecstasy which had so worked upon her the day before. More than once she had told herself during the past few days, and again only a few moments before, that Vronsky was for her only one of the hundreds of young men, forever exactly the same, that are met everywhere, that she would never allow herself to bestow a thought upon him. But now at the first instant of meeting him, she was seized by a feeling of joyful pride. She had no need to ask why he had come. She knew as certainly as if he had told her that he was here to be where she was.
狂暴的暴风雨呼啸着从车厢的车轮之间、脚手架周围、车站的拐角处呼啸而过。马车、驿站、人，所见之处，一侧都被雪覆盖着，而且越来越厚。暴风雨会暂时平静下来，但随后又会猛烈地猛扑下来，让人几乎无法抵挡。与此同时，人们跑来跑去，一起愉快地交谈，他们的脚步在平台上噼啪作响，不断地打开和关闭大门。一个男人弯曲的影子从她脚边滑过，她听到锤子敲打铁的声音。 “交出那份电报！”从另一边暴风雨般的黑暗中传来一个愤怒的声音。 '这边走！ 28号！”几个不同的声音再次喊道，低沉的人影覆盖着积雪跑过。两位点着香烟的绅士从她身边走过。她又深深地吸了一口新鲜空气，刚把手从手筒里伸出来，抓住门柱，回到马车里，另一个穿着军大衣的男人就站在她旁边，站在她中间。她和灯柱上闪烁的光芒。她环顾四周，立刻就认出了渥伦斯基的脸。他把手放在帽檐上，向她鞠了一躬，问道：“她有什么想要的吗？”他能为她提供什么帮助吗？她凝视了他很长一段时间，没有回答，尽管他站在阴影中，她还是看到了，或者说她以为她看到了他的脸和眼睛的表情。这又是前一天在她身上表现出的那种恭敬狂喜的表情。 在过去的几天里，她不止一次地告诉自己，就在几分钟之前，渥伦斯基对她来说只是数百个年轻人中的一个，永远一模一样，到处都会遇到，她永远不会允许她自己对他产生了思念。但现在，在见到他的第一瞬间，她就被一种喜悦的自豪感所占据。她不需要问他为何而来。她清楚地知道，就好像他告诉她，他来这里就是为了她所在的地方。

‘I didn’t know you were going. What are you coming for?’ she said, letting fall the hand with which she had grasped the door post. And irrepressible delight and eagerness shone in her face.
‘我不知道你要走。你来干什么？”她说着，松开了抓着门柱的手。她的脸上闪烁着难以抑制的喜悦和渴望。

‘What am I coming for?’ he repeated, looking straight into her eyes. ‘You know that I have come to be where you are,’ he said; ‘I can’t help it.’
“我来干什么？”他重复道，直视着她的眼睛。 “你知道我来到了你现在所在的地方，”他说。 “我忍不住。”

At that moment the wind, as it were, surmounting all obstacles, sent the snow flying from the carriage roofs, and clanked some sheet of iron it had torn off, while the hoarse whistle of the engine roared in front, plaintively and gloomily. All the awfulness of the storm seemed to her more splendid now. He had said what her soul longed to hear, though she feared it with her reason. She made no answer, and in her face he saw conflict.
就在这时，风仿佛冲破了一切障碍，把车厢顶上的积雪吹得飞扬起来，撕下的铁皮叮当作响，前面传来引擎嘶哑的汽笛声，哀怨而阴沉。暴风雨的所有可怕之处现在对她来说都显得更加美妙。他说出了她灵魂渴望听到的话，尽管她出于理智而害怕。她没有回答，从她的脸上他看到了冲突。

‘Forgive me, if you dislike what I said,’ he said humbly.
“如果你不喜欢我说的话，请原谅我，”他谦虚地说。

He had spoken courteously, deferentially, yet so firmly, so stubbornly, that for a long while she could make no answer.
他说话彬彬有礼，毕恭毕敬，却又那么坚决，那么固执，让她半天都答不上来。

‘It’s wrong, what you say, and I beg you, if you’re a good man, to forget what you’ve said, as I forget it,’ she said at last.
“你说的话是错误的，如果你是个好人，我求你忘记你所说的话，就像我忘记的那样，”她最后说道。

‘Not one word, not one gesture of yours shall I, could I, ever forget...’
“我不会忘记你的任何一句话，任何一个动作……”

‘Enough, enough!’ she cried trying assiduously to give a stern expression to her face, into which he was gazing greedily. And clutching at the cold door post, she clambered up the steps and got rapidly into the corridor of the carriage. But in the little corridor she paused, going over in her imagination what had happened. Though she could not recall her own words or his, she realized instinctively that the momentary conversation had brought them fearfully closer; and she was panic-stricken and blissful at it. After standing still a few seconds, she went into the carriage and sat down in her place. The overstrained condition which had tormented her before did not only come back, but was intensified, and reached such a pitch that she was afraid every minute that something would snap within her from the excessive tension. She did not sleep all night. But in that nervous tension, and in the visions that filled her imagination, there was nothing disagreeable or gloomy: on the contrary there was something blissful, glowing, and exhilarating. Towards morning Anna sank into a doze, sitting in her place, and when she waked it was daylight and the train was near Petersburg. At once thoughts of home, of husband and of son, and the details of that day and the following came upon her.
“够了，够了！”她喊道，努力让自己的脸上露出严肃的表情，而他正贪婪地注视着她。她抓着冰冷的门柱，爬上台阶，快步进入了车厢的走廊。但在小走廊里，她停了下来，在想象中回想发生了什么事。虽然她不记得自己或他说过的话，但她本能地意识到，这短暂的谈话让他们的关系变得可怕起来。她对此既惊慌又高兴。站了几秒，她就上了马车，在自己的位置上坐下。之前折磨她的那种过度紧张的状态不但又回来了，而且还愈演愈烈，以至于她每时每刻都担心自己的内心有什么东西会因为过度的紧张而断裂。她一整晚都没有睡觉。但在那种紧张的神经中，在充满她想象力的幻象中，没有任何令人不快或阴郁的东西：相反，有一些幸福、发光和令人兴奋的东西。黎明时分，安娜坐在自己的位置上打瞌睡，等她醒来时，天已经亮了，火车已经接近彼得堡了。她立刻想到了家、丈夫和儿子，以及那天和接下来的细节。

At Petersburg, as soon as the train stopped and she got out, the first person that attracted her attention was her husband. ‘Oh, mercy! why do his ears look like that?’ she thought, looking at his frigid and imposing figure, and especially the ears that struck her at the moment as propping up the brim of his round hat. Catching sight of her, he came to meet her, his lips falling into their habitual sarcastic smile, and his big, tired eyes looking straight at her. An unpleasant sensation gripped at her heart when she met his obstinate and weary glance, as though she had expected to see him different. She was especially struck by the feeling of dissatisfaction with herself that she experienced on meeting him. That feeling was an intimate, familiar feeling, like a consciousness of hypocrisy, which she experienced in her relations with her husband. But hitherto she had not taken note of the feeling, now she was clearly and painfully aware of it.
到了圣彼得堡，火车一停，她一下车，第一个引起她注意的人就是她的丈夫。 ‘哦，怜悯！ “为什么他的耳朵是这个样子？”她看着他冰冷而威严的身材，尤其是此刻支撑在圆帽檐上的那双耳朵，她心想。看到她，他迎了上去，嘴唇陷入了习惯性的讽刺微笑，一双疲惫的大眼睛直视着她。当她看到他那执拗而疲倦的眼神时，一种不愉快的感觉揪住了她的心，仿佛她早就料到会看到他与众不同。尤其令她震惊的是，她在见到他时所感受到的对自己的不满。那种感觉是一种亲密、熟悉的感觉，就像是一种虚伪的意识，她在与丈夫的关系中体会到了这种感觉。但之前她还没有注意到这种感觉，现在她清楚而痛苦地意识到了。

‘Yes, as you see, your tender spouse, as devoted as the first year after marriage, burned with impatience to see you,’ he said in his deliberate, high-pitched voice, and in that tone which he almost always took with her, a tone of jeering at anyone who should say in earnest what he said.
“是的，正如你所看到的，你温柔的配偶像结婚后第一年一样忠诚，迫不及待地想见到你，”他用他从容的、高亢的声音说道，而且用的是他几乎总是对她采取的语气。 ，一种嘲笑任何应该认真地说出他所说的话的人的语气。

‘Is Seryozha quite well?’ she asked.
“谢廖扎还好吗？”她问。

‘And is this all the reward,’ said he, ‘for my ardor? He’s quite well...’
“这就是对我的热情的全部回报吗？”他说。他很好……”

Chapter 31
第31章

Vronsky had not even tried to sleep all that night. He sat in his armchair, looking straight before him or scanning the people who got in and out. If he had indeed on previous occasions struck and impressed people who did not know him by his air of unhesitating composure, he seemed now more haughty and self-possessed than ever. He looked at people as if they were things. A nervous young man, a clerk in a law court, sitting opposite him, hated him for that look. The young man asked him for a light, and entered into conversation with him, and even pushed against him, to make him feel that he was not a thing, but a person. But Vronsky gazed at him exactly as he did at the lamp, and the young man made a wry face, feeling that he was losing his self-possession under the oppression of this refusal to recognize him as a person.
渥伦斯基整个晚上都没有想睡觉。他坐在扶手椅上，直视前方，或者扫视着进出的人。如果说以前他确实以毫不犹豫的镇定神态给那些不认识他的人留下了深刻的印象，那么现在他似乎比以往任何时候都更加傲慢和沉着。他看人就像看东西一样。坐在他对面的是一个紧张的年轻人，法庭里的一名书记员，讨厌他的样子。年轻人向他要灯，并与他交谈，甚至推挤他，让他觉得自己不是一个东西，而是一个人。但渥伦斯基凝视着他，就像他凝视着油灯一样，年轻人做了个苦脸，觉得在拒绝承认他这个人的压迫下，他正在失去自制。

Vronsky saw nothing and no one. He felt himself a king, not because he believed that he had made an impression on Anna—he did not yet believe that,—but because the impression she had made on him gave him happiness and pride.
渥伦斯基什么也没看到，也没有看到任何人。他觉得自己是一个国王，并不是因为他相信自己给安娜留下了深刻的印象——他还不相信这一点——而是因为她给他留下的印象给了他幸福和自豪。

What would come of it all he did not know, he did not even think. He felt that all his forces, hitherto dissipated, wasted, were centered on one thing, and bent with fearful energy on one blissful goal. And he was happy at it. He knew only that he had told her the truth, that he had come where she was, that all the happiness of his life, the only meaning in life for him, now lay in seeing and hearing her. And when he got out of the carriage at Bologova to get some seltzer water, and caught sight of Anna, involuntarily his first word had told her just what he thought. And he was glad he had told her it, that she knew it now and was thinking of it. He did not sleep all night. When he was back in the carriage, he kept unceasingly going over every position in which he had seen her, every word she had uttered, and before his fancy, making his heart faint with emotion, floated pictures of a possible future.
他不知道这一切会发生什么，他甚至没有想到。他感到自己所有的力量，迄今为止都被消散、浪费了，都集中在一件事上，并以可怕的能量致力于一个幸福的目标。他对此很高兴。他只知道他告诉了她真相，他已经来到了她所在的地方，他一生的幸福，他生命中唯一的意义，现在就在于看到和听到她。当他在博洛戈瓦下马车去买一些苏打水时，看到了安娜，他的第一句话不由自主地告诉了她他的想法。他很高兴他告诉了她这件事，她现在知道了，并且正在考虑这件事。他整夜没有睡觉。回到马车上，他不断地回想自己见过她的每一个姿势，说过的每一句话，脑海中浮现出一幅未来可能的画面，让他心潮澎湃。

When he got out of the train at Petersburg, he felt after his sleepless night as keen and fresh as after a cold bath. He paused near his compartment, waiting for her to get out. ‘Once more,’ he said to himself, smiling unconsciously, ‘once more I shall see her walk, her face; she will say something, turn her head, glance, smile, maybe.’ But before he caught sight of her, he saw her husband, whom the station-master was deferentially escorting through the crowd. ‘Ah, yes! The husband.’ Only now for the first time did Vronsky realize clearly the fact that there was a person attached to her, a husband. He knew that she had a husband, but had hardly believed in his existence, and only now fully believed in him, with his head and shoulders, and his legs clad in black trousers; especially when he saw this husband calmly take her arm with a sense of property.
当他在彼得堡下了火车时，一夜无眠后的他感觉就像洗了一次冷水澡一样精神焕发、神清气爽。他在包厢附近停下来，等着她出去。 “再一次，”他无意识地微笑着对自己说，“我将再一次看到她走路，看到她的脸；”她可能会说些什么，转过头，看一眼，微笑，也许。”但在他看到她之前，他看到了她的丈夫，站长正恭敬地护送他穿过人群。 '是啊！直到现在，渥伦斯基才第一次清楚地意识到，她身边有一个人，一个丈夫。他知道她有丈夫，但几乎不相信他的存在，直到现在才完全相信他，他的头和肩膀，他的腿都穿着黑色的裤子；尤其是当他看到这个丈夫平静地挽着她的手臂，很有财产感的时候。

Seeing Alexey Alexandrovitch with his Petersburg face and severely self-confident figure, in his round hat, with his rather prominent spine, he believed in him, and was aware of a disagreeable sensation, such as a man might feel tortured by thirst, who, on reaching a spring, should find a dog, a sheep, or a pig, who has drunk of it and muddied the water. Alexey Alexandrovitch’s manner of walking, with a swing of the hips and flat feet, particularly annoyed Vronsky. He could recognize in no one but himself an indubitable right to love her. But she was still the same, and the sight of her affected him the same way, physically reviving him, stirring him, and filling his soul with rapture. He told his German valet, who ran up to him from the second class, to take his things and go on, and he himself went up to her. He saw the first meeting between the husband and wife, and noted with a lover’s insight the signs of slight reserve with which she spoke to her husband. ‘No, she does not love him and cannot love him,’ he decided to himself.
看到阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇长着一张彼得堡的脸，有着极其自信的身材，戴着圆帽，脊椎骨相当突出，他相信他，并意识到一种不舒服的感觉，就像一个人可能会因口渴而感到折磨，谁，到了泉水，应有狗、羊、猪，喝了泉水，水就浑了。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇的走路方式，臀部摆动和扁平足，尤其惹恼了渥伦斯基。除了他自己之外，他认不出任何人都拥有爱她的无可置疑的权利。但她还是老样子，一见到她，他就受到同样的影响，让他的肉体苏醒，让他激动，让他的灵魂充满狂喜。他让从二等舱跑到他身边的德国男仆拿走他的东西，然后继续前进，而他自己则走到了她身边。他目睹了这对夫妻的第一次会面，并以情人的洞察力注意到她对丈夫说话时略带保留的迹象。 “不，她不爱他，也不可能爱他，”他暗自决定。

At the moment when he was approaching Anna Arkadyevna he noticed too with joy that she was conscious of his being near, and looked round, and seeing him, turned again to her husband.
当他走近安娜·阿尔卡季耶夫娜时，他也高兴地注意到她意识到他在附近，于是他环顾四周，看到他，又转向她的丈夫。

‘Have you passed a good night?’ he asked, bowing to her and her husband together, and leaving it up to Alexey Alexandrovitch to accept the bow on his own account, and to recognize it or not, as he might see fit.
“你们度过了一个美好的夜晚吗？”他问道，同时向她和她的丈夫鞠了一躬，并让阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇自行接受这一鞠躬，并由他认为合适的时候承认或不承认。

‘Thank you, very good,’ she answered.
“谢谢你，很好，”她回答道。

Her face looked weary, and there was not that play of eagerness in it, peeping out in her smile and her eyes; but for a single instant, as she glanced at him, there was a flash of something in her eyes, and although the flash died away at once, he was happy for that moment. She glanced at her husband to find out whether he knew Vronsky. Alexey Alexandrovitch looked at Vronsky with displeasure, vaguely recalling who this was. Vronsky’s composure and self-confidence here struck, like a scythe against a stone, upon the cold self-confidence of Alexey Alexandrovitch.
她的脸看上去很疲倦，从她的微笑和眼睛里看不出那种热切的神情。但有那么一瞬间，当她看向他的时候，她的眼里闪过一丝光芒，虽然那光芒立刻消失了，但那一刻他还是很高兴。她看了一眼她的丈夫，想知道他是否认识渥伦斯基。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇不满地看着渥伦斯基，隐约想起这是谁。渥伦斯基的冷静和自信，就像镰刀敲打石头一样，打击了阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇的冷漠自信。

‘Count Vronsky,’ said Anna.
“渥伦斯基伯爵，”安娜说。

‘Ah! We are acquainted, I believe,’ said Alexey Alexandrovitch indifferently, giving his hand.
'啊！我相信我们很熟，”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇冷漠地说，伸出了手。

‘You set off with the mother and you return with the son,’ he said, articulating each syllable, as though each were a separate favor he was bestowing.
“你和母亲一起出发，带着儿子回来，”他说，每一个音节都发音清晰，仿佛每个音节都是他给予的一个单独的恩惠。

‘You’re back from leave, I suppose?’ he said, and without waiting for a reply, he turned to his wife in his jesting tone: ‘Well, were a great many tears shed at Moscow at parting?’
“我想你休假回来了？”他说，不等回复，他就用戏谑的语气转向他的妻子：“那么，离别时在莫斯科流了很多眼泪吗？”

By addressing his wife like this he gave Vronsky to understand that he wished to be left alone, and, turning slightly towards him, he touched his hat; but Vronsky turned to Anna Arkadyevna.
通过这样称呼他的妻子，他让渥伦斯基明白他希望一个人呆着，然后他轻轻地转向他，碰了碰帽子；但渥伦斯基转向安娜·阿尔卡季耶芙娜。

‘I hope I may have the honor of calling on you,’ he said.
“我希望我能有幸拜访您，”他说。

Alexey Alexandrovitch glanced with his weary eyes at Vronsky.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇用疲倦的眼睛看了一眼渥伦斯基。

‘Delighted,’ he said coldly. ‘On Mondays we’re at home. Most fortunate,’ he said to his wife, dismissing Vronsky altogether, ‘that I should just have half an hour to meet you, so that I can prove my devotion,’ he went on in the same jesting tone.
“很高兴。”他冷冷地说。 “周一我们都在家。最幸运的是，”他对妻子说，完全不理睬渥伦斯基，“我只有半个小时的时间来见你，这样我就可以证明我的忠诚，”他用同样的开玩笑的语气继续说道。

‘You lay too much stress on your devotion for me to value it much,’ she responded in the same jesting tone, involuntarily listening to the sound of Vronsky’s steps behind them. ‘But what has it to do with me?’ she said to herself, and she began asking her husband how Seryozha had got on without her.
“你太看重你的忠诚了，我根本就不重视它。”她用同样的戏谑语气回答道，同时不由自主地听着身后渥伦斯基的脚步声。 “但这和我有什么关系呢？”她自言自语道，然后她开始问丈夫，没有她，谢廖扎过得怎么样。

‘Oh, capitally! Mariette says he has been very good, And...I must disappoint you...but he has not missed you as your husband has. But once more merci, my dear, for giving me a day. Our dear Samovar will be delighted.’ (He used to call the Countess Lidia Ivanovna, well known in society, a samovar, because she was always bubbling over with excitement.) ‘She has been continually asking after you. And, do you know, if I may venture to advise you, you should go and see her today. You know how she takes everything to heart. Just now, with all her own cares, she’s anxious about the Oblonskys being brought together.’
‘噢，太棒了！玛丽埃特说他一直很好，而且……我一定会让你失望……但他并没有像你丈夫那样想念你。但再次感谢，亲爱的，给我一天的时间。我们亲爱的茶炊会很高兴的。”（他曾把社会上众所周知的莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人称为茶炊，因为她总是兴奋不已。）“她一直在关心你。而且，你知道吗，如果我可以斗胆给你建议的话，你今天就应该去见她。你知道她是如何把一切都放在心上的。现在，她满心忧虑，担心奥布朗斯基一家能聚在一起。

The Countess Lidia Ivanovna was a friend of her husband’s, and the center of that one of the coteries of the Petersburg world with which Anna was, through her husband, in the closest relations.
莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人是她丈夫的朋友，也是彼得堡世界小圈子之一的中心人物，安娜通过她的丈夫与这个小圈子有着最密切的关系。

‘But you know I wrote to her?’
“但你知道我写信给她吗？”

‘Still she’ll want to hear details. Go and see her, if you’re not too tired, my dear. Well, Kondraty will take you in the carriage, while I go to my committee. I shall not be alone at dinner again,’ Alexey Alexandrovitch went on, no longer in a sarcastic tone. ‘You wouldn’t believe how I’ve missed...’ And with a long pressure of her hand and a meaning smile, he put her in her carriage.
“不过她还是想听听细节。亲爱的，如果你不太累的话，就去看她吧。好吧，康德拉蒂会带你坐马车，而我则去我的委员会。我不会再一个人吃饭了。”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇继续说道，语气不再是讽刺。 “你不会相信我怎么会错过……”他用长长的力压着她的手，带着意味深长的微笑，把她放进了马车里。

Chapter 32
第32章

The first person to meet Anna at home was her son. He dashed down the stairs to her, in spite of the governess’s call, and with desperate joy shrieked: ‘Mother! mother!’ Running up to her, he hung on her neck.
第一个在家见到安娜的人是她的儿子。他不顾家庭女教师的呼唤，冲下楼梯来到她身边，带着绝望的喜悦尖叫道：“妈妈！妈妈！”他跑到她面前，掐住了她的脖子。

‘I told you it was mother!’ he shouted to the governess. ‘I knew!’
“我告诉过你那是妈妈！”他对家庭女教师喊道。 '我知道！'

And her son, like her husband, aroused in Anna a feeling akin to disappointment. She had imagined him better than he was in reality. She had to let herself drop down to the reality to enjoy him as he really was. But even as he was, he was charming, with his fair curls, his blue eyes, and his plump, graceful little legs in tightly pulled-up stockings. Anna experienced almost physical pleasure in the sensation of his nearness, and his caresses, and moral soothing, when she met his simple, confiding, and loving glance, and heard his naive questions. Anna took out the presents Dolly’s children had sent him, and told her son what sort of little girl was Tanya at Moscow, and how Tanya could read, and even taught the other children.
而她的儿子，就像她的丈夫一样，让安娜产生了一种类似于失望的感觉。她想象中的他比现实中的他更好。她必须让自己回到现实，才能享受他本来的样子。但即便如此，他还是很迷人，金色的卷发，蓝色的眼睛，还有那双紧紧拉起的长袜，丰满而优雅的小腿。当安娜看到他单纯、信任和爱意的目光，听到他天真的问题时，她在他的亲近和爱抚中体验到几乎是身体上的快乐，以及精神上的抚慰。安娜拿出多莉的孩子们送给他的礼物，告诉儿子塔尼娅在莫斯科是一个什么样的小女孩，塔尼娅会读书，甚至还教了其他孩子。

‘Why, am I not so nice as she?’ asked Seryozha.
“为什么，我没有她那么好？”谢廖扎问道。

‘To me you’re nicer than anyone in the world.’
“对我来说，你比世界上任何人都好。”

‘I know that,’ said Seryozha, smiling.
“我知道，”谢廖扎微笑着说道。

Anna had not had time to drink her coffee when the Countess Lidia Ivanovna was announced. The Countess Lidia Ivanovna was a tall, stout woman, with an unhealthily sallow face and splendid, pensive black eyes. Anna liked her, but today she seemed to be seeing her for the first time with all her defects.
安娜还没来得及喝咖啡，莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人就被宣布了。莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人是一位身材高大、粗壮的女人，有着一张病态的蜡黄脸庞和一双明亮而沉思的黑眼睛。安娜喜欢她，但今天她似乎第一次见到她的所有缺点。

‘Well, my dear, so you took the olive branch?’ inquired Countess Lidia Ivanovna, as soon as she came into the room.
“那么，亲爱的，你拿了橄榄枝吗？”莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人一进屋就问道。

‘Yes, it’s all over, but it was all much less serious than we had supposed,’ answered Anna. ‘My belle-soeur is in general too hasty.’
“是的，一切都结束了，但事情没有我们想象的那么严重。”安娜回答道。 “我的美女总的来说太仓促了。”

But Countess Lidia Ivanovna, though she was interested in everything that did not concern her, had a habit of never listening to what interested her; she interrupted Anna:
然而，莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人虽然对一切与她无关的事情都感兴趣，但她却习惯性地从不听她感兴趣的事情；她打断安娜的话：

‘Yes, there’s plenty of sorrow and evil in the world. I am so worried today.’
是的，世界上有很多悲伤和邪恶。我今天很担心。

‘Oh, why?’ asked Anna, trying to suppress a smile.
“哦，为什么？”安娜问道，试图抑制住笑容。

‘I’m beginning to be weary of fruitlessly championing the truth, and sometimes I’m quite unhinged by it. The Society of the Little Sisters’ (this was a religiously-patriotic, philanthropic institution) ‘was going splendidly, but with these gentlemen it’s impossible to do anything,’ added Countess Lidia Ivanovna in a tone of ironical submission to destiny. ‘They pounce on the idea, and distort it, and then work it out so pettily and unworthily. Two or three people, your husband among them, understand all the importance of the thing, but the others simply drag it down. Yesterday Pravdin wrote to me...’
“我开始厌倦徒劳地捍卫真理，有时我对此感到非常精神错乱。 “小姐妹会”（这是一个宗教爱国慈善机构）“进展得很顺利，但对这些先生来说，什么也做不了”，莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人用一种屈服于命运的讽刺语气补充道。 “他们猛烈抨击这个想法，歪曲它，然后又如此琐碎和不值得地把它付诸实施。有两三个人，其中包括你的丈夫，明白这件事的重要性，但其他人只是拖拖拉拉。昨天普拉夫丁写信给我……”

Pravdin was a well-known Panslavist abroad, and Countess Lidia Ivanovna described the purport of his letter.
普拉夫丁是国外著名的泛斯拉夫主义者，莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人描述了他这封信的主旨。

Then the countess told her of more disagreements and intrigues against the work of the unification of the churches, and departed in haste, as she had that day to be at the meeting of some society and also at the Slavonic committee.
然后伯爵夫人告诉她关于教会统一工作的更多分歧和阴谋，然后匆忙离开，因为她那天要参加一些社团的会议和斯拉夫委员会。

‘It was all the same before, of course; but why was it I didn’t notice it before?’ Anna asked herself. ‘Or has she been very much irritated today? It’s really ludicrous; her object is doing good; she a Christian, yet she’s always angry; and she always has enemies, and always enemies in the name of Christianity and doing good.’
“当然，以前都是这样。但为什么我之前没有注意到呢？”安娜问自己。或者她今天很生气吗？这实在是太可笑了；她的目标是行善；她是基督徒，但她总是生气；她总是有敌人，而且总是以基督教和行善的名义有敌人。

After Countess Lidia Ivanovna another friend came, the wife of a chief secretary, who told her all the news of the town. At three o’clock she too went away, promising to come to dinner. Alexey Alexandrovitch was at the ministry. Anna, left alone, spent the time till dinner in assisting at her son’s dinner (he dined apart from his parents) and in putting her things in order, and in reading and answering the notes and letters which had accumulated on her table.
莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人之后，又来了一位朋友，她是一位首席秘书的妻子，她告诉了她镇上的所有消息。三点钟她也离开了，答应来吃晚饭。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇当时在内阁任职。只剩下安娜一个人，她在晚餐前一直协助儿子准备晚餐（他与父母分开用餐），整理她的东西，阅读和回复桌上堆积的便条和信件。

The feeling of causeless shame, which she had felt on the journey, and her excitement, too, had completely vanished. In the habitual conditions of her life she felt again resolute and irreproachable.
一路上那种无缘无故的羞耻感，以及兴奋之情，都完全消失了。在她惯常的生活条件下，她再次感到坚定和无可指责。

She recalled with wonder her state of mind on the previous day. ‘What was it? Nothing. Vronsky said something silly, which it was easy to put a stop to, and I answered as I ought to have done. To speak of it to my husband would be unnecessary and out of the question. To speak of it would be to attach importance to what has no importance.’ She remembered how she had told her husband of what was almost a declaration made her at Petersburg by a young man, one of her husband’s subordinates, and how Alexey Alexandrovitch had answered that every woman living in the world was exposed to such incidents, but that he had the fullest confidence in her tact, and could never lower her and himself by jealousy. ‘So then there’s no reason to speak of it? And indeed, thank God, there’s nothing to speak of,’ she told herself.
她惊奇地回忆起前一天的心情。 '它以前如何？没有什么。渥伦斯基说了一些愚蠢的话，很容易制止，而我则按我应该做的那样回答。与我丈夫谈论这件事是没有必要的，也是不可能的。谈论它就等于重视那些不重要的事情。”她记得她如何告诉她的丈夫，这几乎是一个年轻人在彼得堡向她发表的声明，她丈夫的下属之一，以及阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇如何他回答说，世界上每个女人都会遇到这样的事情，但他对她的机智充满信心，绝不会因为嫉妒而贬低她和他自己。 ‘既然如此，那就没有理由谈论它了？事实上，感谢上帝，没什么可说的，”她告诉自己。

Chapter 33
第33章

Alexey Alexandrovitch came back from the meeting of the ministers at four o’clock, but as often happened, he had not time to come in to her. He went into his study to see the people waiting for him with petitions, and to sign some papers brought him by his chief secretary. At dinner time (there were always a few people dining with the Karenins) there arrived an old lady, a cousin of Alexey Alexandrovitch, the chief secretary of the department and his wife, and a young man who had been recommended to Alexey Alexandrovitch for the service. Anna went into the drawing room to receive these guests. Precisely at five o’clock, before the bronze Peter the First clock had struck the fifth stroke, Alexey Alexandrovitch came in, wearing a white tie and evening coat with two stars, as he had to go out directly after dinner. Every minute of Alexey Alexandrovitch’s life was portioned out and occupied. And to make time to get through all that lay before him every day, he adhered to the strictest punctuality. ‘Unhasting and unresting,’ was his motto. He came into the dining hall, greeted everyone, and hurriedly sat down, smiling to his wife.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇四点钟从部长会议回来，但像往常一样，他没有时间来见她。他走进书房，看望拿着请愿书等待他的人们，并签署了首席秘书带给他的一些文件。晚餐时间（总有几个人和卡列宁一家一起吃饭）来了一位老太太，她是部门首席秘书阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇及其妻子的表弟，还有一位被推荐给阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇的年轻人。服务。安娜走进客厅接待这些客人。正好五点钟，彼得一世青铜钟敲响第五下之前，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇进来了，他打着白领带，穿着印有两颗星的晚礼服，因为他吃完晚饭就得直接出去。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇生命中的每一分钟都被分配和占用。为了腾出时间来完成每天摆在他面前的所有事情，他坚持最严格的准时。他的座右铭是“不慌不忙、不慌不忙”。他走进餐厅，跟大家打招呼，然后赶紧坐下，对着妻子微笑。

‘Yes, my solitude is over. You wouldn’t believe how uncomfortable’ (he laid stress on the word uncomfortable) ‘it is to dine alone.’
“是的，我的孤独结束了。你不会相信”（他强调“不舒服”这个词）“一个人吃饭是多么不舒服。”

At dinner he talked a little to his wife about Moscow matters, and, with a sarcastic smile, asked her after Stepan Arkadyevitch; but the conversation was for the most part general, dealing with Petersburg official and public news. After dinner he spent half an hour with his guests, and again, with a smile, pressed his wife’s hand, withdrew, and drove off to the council. Anna did not go out that evening either to the Princess Betsy Tverskaya, who, hearing of her return, had invited her, nor to the theater, where she had a box for that evening. She did not go out principally because the dress she had reckoned upon was not ready. Altogether, Anna, on turning, after the departure of her guests, to the consideration of her attire, was very much annoyed. She was generally a mistress of the art of dressing well without great expense, and before leaving Moscow she had given her dressmaker three dresses to transform. The dresses had to be altered so that they could not be recognized, and they ought to have been ready three days before. It appeared that two dresses had not been done at all, while the other one had not been altered as Anna had intended. The dressmaker came to explain, declaring that it would be better as she had done it, and Anna was so furious that she felt ashamed when she thought of it afterwards. To regain her serenity completely she went into the nursery, and spent the whole evening with her son, put him to bed herself, signed him with the cross, and tucked him up. She was glad she had not gone out anywhere, and had spent the evening so well. She felt so light-hearted and serene, she saw so clearly that all that had seemed to her so important on her railway journey was only one of the common trivial incidents of fashionable life, and that she had no reason to feel ashamed before anyone else or before herself. Anna sat down at the hearth with an English novel and waited for her husband. Exactly at half-past nine she heard his ring, and he came into the room.
晚餐时，他和妻子谈了一些莫斯科的事情，并带着讽刺的微笑，问她斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇的情况。但谈话大部分都是一般性的，涉及彼得堡的官方和公共新闻。晚饭后，他和客人们待了半个小时，然后再次微笑着握住妻子的手，退下，开车前往议会。那天晚上，安娜既没有出去见贝特西·特维尔斯卡娅公主（她听说她回来了，就邀请了她），也没有去剧院，因为她那天晚上在那里有包厢。她没有出去，主要是因为她指望的那件衣服还没有准备好。总而言之，安娜在客人离开后，考虑到自己的着装，感到非常恼火。她通常是一位不花钱就能穿得漂亮的艺术女主人，在离开莫斯科之前，她给了她的裁缝师三件衣服来改造。衣服必须改一下，以免被认出来，而且应该在三天前准备好。看来有两件衣服根本就没有做好，而另一件则没有按照安娜的意思进行修改。裁缝过来解释，声称照她做的会更好，安娜气得事后想起来都觉得羞愧。为了彻底恢复平静，她走进育儿室，和儿子一起度过了整个晚上，亲自让他上床睡觉，在他身上画了十字，并为他盖好被子。她很庆幸自己没有出去，这一晚过得很愉快。 她感到如此轻松和平静，她如此清楚地看到，在她的铁路旅途中，所有对她来说如此重要的事情都只是时尚生活中常见的琐事之一，她没有理由在别人面前感到羞耻。或者在她自己面前。安娜拿着一本英文小说坐在炉边等待她的丈夫。九点半整，她听到了他的铃声，他走进了房间。

‘Here you are at last!’ she observed, holding out her hand to him.
“你终于来了！”她向他伸出手说道。

He kissed her hand and sat down beside her.
他吻了吻她的手，然后在她身边坐下。

‘Altogether then, I see your visit was a success,’ he said to her.
“总而言之，我认为你的访问很成功，”他对她说。

‘Oh, yes,’ she said, and she began telling him about everything from the beginning: her journey with Countess Vronskaya, her arrival, the accident at the station. Then she described the pity she had felt, first for her brother, and afterwards for Dolly.
“哦，是的，”她说，然后她开始从头开始告诉他一切：她和渥伦斯卡娅伯爵夫人的旅程，她的到来，车站的事故。然后她描述了她所感受到的怜悯，首先是对她的兄弟，后来是对多莉。

‘I imagine one cannot exonerate such a man from blame, though he is your brother,’ said Alexey Alexandrovitch severely.
“我想，即使他是你的兄弟，也不能为这样一个人开脱，”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇严厉地说。

Anna smiled. She knew that he said that simply to show that family considerations could not prevent him from expressing his genuine opinion. She knew that characteristic in her husband, and liked it.
安娜笑了。她知道，他这么说只是为了表明家庭的考虑，并不能阻止他表达自己的真实想法。她知道她丈夫的这一特点，并且喜欢它。

‘I am glad it has all ended so satisfactorily, and that you are back again,’ he went on. ‘Come, what do they say about the new act I have got passed in the council?’
“我很高兴一切都如此圆满地结束了，而且你又回来了，”他继续说道。 “来吧，他们对我在议会通过的新法案有何看法？”

Anna had heard nothing of this act, And she felt conscience-stricken at having been able so readily to forget what was to him of such importance.
安娜对这件事一无所知，她感到良心不安，因为她竟然能够如此轻易地忘记对他来说如此重要的事情。

‘Here, on the other hand, it has made a great sensation,’ he said, with a complacent smile.
“另一方面，在这里，它引起了巨大的轰动，”他带着自满的微笑说道。

She saw that Alexey Alexandrovitch wanted to tell her something pleasant to him about it, and she brought him by questions to telling it. With the same complacent smile he told her of the ovations he had received in consequence of the act he had passed.
她看出阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇想告诉她一些令他高兴的事情，于是她用问题引导他讲述这件事。他带着同样得意的微笑告诉她，他因自己所做的事情而受到了热烈的欢迎。

‘I was very, very glad. It shows that at last a reasonable and steady view of the matter is becoming prevalent among us.’
“我非常非常高兴。这表明我们终于开始普遍对这个问题有一个合理而稳定的看法。

Having drunk his second cup of tea with cream, and bread, Alexey Alexandrovitch got up, and was going towards his study.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇喝完第二杯加奶油和面包的茶后，起身走向书房。

‘And you’ve not been anywhere this evening? You’ve been dull, I expect?’ he said.
‘今晚你哪儿也没去？我猜你很迟钝吧？”他说。

‘Oh, no!’ she answered, getting up after him and accompanying him across the room to his study. ‘What are you reading now?’ she asked.
“哦，不！”她回答道，在他身后起身，陪着他穿过房间来到书房。 “你现在在读什么？”她问。

‘Just now I’m reading Duc de Lille, Poesie des Enfers,’ he answered. ‘A very remarkable book.’
“我现在正在读里尔公爵的《地狱之诗》，”他回答道。 “一本非常了不起的书。”

Anna smiled, as people smile at the weaknesses of those they love, and, putting her hand under his, she escorted him to the door of the study. She knew his habit, that had grown into a necessity, of reading in the evening. She knew, too, that in spite of his official duties, which swallowed up almost the whole of his time, he considered it his duty to keep up with everything of note that appeared in the intellectual world. She knew, too, that he was really interested in books dealing with politics, philosophy, and theology, that art was utterly foreign to his nature; but, in spite of this, or rather, in consequence of it, Alexey Alexandrovitch never passed over anything in the world of art, but made it his duty to read everything. She knew that in politics, in philosophy, in theology, Alexey Alexandrovitch often had doubts, and made investigations; but on questions of art and poetry, and, above all, of music, of which he was totally devoid of understanding, he had the most distinct and decided opinions. He was fond of talking about Shakespeare, Raphael, Beethoven, of the significance of new schools of poetry and music, all of which were classified by him with very conspicuous consistency.
安娜微笑着，就像人们对自己所爱的人的弱点微笑一样，她把手放在他的手下，护送他到书房门口。她知道他晚上读书的习惯，这已经成为一种必需。她还知道，尽管他的公务几乎占据了他全部的时间，但他认为自己有责任跟上知识界出现的一切值得注意的事情。她也知道，他确实对政治、哲学和神学方面的书籍感兴趣，艺术与他的本性完全不同；他对艺术感兴趣。但是，尽管如此，或者更确切地说，因此，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇从未忽视艺术世界中的任何东西，而是以阅读一切为己任。她知道，在政治上，在哲学上，在神学上，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇经常产生怀疑，并进行调查；但在艺术和诗歌的问题上，尤其是在他完全不懂的音乐问题上，他却有最清晰、最坚定的观点。他喜欢谈论莎士比亚、拉斐尔、贝多芬，喜欢谈论新的诗歌和音乐流派的意义，所有这些都被他以非常明显的一致性进行分类。

‘Well, God be with you,’ she said at the door of the study, where a shaded candle and a decanter of water were already put by his armchair. ‘And I’ll write to Moscow.’
“好吧，愿上帝与你同在。”她在书房门口说道，他的扶手椅旁已经放着一支遮光蜡烛和一瓶水。 “我会写信给莫斯科。”

He pressed her hand, and again kissed it.
他握住她的手，再次吻了上去。

‘All the same he’s a good man; truthful, good-hearted, and remarkable in his own line,’ Anna said to herself going back to her room, as though she were defending him to someone who had attacked him and said that one could not love him. ‘But why is it his ears stick out so strangely? Or has he had his hair cut?’
“尽管如此，他是个好人；诚实、善良、在他自己的行列中是杰出的。”回到自己的房间时，安娜自言自语道，仿佛她在为一个攻击他并说人们不能爱他的人辩护。 “可是他的耳朵为什么这么奇怪地伸出来呢？”或者他剪头发了吗？

Precisely at twelve o’clock, when Anna was still sitting at her writing table, finishing a letter to Dolly, she heard the sound of measured steps in slippers, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, freshly washed and combed, with a book under his arm, came in to her.
正是在十二点钟，当安娜还坐在写字台前，写完给多莉的一封信时，她听到了穿着拖鞋的有节奏的脚步声，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇刚洗漱完毕，腋下夹着一本书，走了过来。进入她的身边。

‘It’s time, it’s time,’ said he, with a meaning smile, and he went into their bedroom.
“是时候了，是时候了，”他意味深长地微笑着说，然后走进了他们的卧室。

‘And what right had he to look at him like that?’ thought Anna, recalling Vronsky’s glance at Alexey Alexandrovitch.
“他有什么权利这样看着他？”安娜想起渥伦斯基看阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇的眼神，心想。

Undressing, she went into the bedroom; but her face had none of the eagerness which, during her stay in Moscow, had fairly flashed from her eyes and her smile; on the contrary, now the fire seemed quenched in her, hidden somewhere far away.
她脱掉衣服，走进卧室。但她的脸上没有任何在莫斯科逗留期间从她的眼睛和微笑中闪现出来的热切。相反，现在她体内的火焰似乎已经熄灭，隐藏在很远的地方。

Chapter 34
第34章

When Vronsky went to Moscow from Petersburg, he had left his large set of rooms in Morskaia to his friend and favorite comrade Petritsky.
当渥伦斯基从彼得堡前往莫斯科时，他把他在莫斯卡亚的一大套房间留给了他的朋友和最喜欢的同志彼得里茨基。

Petritsky was a young lieutenant, not particularly well-connected, and not merely not wealthy, but always hopelessly in debt. Towards evening he was always drunk, and he had often been locked up after all sorts of ludicrous and disgraceful scandals, but he was a favorite both of his comrades and his superior officers. On arriving at twelve o’clock from the station at his flat, Vronsky saw, at the outer door, a hired carriage familiar to him. While still outside his own door, as he rang, he heard masculine laughter, the lisp of a feminine voice, and Petritsky’s voice. ‘If that’s one of the villains, don’t let him in!’ Vronsky told the servant not to announce him, and slipped quietly into the first room. Baroness Shilton, a friend of Petritsky’s, with a rosy little face and flaxen hair, resplendent in a lilac satin gown, and filling the whole room, like a canary, with her Parisian chatter, sat at the round table making coffee. Petritsky, in his overcoat, and the cavalry captain Kamerovsky, in full uniform, probably just come from duty, were sitting each side of her.
佩特里茨基是一位年轻的中尉，人脉并不广，不仅不富有，而且总是负债累累。到了晚上，他总是喝得醉醺醺的，而且经常因各种荒唐可耻的丑闻而被关起来，但他是他的同志和上级军官最喜欢的人。十二点钟，渥伦斯基从车站到达他的公寓，他在外门看到一辆他熟悉的租来的马车。当他还在自家门外时，当他按铃时，他听到了男性的笑声、女性的口齿不清的声音和佩特里茨基的声音。 “如果那是坏人，别让他进来！”渥伦斯基吩咐仆人不要通报他的情况，然后悄悄溜进第一个房间。彼得里茨基的朋友希尔顿男爵夫人坐在圆桌旁煮咖啡，她有着一张红润的小脸，一头亚麻色的头发，穿着一件金光闪闪的淡紫色缎子长袍，像金丝雀一样充满了整个房间。身穿大衣的佩特里茨基和身穿全套制服、可能刚下班的骑兵上尉卡麦罗夫斯基分别坐在她的两侧。

‘Bravo! Vronsky!’ shouted Petritsky, jumping up, scraping his chair. ‘Our host himself! Baroness, some coffee for him out of the new coffee pot. Why, we didn’t expect you! Hope you’re satisfied with the ornament of your study,’ he said, indicating the baroness. ‘You know each other, of course?’
‘太棒了！渥伦斯基！”佩特里茨基喊道，他跳了起来，擦着椅子。 ‘我们的主人本人！男爵夫人，用新咖啡壶给他倒点咖啡。为什么，我们没想到你！希望您对书房的装饰感到满意。”他指着男爵夫人说道。 “你们当然认识吗？”

‘I should think so,’ said Vronsky, with a bright smile, pressing the baroness’s little hand. ‘What next! I’m an old friend.’
“我想是的，”渥伦斯基按着男爵夫人的小手，笑容灿烂地说。 '接下来是什么！我是一个老朋友了。

‘You’re home after a journey,’ said the baroness, ‘so I’m flying. Oh, I’ll be off this minute, if I’m in the way.’
“你旅行结束后回家了，”男爵夫人说，“所以我要飞了。”哦，如果我碍事的话，我马上就走。

‘You’re home, wherever you are, baroness,’ said Vronsky. ‘How do you do, Kamerovsky?’ he added, coldly shaking hands with Kamerovsky.
“无论你身在何处，男爵夫人，你都在家了。”渥伦斯基说道。 “你好，卡麦罗夫斯基？”他补充道，冷冷地与卡麦罗夫斯基握手。

‘There, you never know how to say such pretty things,’ said the baroness, turning to Petritsky.
“在那里，你永远不知道如何说出如此漂亮的话，”男爵夫人转向佩特里茨基说道。

‘No; what’s that for? After dinner I say things quite as good.’
'不;那个有什么用途？晚餐后我说的话也同样好。

‘After dinner there’s no credit in them? Well, then, I’ll make you some coffee, so go and wash and get ready,’ said the baroness, sitting down again, and anxiously turning the screw in the new coffee pot. ‘Pierre, give me the coffee,’ she said, addressing Petritsky, whom she called Pierre as a contraction of his surname, making no secret of her relations with him. ‘I’ll put it in.’
‘吃完晚饭，他们就没有信用了？好吧，那我给你泡点咖啡，你去洗漱准备吧。”男爵夫人说着又坐下来，焦急地转动着新咖啡壶的螺丝。 “皮埃尔，给我咖啡，”她对佩特里茨基说，她称他为皮埃尔，是他姓氏的缩写，毫不掩饰她和他的关系。 “我会把它放进去的。”

‘You’ll spoil it!’
“你会毁掉它的！”

‘No, I won’t spoil it! Well, and your wife?’ said the baroness suddenly, interrupting Vronsky’s conversation with his comrade. ‘We’ve been marrying you here. Have you brought your wife?’
‘不，我不会破坏它！那么，你的妻子呢？”男爵夫人突然说道，打断了渥伦斯基与他同伴的谈话。 “我们一直在这里与你结婚。你带你妻子来了吗？

‘No, baroness. I was born a Bohemian, and a Bohemian I shall die.’
“不，男爵夫人。我生来就是一个波西米亚人，我也将是一个波西米亚人。”

‘So much the better, so much the better. Shake hands on it.’
‘那就更好了，更好了。握手吧。

And the baroness, detaining Vronsky, began telling him, with many jokes, about her last new plans of life, asking his advice.
男爵夫人拘留了渥伦斯基，开始用许多笑话向他讲述她最后的新生活计划，并征求他的意见。

‘He persists in refusing to give me a divorce! Well, what am I to do?’ (He was her husband.) ‘Now I want to begin a suit against him. What do you advise? Kamerovsky, look after the coffee; it’s boiling over. You see, I’m engrossed with business! I want a lawsuit, because I must have my property. Do you understand the folly of it, that on the pretext of my being unfaithful to him,’ she said contemptuously, ‘he wants to get the benefit of my fortune.’
‘他执意不肯跟我离婚！好吧，我该怎么办？”（他是她的丈夫。）“现在我想对他提起诉讼。你有什么建议？卡麦罗夫斯基，照顾咖啡；它已经沸腾了。你看，我全神贯注于生意！我想打官司，因为我必须拥有我的财产。你知道这有多愚蠢吗？以我对他不忠为借口，”她轻蔑地说，“他想从我的财产中获益。”

Vronsky heard with pleasure this light-hearted prattle of a pretty woman, agreed with her, gave her half-joking counsel, and altogether dropped at once into the tone habitual to him in talking to such women. In his Petersburg world all people were divided into utterly opposed classes. One, the lower class, vulgar, stupid, and, above all, ridiculous people, who believe that one husband ought to live with the one wife whom he has lawfully married; that a girl should be innocent, a woman modest, and a man manly, self-controlled, and strong; that one ought to bring up one’s children, earn one’s bread, and pay one’s debts; and various similar absurdities. This was the class of old-fashioned and ridiculous people. But there was another class of people, the real people. To this class they all belonged, and in it the great thing was to be elegant, generous, plucky, gay, to abandon oneself without a blush to every passion, and to laugh at everything else.
渥伦斯基高兴地听到了一位漂亮女人的这种轻松愉快的闲聊，同意她的说法，半开玩笑地给了她忠告，并立即完全变成了他与这样的女人交谈时惯用的语气。在他的彼得堡世界里，所有人都被分为完全对立的阶级。一是下层阶级，粗俗，愚蠢，最重要的是，可笑的人，他们认为一个丈夫应该与他合法结婚的一个妻子住在一起；女孩应该纯真，女人应该谦虚，男人应该有男子气概、自制和坚强；一个人应该养育自己的孩子，养活自己的面包，还清自己的债务；以及各种类似的荒唐事。这是一类守旧而可笑的人。但还有另一类人，真正的人。他们都属于这个阶级，在这个阶级中，最伟大的事情就是优雅、慷慨、勇敢、快乐，对每一种激情都毫不羞愧地放弃自己，并对其他一切一笑置之。

For the first moment only, Vronsky was startled after the impression of a quite different world that he had brought with him from Moscow. But immediately as though slipping his feet into old slippers, he dropped back into the light-hearted, pleasant world he had always lived in.
渥伦斯基第一次从莫斯科带来了一个完全不同的世界的印象，感到震惊。但他立刻就像把脚穿上旧拖鞋一样，又回到​​了他一直生活的轻松愉快的世界。

The coffee was never really made, but spluttered over every one, and boiled away, doing just what was required of it—that is, providing much cause for much noise and laughter, and spoiling a costly rug and the baroness’s gown.
咖啡从来没有真正煮好，而是溅到每个人身上，然后煮掉，做了它所需要的事情——也就是说，提供了很多噪音和笑声的理由，并破坏了昂贵的地毯和男爵夫人的礼服。

‘Well now, good-bye, or you’ll never get washed, and I shall have on my conscience the worst sin a gentleman can commit. So you would advise a knife to his throat?’
“好吧，再见，否则你永远洗不干净，我的良心将犯下绅士所能犯下的最严重的罪孽。”那么你会建议用刀架在他的喉咙上吗？

‘To be sure, and manage that your hand may not be far from his lips. He’ll kiss your hand, and all will end satisfactorily,’ answered Vronsky.
“当然，要设法​​让你的手离他的嘴唇不远。”他会亲吻你的手，一切都会圆满结束。”渥伦斯基回答道。

‘So at the Francais!’ and, with a rustle of her skirts, she vanished.
“在法国也是如此！”随着裙子沙沙作响，她消失了。

Kamerovsky got up too, and Vronsky, not waiting for him to go, shook hands and went off to his dressing room.
卡麦罗夫斯基也站了起来，渥伦斯基不等他走，就和他握手，然后走向更衣室。

While he was washing, Petritsky described to him in brief outlines his position, as far as it had changed since Vronsky had left Petersburg. No money at all. His father said he wouldn’t give him any and pay his debts. His tailor was trying to get him locked up, and another fellow, too, was threatening to get him locked up. The colonel of the regiment had announced that if these scandals did not cease he would have to leave. As for the baroness, he was sick to death of her, especially since she’d taken to offering continually to lend him money. But he had found a girl—he’d show her to Vronsky—a marvel, exquisite, in the strict Oriental style, ‘genre of the slave Rebecca, don’t you know.’ He’d had a row, too, with Berkoshov, and was going to send seconds to him, but of course it would come to nothing. Altogether everything was supremely amusing and jolly. And, not letting his comrade enter into further details of his position, Petritsky proceeded to tell him all the interesting news. As he listened to Petritsky’s familiar stories in the familiar setting of the rooms he had spent the last three years in, Vronsky felt a delightful sense of coming back to the careless Petersburg life that he was used to.
当他洗澡的时候，佩特里茨基向他简要描述了自己的立场，以及自从渥伦斯基离开彼得堡以来情况发生的变化。根本没钱。他的父亲说他不会给他任何东西并偿还他的债务。他的裁缝试图把他关起来，另一个人也威胁要把他关起来。该团的上校宣布，如果这些丑闻不停止，他就必须离开。至于男爵夫人，他实在是烦死她了，尤其是她还不断地借钱给他。但他找到了一个女孩——他会把她展示给渥伦斯基——一个奇迹，精致，具有严格的东方风格，“奴隶丽贝卡的风格，你不知道吗。”他也和他发生过争吵。别尔科绍夫，本来打算给他发几条消息，但当然不会有结果。总而言之，一切都非常有趣和愉快。佩特里茨基没有让他的同志进一步了解他的立场，而是继续告诉他所有有趣的消息。当渥伦斯基在他过去三年呆过的熟悉的房间里听着彼得里茨基熟悉的故事时，他有一种回到他习惯的无忧无虑的彼得堡生活的愉快感觉。

‘Impossible!’ he cried, letting down the pedal of the washing basin in which he had been sousing his healthy red neck. ‘Impossible!’ he cried, at the news that Laura had flung over Fertinghof and had made up to Mileev. ‘And is he as stupid and pleased as ever? Well, and how’s Buzulukov?’
“不可能！”他喊道，放下了洗脸盆的踏板，他一直在洗脸盆里浸泡健康的红脖子。 “不可能！”得知劳拉已经越过费廷霍夫并向米列夫和解的消息后，他喊道。 “他还像以前一样愚蠢而高兴吗？”嗯，布祖卢科夫怎么样？

‘Oh, there is a tale about Buzulukov—simply lovely!’ cried Petritsky. ‘You know his weakness for balls, and he never misses a single court ball. He went to a big ball in a new helmet. Have you seen the new helmets? Very nice, lighter. Well, so he’s standing.... No, I say, do listen.’
“哦，有一个关于布祖卢科夫的故事——太可爱了！”佩特里茨基喊道。 “你知道他在球方面的弱点，他从不错过任何一个球场球。他戴着新头盔去参加一个大型舞会。你见过新头盔吗？非常好，比较轻。好吧，所以他站着……不，我说，听着。

‘I am listening,’ answered Vronsky, rubbing himself with a rough towel.
“我在听。”渥伦斯基一边回答，一边用一条粗糙的毛巾擦着自己。

‘Up comes the Grand Duchess with some ambassador or other, and, as ill-luck would have it, she begins talking to him about the new helmets. The Grand Duchess positively wanted to show the new helmet to the ambassador. They see our friend standing there.’ (Petritsky mimicked how he was standing with the helmet.) ‘The Grand Duchess asked him to give her the helmet; he doesn’t give it to her. What do you think of that? Well, every one’s winking at him, nodding, frowning—give it to her, do! He doesn’t give it to her. He’s mute as a fish. Only picture it!... Well, the...what’s his name, whatever he was...tries to take the helmet from him...he won’t give it up!... He pulls it from him, and hands it to the Grand Duchess. ‘Here, your Highness,’ says he, ‘is the new helmet.’ She turned the helmet the other side up, And—just picture it!—plop went a pear and sweetmeats out of it, two pounds of sweetmeats!...He’d been storing them up, the darling!’
“大公夫人带着一些大使或其他人出现了，不幸的是，她开始与他谈论新头盔。大公夫人非常想向大使展示新头盔。他们看到我们的朋友站在那里。”（佩特里茨基模仿他戴着头盔站着的样子。）“大公夫人让他把头盔给她；他把头盔给了她。他不给她。你对那个怎么想的？好吧，每个人都对他眨眼、点头、皱眉——把它给她，做吧！他不给她。他像鱼一样沉默。只要想象一下！...好吧，那个...他叫什么名字，不管他是什么...试图从他身上夺走头盔...他不会放弃它！...他把它从他身上拉下来，并将其交给大公夫人。 “这是殿下，”他说，“这是新头盔。”她把头盔的另一面朝上，然后——想象一下吧！——扑通一声，一个梨子和甜食从里面出来了，两磅甜食！ “亲爱的，他一直在储存它们！”

Vronsky burst into roars of laughter. And long afterwards, when he was talking of other things, he broke out into his healthy laugh, showing his strong, close rows of teeth, when he thought of the helmet.
渥伦斯基突然放声大笑。很久以后，当他谈论其他事情时，当他想到头盔时，他就会爆发出健康的笑声，露出他坚固而紧密的牙齿。

Having heard all the news, Vronsky, with the assistance of his valet, got into his uniform, and went off to report himself. He intended, when he had done that, to drive to his brother’s and to Betsy’s and to pay several visits with a view to beginning to go into that society where he might meet Madame Karenina. As he always did in Petersburg, he left home not meaning to return till late at night.
听到这个消息后，渥伦斯基在贴身男仆的帮助下穿上制服，前去报到。当他这样做之后，他打算开车去他哥哥和贝特西家，并进行几次访问，以期开始进入那个社会，在那里他可能会遇到卡列尼娜夫人。正如他在彼得堡时常做的那样，他离开家直到深夜才回来。

PART TWO
第二部分

Chapter 1
第1章

At the end of the winter, in the Shtcherbatskys’ house, a consultation was being held, which was to pronounce on the state of Kitty’s health and the measures to be taken to restore her failing strength. She had been ill, and as spring came on she grew worse. The family doctor gave her cod liver oil, then iron, then nitrate of silver, but as the first and the second and the third were alike in doing no good, and as his advice when spring came was to go abroad, a celebrated physician was called in. The celebrated physician, a very handsome man, still youngish, asked to examine the patient. He maintained, with peculiar satisfaction, it seemed, that maiden modesty is a mere relic of barbarism, and that nothing could be more natural than for a man still youngish to handle a young girl naked. He thought it natural because he did it every day, and felt and thought, as it seemed to him, no harm as he did it and consequently he considered modesty in the girl not merely as a relic of barbarism, but also as an insult to himself.
冬末，在谢尔巴茨基夫妇的家里，正在举行一次咨询会，目的是宣布基蒂的健康状况以及恢复她日渐衰弱的体力所需采取的措施。她本来就生过病，随着春天的到来，她的病情变得更加严重。家庭医生给了她鱼肝油，然后是铁剂，然后是硝酸银，但由于第一个、第二个和第三个都没有什么效果，而且春天来了他的建议是出国，一位著名的医生那位著名的医生进来了，他是一位非常英俊的男人，还很年轻，要求给病人做检查。他似乎非常满意地坚持认为，处女的端庄只不过是野蛮的遗风，没有什么比一个还年轻的男人赤身裸体地抚摸年轻女孩更自然的了。他认为这是很自然的，因为他每天都这样做，并且感觉和认为，在他看来，他这样做并没有什么害处，因此他认为女孩的谦虚不仅是野蛮的遗风，而且是对他的侮辱。他自己。

There was nothing for it but to submit, since, although all the doctors had studied in the same school, had read the same books, and learned the same science, and though some people said this celebrated doctor was a bad doctor, in the princess’s household and circle it was for some reason accepted that this celebrated doctor alone had some special knowledge, and that he alone could save Kitty. After a careful examination and sounding of the bewildered patient, dazed with shame, the celebrated doctor, having scrupulously washed his hands, was standing in the drawing room talking to the prince. The prince frowned and coughed, listening to the doctor. As a man who had seen something of life, and neither a fool nor an invalid, he had no faith in medicine, and in his heart was furious at the whole farce, specially as he was perhaps the only one who fully comprehended the cause of Kitty’s illness. ‘Conceited blockhead!’ he thought, as he listened to the celebrated doctor’s chatter about his daughter’s symptoms. The doctor was meantime with difficulty restraining the expression of his contempt for this old gentleman, and with difficulty condescending to the level of his intelligence. He perceived that it was no good talking to the old man, and that the principal person in the house was the mother. Before her he decided to scatter his pearls. At that instant the princess came into the drawing room with the family doctor. The prince withdrew, trying not to show how ridiculous he thought the whole performance. The princess was distracted, and did not know what to do. She felt she had sinned against Kitty.
没有什么办法，只能服从，因为虽然所有的医生都在同一所学校学习，读过同样的书，学过同样的科学，尽管有人说这位名医是个坏医生，但在公主的医院里，出于某种原因，家庭和圈子都认为，只有这位著名的医生拥有一些特殊的知识，而且只有他才能拯救基蒂。这位名医对这位因羞愧而茫然不知所措的病人进行了仔细的检查和探诊后，认真地洗手，站在客厅里与王子交谈。王子皱着眉头，咳嗽着，听着医生的话。作为一个见识过生命的人，既不是傻子，也不是病人，他对医学没有信心，心里对整场闹剧感到愤怒，尤其是他可能是唯一一个完全明白事情起因的人。凯蒂的病。 “自负的傻瓜！”当他听着这位著名医生喋喋不休地谈论他女儿的症状时，他想。医生此时难掩对这位老先生的蔑视，也难以屈尊于他的智力水平。他意识到和老人说话是没有好处的，家里的主要人物是母亲。他决定在她面前撒下他的珍珠。就在这时，公主带着家庭医生走进了客厅。王子退了出去，试图不表现出他认为整个表演有多么荒谬。公主心烦意乱，不知道该怎么办。她觉得自己得罪了凯蒂。

‘Well, doctor, decide our fate,’ said the princess. ‘Tell me everything.’
“好吧，医生，决定我们的命运吧，”公主说道。 '告诉我一切。'

‘Is there hope?’ she meant to say, but her lips quivered, and she could not utter the question. ‘Well, doctor?’
“还有希望吗？”她想说，但嘴唇颤抖着，说不出话来。 “怎么样，医生？”

‘Immediately, princess. I will talk it over with my colleague, and then I will have the honor of laying my opinion before you.’
‘马上，公主。我会和我的同事讨论一下，然后我将荣幸地向您提出我的意见。

‘So we had better leave you?’
“所以我们最好离开你？”

‘As you please.’
“随你便吧。”

The princess went out with a sigh.
公主叹了一口气，出去了。

When the doctors were left alone, the family doctor began timidly explaining his opinion, that there was a commencement of tuberculous trouble, but...and so on. The celebrated doctor listened to him, and in the middle of his sentence looked at his big gold watch.
当医生们独自一人时，家庭医生开始胆怯地解释他的观点，即结核病开始出现，但是……等等。名医听着他的话，说话间看了一眼自己的大金表。

‘Yes,’ said he. ‘But...’
“是的，”他说。 '但...'

The family doctor respectfully ceased in the middle of his observations.
家庭医生观察到一半就恭敬地停了下来。

‘The commencement of the tuberculous process we are not, as you are aware, able to define; till there are cavities, there is nothing definite. But we may suspect it. And there are indications; malnutrition, nervous excitability, and so on. The question stands thus: in presence of indications of tuberculous process, what is to be done to maintain nutrition?’
‘如您所知，我们无法定义结核病过程的开始；在出现空洞之前，没有什么是确定的。但我们可能会怀疑。并且有迹象表明；营养不良、神经兴奋等。问题是这样的：在出现结核病迹象的情况下，应该采取什么措施来维持营养？

‘But, you know, there are always moral, spiritual causes at the back in these cases,’ the family doctor permitted himself to interpolate with a subtle smile.
“但是，你知道，这些病例的背后总是有道德、精神上的原因，”家庭医生微笑着插话道。

‘Yes, that’s an understood thing,’ responded the celebrated physician, again glancing at his watch. ‘Beg pardon, is the Yausky bridge done yet, or shall I have to drive around?’ he asked. ‘Ah! it is. Oh, well, then I can do it in twenty minutes. So we were saying the problem may be put thus: to maintain nutrition and to give tone to the nerves. The one is in close connection with the other, one must attack both sides at once.’
“是的，这是一个可以理解的事情，”这位著名的医生回答道，再次看了一眼手表。 “请问，Yausky 桥已经完工了吗？还是我得开车绕一圈？”他问道。 '啊！这是。哦，好吧，那我二十分钟内就能搞定。所以我们说这个问题可以这样表述：保持营养并调节神经。二者紧密相连，必须同时进攻。

‘And how about a tour abroad?’ asked the family doctor.
“出国旅游怎么样？”家庭医生问道。

‘I’ve no liking for foreign tours. And take note: if there is an early stage of tuberculous process, of which we cannot be certain, a foreign tour will be of no use. What is wanted is means of improving nutrition, and not for lowering it.’ And the celebrated doctor expounded his plan of treatment with Soden waters, a remedy obviously prescribed primarily on the ground that they could do no harm.
“我不喜欢出国旅游。请注意：如果结核病处于早期阶段，而我们无法确定这一点，那么出国旅行将毫无用处。我们需要的是改善营养的方法，而不是降低营养的方法。”这位著名的医生阐述了他用索登水治疗的计划，这种疗法显然主要是因为它们不会造成伤害。

The family doctor listened attentively and respectfully.
家庭医生恭敬地听着。

‘But in favor of foreign travel I would urge the change of habits, the removal from conditions calling up reminiscences. And then the mother wishes it,’ he added.
“但为了支持出国旅行，我会敦促人们改变习惯，摆脱唤起回忆的环境。然后母亲就希望如此，”他补充道。

‘Ah! Well, in that case, to be sure, let them go. Only, those German quacks are mischievous.... They ought to be persuaded.... Well, let them go then.’
'啊！好吧，既然如此，那当然就让他们走吧。只是，那些德国江湖庸医太调皮了……应该说服他们……好吧，那就让他们走吧。

He glanced once more at his watch.
他又看了一眼手表。

‘Oh! time’s up already,’ And he went to the door. The celebrated doctor announced to the princess (a feeling of what was due from him dictated his doing so) that he ought to see the patient once more.
'哦！时间已经到了。”然后他向门口走去。这位著名的医生向公主宣布（一种他应得的感觉决定了他这样做）他应该再次去看病人。

‘What! another examination!’ cried the mother, with horror.
'什么！ “又是一次检查！”母亲惊恐地喊道。

‘Oh, no, only a few details, princess.’
“哦，不，只有一些细节，公主。”

‘Come this way.’
“这边过来。”

And the mother, accompanied by the doctor, went into the drawing room to Kitty. Wasted and flushed, with a peculiar glitter in her eyes, left there by the agony of shame she had been put through, Kitty stood in the middle of the room. When the doctor came in she flushed crimson, and her eyes filled with tears. All her illness and treatment struck her as a thing so stupid, ludicrous even! Doctoring her seemed to her as absurd as putting together the pieces of a broken vase. Her heart was broken. Why would they try to cure her with pills and powders? But she could not grieve her mother, especially as her mother considered herself to blame.
母亲在医生的陪同下，走进客厅去看基蒂。凯蒂站在房间中央，脸色憔悴，脸色通红，眼睛里闪烁着一种奇特的光芒，这是她所经历的耻辱的痛苦所留下的。当医生进来时，她脸色涨红，眼里充满了泪水。她所有的疾病和治疗都让她觉得是愚蠢的，甚至可笑的！在她看来，对她进行治疗就像把破花瓶的碎片拼凑起来一样荒谬。她的心碎了。他们为什么要尝试用药丸和粉末来治疗她？但她不能让母亲悲伤，尤其是她母亲认为自己应该受到责备。

‘May I trouble you to sit down, princess?’ the celebrated doctor said to her.
“公主，可以麻烦您坐下吗？”这位著名的医生对她说道。

He sat down with a smile, facing her, felt her pulse, and again began asking her tiresome questions. She answered him, and all at once got up, furious.
他微笑着坐下来，面对着她，摸了摸她的脉搏，然后又开始问她一些烦人的问题。她回答了他，然后立刻站了起来，愤怒极了。

‘Excuse me, doctor, but there is really no object in this. This is the third time you’ve asked me the same thing.’
“对不起，医生，但这确实没有什么目的。这是你第三次问我同样的事情了。

The celebrated doctor did not take offense.
这位著名的医生并没有生气。

‘Nervous irritability,’ he said to the princess, when Kitty had left the room. ‘However, I had finished...’
“神经过敏，”当基蒂离开房间时，他对公主说。 「不过，我已经完成了……」

And the doctor began scientifically explaining to the princess, as an exceptionally intelligent woman, the condition of the young princess, and concluded by insisting on the drinking of the waters, which were certainly harmless. At the question: Should they go abroad? the doctor plunged into deep meditation, as though resolving a weighty problem. Finally his decision was pronounced: they were to go abroad, but to put no faith in foreign quacks, and to apply to him in any need.
作为一位非常聪明的女人，医生开始向公主科学地解释年轻公主的状况，最后坚持要喝这些水，这些水当然是无害的。问：他们应该出国吗？医生陷入了沉思，仿佛在解决一个重大问题。最后他宣布了决定：他们要出国，但不要相信外国庸医，有任何需要都可以向他申请。

It seemed as though some piece of good fortune had come to pass after the doctor had gone. The mother was much more cheerful when she went back to her daughter, and Kitty pretended to be more cheerful. She had often, almost always, to be pretending now.
医生走后，似乎有什么好运气降临了。当母亲回到女儿身边时，心情愉快多了，基蒂也假装心情愉快。她现在常常、几乎总是在假装。

‘Really, I’m quite well, mamma. But if you want to go abroad, let’s go!’ she said, and trying to appear interested in the proposed tour, she began talking of the preparations for the journey.
“真的，我很好，妈妈。但如果你想出国，那就走吧！”她说，并试图表现出对拟议的旅行感兴趣，并开始谈论这次旅行的准备工作。

Chapter 2
第2章

Soon after the doctor, Dolly had arrived. She knew that there was to be a consultation that day, and though she was only just up after her confinement (she had another baby, a little girl, born at the end of the winter), though she had trouble and anxiety enough of her own, she had left her tiny baby and a sick child, to come and hear Kitty’s fate, which was to be decided that day.
医生过后不久，多莉就到了。她知道那天要进行会诊，虽然她产后才刚刚起床（她又生了一个孩子，一个小女孩，在冬末出生），尽管她已经有足够的麻烦和焦虑了。她自己留下了她的小婴儿和一个生病的孩子，来听听凯蒂的命运，这将在那天决定。

‘Well, well?’ she said, coming into the drawing room, without taking off her hat. ‘You’re all in good spirits. Good news, then?’
“好吧，好吧？”她走进客厅，没有摘下帽子。 ‘你们的精神都很好。那么好消息吗？

They tried to tell her what the doctor had said, but it appeared that though the doctor had talked distinctly enough and at great length, it was utterly impossible to report what he had said. The only point of interest was that it was settled they should go abroad.
他们试图告诉她医生说的话，但似乎医生虽然说得够清楚、够长，但完全不可能报告他所说的内容。唯一有趣的是他们决定出国。

Dolly could not help sighing. Her dearest friend, her sister, was going away. And her life was not a cheerful one. Her relations with Stepan Arkadyevitch after their reconciliation had become humiliating. The union Anna had cemented turned out to be of no solid character, and family harmony was breaking down again at the same point. There had been nothing definite, but Stepan Arkadyevitch was hardly ever at home; money, too, was hardly ever forthcoming, and Dolly was continually tortured by suspicions of infidelity, which she tried to dismiss, dreading the agonies of jealousy she had been through already. The first onslaught of jealousy, once lived through, could never come back again, and even the discovery of infidelities could never now affect her as it had the first time. Such a discovery now would only mean breaking up family habits, and she let herself be deceived, despising him and still more herself, for the weakness. Besides this, the care of her large family was a constant worry to her: first, the nursing of her young baby did not go well, then the nurse had gone away, now one of the children had fallen ill.
多莉忍不住叹了口气。她最亲爱的朋友，她的妹妹，要走了。而她的生活也并不幸福。她与斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇和解后，他们的关系变得令人羞辱。事实证明，安娜所巩固的婚姻并不牢固，家庭的和谐也在同一时刻再次破裂。虽然没有什么确定的事情，但斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇却几乎不在家。钱也很难得到，多莉不断地受到不忠嫌疑的折磨，她试图消除这种怀疑，害怕她已经经历过的嫉妒的痛苦。第一次嫉妒的冲击一旦经历过，就再也不会回来了，即使是发现不忠，现在也不会像第一次那样对她产生影响。现在这样的发现只会意味着打破家庭习惯，而她却让自己被欺骗了，鄙视他，更鄙视自己的弱点。除此之外，照顾她这个大家庭一直是她的烦恼：首先，她的小婴儿的护理不顺利，然后护士走了，现在其中一个孩子生病了。

‘Well, how are all of you?’ asked her mother.
“嗯，你们都好吗？”她妈妈问。

‘Ah, mamma, we have plenty of troubles of our own. Lili is ill, and I’m afraid it’s scarlatina. I have come here now to hear about Kitty, and then I shall shut myself up entirely, if—God forbid—it should be scarlatina.’
“啊，妈妈，我们自己也有很多麻烦。莉莉病了，恐怕是猩红热。我现在来这里是为了听听基蒂的事，然后我会把自己完全封闭起来，如果——上帝保佑——那是猩红病毒。

The old prince too had come in from his study after the doctor’s departure, and after presenting his cheek to Dolly, and saying a few words to her, he turned to his wife:
医生离开后，老王子也从书房回来了，他把脸颊凑到多莉面前，对她说了几句话，然后转向他的妻子：

‘How have you settled it? you’re going? Well, and what do you mean to do with me?’
‘你是怎么解决的？你要去吗？好吧，你想对我做什么？

‘I suppose you had better stay here, Alexander,’ said his wife.
“我想你最好留在这里，亚历山大，”他的妻子说。

‘That’s as you like.’
“随你便吧。”

‘Mamma, why shouldn’t father come with us?’ said Kitty. ‘It would be nicer for him and for us too.’
“妈妈，爸爸为什么不和我们一起去呢？”基蒂说。 “这对他和我们来说都会更好。”

The old prince got up and stroked Kitty’s hair. She lifted her head and looked at him with a forced smile. It always seemed to her that he understood her better than anyone in the family, though he did not say much about her. Being the youngest, she was her father’s favorite, and she fancied that his love gave him insight. When now her glance met his blue kindly eyes looking intently at her, it seemed to her that he saw right through her, and understood all that was not good that was passing within her. Reddening, she stretched out towards him expecting a kiss, but he only patted her hair and said:
老王子站起来，抚摸凯蒂的头发。她抬起头，苦笑着看着他。在她看来，他似乎比家里的任何人都更了解她，尽管他很少谈论她。作为最小的孩子，她是父亲的最爱，她认为他的爱给了他洞察力。现在，当她的目光与他专注地注视着她的蓝色慈祥的眼睛相遇时，她觉得他仿佛看穿了她，并且了解了她内心的所有不好的事情。她红着脸，向他伸了个懒腰，期待着亲吻，但他只是拍拍她的头发，说道：

‘These stupid chignons! There’s no getting at the real daughter. One simply strokes the bristles of dead women. Well, Dolinka,’ he turned to his elder daughter, ‘what’s your young buck about, hey?’
‘这些愚蠢的发髻！没有真正的女儿。人们只需抚摸死去妇女的鬃毛即可。好吧，多林卡，”他转向他的大女儿，“你这个小家伙在做什么，嘿？”

‘Nothing, father,’ answered Dolly, understanding that her husband was meant. ‘He’s always out; I scarcely ever see him,’ she could not resist adding with a sarcastic smile.
“没什么，父亲。”多莉回答道，她明白这是她丈夫的意思。 “他总是外出；我几乎没见过他。”她忍不住讽刺地笑着补充道。

‘Why, hasn’t he gone into the country yet—to see about selling that forest?’
“怎么，他还没有到乡下去看看出售那片森林的事吗？”

‘No, he’s still getting ready for the journey.’
“不，他还在为旅程做准备。”

‘Oh, that’s it!’ said the prince. ‘And so am I to be getting ready for a journey too? At your service,’ he said to his wife, sitting down. ‘And I tell you what, Katia,’ he went on to his younger daughter, ‘you must wake up one fine day and say to yourself: Why, I’m quite well, and merry, and going out again with father for an early morning walk in the frost. Hey?’
“哦，就是这样！”王子说。 “那我也该准备踏上旅程了吗？”为您服务，”他坐下来对妻子说道。 “我告诉你，卡蒂亚，”他继续对他的小女儿说，“你必须在一个晴朗的日子醒来，对自己说：哎呀，我很好，很快乐，又和父亲一起出去玩了。”清晨在霜冻中行走。嘿？'

What her father said seemed simple enough, yet at these words Kitty became confused and overcome like a detected criminal. ‘Yes, he sees it all, he understands it all, and in these words he’s telling me that though I’m ashamed, I must get over my shame.’ She could not pluck up spirit to make any answer. She tried to begin, and all at once burst into tears, and rushed out of the room.
父亲说的话看似简单，但听到这句话，基蒂却像一个被侦破的罪犯一样迷茫、不知所措。 “是的，他看到了这一切，他明白了这一切，他用这些话告诉我，虽然我感到羞耻，但我必须克服我的羞耻。”她无法鼓起勇气做出任何回答。她刚想开口，却突然泪流满面，冲出了房间。

‘See what comes of your jokes!’ the princess pounced down on her husband. ‘You’re always...’ she began a string of reproaches.
“看看你的笑话会开出什么花样！”公主扑向她的丈夫。 “你总是……”她开始了一连串的责备。

The prince listened to the princess’s scolding rather a long while without speaking, but his face was more and more frowning.
王子听着公主的责骂，半晌没有说话，脸色却是越皱越紧。

‘She’s so much to be pitied, poor child, so much to be pitied, and you don’t feel how it hurts her to hear the slightest reference to the cause of it. Ah! to be so mistaken in people!’ said the princess, and by the change in her tone both Dolly and the prince knew she was speaking of Vronsky. ‘I don’t know why there aren’t laws against such base, dishonorable people.’
“她太值得可怜了，可怜的孩子，太值得可怜了，你不会感觉到听到哪怕一点点提及事情的起因，她会感到多么痛苦。啊!公主说，从她语气的变化，多莉和王子都知道她说的是渥伦斯基。 “我不知道为什么没有针对这些卑鄙、不光彩的人的法律。”

‘Ah, I can’t bear to hear you!’ said the prince gloomily, getting up from his low chair, and seeming anxious to get away, yet stopping in the doorway. ‘There are laws, madam, and since you’ve challenged me to it, I’ll tell you who’s to blame for it all: you and you, you and nobody else. Laws against such young gallants there have always been, and there still are! Yes, if there has been nothing that ought not to have been, old as I am, I’d have called him out to the barrier, the young dandy. Yes, and now you physic her and call in these quacks.’
“啊，我不忍心听你说话！”王子阴沉地说，从矮椅子上站起来，似乎急于离开，却在门口停了下来。 “法律是有的，女士，既然你向我提出了挑战，我就告诉你谁应该为这一切负责：你和你，你和其他人。针对这些年轻勇者的法律一直存在，而且仍然存在！是的，如果没有什么不该发生的事情的话，像我这么大的年纪，我就会把他这个年轻的花花公子叫到栅栏去。是的，现在你给她看病，然后叫来这些庸医。”

The prince apparently had plenty more to say, but as soon as the princess heard his tone she subsided at once, and became penitent, as she always did on serious occasions.
王子显然还有很多话要说，但公主一听到他的语气，立刻就平静下来，开始忏悔，就像她在严肃场合总是做的那样。

‘Alexander, Alexander,’ she whispered, moving to him and beginning to weep.
“亚历山大，亚历山大，”她低声说道，走到他身边，开始哭泣。

As soon as she began to cry the prince too calmed down. He went up to her.
当她开始哭泣时，王子也平静下来。他走到她身边。

‘There, that’s enough, that’s enough! You’re wretched too, I know. It can’t be helped. There’s no great harm done. God is merciful...thanks...’ he said, not knowing what he was saying, as he responded to the tearful kiss of the princess that he felt on his hand. And the prince went out of the room.
‘好了，够了，够了！你也很可怜，我知道。这是没办法的事。没有造成太大的伤害。上帝是仁慈的……谢谢……”他不知道自己在说什么，一边回应着公主在他手上流着泪的吻。王子走出了房间。

Before this, as soon as Kitty went out of the room in tears, Dolly, with her motherly, family instincts, had promptly perceived that here a woman’s work lay before her, and she prepared to do it. She took off her hat, and, morally speaking, tucked up her sleeves and prepared for action. While her mother was attacking her father, she tried to restrain her mother, so far as filial reverence would allow. During the prince’s outburst she was silent; she felt ashamed for her mother, and tender towards her father for so quickly being kind again. But when her father left them she made ready for what was the chief thing needful—to go to Kitty and console her.
在此之前，当基蒂泪流满面地走出房间时，多莉带着她母亲般的家庭本能，立刻意识到这里有一个女人的工作摆在她面前，她准备去做。她摘下帽子，从道义上讲，挽起袖子，准备行动。当她的母亲攻击她的父亲时，她试图在孝道允许的范围内约束她的母亲。王子发脾气的时候，她沉默不语。她为母亲感到羞耻，又为父亲这么快又变得友善而感到温柔。但当她父亲离开他们后，她做好了最重要的准备——去找基蒂安慰她。

‘I’d been meaning to tell you something for a long while, mamma: did you know that Levin meant to make Kitty an offer when he was here the last time? He told Stiva so.’
“我一直想告诉你一件事，妈妈：你知道莱文上次来这里时打算向基蒂提出要约吗？他是这么告​​诉斯蒂瓦的。”

‘Well, what then? I don’t understand...’
‘那么，然后呢？我不明白...'

‘So did Kitty perhaps refuse him?... She didn’t tell you so?’
“那么基蒂也许拒绝了他吗？……她没有告诉你吗？”

‘No, she has said nothing to me either of one or the other; she’s too proud. But I know it’s all on account of the other.’
“不，她没有对我说过任何一句话；”她太骄傲了。但我知道这都是因为对方。”

‘Yes, but suppose she has refused Levin, and she wouldn’t have refused him if it hadn’t been for the other, I know. And then, he has deceived her so horribly.’
“是的，但假设她拒绝了莱文，如果不是对方，她也不会拒绝他，我知道。然后，他欺骗了她，真是太可怕了。”

It was too terrible for the princess to think how she had sinned against her daughter, and she broke out angrily.
公主想想自己是如何得罪了自己的女儿，真是太可怕了，她愤怒地爆发了。

‘Oh, I really don’t understand! Nowadays they will all go their own way, and mothers haven’t a word to say in anything, and then...’
‘哦，我实在是不明白！现在他们各走各的路，母亲也无话可说，然后……”

‘Mamma, I’ll go up to her.’
“妈妈，我去见她。”

‘Well, do. Did I tell you not to?’ said her mother.
'干的好。 “我有告诉过你不要这么做吗？”她母亲问道。

Chapter 3
第3章

When she went into Kitty’s little room, a pretty, pink little room, full of knick-knacks in vieux saxe, as fresh, and pink, and white, and gay as Kitty herself had been two months ago, Dolly remembered how they had decorated the room the year before together, with what love and gaiety. Her heart turned cold when she saw Kitty sitting on a low chair near the door, her eyes fixed immovably on a corner of the rug. Kitty glanced at her sister, and the cold, rather ill-tempered expression of her face did not change.
当她走进基蒂的小房间时，这是一间漂亮的粉红色小房间，里面摆满了老萨克斯的小摆设，就像两个月前基蒂本人一样新鲜、粉红色、白色和快乐，多莉记得他们是如何装饰的。去年一起的房间，充满了爱和欢乐。当她看到凯蒂坐在靠近门的一张矮椅上，目光一动不动地盯着地毯的一角时，她的心就凉了。凯蒂看了姐姐一眼，脸上冰冷而有些暴躁的表情没有变化。

‘I’m just going now, and I shall have to keep in and you won’t be able to come to see me,’ said Dolly, sitting down beside her. ‘I want to talk to you.’
“我现在要走了，我得留在家里，你就不能来看我了，”多莉在她旁边坐下说。 '我想跟你说话。'

‘What about?’ Kitty asked swiftly, lifting her head in dismay.
“那又怎样？”凯蒂惊愕地抬起头，连忙问道。

‘What should it be, but your trouble?’
“除了你的麻烦，应该是什么？”

‘I have no trouble.’
“我没有麻烦。”

‘Nonsense, Kitty. Do you suppose I could help knowing? I know all about it. And believe me, it’s of so little consequence.... We’ve all been through it.’
‘废话，基蒂。你认为我能帮忙知道吗？我知道这一切。相信我，这没什么影响……我们都经历过。

Kitty did not speak, and her face had a stern expression.
凯蒂没有说话，脸上的表情十分严峻。

‘He’s not worth your grieving over him,’ pursued Darya Alexandrovna, coming straight to the point.
“他不值得你为他悲伤，”达里娅·亚历山德罗芙娜开门见山地继续说道。

‘No, because he has treated me with contempt,’ said Kitty, in a breaking voice. ‘Don’t talk of it! Please, don’t talk of it!’
“不，因为他蔑视我。”基蒂声音断断续续地说。 ‘别说这个了！拜托，别再说了！”

‘But who can have told you so? No one has said that. I’m certain he was in love with you, and would still be in love with you, if it hadn’t...
“但是谁能告诉你呢？没有人这么说过。我确信他曾经爱过你，并且仍然会爱你，如果不是的话……

‘Oh, the most awful thing of all for me is this sympathizing!’ shrieked Kitty, suddenly flying into a passion. She turned round on her chair, flushed crimson, and rapidly moving her fingers, pinched the clasp of her belt first with one hand and then with the other. Dolly knew this trick her sister had of clenching her hands when she was much excited; she knew, too, that in moments of excitement Kitty was capable of forgetting herself and saying a great deal too much, and Dolly would have soothed her, but it was too late.
“哦，对我来说最可怕的事情就是这种同情！”基蒂尖叫道，突然变得热情起来。她在椅子上转过身来，脸色涨得通红，手指飞快地活动着，先用一只手捏住皮带扣，然后用另一只手捏住。多莉知道她姐姐兴奋时会握紧双手的这个伎俩。她也知道，在兴奋的时刻，基蒂会忘记自己，说太多话，多莉本可以安抚她，但为时已晚。

‘What, what is it you want to make me feel, eh?’ said Kitty quickly. ‘That I’ve been in love with a man who didn’t care a straw for me, and that I’m dying of love for him? And this is said to me by my own sister, who imagines that...that...that she’s sympathizing with me!...I don’t want these condolences and humbug!’
“什么，你想让我感觉到什么，嗯？”基蒂很快说道。 ‘我爱上了一个对我毫不关心的男人，而我却爱得要死？这是我自己的姐姐对我说的，她想象……她同情我！……我不需要这些慰问和欺骗！

‘Kitty, you’re unjust.’
“凯蒂，你不公正。”

‘Why are you tormenting me?’
“你为什么要折磨我？”

‘But I...quite the contrary...I see you’re unhappy...’
“但我……恰恰相反……我看到你不高兴……”

But Kitty in her fury did not hear her.
但愤怒的基蒂没有听到她的声音。

‘I’ve nothing to grieve over and be comforted about. I am too proud ever to allow myself to care for a man who does not love me.’
“我没有什么可悲伤和安慰的。我太骄傲了，不允许自己去关心一个不爱我的男人。

‘Yes, I don’t say so either.... Only one thing. Tell me the truth,’ said Darya Alexandrovna, taking her by the hand: ‘tell me, did Levin speak to you?...’
‘是的，我也不这么说……只有一件事。告诉我真相吧，”达里娅·亚历山德罗夫娜拉着她的手说道：“告诉我，列文跟你说过话吗？……”

The mention of Levin’s name seemed to deprive Kitty of the last vestige of self-control. She leaped up from her chair, and flinging her clasp on the ground, she gesticulated rapidly with her hands and said:
一提到莱文的名字，基蒂似乎就失去了最后一丝自制力。她从椅子上跳起来，把扣子往地上一扔，双手飞快地比划着说道：

‘Why bring Levin in too? I can’t understand what you want to torment me for. I’ve told you, and I say it again, that I have some pride, and never, never would I do as you’re doing—go back to a man who’s deceived you, who has cared for another woman. I can’t understand it! You may, but I can’t!’
“为什么要把莱文也带进来？我不明白你为什么要折磨我。我已经告诉过你了，我再说一遍，我有一些骄傲，我永远不会像你那样做——回到一个欺骗你、关心另一个女人的男人身边。我无法理解！你可以，但我不能！

And saying these words she glanced at her sister, and seeing that Dolly sat silent, her head mournfully bowed, Kitty, instead of running out of the room as she had meant to do, sat down near the door, and hid her face in her handkerchief.
说着这句话，她看了一眼姐姐，看到多莉一言不发地坐着，悲哀地低着头，基蒂并没有像她本来想的那样跑出房间，而是在门边坐下，把脸埋在她的身上。手帕。

The silence lasted for two minutes: Dolly was thinking of herself. That humiliation of which she was always conscious came back to her with a peculiar bitterness when her sister reminded her of it. She had not looked for such cruelty in her sister, and she was angry with her. But suddenly she heard the rustle of a skirt, and with it the sound of heart-rending, smothered sobbing, and felt arms about her neck. Kitty was on her knees before her.
沉默持续了两分钟：多莉正在想着自己。当她姐姐提醒她时，她总是感到的那种羞辱带着一种特殊的痛苦又回到了她的脑海中。她并没有在姐姐身上看到如此残忍的行为，她对她很生气。但突然她听到裙子的沙沙声，随之而来的是令人心碎、窒息的抽泣声，感觉到有人搂住了她的脖子。基蒂跪在她面前。

‘Dolinka, I am so, so wretched!’ she whispered penitently. And the sweet face covered with tears hid itself in Darya Alexandrovna’s skirt.
“多林卡，我真是太可怜了！”她悔恨地低声说道。那张满是泪水的甜美脸庞藏在达里娅·亚历山德罗夫娜的裙子里。

As though tears were the indispensable oil, without which the machinery of mutual confidence could not run smoothly between the two sisters, the sisters after their tears talked, not of what was uppermost in their minds, but, though they talked of outside matters, they understood each other. Kitty knew that the words she had uttered in anger about her husband’s infidelity and her humiliating position had cut her poor sister to the heart, but that she had forgiven her. Dolly for her part knew all she had wanted to find out. She felt certain that her surmises were correct; that Kitty’s misery, her inconsolable misery, was due precisely to the fact that Levin had made her an offer and she had refused him, and Vronsky had deceived her, and that she was fully prepared to love Levin and to detest Vronsky. Kitty said not a word of that; she talked of nothing but her spiritual condition.
仿佛眼泪是必不可少的油，没有它，两姐妹之间的相互信任机制就无法顺利运转，姐妹俩流泪后所谈论的，不是她们心里最重要的事情，而是，虽然她们谈论的是外面的事情，互相理解。基蒂知道，她因丈夫的不忠和自己的屈辱地位而愤怒地说出的话刺痛了她可怜的妹妹的心，但她已经原谅了她。就多莉而言，她知道她想知道的一切。她确信自己的猜测是正确的。基蒂的痛苦，她无法安慰的痛苦，正是由于列文向她提出了要约而她拒绝了他，而渥伦斯基欺骗了她，而她已经做好了充分的准备去爱列文并厌恶渥伦斯基。基蒂对此一言不发。她只谈论了她的精神状况。

‘I have nothing to make me miserable,’ she said, getting calmer; ‘but can you understand that everything has become hateful, loathsome, coarse to me, and I myself most of all? You can’t imagine what loathsome thoughts I have about everything.’
“我没有什么可以让我痛苦的，”她说，心情变得平静下来。 ‘但是你能理解，一切对我来说，尤其是对我自己来说，都变得可恨、可憎、粗俗吗？你无法想象我对一切都有多么令人厌恶的想法。

‘Why, whatever loathsome thoughts can you have?’ asked Dolly, smiling.
“为什么，你能有什么令人厌恶的想法？”多莉微笑着问道。

‘The most utterly loathsome and coarse: I can’t tell you. It’s not unhappiness, or low spirits, but much worse. As though everything that was good in me was all hidden away, and nothing was left but the most loathsome. Come, how am I to tell you?’ she went on, seeing the puzzled look in her sister’s eyes. ‘Father began saying something to me just now.... It seems to me he thinks all I want is to be married. Mother takes me to a ball: it seems to me she only takes me to get me married off as soon as may be, and be rid of me. I know it’s not the truth, but I can’t drive away such thoughts. Eligible suitors, as they call them—I can’t bear to see them. It seems to me they’re taking stock of me and summing me up. In old days to go anywhere in a ball dress was a simple joy to me, I admired myself; now I feel ashamed and awkward. And then! The doctor.... Then...’ Kitty hesitated; she wanted to say further that ever since this change had taken place in her, Stepan Arkadyevitch had become insufferably repulsive to her, and that she could not see him without the grossest and most hideous conceptions rising before her imagination.
“最令人厌恶和粗俗的：我不能告诉你。这不是不快乐，也不是情绪低落，而是更糟。仿佛我身上一切美好的东西都被隐藏起来，除了最令人厌恶的东西之外，什么也没有留下。来吧，我该怎么告诉你呢？”她继续说道，看到姐姐眼中困惑的表情。 “父亲刚才开始对我说话……在我看来，他认为我只想结婚。母亲带我去参加一个舞会：在我看来，她带我只是为了尽快让我结婚，然后摆脱我。我知道这不是事实，但我无法赶走这样的想法。合格的追求者，正如他们所说的那样——我不忍心见到他们。在我看来，他们正在评估我并总结我。以前，穿着舞会礼服去任何地方对我来说都是一种简单的快乐，我很佩服自己；现在我感到羞愧和尴尬。进而！医生……然后……”基蒂犹豫了一下；她还想进一步说，自从她身上发生了这种变化，斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇就变得令她难以忍受地厌恶，她一见到他，就会在她的想象中浮现出最粗俗、最可怕的想法。

‘Oh, well, everything presents itself to me, in the coarsest, most loathsome light,’ she went on. ‘That’s my illness. Perhaps it will pass off.’
“哦，好吧，一切都以最粗俗、最令人厌恶的方式呈现在我面前，”她继续说道。 ‘这就是我的病。也许它会过去。

‘But you mustn’t think about it.’
“但你千万别想这个。”

‘I can’t help it. I’m never happy except with the children at your house.’
“我忍不住。”除了和你家的孩子们在一起之外，我从来都不快乐。”

‘What a pity you can’t be with me!’
“可惜你不能和我在一起！”

‘Oh, yes, I’m coming. I’ve had scarlatina, and I’ll persuade mamma to let me.’
‘哦，是的，我来了。我得过猩红热，我会说服妈妈让我这么做。

Kitty insisted on having her way, and went to stay at her sister’s and nursed the children all through the scarlatina, for scarlatina it turned out to be. The two sisters brought all the six children successfully through it, but Kitty was no better in health, and in Lent the Shtcherbatskys went abroad.
凯蒂坚持要按自己的方式行事，她去姐姐家住下，在猩红热期间照顾孩子们，因为事实证明是猩红热。两姐妹带着六个孩子顺利度过了难关，但基蒂的健康状况并没有好转，四旬斋期间，谢尔巴茨基一家出国了。

Chapter 4
第4章

The highest Petersburg society is essentially one: in it everyone knows everyone else, everyone even visits everyone else. But this great set has its subdivisions. Anna Arkadyevna Karenina had friends and close ties in three different circles of this highest society. One circle was her husband’s government official set, consisting of his colleagues and subordinates, brought together in the most various and capricious manner, and belonging to different social strata. Anna found it difficult now to recall the feeling of almost awe-stricken reverence which she had at first entertained for these persons. Now she knew all of them as people know one another in a country town; she knew their habits and weaknesses, and where the shoe pinched each one of them. She knew their relations with one another and with the head authorities, knew who was for whom, and how each one maintained his position, and where they agreed and disagreed. But the circle of political, masculine interests had never interested her, in spite of countess Lidia Ivanovna’s influence, and she avoided it.
圣彼得堡的最高社会本质上是一个：其中每个人都认识其他人，每个人甚至拜访其他人。但这个伟大的集合还有它的细分。安娜·阿尔卡季耶夫娜·卡列尼娜在这个最高社会的三个不同圈子里都有朋友和密切的联系。其中一个圈子是她丈夫的官僚圈子，由他的同事和下属组成，形式极其多样、反复无常，属于不同的社会阶层。安娜现在很难回忆起她最初对这些人抱有的近乎敬畏的感觉。现在她对他们所有人都了如指掌，就像乡村小镇里的人们互相认识一样。她了解他们的习惯和弱点，也知道鞋子对他们每个人造成的伤害。她了解他们之间的关系以及他们与最高当局的关系，知道谁是为谁服务的，以及每个人如何维持自己的立场，以及他们同意和不同意的地方。但尽管莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人有影响力，但她对政治、男性利益圈子从来不感兴趣，而且她回避它。

Another little set with which Anna was in close relations was the one by means of which Alexey Alexandrovitch had made his career. The center of this circle was the Countess Lidia Ivanovna. It was a set made up of elderly, ugly, benevolent, and godly women, and clever, learned, and ambitious men. One of the clever people belonging to the set had called it ‘the conscience of Petersburg society.’ Alexey Alexandrovitch had the highest esteem for this circle, and Anna with her special gift for getting on with everyone, had in the early days of her life in Petersburg made friends in this circle also. Now, since her return from Moscow, she had come to feel this set insufferable. It seemed to her that both she and all of them were insincere, and she felt so bored and ill at ease in that world that she went to see the Countess Lidia Ivanovna as little as possible.
与安娜关系密切的另一套小套装是阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇赖以取得事业的一套。这个圆圈的中心是莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人。这是一个由年老、丑陋、仁慈、虔诚的女性和聪明、博学、雄心勃勃的男性组成的群体。这个圈子里的一位聪明人称其为“彼得堡社会的良心”。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇对这个圈子怀有最高的敬意，而安娜则有着与每个人相处融洽的特殊天赋，在她生命的早期，在彼得堡也结识了这个圈子的朋友。现在，自从她从莫斯科回来后，她开始觉得这一套令人难以忍受。在她看来，她和他们所有人都是不真诚的，她在那个世界里感到无聊和不安，所以她尽量少去见莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人。

The third circle with which Anna had ties was preeminently the fashionable world—the world of balls, of dinners, of sumptuous dresses, the world that hung on to the court with one hand, so as to avoid sinking to the level of the demi-monde. For the demi-monde the members of that fashionable world believed that they despised, though their tastes were not merely similar, but in fact identical. Her connection with this circle was kept up through Princess Betsy Tverskaya, her cousin’s wife, who had an income of a hundred and twenty thousand roubles, and who had taken a great fancy to Anna ever since she first came out, showed her much attention, and drew her into her set, making fun of Countess Lidia Ivanovna’s coterie.
与安娜有联系的第三个圈子主要是时尚世界——舞会、晚宴、华丽礼服的世界，是一个用一只手紧紧抓住球场的世界，以避免沉沦到半官方的水平。世界。对于半世界人士来说，时尚界的成员认为他们鄙视他们，尽管他们的品味不仅相似，而且实际上是相同的。她与这个圈子的联系是通过她表弟的妻子贝特西·特维尔斯卡娅公主保持的，她的收入有十二万卢布，从安娜刚出道时就很喜欢她，对她表现出了极大的关注，并把她拉进自己的圈子，取笑莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人的小圈子。

‘When I’m old and ugly I’ll be the same,’ Betsy used to say; ‘but for a pretty young woman like you it’s early days for that house of charity.’
贝特西常说：“当我又老又丑的时候，我还是老样子。” “但对于像你这样年轻漂亮的女人来说，慈善之家还处于早期发展阶段。”

Anna had at first avoided as far as she could Princess Tverskaya’s world, because it necessitated an expenditure beyond her means, and besides in her heart she preferred the first circle.
