The princess thought everything delightful, and in spite of her established position in Russian society, she tried abroad to be like a European fashionable lady, which she was not—for the simple reason that she was a typical Russian gentlewoman; and so she was affected, which did not altogether suit her. The prince, on the contrary, thought everything foreign detestable, got sick of European life, kept to his Russian habits, and purposely tried to show himself abroad less European than he was in reality.
王子和公主对于国外生活的看法截然相反。公主认为一切都令人愉快，尽管她在俄罗斯社会中拥有既定的地位，但她在国外试图像欧洲时尚女士一样，但她没有——原因很简单，因为她是一位典型的俄罗斯淑女；所以她受到了影响，这并不完全适合她。相反，王子认为外国的一切都是可憎的，厌倦了欧洲的生活，保留了他的俄罗斯习惯，并故意在国外表现得不像现实中的欧洲人。

The prince returned thinner, with the skin hanging in loose bags on his cheeks, but in the most cheerful frame of mind. His good humor was even greater when he saw Kitty completely recovered. The news of Kitty’s friendship with Madame Stahl and Varenka, and the reports the princess gave him of some kind of change she had noticed in Kitty, troubled the prince and aroused his habitual feeling of jealousy of everything that drew his daughter away from him, and a dread that his daughter might have got out of the reach of his influence into regions inaccessible to him. But these unpleasant matters were all drowned in the sea of kindliness and good humor which was always within him, and more so than ever since his course of Carlsbad waters.
王子回来时瘦了，脸颊上的皮肤松松垮垮，但心情却很愉快。当看到凯蒂完全康复后，他的心情更加愉悦。基蒂与斯塔尔夫人和瓦伦卡的友谊的消息，以及公主向他报告的她在基蒂身上注意到的某种变化，使王子感到不安，并引起了他对一切使他的女儿远离他的事物的习惯性嫉妒感，并且担心他的女儿可能会脱离他的影响力，进入他无法进入的地区。但这些不愉快的事情都淹没在他内心始终充满的仁慈和幽默的海洋中，自从他在卡尔斯巴德海域航行以来，这种情况比以往任何时候都更加明显。

The day after his arrival the prince, in his long overcoat, with his Russian wrinkles and baggy cheeks propped up by a starched collar, set off with his daughter to the spring in the greatest good humor.
抵达后的第二天，王子穿着长大衣，带着俄罗斯式的皱纹，浆过的衣领支撑着松垮的脸颊，兴高采烈地带着女儿出发去春天。

It was a lovely morning: the bright, cheerful houses with their little gardens, the sight of the red-faced, red-armed, beer-drinking German waitresses, working away merrily, did the heart good. But the nearer they got to the springs the oftener they met sick people; and their appearance seemed more pitiable than ever among the everyday conditions of prosperous German life. Kitty was no longer struck by this contrast. The bright sun, the brilliant green of the foliage, the strains of the music were for her the natural setting of all these familiar faces, with their changes to greater emaciation or to convalescence, for which she watched. But to the prince the brightness and gaiety of the June morning, and the sound of the orchestra playing a gay waltz then in fashion, and above all, the appearance of the healthy attendants, seemed something unseemly and monstrous, in conjunction with these slowly moving, dying figures gathered together from all parts of Europe. In spite of his feeling of pride and, as it were, of the return of youth, with his favorite daughter on his arm, he felt awkward, and almost ashamed of his vigorous step and his sturdy, stout limbs. He felt almost like a man not dressed in a crowd.
这是一个美好的早晨：明亮、欢快的房子和小花园，红脸、红臂、喝着啤酒的德国女服务员愉快地工作，使心脏受益匪浅。但越靠近泉水，就越常遇到病人。在德国人富裕的日常生活中，他们的外表似乎比以往任何时候都更加可怜。基蒂不再对这种对比感到震惊。明媚的阳光、翠绿的树叶、悠扬的音乐，对她来说都是所有这些熟悉的面孔的自然背景，她注视着他们变得更加憔悴或康复。但对王子来说，六月早晨的明亮和欢乐，管弦乐队演奏着当时流行的欢快华尔兹的声音，尤其是健康侍从的外表，与这些缓慢移动的东西结合在一起，似乎有些不合时宜和可怕的。 ，来自欧洲各地的垂死人物聚集在一起。尽管他感到自豪，可以说，他的手臂上挽着他最喜欢的女儿，他感到自己又回到了青春，但他却感到很尴尬，几乎为自己有力的步伐和粗壮的四肢感到羞愧。他感觉自己就像一个不穿衣服出现在人群中的人。

‘Present me to your new friends,’ he said to his daughter, squeezing her hand with his elbow. ‘I like even your horrid Soden for making you so well again. Only it’s melancholy, very melancholy here. Who’s that?’
“把我介绍给你的新朋友，”他对女儿说，用肘部捏着她的手。 “我什至喜欢你那可怕的索登，因为他让你又恢复了健康。”只是这里很忧郁，非常忧郁。那是谁？'

Kitty mentioned the names of all the people they met, with some of whom she was acquainted and some not. At the entrance of the garden they met the blind lady, Madame Berthe, with her guide, and the prince was delighted to see the old Frenchwoman’s face light up when she heard Kitty’s voice. She at once began talking to him with French exaggerated politeness, applauding him for having such a delightful daughter, extolling Kitty to the skies before her face, and calling her a treasure, a pearl, and a consoling angel.
基蒂提到了他们遇到的所有人的名字，其中有些是她认识的，有些是不认识的。在花园入口处，他们遇到了盲人女士贝尔特夫人和她的向导，王子很高兴看到这位法国老妇人听到基蒂的声音时脸上露出了笑容。她立刻开始用法国人夸张的礼貌和他说话，称赞他有一个如此可爱的女儿，当着她的面把凯蒂捧上天，称她为宝贝、珍珠、安慰天使。

‘Well, she’s the second angel, then,’ said the prince, smiling. ‘she calls Mademoiselle Varenka angel number one.’
“那么，她就是第二位天使了，”王子微笑着说道。 “她称瓦伦卡小姐为第一天使。”

‘Oh! Mademoiselle Varenka, she’s a real angel, allez,’ Madame Berthe assented.
'哦！瓦伦卡小姐，她是一位真正的天使，好啊，”贝尔特夫人表示同意。

In the arcade they met Varenka herself. She was walking rapidly towards them carrying an elegant red bag.
在拱廊里，他们遇见了瓦伦卡本人。她提着一个优雅的红色包包，快步向他们走来。

‘Here is papa come,’ Kitty said to her.
“爸爸来了，”基蒂对她说。

Varenka made—simply and naturally as she did everything—a movement between a bow and a curtsey, and immediately began talking to the prince, without shyness, naturally, as she talked to everyone.
瓦伦卡做了一个介于鞠躬和屈膝礼之间的动作，就像她做任何事情一样简单而自然，然后立即开始与王子交谈，毫不害羞，自然，就像她对每个人交谈一样。

‘Of course I know you; I know you very well,’ the prince said to her with a smile, in which Kitty detected with joy that her father liked her friend. ‘Where are you off to in such haste?’
‘我当然认识你； “我很了解你。”王子微笑着对她说，基蒂高兴地发现父亲喜欢她的朋友。 “这么着急，你要去哪里？”

‘Maman’s here,’ she said, turning to Kitty. ‘She has not slept all night, and the doctor advised her to go out. I’m taking her her work.’
“妈妈在这里，”她转向基蒂说道。 ‘她一夜没睡，医生建议她出去。我要把她的工作交给她。

‘So that’s angel number one?’ said the prince when Varenka had gone on.
“那么，那是第一号天使？”瓦伦卡继续说下去时，王子问道。

Kitty saw that her father had meant to make fun of Varenka, but that he could not do it because he liked her.
基蒂看出父亲是想取笑瓦伦卡，但他不能这么做，因为他喜欢她。

‘Come, so we shall see all your friends,’ he went on, ‘even Madame Stahl, if she deigns to recognize me.’
“来吧，这样我们就能见到你所有的朋友了，”他继续说道，“甚至包括斯塔尔夫人，如果她能认出我的话。”

‘Why, did you know her, papa?’ Kitty asked apprehensively, catching the gleam of irony that kindled in the prince’s eyes at the mention of Madame Stahl.
“为什么，你认识她，爸爸？”基蒂忧心忡忡地问道，她注意到王子一提到斯塔尔夫人，眼中就闪烁着讽刺的光芒。

‘I used to know her husband, and her too a little, before she’d joined the Pietists.’
“在她加入敬虔派之前，我曾经认识她的丈夫，对她也有一点了解。”

‘What is a Pietist, papa?’ asked Kitty, dismayed to find that what she prized so highly in Madame Stahl had a name.
“爸爸，什么是敬虔主义者？”基蒂问道，她沮丧地发现斯塔尔夫人身上她如此珍视的东西竟然有一个名字。

‘I don’t quite know myself. I only know that she thanks God for everything, for every misfortune, and thanks God too that her husband died. And that’s rather droll, as they didn’t get on together.’
‘我不太了解自己。我只知道她感谢上帝的一切，感谢上帝的每一次不幸，也感谢上帝让她的丈夫去世了。这很滑稽，因为他们相处得不好。

‘Who’s that? What a piteous face!’ he asked, noticing a sick man of medium height sitting on a bench, wearing a brown overcoat and white trousers that fell in strange folds about his long, fleshless legs. This man lifted his straw hat, showed his scanty curly hair and high forehead, painfully reddened by the pressure of the hat.
'那是谁？多么可怜的脸啊！”他问道，注意到一个中等身材的病人坐在长凳上，穿着棕色大衣和白色裤子，奇怪的褶皱落在他长而无肉的腿上。这人掀起了草帽，露出稀疏的卷发和高高的额头，被帽子压得通红。

‘That’s Petrov, an artist,’ answered Kitty, blushing. ‘And that’s his wife,’ she added, indicating Anna Pavlovna, who, as though on purpose, at the very instant they approached walked away after a child that had run off along a path.
“那是彼得罗夫，一位艺术家。”基蒂红着脸回答道。 “那是他的妻子，”她补充道，指着安娜·帕夫洛夫娜，在他们走近的那一刻，安娜·帕夫洛夫娜似乎是故意的，跟着一个沿着小路跑掉的孩子走开了。

‘Poor fellow! and what a nice face he has!’ said the prince. ‘Why don’t you go up to him? He wanted to speak to you.’
'可怜的家伙！他的脸多漂亮啊！”王子说道。 ‘你为什么不去找他？他想和你说话。

‘Well, let us go, then,’ said Kitty, turning round resolutely. ‘How are you feeling today?’ she asked Petrov.
“好吧，那我们走吧。”基蒂坚定地转过身说道。 “你今天感觉怎么样？”她问彼得罗夫。

Petrov got up, leaning on his stick, and looked shyly at the prince.
彼得罗夫站起来，拄着拐杖，害羞地看着王子。

‘This is my daughter,’ said the prince. ‘Let me introduce myself.’
“这是我的女儿，”王子说。 '让我自我介绍一下。'

The painter bowed and smiled, showing his strangely dazzling white teeth.
画家躬身微笑，露出奇异耀眼的白牙。

‘We expected you yesterday, princess,’ he said to Kitty. He staggered as he said this, and then repeated the motion, trying to make it seem as if it had been intentional.
“我们昨天就在等你，公主，”他对基蒂说。他说这句话时摇摇晃晃，然后又重复了这个动作，试图让自己看起来像是故意的。

‘I meant to come, but Varenka said that Anna Pavlovna sent word you were not going.’
“我本来想来的，但瓦伦卡说安娜·帕夫洛夫娜送来了你不去的消息。”

‘Not going!’ said Petrov, blushing, and immediately beginning to cough, and his eyes sought his wife. ‘Anita! Anita!’ he said loudly, and the swollen veins stood out like cords on his thin white neck.
“不去！”彼得罗夫说，脸红了，立刻开始咳嗽，眼睛寻找着他的妻子。 ‘安妮塔！安妮塔！”他大声说道，细白的脖子上肿胀的血管像绳子一样突出。

Anna Pavlovna came up.
安娜·帕夫洛夫娜走了过来。

‘So you sent word to the princess that we weren’t going!’ he whispered to her angrily, losing his voice.
“所以你传话给公主说我们不会去！”他愤怒地低声对她说，声音哑了。

‘Good morning, princess,’ said Anna Pavlovna, with an assumed smile utterly unlike her former manner. ‘Very glad to make your acquaintance,’ she said to the prince. ‘You’ve long been expected, prince.’
“早上好，公主。”安娜·帕夫洛夫娜说道，脸上带着与以前完全不同的笑容。 “很高兴认识你，”她对王子说。 “人们一直在期待您的到来，王子。”

‘What did you send word to the princess that we weren’t going for?’ the artist whispered hoarsely once more, still more angrily, obviously exasperated that his voice failed him so that he could not give his words the expression he would have liked to.
“你给公主发了什么消息说我们不去？”艺术家再次沙哑地低声说道，更加愤怒，显然是因为他的声音失败了，所以他无法表达出他想要的表达方式，这让他很恼火。到。

‘Oh, mercy on us! I thought we weren’t going,’ his wife answered crossly.
‘哦，怜悯我们吧！我以为我们不会去。”他的妻子生气地回答道。

‘What, when....’ He coughed and waved his hand. The prince took off his hat and moved away with his daughter.
“什么，什么时候……”他咳嗽了一声，挥了挥手。王子摘下帽子，带着女儿离开了。

‘Ah! ah!’ he sighed deeply. ‘Oh, poor things!’
'啊！啊！”他深深地叹了口气。 “哦，可怜的东西！”

‘Yes, papa,’ answered Kitty. ‘And you must know they’ve three children, no servant, and scarcely any means. He gets something from the Academy,’ she went on briskly, trying to drown the distress that the queer change in Anna Pavlovna’s manner to her had aroused in her.
“是的，爸爸，”基蒂回答。 “你必须知道他们有三个孩子，没有仆人，几乎没有任何经济来源。他从学院得到了一些东西，”她轻快地继续说道，试图淹没安娜·帕夫洛夫娜对她态度的奇怪变化给她带来的痛苦。

‘Oh, here’s Madame Stahl,’ said Kitty, indicating an invalid carriage, where, propped on pillows, something in gray and blue was lying under a sunshade. This was Madame Stahl. Behind her stood the gloomy, healthy-looking German workman who pushed the carriage. Close by was standing a flaxen-headed Swedish count, whom Kitty knew by name. Several invalids were lingering near the low carriage, staring at the lady as though she were some curiosity.
“噢，斯塔尔夫人来了，”基蒂指着一辆伤残的马车说道，车上的遮阳伞下躺着一个灰色和蓝色的东西，靠在枕头上。这是斯塔尔夫人。她身后站着推着马车的那个面色阴沉、看上去很健康的德国工人。附近站着一位淡黄色头发的瑞典伯爵，基蒂知道他的名字。几个病人在低矮的马车附近徘徊，好奇地看着这位女士。

The prince went up to her, and Kitty detected that disconcerting gleam of irony in his eyes. He went up to Madame Stahl, and addressed her with extreme courtesy and affability in that excellent French that so few speak nowadays.
王子走到她面前，基蒂察觉到他眼中闪烁着令人不安的讽刺光芒。他走到斯塔尔夫人面前，用现在很少有人会说的流利法语，极其礼貌和和蔼地与她交谈。

‘I don’t know if you remember me, but I must recall myself to thank you for your kindness to my daughter,’ he said, taking off his hat and not putting it on again.
“我不知道你是否还记得我，但我必须回忆起自己，感谢你对我女儿的好意，”他说，摘下帽子，没有再戴上。

‘Prince Alexander Shtcherbatsky,’ said Madame Stahl, lifting upon him her heavenly eyes, in which Kitty discerned a look of annoyance. ‘Delighted! I have taken a great fancy to your daughter.’
“亚历山大·谢尔巴茨基王子。”斯塔尔夫人抬起她那双天上的眼睛看着他，基蒂在其中看出了一丝恼怒。 '高兴极了！我非常喜欢你的女儿。

‘You are still in weak health?’
“你的身体还很虚弱吗？”

‘Yes; I’m used to it,’ said Madame Stahl, and she introduced the prince to the Swedish count.
'是的; “我已经习惯了。”斯塔尔夫人说道，然后她把王子介绍给了瑞典伯爵。

‘You are scarcely changed at all,’ the prince said to her. ‘It’s ten or eleven years since I had the honor of seeing you.’
“你几乎没有任何改变，”王子对她说。 “我有幸见到你已经有十年或十一年了。”

‘Yes; God sends the cross and sends the strength to bear it. Often one wonders what is the goal of this life?... The other side!’ she said angrily to Varenka, who had rearranged the rug over her feet not to her satisfaction.
'是的;神赐下十字架，也赐下力量来背负它。人们常常想知道这一生的目标是什么？……另一边！”她愤怒地对瓦伦卡说道，瓦伦卡重新把她脚上的地毯重新布置得令她不满意。

‘To do good, probably,’ said the prince with a twinkle in his eye.
“也许是为了做好事，”王子说道，眼睛里闪烁着光芒。

‘That is not for us to judge,’ said Madame Stahl, perceiving the shade of expression on the prince’s face. ‘So you will send me that book, dear count? I’m very grateful to you,’ she said to the young Swede.
“这不是我们可以判断的，”斯塔尔夫人说道，察觉到了王子脸上的阴暗表情。 “所以你会把那本书寄给我吗，亲爱的伯爵？我非常感谢你，”她对年轻的瑞典人说。

‘Ah!’ cried the prince, catching sight of the Moscow colonel standing near, and with a bow to Madame Stahl he walked away with his daughter and the Moscow colonel, who joined them.
“啊！”王子看到站在附近的莫斯科上校，喊道，向斯塔尔夫人鞠了一躬，他带着女儿和莫斯科上校走开了，他们也加入了他们。

‘That’s our aristocracy, prince!’ the Moscow colonel said with ironical intention. He cherished a grudge against Madame Stahl for not making his acquaintance.
“这就是我们的贵族，王子！”莫斯科上校讽刺地说。他对斯塔尔夫人怀恨在心，因为他没有结识斯塔尔夫人。

‘She’s just the same,’ replied the prince.
“她还是一样，”王子回答道。

‘Did you know her before her illness, prince—that’s to say before she took to her bed?’
“您在她生病之前认识她吗，王子——也就是说，在她上床睡觉之前？”

‘Yes. She took to her bed before my eyes,’ said the prince.
'是的。她在我眼前躺在床上，”王子说道。

‘They say it’s ten years since she has stood on her feet.’
“他们说她已经十年没有站起来了。”

‘She doesn’t stand up because her legs are too short. She’s a very bad figure.’
“她没有站起来，因为她的腿太短了。她是一个非常糟糕的人物。

‘Papa, it’s not possible!’ cried Kitty.
“爸爸，这不可能！”基蒂喊道。

‘That’s what wicked tongues say, my darling. And your Varenka catches it too,’ he added. ‘Oh, these invalid ladies!’
‘这就是邪恶的舌头所说的，我亲爱的。你的瓦伦卡也抓住了它，”他补充道。 “哦，这些病弱的女士们！”

‘Oh, no, papa!’ Kitty objected warmly. ‘Varenka worships her. And then she does so much good! Ask anyone! Everyone knows her and Aline Stahl.’
“哦，不，爸爸！”基蒂热烈地反对。 “瓦伦卡崇拜她。然后她做了很多好事！问任何人！每个人都认识她和艾琳斯塔尔。

‘Perhaps so,’ said the prince, squeezing her hand with his elbow; ‘but it’s better when one does good so that you may ask everyone and no one knows.’
“也许是这样，”王子说，用肘部捏住她的手。 “但最好是一个人做好事，这样你就可以问所有人，却没有人知道。”

Kitty did not answer, not because she had nothing to say, but because she did not care to reveal her secret thoughts even to her father. But, strange to say, although she had so made up her mind not to be influenced by her father’s views, not to let him into her inmost sanctuary, she felt that the heavenly image of Madame Stahl, which she had carried for a whole month in her heart, had vanished, never to return, just as the fantastic figure made up of some clothes thrown down at random vanishes when one sees that it is only some garment lying there. All that was left was a woman with short legs, who lay down because she had a bad figure, and worried patient Varenka for not arranging her rug to her liking. And by no effort of the imagination could Kitty bring back the former Madame Stahl.
凯蒂没有回答，不是因为她无话可说，而是因为她甚至不愿意向父亲透露自己的秘密想法。但奇怪的是，尽管她已经下定决心不被父亲的观点影响，不让他进入她最内心的庇护所，但她却觉得自己怀着整整一个月的斯塔尔夫人的天堂般的形象在她心里，已经消失了，再也没有回来，就像那由随意扔下的衣服组成的梦幻人物，当你看到那只是一件衣服时，就消失了。只剩下一个腿短的女人，她因为身材不好而躺了下来，并担心病人瓦伦卡没有按照自己的喜好安排地毯。基蒂无论如何也无法带回以前的斯塔尔夫人。

Chapter 35
第35章

The prince communicated his good humor to his own family and his friends, and even to the German landlord in whose rooms the Shtcherbatskys were staying.
王子向自己的家人和朋友表达了他的幽默感，甚至向谢尔巴茨基夫妇所住房间的德国房东表达了他的幽默感。

On coming back with Kitty from the springs, the prince, who had asked the colonel, and Marya Yevgenyevna, and Varenka all to come and have coffee with them, gave orders for a table and chairs to be taken into the garden under the chestnut tree, and lunch to be laid there. The landlord and the servants, too, grew brisker under the influence of his good spirits. They knew his open-handedness; and half an hour later the invalid doctor from Hamburg, who lived on the top floor, looked enviously out of the window at the merry party of healthy Russians assembled under the chestnut tree. In the trembling circles of shadow cast by the leaves, at a table, covered with a white cloth, and set with coffeepot, bread-and-butter, cheese, and cold game, sat the princess in a high cap with lilac ribbons, distributing cups and bread-and-butter. At the other end sat the prince, eating heartily, and talking loudly and merrily. The prince had spread out near him his purchases, carved boxes, and knick-knacks, paper-knives of all sorts, of which he bought a heap at every watering-place, and bestowed them upon everyone, including Lieschen, the servant girl, and the landlord, with whom he jested in his comically bad German, assuring him that it was not the water had cured Kitty, but his splendid cookery, especially his plum soup. The princess laughed at her husband for his Russian ways, but she was more lively and good-humored than she had been all the while she had been at the waters. The colonel smiled, as he always did, at the prince’s jokes, but as far as regards Europe, of which he believed himself to be making a careful study, he took the princess’s side. The simple-hearted Marya Yevgenyevna simply roared with laughter at everything absurd the prince said, and his jokes made Varenka helpless with feeble but infectious laughter, which was something Kitty had never seen before.
带着凯蒂从泉水回来后，王子邀请上校、玛丽亚·叶夫根尼耶夫娜和瓦伦卡一起来喝咖啡，他吩咐把桌子和椅子搬到花园里的栗子树下。 ，午餐就放在那里。地主和仆人们在他的好心情的影响下也变得精神抖擞。他们知道他的慷慨。半小时后，住在顶楼的来自汉堡的病人医生羡慕地看着窗外聚集在栗树下的健康俄罗斯人的欢乐聚会。在树叶投下的一圈圈颤抖的阴影中，公主坐在一张铺着白布、摆着咖啡壶、面包黄油、奶酪和冷野味的桌子旁，戴着一顶饰有淡紫色丝带的高帽，分发着食物。杯子和面包和黄油。另一头坐着王子，他正在吃得津津有味，大声说话。王子把他买的东西摊在身边，雕花的盒子、小摆设、各种裁纸刀，他在每个饮水处都买了一堆，送给每个人，包括女仆利申，他用蹩脚的德语跟房东开玩笑，向他保证不是水治愈了基蒂，而是他出色的厨艺，尤其是他的梅子汤。公主嘲笑她丈夫的俄罗斯风格，但她比在水里时更加活泼、幽默。听到王子的笑话，上校一如既往地微笑着，但就欧洲而言，他相信自己正在仔细研究欧洲，他站在公主一边。 心地单纯的玛丽亚·叶夫根尼耶夫娜只是对王子所说的一切荒唐事哈哈大笑，他的笑话让瓦伦卡无可奈何，笑声微弱却富有感染力，这是凯蒂从未见过的。

Kitty was glad of all this, but she could not be light-hearted. She could not solve the problem her father had unconsciously set her by his goodhumored view of her friends, and of the life that had so attracted her. To this doubt there was joined the change in her relations with the Petrovs, which had been so conspicuously and unpleasantly marked that morning. Everyone was good humored, but Kitty could not feel good humored, and this increased her distress. She felt a feeling such as she had known in childhood, when she had been shut in her room as a punishment, and had heard her sisters’ merry laughter outside.
凯蒂对此很高兴，但她却不能轻松。她无法解决父亲对她的朋友以及如此吸引她的生活的幽默看法，无意识地给她带来的问题。除了这种怀疑之外，她与彼得罗夫一家的关系也发生了变化，那天早上这种关系变得如此明显和不愉快。每个人都很幽默，但凯蒂却感觉不到幽默，这增加了她的苦恼。她感受到了一种童年时的感觉，当时她被关在自己的房间里作为惩罚，听到外面姐姐们欢快的笑声。

‘Well, but what did you buy this mass of things for?’ said the princess, smiling, and handing her husband a cup of coffee.
“好吧，但是你买这么多东西干什么？”公主微笑着说道，递给丈夫一杯咖啡。

‘One goes for a walk, one looks in a shop, and they ask you to buy. ‘Erlaucht, Durchlaucht?’ Directly they say ‘Durchlaucht,’ I can’t hold out. I lose ten thalers.’
“一个人去散步，一个人去商店看看，他们会请你买东西。 “Erlaucht，Durchlaucht？”他们直接说“Durchlaucht”，我实在忍不住了。我损失了十塔勒。

‘It’s simply from boredom,’ said the princess.
“这只是因为无聊，”公主说。

‘Of course it is. Such boredom, my dear, that one doesn’t know what to do with oneself.’
'当然如此。亲爱的，无聊得让人不知道该做什么。

‘How can you be bored, prince? There’s so much that’s interesting now in Germany,’ said Marya Yevgenyevna.
‘王子，你怎么会觉得无聊呢？德国现在有很多有趣的事情，”玛丽亚·叶夫根尼耶芙娜 (Marya Yevgenyevna) 说道。

‘But I know everything that’s interesting: the plum soup I know, and the pea sausages I know. I know everything.’
“但我知道一切有趣的东西：我知道梅子汤，我知道豌豆香肠。我知道所有的东西。'

‘No, you may say what you like, prince, there’s the interest of their institutions,’ said the colonel.
“不，你想说什么都可以，王子，这是他们机构的利益，”上校说。

‘But what is there interesting about it? They’re all as pleased as brass halfpence. They’ve conquered everybody, and why am I to be pleased at that? I haven’t conquered anyone; and I’m obliged to take off my own boots, yes, and put them away too; in the morning, get up and dress at once, and go to the dining room to drink bad tea! How different it is at home! You get up in no haste, you get cross, grumble a little, and come round again. You’ve time to think things over, and no hurry.’
‘但是这有什么有趣的呢？他们都很高兴。他们已经征服了所有人，我为什么要为此感到高兴呢？我没有征服任何人；是的，我不得不脱掉自己的靴子，并将它们也收起来。早上，立刻起床穿好衣服，去餐厅喝坏茶！在家里是多么的不同啊！你不慌不忙地站起来，你生气了，抱怨了一会儿，然后又回过神来。你有时间好好考虑一下，别着急。”

‘But time’s money, you forget that,’ said the colonel.
“但是时间就是金钱，你忘了这一点，”上校说。

‘Time, indeed, that depends! Why, there’s time one would give a month of for sixpence, and time you wouldn’t give half an hour of for any money. Isn’t that so, Katinka? What is it? why are you so depressed?’
“确实，时间要看情况！为什么，有些时间人们愿意花六便士花一个月的时间，而有些时间你不会花任何钱花半个小时。不是这样吗，卡廷卡？它是什么？你为什么这么沮丧？

‘I’m not depressed.’
“我没有抑郁。”

‘Where are you off to? Stay a little longer,’ he said to Varenka.
'你要去哪里？多呆一会儿，”他对瓦伦卡说。

‘I must be going home,’ said Varenka, getting up, and again she went off into a giggle. When she had recovered, she said good-bye, and went into the house to get her hat.
“我得回家了，”瓦伦卡站起来说道，然后她又咯咯地笑了起来。当她恢复过来后，她道了再见，进屋去拿帽子。

Kitty followed her. Even Varenka struck her as different. She was not worse, but different from what she had fancied her before.
凯蒂跟着她。就连瓦伦卡也让她觉得与众不同。她并不差，只是和她想象中的她不一样。

‘Oh, dear! it’s a long while since I’ve laughed so much!’ said Varenka, gathering up her parasol and her bag. ‘How nice he is, your father!’
'哦亲爱的！ “我已经很久没有笑得这么开心了！”瓦伦卡一边说，一边收起她的阳伞和包。 “他真是太好了，你的父亲！”

Kitty did not speak.
基蒂没有说话。

‘When shall I see you again?’ asked Varenka.
“我什么时候才能再见到你？”瓦伦卡问道。

‘Mamma meant to go and see the Petrovs. Won’t you be there?’ said Kitty, to try Varenka.
“妈妈想去看看彼得罗夫一家。你不去吗？”基蒂说，想试试瓦伦卡。

‘Yes,’ answered Varenka. ‘They’re getting ready to go away, so I promised to help them pack.’
“是的，”瓦伦卡回答。 “他们正准备离开，所以我答应帮他们收拾行李。”

‘Well, I’ll come too, then.’
“好吧，那我也来吧。”

‘No, why should you?’
“不，你为什么要这么做？”

‘Why not? why not? why not?’ said Kitty, opening her eyes wide, and clutching at Varenka’s parasol, so as not to let her go. ‘No, wait a minute; why not?’
'为什么不？为什么不？ “为什么不呢？”凯蒂睁大眼睛说道，紧紧抓住瓦伦卡的阳伞，不让她走。 ‘不，等一下；为什么不？'

‘Oh, nothing; your father has come, and besides, they will feel awkward at your helping.’
‘哦，没什么；你父亲来了，而且，他们会因为你的帮助而感到尴尬。

‘No, tell me why you don’t want me to be often at the Petrovs’. You don’t want me to—why not?’
“不，告诉我为什么你不想让我经常去彼得罗夫家。”你不想让我这么做——为什么不呢？

‘I didn’t say that,’ said Varenka quietly.
“我没这么说。”瓦伦卡平静地说。

‘No, please tell me!’
“不，请告诉我！”

‘Tell you everything?’ asked Varenka.
“告诉你一切？”瓦伦卡问。

‘Everything, everything!’ Kitty assented.
“一切，一切！”基蒂附和道。

‘Well, there’s really nothing of any consequence; only that Mihail Alexeyevitch’ (that was the artist’s name) ‘had meant to leave earlier, and now he doesn’t want to go away,’ said Varenka, smiling.
“好吧，确实没有什么重要的事情；只是米哈伊尔·阿列克谢耶维奇”（这是艺术家的名字）“本来想早点离开，但现在他不想走，”瓦伦卡微笑着说道。

‘Well, well!’ Kitty urged impatiently, looking darkly at Varenka.
“好吧，好吧！”基蒂不耐烦地催促道，阴沉地看着瓦伦卡。

‘Well, and for some reason Anna Pavlovna told him that he didn’t want to go because you are here. Of course, that was nonsense; but there was a dispute over it—over you. You know how irritable these sick people are.’
“好吧，出于某种原因，安娜·帕夫洛夫娜告诉他，他不想走，因为你在这里。当然，这是无稽之谈。但关于这件事——关于你——存在争议。你知道这些病人有多烦躁。

Kitty, scowling more than ever, kept silent, and Varenka went on speaking alone, trying to soften or soothe her, and seeing a storm coming—she did not know whether of tears or of words.
基蒂的愁眉苦脸比以往任何时候都更严重，保持沉默，瓦伦卡继续独自说话，试图软化或安抚她，并看到暴风雨即将来临——她不知道是泪水还是言语。

‘So you’d better not go.... You understand; you won’t be offended?...’
‘所以你最好别去……你明白；你不会生气吧？……”

‘And it serves me right! And it serves me right!’ Kitty cried quickly, snatching the parasol out of Varenka’s hand, and looking past her friend’s face.
‘这对我来说是对的！这对我来说是对的！”基蒂迅速喊道，从瓦伦卡手中夺过阳伞，目光越过她朋友的脸。

Varenka felt inclined to smile, looking at her childish fury, but she was afraid of wounding her.
瓦伦卡看着她孩子气的愤怒，想微笑，但她害怕伤害她。

‘How does it serve you right? I don’t understand,’ she said.
‘它对你有什么好处？我不明白，”她说。

‘It serves me right, because it was all sham; because it was all done on purpose, and not from the heart. What business had I to interfere with outsiders? And so it’s come about that I’m a cause of quarrel, and that I’ve done what nobody asked me to do. Because it was all a sham! a sham! a sham!...’
“这对我来说是对的，因为这都是假的；因为这一切都是故意的，而不是发自内心的。我有什么事要干涉外人呢？所以我成了争吵的根源，而且我做了没人要求我做的事。因为这一切都是骗局！一个骗局！一个骗局！...”

‘A sham! with what object?’ said Varenka gently.
‘一个骗局！ “什么东西？”瓦伦卡温和地说。

‘Oh, it’s so idiotic! so hateful! There was no need whatever for me.... Nothing but sham!’ she said, opening and shutting the parasol.
‘噢，这真是太愚蠢了！太可恨了！对我来说没有任何必要……只不过是假的！”她一边说，一边打开又合上遮阳伞。

‘But with what object?’
“但是用什么东西呢？”

‘To seem better to people, to myself, to God; to deceive everyone. No! now I won’t descend to that. I’ll be bad; but anyway not a liar, a cheat.’
“让人们、我自己、上帝看起来更好；来欺骗所有人。不！现在我不会再谈这个了。我会变坏；但无论如何，他不是骗子，是骗子。”

‘But who is a cheat?’ said Varenka reproachfully. ‘You speak as if...’
“但是谁是骗子呢？”瓦伦卡责备地说。 “你说得好像……”

But Kitty was in one of her gusts of fury, and she would not let her finish.
但基蒂正处于一阵狂怒之中，她不肯让她说完。

‘I don’t talk about you, not about you at all. You’re perfection. Yes, yes, I know you’re all perfection; but what am I to do if I’m bad? This would never have been if I weren’t bad. So let me be what I am. I won’t be a sham. What have I to do with Anna Pavlovna? Let them go their way, and me go mine. I can’t be different.... And yet it’s not that, it’s not that.’
“我不是在谈论你，根本不是在谈论你。你是完美的。是的，是的，我知道你们都是完美的；但如果我不好怎么办？如果我不坏的话，这永远不会发生。所以让我成为我自己吧。我不会是一个骗子。我和安娜·帕夫洛芙娜有什么关系？让他们走他们的路，我走我的路。我不能有所不同……但事实并非如此，并非如此。

‘What is not that?’ asked Varenka in bewilderment.
“那不是什么呢？”瓦伦卡困惑地问道。

‘Everything. I can’t act except from the heart, and you act from principle. I liked you simply, but you most likely only wanted to save me, to improve me.’
'一切。我只能凭心而行，而你则凭原则而行。我只是喜欢你，但你很可能只是想拯救我，提高我。

‘You are unjust,’ said Varenka.
“你不公正，”瓦伦卡说。

‘But I’m not speaking of other people, I’m speaking of myself.’
“但我不是在说别人，我是在说我自己。”

‘Kitty,’ they heard her mother’s voice, ‘come here, show papa your necklace.’
“基蒂，”他们听到她母亲的声音，“过来，给爸爸看你的项链。”

Kitty, with a haughty air, without making peace with her friend, took the necklace in a little box from the table and went to her mother.
基蒂带着傲慢的神情，没有与她的朋友和解，而是从桌子上拿起装在小盒子里的项链，走向她的母亲。

‘What’s the matter? Why are you so red?’ her mother and father said to her with one voice.
'怎么了？你怎么这么红？”爸爸妈妈异口同声地对她说道。

‘Nothing,’ she answered. ‘I’ll be back directly,’ and she ran back.
“没什么，”她回答。 “我马上就回来。”说着她就跑了回去。

‘She’s still here,’ she thought. ‘What am I to say to her? Oh, dear! what have I done, what have I said? Why was I rude to her? What am I to do? What am I to say to her?’ thought Kitty, and she stopped in the doorway.
“她还在这里，”她想。 ‘我该对她说什么？哦亲爱的！我做了什么，我说过什么？我为什么对她无礼？我是什么做的？ “我该对她说什么？”基蒂想道，然后她在门口停了下来。

Varenka in her hat and with the parasol in her hands was sitting at the table examining the spring which Kitty had broken. She lifted her head.
瓦伦卡戴着帽子，手里拿着阳伞，坐在桌边检查基蒂弄断的弹簧。她抬起头。

‘Varenka, forgive me, do forgive me,’ whispered Kitty, going up to her. ‘I don’t remember what I said. I...’
“瓦伦卡，原谅我，一定要原谅我，”基蒂走到她面前低声说道。 ‘我不记得我说过什么了。我...'

‘I really didn’t mean to hurt you,’ said Varenka, smiling.
“我真的不是故意伤害你的，”瓦伦卡微笑着说道。

Peace was made. But with her father’s coming all the world in which she had been living was transformed for Kitty. She did not give up everything she had learned, but she became aware that she had deceived herself in supposing she could be what she wanted to be. Her eyes were, it seemed, opened; she felt all the difficulty of maintaining herself without hypocrisy and self-conceit on the pinnacle to which she had wished to mount. Moreover, she became aware of all the dreariness of the world of sorrow, of sick and dying people, in which she had been living. The efforts she had made to like it seemed to her intolerable, and she felt a longing to get back quickly into the fresh air, to Russia, to Ergushovo, where, as she knew from letters, her sister Dolly had already gone with her children.
和平得以实现。但随着她父亲的到来，她所生活的整个世界对于基蒂来说都发生了变化。她并没有放弃她所学到的一切，但她意识到自己欺骗了自己，以为自己可以成为自己想成为的人。她的眼睛似乎睁开了；她感到很难保持自己不虚伪和自负，登上她希望登上的顶峰。此外，她开始意识到她所生活的这个充满悲伤、生病和垂死的人的世界是多么悲惨。她为喜欢它而付出的努力在她看来似乎无法忍受，她渴望尽快回到空气新鲜的地方，回到俄罗斯，回到埃尔古绍沃，正如她从信件中得知的那样，她的妹妹多莉已经带着孩子们去了那里。

But her affection for Varenka did not wane. As she said good-bye, Kitty begged her to come to them in Russia.
但她对瓦伦卡的感情并没有减弱。当她告别时，基蒂恳求她去俄罗斯找他们。

‘I’ll come when you get married,’ said Varenka.
“你结婚时我会来，”瓦伦卡说。

‘I shall never marry.’
“我永远不会结婚。”

‘Well, then, I shall never come.’
“那么，我永远不会来了。”

‘Well, then, I shall be married simply for that. Mind now, remember your promise,’ said Kitty.
‘那么，我就为了这个而结婚。现在请注意，记住你的承诺，”基蒂说。

The doctor’s prediction was fulfilled. Kitty returned home to Russia cured. She was not so gay and thoughtless as before, but she was serene. Her Moscow troubles had become a memory to her.
医生的预言应验了。基蒂痊愈回到俄罗斯家乡。她不再像以前那样开朗、轻率，但她很平静。莫斯科的麻烦已经成为她的记忆。

PART THREE
第三部分

Chapter 1
第1章

Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev wanted a rest from mental work, and instead of going abroad as he usually did, he came towards the end of May to stay in the country with his brother. In his judgment the best sort of life was a country life. He had come now to enjoy such a life at his brother’s. Konstantin Levin was very glad to have him, especially as he did not expect his brother Nikolay that summer. But in spite of his affection and respect for Sergey Ivanovitch, Konstantin Levin was uncomfortable with his brother in the country. It made him uncomfortable, and it positively annoyed him to see his brother’s attitude to the country. To Konstantin Levin the country was the background of life, that is of pleasures, endeavors, labor. To Sergey Ivanovitch the country meant on one hand rest from work, on the other a valuable antidote to the corrupt influences of town, which he took with satisfaction and a sense of its utility. To Konstantin Levin the country was good first because it afforded a field for labor, of the usefulness of which there could be no doubt. To Sergey Ivanovitch the country was particularly good, because there it was possible and fitting to do nothing. Moreover, Sergey Ivanovitch’s attitude to the peasants rather piqued Konstantin. Sergey Ivanovitch used to say that he knew and liked the peasantry, and he often talked to the peasants, which he knew how to do without affectation or condescension, and from every such conversation he would deduce general conclusions in favor of the peasantry and in confirmation of his knowing them. Konstantin Levin did not like such an attitude to the peasants. To Konstantin the peasant was simply the chief partner in their common labor, and in spite of all the respect and the love, almost like that of kinship, he had for the peasant— sucked in probably, as he said himself, with the milk of his peasant nurse—still as a fellow-worker with him, while sometimes enthusiastic over the vigor, gentleness, and justice of these men, he was very often, when their common labors called for other qualities, exasperated with the peasant for his carelessness, lack of method, drunkenness, and lying. If he had been asked whether he liked or didn’t like the peasants, Konstantin Levin would have been absolutely at a loss what to reply. He liked and did not like the peasants, just as he liked and did not like men in general. Of course, being a good-hearted man, he liked men rather than he disliked them, and so too with the peasants. But like or dislike ‘the people’ as something apart he could not, not only because he lived with ‘the people,’ and all his interests were bound up with theirs, but also because he regarded himself as a part of ‘the people,’ did not see any special qualities or failings distinguishing himself and ‘the people,’ and could not contrast himself with them. Moreover, although he had lived so long in the closest relations with the peasants, as farmer and arbitrator, and what was more, as adviser (the peasants trusted him, and for thirty miles round they would come to ask his advice), he had no definite views of ‘the people,’ and would have been as much at a loss to answer the question whether he knew ‘the people’ as the question whether he liked them. For him to say he knew the peasantry would have been the same as to say he knew men. He was continually watching and getting to know people of all sorts, and among them peasants, whom he regarded as good and interesting people, and he was continually observing new points in them, altering his former views of them and forming new ones. With Sergey Ivanovitch it was quite the contrary. Just as he liked and praised a country life in comparison with the life he did not like, so too he liked the peasantry in contradistinction to the class of men he did not like, and so too he knew the peasantry as something distinct from and opposed to men generally. In his methodical brain there were distinctly formulated certain aspects of peasant life, deduced partly from that life itself, but chiefly from contrast with other modes of life. He never changed his opinion of the peasantry and his sympathetic attitude towards them.
谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇·科兹尼舍夫（Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev）想从脑力工作中得到休息，所以他没有像往常一样出国，而是在五月底来到该国与他的兄弟一起居住。在他看来，最好的生活就是乡村生活。他现在来到他哥哥那里享受这样的生活。康斯坦丁·莱文（Konstantin Levin）非常高兴能拥有他，尤其是他没想到那个夏天会有他的兄弟尼古拉（Nikolay）。尽管康斯坦丁·莱文对谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇充满感情和尊重，但他对自己在乡下的兄弟感到不舒服。这让他感到不舒服，而且看到他哥哥对国家的态度也让他非常恼火。对康斯坦丁·莱文来说，乡村是生活的背景，是快乐、努力和劳动的背景。对于谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇来说，乡村一方面意味着工作的休息，另一方面是城市腐败影响的宝贵解毒剂，他满意地接受了它，并感受到了它的实用性。对康斯坦丁·莱文来说，这个国家首先是好的，因为它提供了一个劳动场所，其用处是毫无疑问的。对于谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇来说，这个国家特别好，因为在那里什么都不做是可能的，也是合适的。此外，谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇对农民的态度也激怒了康斯坦丁。谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇曾经说过，他了解并喜欢农民，他经常与农民交谈，他知道如何在不做作或居高临下的情况下进行交谈，并且从每次这样的谈话中，他都会得出有利于农民的一般结论，并证实他了解他们。康斯坦丁·莱文不喜欢对农民的这种态度。 对康斯坦丁来说，农民只是他们共同劳动的主要伙伴，尽管他对农民充满了尊重和爱戴，几乎就像亲属关系一样——正如他自己所说，可能是吸吮了农民的牛奶。他的农民护士——仍然是他的同事，虽然有时对这些人的活力、温柔和正义充满热情，但当他们的共同劳动需要其他品质时，他常常对农民的粗心大意感到愤怒，缺乏方法、酗酒、撒谎。如果有人问他是否喜欢农民，康斯坦丁·莱文绝对不知如何回答。他喜欢和不喜欢农民，就像他喜欢和不喜欢一般男人一样。当然，作为一个好心人，他喜欢人而不是讨厌人，对农民也是如此。但他却不能把“人民”当作独立的东西来喜欢或不喜欢，不仅因为他与“人民”生活在一起，他的一切利益都与人民的利益息息相关，而且还因为他把自己视为“人民”的一部分，他没有看到自己与“人民”有任何区别的特殊品质或缺点，也无法将自己与他们进行对比。此外，虽然他作为农民和仲裁者，更重要的是作为顾问（农民信任他，方圆三十英里的范围内都会来征求他的意见），与农民保持着最密切的关系，但他他对“人民”没有明确的看法，他既无法回答他是否了解“人民”的问题，也无法回答他是否喜欢他们的问题。对他来说，说他了解农民就等于说他了解人。 他不断地观察和认识各种各样的人，其中包括农民，他认为他们是善良而有趣的人，他不断地观察他们的新观点，改变他以前对他们的看法并形成新的观点。谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇的情况则恰恰相反。正如他喜欢并赞扬乡村生活与他不喜欢的生活相比，他也喜欢农民与他不喜欢的阶级相对，同样他也知道农民是不同于并反对的东西。一般对男性来说。在他有条不紊的大脑中，清楚地表述了农民生活的某些方面，这些方面部分是从生活本身推论出来的，但主要是从与其他生活方式的对比中推论出来的。他对农民的看法和对农民的同情态度始终没有改变。

In the discussions that arose between the brothers on their views of the peasantry, Sergey Ivanovitch always got the better of his brother, precisely because Sergey Ivanovitch had definite ideas about the peasant—his character, his qualities, and his tastes. Konstantin Levin had no definite and unalterable idea on the subject, and so in their arguments Konstantin was readily convicted of contradicting himself.
在兄弟俩讨论对农民的看法时，谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇总是占上风，因为谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇对农民有明确的看法——他的性格、他的品质和他的品味。康斯坦丁·莱文在这个问题上没有明确的、不可改变的想法，因此在他们的论点中，康斯坦丁很容易被判自相矛盾。

In Sergey Ivanovitch’s eyes his younger brother was a capital fellow, with his heart in the right place (as he expressed it in French), but with a mind which, though fairly quick, was too much influenced by the impressions of the moment, and consequently filled with contradictions. With all the condescension of an elder brother he sometimes explained to him the true import of things, but he derived little satisfaction from arguing with him because he got the better of him too easily.
在谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇眼中，他的弟弟是一个资本家，他的心在正确的地方（正如他用法语表达的那样），但他的头脑虽然相当敏捷，但太容易受到当时印象的影响，并且从而充满了矛盾。有时，他会以一位大哥的居高临下的态度向他解释事物的真正重要性，但与他争论却得不到什么满足，因为他太容易胜过他了。

Konstantin Levin regarded his brother as a man of immense intellect and culture, as generous in the highest sense of the word, and possessed of a special faculty for working for the public good. But in the depths of his heart, the older he became, and the more intimately he knew his brother, the more and more frequently the thought struck him that this faculty of working for the public good, of which he felt himself utterly devoid, was possibly not so much a quality as a lack of something —not a lack of good, honest, noble desires and tastes, but a lack of vital force, of what is called heart, of that impulse which drives a man to choose someone out of the innumerable paths of life, and to care only for that one. The better he knew his brother, the more he noticed that Sergey Ivanovitch, and many other people who worked for the public welfare, were not led by an impulse of the heart to care for the public good, but reasoned from intellectual considerations that it was a right thing to take interest in public affairs, and consequently took interest in them. Levin was confirmed in this generalization by observing that his brother did not take questions affecting the public welfare or the question of the immortality of the soul a bit more to heart than he did chess problems, or the ingenious construction of a new machine.
康斯坦丁·莱文认为他的兄弟是一个具有巨大智慧和文化的人，在最高意义上是慷慨的，并且拥有为公共利益而工作的特殊能力。但在他内心深处，随着年龄的增长，对弟弟的了解越深入，他就越频繁地想到，这种为公共利益而努力的能力，而他觉得自己完全缺乏这种能力。也许与其说是一种品质，不如说是缺乏某种东西——不是缺乏良好、诚实、高尚的欲望和品味，而是缺乏生命力，缺乏所谓的心灵，缺乏驱使一个人从他人中选择某人的冲动。生命的道路有无数条，而只关心那一条。他越了解他的兄弟，就越注意到谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇和许多其他为公共福利工作的人并不是出于关心公共利益的内心冲动，而是出于理智的考虑而得出的结论：对公共事务感兴趣是正确的事情，并且因此对它们感兴趣。莱文通过观察他的兄弟并没有像对待国际象棋问题或新机器的巧妙构造那样更加关注影响公共福利或灵魂不朽的问题，证实了这一概括。

Besides this, Konstantin Levin was not at his ease with his brother, because in summer in the country Levin was continually busy with work on the land, and the long summer day was not long enough for him to get through all he had to do, while Sergey Ivanovitch was taking a holiday. But though he was taking a holiday now, that is to say, he was doing no writing, he was so used to intellectual activity that he liked to put into concise and eloquent shape the ideas that occurred to him, and liked to have someone to listen to him. His most usual and natural listener was his brother. And so in spite of the friendliness and directness of their relations, Konstantin felt an awkwardness in leaving him alone. Sergey Ivanovitch liked to stretch himself on the grass in the sun, and to lie so, basking and chatting lazily.
除此之外，康斯坦丁·莱文和他的兄弟在一起并不轻松，因为在乡下的夏天，莱文一直忙于土地上的工作，而漫长的夏日时间不足以让他完成所有他必须做的事情，当时谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇正在度假。不过，尽管他现在正在休假，也就是说，他没有写作，但他已经习惯了智力活动，所以他喜欢将他想到的想法简洁而雄辩地表达出来，并喜欢有人来表达。听他的。他最常见、最自然的倾听者是他的兄弟。因此，尽管他们的关系友好而直接，康斯坦丁却对让他独自一人感到尴尬。谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇喜欢在阳光下躺在草地上，懒洋洋地晒着太阳，闲聊。

‘You wouldn’t believe,’ he would say to his brother, ‘what a pleasure this rural laziness is to me. Not an idea in one’s brain, as empty as a drum!’
“你不会相信，”他会对他的兄弟说，“这种乡村的懒惰对我来说是多么快乐。”脑子里一点想法都没有，空如鼓！”

But Konstantin Levin found it dull sitting and listening to him, especially when he knew that while he was away they would be carting dung onto the fields not ploughed ready for it, and heaping it all up anyhow; and would not screw the shares in the ploughs, but would let them come off and then say that the new ploughs were a silly invention, and there was nothing like the old Andreevna plough, and so on.
但康斯坦丁·莱文觉得坐着听他说话很无聊，尤其是当他知道他不在的时候，他们会把粪便运到没有犁过的田地里，然后把它们堆起来；他不会把犁铧拧在犁上，而是让它们脱落，然后说新犁是一个愚蠢的发明，没有什么比旧的安德烈耶夫娜犁更好的了，等等。

‘Come, you’ve done enough trudging about in the heat,’ Sergey Ivanovitch would say to him.
“来吧，你在炎热的天气里跋涉已经够多了，”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇会对他说。

‘No, I must just run round to the counting-house for a minute,’ Levin would answer, and he would run off to the fields.
“不，我必须跑到账房去一会儿，”莱文回答道，然后他就会跑到田里去。

Chapter 2
第2章

Early in June it happened that Agafea Mihalovna, the old nurse and housekeeper, in carrying to the cellar a jar of mushrooms she had just pickled, slipped, fell, and sprained her wrist. The district doctor, a talkative young medical student, who had just finished his studies, came to see her. He examined the wrist, said it was not broken, was delighted at a chance of talking to the celebrated Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev, and to show his advanced views of things told him all the scandal of the district, complaining of the poor state into which the district council had fallen. Sergey Ivanovitch listened attentively, asked him questions, and, roused by a new listener, he talked fluently, uttered a few keen and weighty observations, respectfully appreciated by the young doctor, and was soon in that eager frame of mind his brother knew so well, which always, with him, followed a brilliant and eager conversation. After the departure of the doctor, he wanted to go with a fishing rod to the river. Sergey Ivanovitch was fond of angling, and was, it seemed, proud of being able to care for such a stupid occupation.
六月初，老护士兼女管家阿加菲亚·米哈伊洛夫娜（Agafea Mihalovna）在把一罐刚腌制的蘑菇搬到地窖时，滑倒了，扭伤了手腕。区医生是一位健谈的年轻医科学生，刚完成学业，来看望她。他检查了手腕，说它没有折断，很高兴有机会与著名的谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇·科兹尼舍夫交谈，并向他展示了他对事物的先进看法，告诉他该地区的所有丑闻，抱怨该地区的贫困状况。区议会垮台了。谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇聚精会神地听着，问了他一些问题，在一位新听众的激励下，他流利地说话，发表了一些敏锐而有分量的评论，受到这位年轻医生的恭敬赞赏，很快就陷入了他哥哥所熟悉的那种热切的心态。 ，与他总是伴随着一场精彩而热切的谈话。医生走后，他想拿着钓鱼竿去河边。谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇喜欢钓鱼，并且似乎为能够从事如此愚蠢的职业而感到自豪。

Konstantin Levin, whose presence was needed in the plough land and meadows, had come to take his brother in the trap.
康斯坦丁·莱文在耕地和草地上需要他的存在，他来是为了把他的兄弟带入陷阱。

It was that time of the year, the turning-point of summer, when the crops of the present year are a certainty, when one begins to think of the sowing for next year, and the mowing is at hand; when the rye is all in ear, though its ears are still light, not yet full, and it waves in gray-green billows in the wind; when the green oats, with tufts of yellow grass scattered here and there among it, droop irregularly over the late-sown fields; when the early buckwheat is already out and hiding the ground; when the fallow lands, trodden hard as stone by the cattle, are half ploughed over, with paths left untouched by the plough; when from the dry dung-heaps carted onto the fields there comes at sunset a smell of manure mixed with meadow-sweet, and on the low-lying lands the riverside meadows are a thick sea of grass waiting for the mowing, with blackened heaps of the stalks of sorrel among it.
正是一年中的这个时候，夏季的转折点，今年的庄稼收成已定，人们开始考虑明年的播种，割草也即将到来。当黑麦全部抽穗时，虽然它的穗子还很轻，但还没有饱满，在风中摇曳着灰绿色的波涛；当绿色的燕麦和一丛丛黄草散落在其中时，不规则地垂落在晚播的田野上；当早熟的荞麦已经长出来并藏在地里的时候；当休耕地被牛群踩得像石头一样坚硬时，犁过一半，而犁耕的道路却没有被犁过；日落时分，干粪堆被运到田里时，一股粪肥和草甸的气味混合在一起，河边的低洼地上是一片茂密的草海，等待着割草，黑黑的草堆堆在河边草甸上。其中有酢浆草的茎。

It was the time when there comes a brief pause in the toil of the fields before the beginning of the labors of harvest—every year recurring, every year straining every nerve of the peasants. The crop was a splendid one, and bright, hot summer days had set in with short, dewy nights.
正是在收获劳动开始之前，田地里的劳作会有短暂的停顿的时候——年复一年，年复一年，让农民的每一根神经都紧张起来。农作物丰收，明亮炎热的夏季来临，夜晚短暂而露水。

The brothers had to drive through the woods to reach the meadows. Sergey Ivanovitch was all the while admiring the beauty of the woods, which were a tangled mass of leaves, pointing out to his brother now an old lime tree on the point of flowering, dark on the shady side, and brightly spotted with yellow stipules, now the young shoots of this year’s saplings brilliant with emerald. Konstantin Levin did not like talking and hearing about the beauty of nature. Words for him took away the beauty of what he saw. He assented to what his brother said, but he could not help beginning to think of other things. When they came out of the woods, all his attention was engrossed by the view of the fallow land on the upland, in parts yellow with grass, in parts trampled and checkered with furrows, in parts dotted with ridges of dung, and in parts even ploughed. A string of carts was moving across it. Levin counted the carts, and was pleased that all that were wanted had been brought, and at the sight of the meadows his thoughts passed to the mowing. He always felt something special moving him to the quick at the hay-making. On reaching the meadow Levin stopped the horse.
兄弟俩必须开车穿过树林才能到达草地。谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇一直在欣赏树林的美丽，树林里有一堆纠缠的叶子，他向他的兄弟指出一棵即将开花的老椴树，阴暗的一面呈黑色，有明亮的黄色托叶斑点，现在，今年的树苗嫩芽翠绿欲滴。康斯坦丁·莱文不喜欢谈论和听到自然之美。对他来说，言语夺走了他所看到的美丽。他同意哥哥的话，但又忍不住开始想别的事情。当他们走出树林时，他全神贯注于高地的休耕地，有的地方长满青草，有的地方被践踏，有的沟壑纵横，有的地方布满粪土，有的地方还犁过的。一串手推车正在上面行驶。莱文数了数车子，很高兴所有想要的东西都已经运来了，一看到草地，他的思绪就转到了割草上。他总是感觉到有什么特别的东西让他在干草时迅速行动起来。到达草地后，莱文停住了马。

The morning dew was still lying on the thick undergrowth of the grass, and that he might not get his feet wet, Sergey Ivanovitch asked his brother to drive him in the trap up to the willow tree from which the carp was caught. Sorry as Konstantin Levin was to crush down his mowing grass, he drove him into the meadow. The high grass softly turned about the wheels and the horse’s legs, leaving its seeds clinging to the wet axles and spokes of the wheels. His brother seated himself under a bush, arranging his tackle, while Levin led the horse away, fastened him up, and walked into the vast gray-green sea of grass unstirred by the wind. The silky grass with its ripe seeds came almost to his waist in the dampest spots.
草丛里浓密的草丛上还沾着清晨的露珠，为了不让他的脚沾湿，谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇让他的兄弟把他装进陷阱，赶到那棵钓鲤鱼的柳树上。抱歉，康斯坦丁·莱文要压碎他正在割草的草，他把他赶到了草地上。高高的草丛轻轻地围绕着车轮和马腿转动，留下的种子粘在潮湿的车轴和车轮辐条上。他的兄弟坐在灌木丛下，整理着他的装备，而莱文牵着马走，拴好，走进了无风的灰绿色草海。在最潮湿的地方，丝滑的草和成熟的种子几乎长到了他的腰部。

Crossing the meadow, Konstantin Levin came out onto the road, and met an old man with a swollen eye, carrying a skep on his shoulder.
穿过草地，康斯坦丁·莱文来到路上，遇到了一位眼睛肿胀、肩上扛着一把小刀的老人。

‘What? taken a stray swarm, Fomitch?’ he asked.
'什么？ “福米奇，被一群迷失的人抓走了吗？”他问道。

‘No, indeed, Konstantin Dmitrich! All we can do to keep our own! This is the second swarm that has flown away.... Luckily the lads caught them. They were ploughing your field. They unyoked the horses and galloped after them.’
“不，确实如此，康斯坦丁·德米特里希！我们能做的就是保住我们自己！这是第二群飞走了……幸运的是，小伙子们抓住了它们。他们正在耕种你的田地。他们解开马匹，疾驰追赶。

‘Well, what do you say, Fomitch—start mowing or wait a bit?’
“好吧，你觉得怎么样，福米奇——开始割草还是稍等一下？”

‘Eh, well. Our way’s to wait till St. Peter’s Day. But you always mow sooner. Well, to be sure, please God, the hay’s good. There’ll be plenty for the beasts.’
‘呃，好吧。我们的办法是等到圣彼得节。但你总是会早点割草。好吧，当然，上帝保佑，干草很好。会有足够的东西供野兽使用。

‘What do you think about the weather?’
“你觉得天气怎么样？”

‘That’s in God’s hands. Maybe it will be fine.’
‘那是在上帝的手中。也许会好起来的。

Levin went up to his brother.
列文走到他哥哥跟前。

Sergey Ivanovitch had caught nothing, but he was not bored, and seemed in the most cheerful frame of mind. Levin saw that, stimulated by his conversation with the doctor, he wanted to talk. Levin, on the other hand, would have liked to get home as soon as possible to give orders about getting together the mowers for next day, and to set at rest his doubts about the mowing, which greatly absorbed him.
谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇什么也没抓到，但他并不感到无聊，而且看上去心情非常愉快。莱文看出，他受到与医生谈话的刺激，想要说话。另一方面，莱文则希望尽快回家，下达第二天将割草机集合起来的命令，并消除他对割草的疑虑，这让他全神贯注。

‘Well, let’s be going,’ he said.
“好吧，我们走吧，”他说。

‘Why be in such a hurry? Let’s stay a little. But how wet you are! Even though one catches nothing, it’s nice. That’s the best thing about every part of sport, that one has to do with nature. How exquisite this steely water is!’ said Sergey Ivanovitch. ‘These riverside banks always remind me of the riddle—do you know it? ‘The grass says to the water: we quiver and we quiver.’’
‘何必这么着急呢？让我们停留一会儿。但你有多湿啊！虽然什么也没抓到，但也挺好的。这是体育运动每一部分最好的一点，那就是与自然有关。这钢铁般的水多么美妙啊！”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇说道。 “这些河岸总是让我想起这个谜语——你知道吗？ “草对水说：我们颤抖，我们颤抖。”

‘I don’t know the riddle,’ answered Levin wearily.
“我不知道这个谜语。”莱文疲倦地回答。

Chapter 3
第3章

‘Do you know, I’ve been thinking about you,’ said Sergey Ivanovitch. ‘It’s beyond everything what’s being done in the district, according to what this doctor tells me. He’s a very intelligent fellow. And as I’ve told you before, I tell you again: it’s not right for you not to go to the meetings, and altogether to keep out of the district business. If decent people won’t go into it, of course it’s bound to go all wrong. We pay the money, and it all goes in salaries, and there are no schools, nor district nurses, nor midwives, nor drugstores— nothing.’
“你知道吗，我一直在想你，”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇说。 “据这位医生告诉我，这超出了该地区正在做的一切。”他是一个非常聪明的人。我以前已经告诉过你们了，我再告诉你们：你们不去聚会，完全不插手区里的事，是不对的。如果正派的人不去参与，当然就一定会出问题。我们付钱，这一切都以工资的形式进行，没有学校，没有地区护士，没有助产士，也没有药店——什么都没有。

‘Well, I did try, you know,’ Levin said slowly and unwillingly. ‘I can’t! and so there’s no help for it.’
“好吧，我确实尝试过，你知道，”莱文缓慢而不情愿地说。 ‘我不能！所以没有任何帮助。

‘But why can’t you? I must own I can’t make it out. Indifference, incapacity—I won’t admit; surely it’s not simply laziness?’
‘但是你为什么不能呢？我必须承认我无法做到这一点。冷漠、无能——我不承认；这肯定不只是懒惰吗？

‘None of those things. I’ve tried, and I see I can do nothing,’ said Levin.
“那些都不是。”我已经尝试过，但我发现我无能为力，”莱文说。

He had hardly grasped what his brother was saying. Looking towards the plough land across the river, he made out something black, but he could not distinguish whether it was a horse or the bailiff on horseback.
他几乎没听懂他哥哥在说什么。他向河对岸的耕地看去，看见了一个黑色的东西，却分不清那是一匹马，还是马背上的法警。

‘Why is it you can do nothing? You made an attempt and didn’t succeed, as you think, and you give in. How can you have so little self-respect?’
‘为什么你却无能为力？你尝试过，但没有成功，正如你所想的那样，你就屈服了。你怎么能这么没有自尊呢？

‘Self-respect!’ said Levin, stung to the quick by his brother’s words; ‘I don’t understand. If they’d told me at college that other people understood the integral calculus, and I didn’t, then pride would have come in. But in this case one wants first to be convinced that one has certain qualifications for this sort of business, and especially that all this business is of great importance.’
“自尊心！”列文说，他哥哥的话刺痛了他的心。 '我不明白。如果他们在大学时告诉我，其他人都了解积分，而我却不懂，那么我就会感到自豪。但在这种情况下，人们首先要确信自己具有从事此类业务的某些资格，尤其是所有这些业务都非常重要。”

‘What! do you mean to say it’s not of importance?’ said Sergey Ivanovitch, stung to the quick too at his brother’s considering anything of no importance that interested him, and still more at his obviously paying little attention to what he was saying.
'什么！ “你的意思是说这不重要吗？”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇问道，他的哥哥考虑到任何他感兴趣的无关紧要的事情，而且更明显的是他显然对自己所说的话毫不在意，这也让他感到很刺痛。

‘I don’t think it important; it does not take hold of me, I can’t help it,’ answered Levin, making out that what he saw was the bailiff, and that the bailiff seemed to be letting the peasants go off the ploughed land. They were turning the plough over. ‘Can they have finished ploughing?’ he wondered.
“我认为这并不重要； “它无法控制我，我无能为力。”莱文回答道，他看出他看到的是法警，而法警似乎正在让农民离开耕地。他们正在把犁翻过来。 “他们能犁完田吗？”他想知道。

‘Come, really though,’ said the elder brother, with a frown on his handsome, clever face, ‘there’s a limit to everything. It’s very well to be original and genuine, and to dislike everything conventional—I know all about that; but really, what you’re saying either has no meaning, or it has a very wrong meaning. How can you think it a matter of no importance whether the peasant, whom you love as you assert...’
“好吧，说实话，”哥哥英俊聪明的脸上皱着眉头说道，“凡事都有个限度。”保持原创性和真诚，并且不喜欢一切传统的东西是很好的——这一点我都知道；但我知道。但实际上，你所说的要么没有意义，要么意义非常错误。你怎么能认为你所爱的那个农民是否无关紧要呢……”

‘I never did assert it,’ thought Konstantin Levin.
“我从来没有断言过，”康斯坦丁·莱文想。

‘...dies without help? The ignorant peasant-women starve the children, and the people stagnate in darkness, and are helpless in the hands of every village clerk, while you have at your disposal a means of helping them, and don’t help them because to your mind it’s of no importance.’
‘……没有帮助就死了？无知的农妇让孩子们挨饿，人民在黑暗中停滞不前，在每个村官的手里都束手无策，而你有办法帮助他们，却不帮助他们，因为你认为这是不重要。

And Sergey Ivanovitch put before him the alternative: either you are so undeveloped that you can’t see all that you can do, or you won’t sacrifice your ease, your vanity, or whatever it is, to do it.
谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇向他提出了另一种选择：要么你太不发达，看不到你能做的一切，要么你不会牺牲你的安逸、你的虚荣心或其他什么来去做这件事。

Konstantin Levin felt that there was no course open to him but to submit, or to confess to a lack of zeal for the public good. And this mortified him and hurt his feelings.
康斯坦丁·莱文觉得，除了屈服或承认对公共利益缺乏热情之外，他别无选择。这让他感到羞愧并伤害了他的感情。

‘It’s both,’ he said resolutely: ‘I don’t see that it was possible...’
“两者都是，”他坚决地说，“我不认为这是可能的……”

‘What! was it impossible, if the money were properly laid out, to provide medical aid?’
'什么！如果资金分配得当，是否不可能提供医疗援助？

‘Impossible, as it seems to me.... For the three thousand square miles of our district, what with our thaws, and the storms, and the work in the fields, I don’t see how it is possible to provide medical aid all over. And besides, I don’t believe in medicine.’
“在我看来，不可能……对于我们地区三千平方英里的地区，由于解冻、暴风雨和田间工作，我不认为如何能够提供医疗服务。”援助遍地。而且，我不相信医学。

‘Oh, well, that’s unfair...I can quote to you thousands of instances.... But the schools, anyway.’
“哦，好吧，这不公平……我可以向你引用数千个例子……但无论如何，学校。”

‘Why have schools?’
“为什么要有学校？”

‘What do you mean? Can there be two opinions of the advantage of education? If it’s a good thing for you, it’s a good thing for everyone.’
'你是什么意思？对于教育的优势能有两种看法吗？如果这对你来说是件好事，那么对每个人来说也是件好事。”

Konstantin Levin felt himself morally pinned against a wall, and so he got hot, and unconsciously blurted out the chief cause of his indifference to public business.
康斯坦丁·莱文感到自己在道德上被逼到了墙角，于是他火冒三丈，不自觉地脱口说出了他对公共事务漠不关心的主要原因。

‘Perhaps it may all be very good; but why should I worry myself about establishing dispensaries which I shall never make use of, and schools to which I shall never send my children, to which even the peasants don’t want to send their children, and to which I’ve no very firm faith that they ought to send them?’ said he.
‘也许一切都很好；但是我为什么要担心建立我永远不会使用的药房和我永远不会送孩子去的学校，甚至农民也不想送他们的孩子去那里，我也没有太多的钱去那里。 “坚信他们应该派他们来吗？”他说。

Sergey Ivanovitch was for a minute surprised at this unexpected view of the subject; but he promptly made a new plan of attack. He was silent for a little, drew out a hook, threw it in again, and turned to his brother smiling.
谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇对这个话题的这种出乎意料的看法感到惊讶了一分钟。但他很快制定了新的进攻计划。他沉默了一会儿，抽出了一个钩子，又扔了进去，然后转向他的兄弟微笑着。

‘Come, now.... In the first place, the dispensary is needed. We ourselves sent for the district doctor for Agafea Mihalovna.’
‘来吧，现在……首先，需要药房。我们亲自为阿加菲亚·米哈伊洛夫娜请了地区医生。

‘Oh, well, but I fancy her wrist will never be straight again.’
“哦，好吧，但我想她的手腕再也不会伸直了。”

‘That remains to be proved.... Next, the peasant who can read and write is as a workman of more use and value to you.’
“这还有待证明……接下来，会读写的农民对你来说是更有用和更有价值的工人。”

‘No, you can ask anyone you like,’ Konstantin Levin answered with decision, ‘the man that can read and write is much inferior as a workman. And mending the highroads is an impossibility; and as soon as they put up bridges they’re stolen.’
“不，你可以问任何你喜欢的人，”康斯坦丁·莱文斩钉截铁地回答，“会读写的人比工人低劣得多。”修复高速公路是不可能的；一旦他们架起桥梁，他们就会被偷走。

‘Still, that’s not the point,’ said Sergey Ivanovitch, frowning. He disliked contradiction, and still more, arguments that were continually skipping from one thing to another, introducing new and disconnected points, so that there was no knowing to which to reply. ‘Do you admit that education is a benefit for the people?’
“不过，这不是重点，”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇皱着眉头说道。他不喜欢矛盾，更不喜欢不断地从一件事跳到另一件事的争论，引入新的、不连贯的观点，以至于不知道该回答哪一个。 “你承认教育是造福人民的吗？”

‘Yes, I admit it,’ said Levin without thinking, and he was conscious immediately that he had said what he did not think. He felt that if he admitted that, it would be proved that he had been talking meaningless rubbish. How it would be proved he could not tell, but he knew that this would inevitably be logically proved to him, and he awaited the proofs.
“是的，我承认。”莱文不假思索地说，他立刻意识到自己说出了自己没想到的话。他觉得，如果他承认了，就证明他一直在说毫无意义的废话。如何证明他不知道，但他知道这必然会在逻辑上向他证明，他等待着证明。

The argument turned out to be far simpler than he had expected.
事实证明，这场争论比他想象的要简单得多。

‘If you admit that it is a benefit,’ said Sergey Ivanovitch, ‘then, as an honest man, you cannot help caring about it and sympathizing with the movement, and so wishing to work for it.’
“如果你承认这是一种好处，”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇说，“那么，作为一个诚实的人，你就会情不自禁地关心它、同情这场运动，并愿意为此而努力。”

‘But I still do not admit this movement to be just,’ said Konstantin Levin, reddening a little.
“但我仍然不承认这场运动是正义的，”康斯坦丁·莱文脸红了一点说道。

‘What! But you said just now...’
'什么！但你刚才说……”

‘That’s to say, I don’t admit it’s being either good or possible.’
“也就是说，我不承认这是好事，也不承认这是可能的。”

‘That you can’t tell without making the trial.’
“不经过审判你就无法判断。”

‘Well, supposing that’s so,’ said Levin, though he did not suppose so at all, ‘supposing that is so, still I don’t see, all the same, what I’m to worry myself about it for.’
“好吧，就算是这样，”莱文说道，尽管他根本不这么认为，“就算是这样，我还是不明白我有什么好担心的。”

‘How so?’
'为何如此？'

‘No; since we are talking, explain it to me from the philosophical point of view,’ said Levin.
'不;既然我们在说话，那就从哲学的角度给我解释一下吧。”莱文说道。

‘I can’t see where philosophy comes in,’ said Sergey Ivanovitch, in a tone, Levin fancied, as though he did not admit his brother’s right to talk about philosophy. And that irritated Levin.
“我看不出哲学在哪里，”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇说，他的语气是莱文想象的，好像他不承认他哥哥有权谈论哲学。这激怒了莱文。

‘I’ll tell you, then,’ he said with heat, ‘I imagine the mainspring of all our actions is, after all, self-interest. Now in the local institutions I, as a nobleman, see nothing that could conduce to my prosperity, and the roads are not better and could not be better; my horses carry me well enough over bad ones. Doctors and dispensaries are no use to me. An arbitrator of disputes is no use to me. I never appeal to him, and never shall appeal to him. The schools are no good to me, but positively harmful, as I told you. For me the district institutions simply mean the liability to pay fourpence halfpenny for every three acres, to drive into the town, sleep with bugs, and listen to all sorts of idiocy and loathsomeness, and self-interest offers me no inducement.’
“那我告诉你，”他热情地说，“我想我们所有行为的主要动力毕竟是自利。”现在，在地方机构中，我作为一个贵族，看不到任何有助于我繁荣的东西，道路也好得不能再好了；我的马匹能很好地载着我，胜过坏马。医生和药房对我来说没有用。争端仲裁员对我来说没有用处。我从不向他求助，也永远不会向他求助。正如我告诉过你的，学校对我没有好处，反而有害。对我来说，地区机构仅仅意味着每三英亩土地支付四便士半便士的责任，开车进城，和虫子一起睡觉，听各种各样的白痴和令人厌恶的言论，而私利对我来说没有任何诱因。

‘Excuse me,’ Sergey Ivanovitch interposed with a smile, ‘self-interest did not induce us to work for the emancipation of the serfs, but we did work for it.’
“对不起，”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇微笑着插话道，“我们并不是出于自身利益而为农奴的解放而努力，但我们确实为此而努力。”

‘No!’ Konstantin Levin broke in with still greater heat; ‘the emancipation of the serfs was a different matter. There self-interest did come in. One longed to throw off that yoke that crushed us, all decent people among us. But to be a town councilor and discuss how many dustmen are needed, and how chimneys shall be constructed in the town in which I don’t live—to serve on a jury and try a peasant who’s stolen a flitch of bacon, and listen for six hours at a stretch to all sorts of jabber from the counsel for the defense and the prosecution, and the president cross-examining my old half-witted Alioshka, ‘Do you admit, prisoner in the dock, the fact of the removal of the bacon?’ ‘Eh?’’
“不！”康斯坦丁·莱文语气更加激烈地插话道。 “农奴的解放则是另一回事。确实存在私利。人们渴望摆脱压迫我们的枷锁，我们当中所有正派的人都被压垮了。但要成为一名镇议员，讨论需要多少清洁工，以及如何在我不住的城镇里建造烟囱——担任陪审团成员，审判一个偷了一块培根的农民，并倾听他的意见。连续六个小时，辩方律师和检方律师喋喋不休，总统盘问我那老糊涂的阿廖什卡，‘你承认吗，被告席上的囚犯，驱逐了培根？” “呃？”

Konstantin Levin had warmed to his subject, and began mimicking the president and the half-witted Alioshka: it seemed to him that it was all to the point.
康斯坦丁·莱文对他的话题产生了兴趣，并开始模仿总统和愚蠢的阿廖什卡：在他看来，这一切都是切中要害的。

But Sergey Ivanovitch shrugged his shoulders.
但谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇耸了耸肩。

‘Well, what do you mean to say, then?’
“那么，你想说什么？”

‘I simply mean to say that those rights that touch me...my interest, I shall always defend to the best of my ability; that when they made raids on us students, and the police read our letters, I was ready to defend those rights to the utmost, to defend my rights to education and freedom. I can understand compulsory military service, which affects my children, my brothers, and myself, I am ready to deliberate on what concerns me; but deliberating on how to spend forty thousand roubles of district council money, or judging the half-witted Alioshka—I don’t understand, and I can’t do it.’
“我只是想说，那些触及我的权利……我的利益，我将永远尽我所能捍卫；当他们袭击我们学生时，当警察读到我们的信时，我准备竭尽全力捍卫这些权利，捍卫我的受教育权和自由权。我能理解义务兵役制，这会影响我的孩子、我的兄弟和我自己，我准备好考虑与我有关的事情；但思考如何花掉区议会的四万卢布的钱，或者评判愚蠢的阿廖什卡——我不明白，我也做不到。

Konstantin Levin spoke as though the floodgates of his speech had burst open. Sergey Ivanovitch smiled.
康斯坦丁·莱文的讲话就像他的演讲的闸门突然打开了一样。谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇笑了。

‘But tomorrow it’ll be your turn to be tried; would it have suited your tastes better to be tried in the old criminal tribunal?’
“但是明天就轮到你受审了；在旧的刑事法庭受审会更适合你的口味吗？

‘I’m not going to be tried. I shan’t murder anybody, and I’ve no need of it. Well, I tell you what,’ he went on, flying off again to a subject quite beside the point, ‘our district self-government and all the rest of it—it’s just like the birch branches we stick in the ground on Trinity Day, for instance, to look like a copse which has grown up of itself in Europe, and I can’t gush over these birch branches and believe in them.’
‘我不会受到审判。我不会谋杀任何人，我也不需要它。好吧，我告诉你什么，”他继续说道，又飞奔到一个完全无关紧要的话题，“我们的地区自治以及所有其他的东西——就像我们在三一日插在地上的桦树枝一样。 ，例如，看起来像欧洲自然生长的灌木丛，我无法滔滔不绝地谈论这些白桦树枝并相信它们。

Sergey Ivanovitch merely shrugged his shoulders, as though to express his wonder how the birch branches had come into their argument at that point, though he did really understand at once what his brother meant.
谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇只是耸了耸肩，似乎想表达他对桦树枝怎么会在此时介入他们的争论感到惊讶，尽管他立刻就明白了他哥哥的意思。

‘Excuse me, but you know one really can’t argue in that way,’ he observed.
“对不起，但你知道人们真的不能以这种方式争论，”他评论道。

But Konstantin Levin wanted to justify himself for the failing, of which he was conscious, of lack of zeal for the public welfare, and he went on.
但康斯坦丁·莱文想为自己的失败辩护，他意识到这一点，即对公共福利缺乏热情，他继续说下去。

‘I imagine,’ he said, ‘that no sort of activity is likely to be lasting if it is not founded on self-interest, that’s a universal principle, a philosophical principle,’ he said, repeating the word ‘philosophical’ with determination, as though wishing to show that he had as much right as any one else to talk of philosophy.
“我想，”他说，“如果不是建立在自身利益的基础上，任何活动都不可能持久，这是一条普遍原则，一条哲学原则，”他坚定地重复着“哲学”这个词。 ，好像希望表明他和其他人一样有权利谈论哲学。

Sergey Ivanovitch smiled. ‘He too has a philosophy of his own at the service of his natural tendencies,’ he thought.
谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇笑了。 “他也有自己的哲学，为他的自然倾向服务，”他想。

‘Come, you’d better let philosophy alone,’ he said. ‘The chief problem of the philosophy of all ages consists just in finding the indispensable connection which exists between individual and social interests. But that’s not to the point; what is to the point is a correction I must make in your comparison. The birches are not simply stuck in, but some are sown and some are planted, and one must deal carefully with them. It’s only those peoples that have an intuitive sense of what’s of importance and significance in their institutions, and know how to value them, that have a future before them—it’s only those peoples that one can truly call historical.’
“来吧，你最好别管哲学，”他说。 “历代哲学的主要问题在于寻找个人利益与社会利益之间存在的不可或缺的联系。但这不是重点；重点是我必须在你的比较中做出修正。桦树不是简单地插进去的，而是有的播种的，有的栽植的，一定要小心对待。只有那些对自己的机构中的重要性和意义有直观认识并知道如何评价它们的民族，他们才有未来——只有这些民族才能真正被称为历史性的。

And Sergey Ivanovitch carried the subject into the regions of philosophical history where Konstantin Levin could not follow him, and showed him all the incorrectness of his view.
谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇将这个主题带入了康斯坦丁·莱文无法追随的哲学史领域，并向他展示了他的观点的全部错误。

‘As for your dislike of it, excuse my saying so, that’s simply our Russian sloth and old serf-owner’s ways, and I’m convinced that in you it’s a temporary error and will pass.’
“至于你不喜欢它，请原谅我这么说，这只是我们俄罗斯树懒和老农奴主的方式，我相信这对你来说只是暂时的错误，会过去的。”

Konstantin was silent. He felt himself vanquished on all sides, but he felt at the same time that what he wanted to say was unintelligible to his brother. Only he could not make up his mind whether it was unintelligible because he was not capable of expressing his meaning clearly, or because his brother would not or could not understand him. But he did not pursue the speculation, and without replying, he fell to musing on a quite different and personal matter.
康斯坦丁沉默了。他感觉自己四面楚歌，但同时又觉得自己想说的话对弟弟来说是听不懂的。只是他无法判断这句话听不懂是因为他没有能力清楚地表达自己的意思，还是因为他的兄弟不会或不能理解他。但他没有追究这个猜测，也没有回答，而是开始思考一件完全不同的个人问题。

Sergey Ivanovitch wound up the last line, untied the horse, and they drove off.
谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇拉紧最后一根绳子，解开马匹，然后他们就出发了。

Chapter 4
第4章

The personal matter that absorbed Levin during his conversation with his brother was this. Once in a previous year he had gone to look at the mowing, and being made very angry by the bailiff he had recourse to his favorite means for regaining his temper,— he took a scythe from a peasant and began mowing.
莱文在与他的兄弟交谈时，最关心的就是这个个人问题。前一年有一次，他去看割草，被法警激怒了，他用了他最喜欢的方法来平复自己的脾气——他从一个农民手中接过一把镰刀，开始割草。

He liked the work so much that he had several times tried his hand at mowing since. He had cut the whole of the meadow in front of his house, and this year ever since the early spring he had cherished a plan for mowing for whole days together with the peasants. Ever since his brother’s arrival, he had been in doubt whether to mow or not. He was loath to leave his brother alone all day long, and he was afraid his brother would laugh at him about it. But as he drove into the meadow, and recalled the sensations of mowing, he came near deciding that he would go mowing. After the irritating discussion with his brother, he pondered over this intention again.
他非常喜欢这项工作，从那以后他曾多次尝试割草。他把家门前的草地都割光了，今年从早春开始，他就盘算着要和农民们一起割草一整天。自从他哥哥到来后，他一直在犹豫是否要割草。他不愿意整天丢下弟弟一个人，他害怕弟弟会因此而笑话他。但当他开车进入草地，回想起割草的感觉时，他几乎决定去割草。与哥哥进行了一番令人恼火的争论后，他再次思考了这个意图。

‘I must have physical exercise, or my temper’ll certainly be ruined,’ he thought, and he determined he would go mowing, however awkward he might feel about it with his brother or the peasants.
“我必须锻炼身体，否则我的脾气肯定会被毁掉。”他想，然后他决定去割草，不管他和他的兄弟或农民在一起会感到多么尴尬。

Towards evening Konstantin Levin went to his counting house, gave directions as to the work to be done, and sent about the village to summon the mowers for the morrow, to cut the hay in Kalinov meadow, the largest and best of his grass lands.
傍晚时分，康斯坦丁·莱文来到他的账房，指示了要做的工作，然后派人去村子里召集明天的割草机，去卡利诺夫草甸割草，那是他最大、最好的草地。

‘And send my scythe, please, to Tit, for him to set it, and bring it round tomorrow. I shall maybe do some mowing myself too,’ he said, trying not to be embarrassed.
“请把我的镰刀寄给蒂特，让他安装，明天再送来。”我也许也会自己割草，”他说道，尽量不感到尴尬。

The bailiff smiled and said: ‘Yes, sir.’
法警微笑着说：“是的，先生。”

At tea the same evening Levin said to his brother:
当天晚上喝茶时，莱文对他的兄弟说：

‘I fancy the fine weather will last. Tomorrow I shall start mowing.’
“我想好天气会持续下去。明天我就开始割草了。”

‘I’m so fond of that form of field labor,’ said Sergey Ivanovitch.
“我非常喜欢这种形式的田野劳动，”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇说。

‘I’m awfully fond of it. I sometimes mow myself with the peasants, and tomorrow I want to try mowing the whole day.’
‘我非常喜欢它。有时我会和农民一起割草，明天我想尝试一整天割草。

Sergey Ivanovitch lifted his head, and looked with interest at his brother.
谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇抬起头，饶有兴趣地看着他的兄弟。

‘How do you mean? Just like one of the peasants, all day long?’
'你是什么意思？就像一个农民一样，整天这样吗？

‘Yes, it’s very pleasant,’ said Levin.
“是的，这非常令人愉快，”莱文说。

‘It’s splendid as exercise, only you’ll hardly be able to stand it,’ said Sergey Ivanovitch, without a shade of irony.
“作为锻炼来说，这真是太棒了，只是你几乎无法忍受。”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇毫不讽刺地说。

‘I’ve tried it. It’s hard work at first, but you get into it. I dare say I shall manage to keep it up...’
‘我已经尝试过了。一开始很辛苦，但你就会投入其中。我敢说我会设法坚持下去……”

‘Really! what an idea! But tell me, how do the peasants look at it? I suppose they laugh in their sleeves at their master’s being such a queer fish?’
'真的吗！多好的主意啊！但你告诉我，农民们怎么看？我想他们会暗自嘲笑他们的主人是一条如此奇怪的鱼吧？

‘No, I don’t think so; but it’s so delightful, and at the same time such hard work, that one has no time to think about it.’
“不，我不这么认为；”但它是如此令人愉快，同时又如此辛苦，以至于人们没有时间去想它。”

‘But how will you do about dining with them? To send you a bottle of Lafitte and roast turkey out there would be a little awkward.’
“但是和他们一起吃饭你会怎么样呢？送你一瓶拉菲特和烤火鸡就有点尴尬了。”

‘No, I’ll simply come home at the time of their noonday rest.’
“不，我会在他们中午休息的时候回家。”

Next morning Konstantin Levin got up earlier than usual, but he was detained giving directions on the farm, and when he reached the mowing grass the mowers were already at their second row.
第二天早上，康斯坦丁·莱文比平时起得更早，但他被拘留在农场里指挥，当他到达割草处时，割草机已经在第二排了。

From the uplands he could get a view of the shaded cut part of the meadow below, with its grayish ridges of cut grass, and the black heaps of coats, taken off by the mowers at the place from which they had started cutting.
从高地他可以看到下面草甸被遮荫的割草部分，割草的灰色山脊，以及割草机在开始割草的地方脱下的黑色外套。

Gradually, as he rode towards the meadow, the peasants came into sight, some in coats, some in their shirts mowing, one behind another in a long string, swinging their scythes differently. He counted forty-two of them.
渐渐地，当他骑马向草地走去时，农民们出现在了视野中，有的穿着外套，有的穿着衬衫，一前一后地排成一长串，挥舞着不同的镰刀。他数了数，有四十二个。

They were mowing slowly over the uneven, low-lying parts of the meadow, where there had been an old dam. Levin recognized some of his own men. Here was old Yermil in a very long white smock, bending forward to swing a scythe; there was a young fellow, Vaska, who had been a coachman of Levin’s, taking every row with a wide sweep. Here, too, was Tit, Levin’s preceptor in the art of mowing, a thin little peasant. He was in front of all, and cut his wide row without bending, as though playing with the scythe.
他们正在草地上不平坦、低洼的地方缓慢地割草，那里曾经有一座旧水坝。莱文认出了一些自己的手下。老耶米尔穿着一件很长的白色罩衫，弯着腰挥舞着一把镰刀。有一个年轻人，名叫瓦斯卡，曾是莱文的马车夫，每排都横扫一切。这里还有蒂特，莱文的割草艺术导师，一个瘦弱的小农夫。他走在所有人的前面，毫不弯腰地割着宽排，就像玩镰刀一样。

Levin got off his mare, and fastening her up by the roadside went to meet Tit, who took a second scythe out of a bush and gave it to him.
莱文下了马，把她拴在路边，去见蒂特，蒂特从灌木丛中取出第二把镰刀，递给了他。

‘It’s ready, sir; it’s like a razor, cuts of itself,’ said Tit, taking off his cap with a smile and giving him the scythe.
“已经准备好了，先生；它就像一把剃刀，会自动割伤。”蒂特微笑着摘下帽子，把镰刀递给他。

Levin took the scythe, and began trying it. As they finished their rows, the mowers, hot and good-humored, came out into the road one after another, and, laughing a little, greeted the master. They all stared at him, but no one made any remark, till a tall old man, with a wrinkled, beardless face, wearing a short sheepskin jacket, came out into the road and accosted him.
莱文拿起镰刀，开始尝试。当他们完成了割草工作后，割草工们热情而幽默地陆续来到马路上，笑着向​​主人打招呼。大家都盯着他看，但没有人出声，直到一个穿着短羊皮袄、满脸皱纹、没有胡须、身材高大的老人走到路上，向他搭话。

‘Look’ee now, master, once take hold of the rope there’s no letting it go!’ he said, and Levin heard smothered laughter among the mowers.
“看，主人，一旦抓住绳子，就不会放手！”他说，莱文听到割草机中压抑的笑声。

‘I’ll try not to let it go,’ he said, taking his stand behind Tit, and waiting for the time to begin.
“我会尽力不让事情发生，”他说，站在蒂特身后，等待时间开始。

‘Mind’ee,’ repeated the old man.
“注意，”老人重复道。

Tit made room, and Levin started behind him. The grass was short close to the road, and Levin, who had not done any mowing for a long while, and was disconcerted by the eyes fastened upon him, cut badly for the first moments, though he swung his scythe vigorously. Behind him he heard voices:
蒂特让出了空间，莱文在他身后开始行动。靠近路的草很短，莱文已经很长一段时间没有割草了，他被盯着他的眼睛弄得不知所措，尽管他用力挥舞着镰刀，但刚开始的时候还是割得很厉害。他听到身后有声音：

‘It’s not set right; handle’s too high; see how he has to stoop to it,’ said one.
‘设置不正确；手柄太高；看看他如何不得不屈尊去做，”其中一位说道。

‘Press more on the heel,’ said another.
“多按一下脚跟，”另一个人说。

‘Never mind, he’ll get on all right,’ the old man resumed.
“没关系，他会过得很好的，”老人继续说道。

‘He’s made a start.... You swing it too wide, you’ll tire yourself out.... The master, sure, does his best for himself! But see the grass missed out! For such work us fellows would catch it!’
‘他已经开始了……你把球摆得太宽了，你会累死自己的……当然，主人会尽力而为！但看到草错过了！对于这样的工作，我们这些人会接受的！

The grass became softer, and Levin, listening without answering, followed Tit, trying to do the best he could. They moved a hundred paces. Tit kept moving on, without stopping, not showing the slightest weariness, but Levin was already beginning to be afraid he would not be able to keep it up: he was so tired.
草变得更软了，莱文听着，没有回答，跟着蒂特，尽力做到最好。他们移动了一百步。蒂特继续前行，没有停下来，没有表现出丝毫疲倦，但莱文已经开始担心自己无法坚持下去了：他太累了。

He felt as he swung his scythe that he was at the very end of his strength, and was making up his mind to ask Tit to stop. But at that very moment Tit stopped of his own accord, and stooping down picked up some grass, rubbed his scythe, and began whetting it. Levin straightened himself, and drawing a deep breath looked round. Behind him came a peasant, and he too was evidently tired, for he stopped at once without waiting to mow up to Levin, and began whetting his scythe. Tit sharpened his scythe and Levin’s, and they went on. The next time it was just the same. Tit moved on with sweep after sweep of his scythe, not stopping nor showing signs of weariness. Levin followed him, trying not to get left behind, and he found it harder and harder: the moment came when he felt he had no strength left, but at that very moment Tit stopped and whetted the scythes.
当他挥动镰刀时，他感到自己已经力竭了，并决定让蒂特停下来。但就在这时，蒂特自己停了下来，弯下腰捡起一些草，擦了擦镰刀，开始磨它。莱文直起身子，深吸了一口气，环顾四周。他身后跟着一个农民，显然他也累了，因为他没有等莱文割草，就立刻停下来，开始磨镰刀。蒂特和莱文磨利了镰刀，然后他们继续前行。下次还是一样。蒂特继续挥舞镰刀，没有停下来，也没有表现出疲倦的迹象。莱文跟在他后面，努力不被抛在后面，他发现事情越来越难：当他感到自己没有力气的时候，蒂特停了下来，磨起了镰刀。

So they mowed the first row. And this long row seemed particularly hard work to Levin; but when the end was reached and Tit, shouldering his scythe, began with deliberate stride returning on the tracks left by his heels in the cut grass, and Levin walked back in the same way over the space he had cut, in spite of the sweat that ran in streams over his face and fell in drops down his nose, and drenched his back as though he had been soaked in water, he felt very happy. What delighted him particularly was that now he knew he would be able to hold out.
所以他们割了第一行。对莱文来说，这一长排似乎特别辛苦。但当到达终点时，蒂特扛着镰刀，开始从容地沿着他的脚后跟在割过的草丛中留下的痕迹返回，莱文以同样的方式走回他割过的地方，尽管满头大汗溪水流过他的脸，滴落到他的鼻子里，淋湿了他的后背，就像被水浸湿了一样，他感到非常高兴。让他特别高兴的是，现在他知道自己能够坚持下去。

His pleasure was only disturbed by his row not being well cut. ‘I will swing less with my arm and more with my whole body,’ he thought, comparing Tit’s row, which looked as if it had been cut with a line, with his own unevenly and irregularly lying grass.
他的快乐只是因为他的划船没有剪好而受到干扰。 “我会少用手臂挥动，多用全身挥动，”他一边想，一边将蒂特的划船（看起来像是用线划过的）与他自己那凹凸不平、不规则的草地进行了比较。

The first row, as Levin noticed, Tit had mowed specially quickly, probably wishing to put his master to the test, and the row happened to be a long one. The next rows were easier, but still Levin had to strain every nerve not to drop behind the peasants.
莱文注意到，第一排山雀割草的速度特别快，可能是想考验一下他的主人，而这一排恰好很长。接下来的几排就容易多了，但莱文仍然必须竭尽全力不落后于农民。

He thought of nothing, wished for nothing, but not to be left behind the peasants, and to do his work as well as possible. He heard nothing but the swish of scythes, and saw before him Tit’s upright figure mowing away, the crescent-shaped curve of the cut grass, the grass and flower heads slowly and rhythmically falling before the blade of his scythe, and ahead of him the end of the row, where would come the rest.
他什么也不想，什么也不要，就是不落下农民的后尘，尽力做好自己的工作。除了镰刀的嗖嗖声，他什么也没听见，看见蒂特在他面前直立的身影正在割草，割草的新月形曲线，草和花头慢慢地有节奏地落在他的镰刀刀刃前，在他面前，行的末尾，剩下的会到哪里。

Suddenly, in the midst of his toil, without understanding what it was or whence it came, he felt a pleasant sensation of chill on his hot, moist shoulders. He glanced at the sky in the interval for whetting the scythes. A heavy, lowering storm cloud had blown up, and big raindrops were falling. Some of the peasants went to their coats and put them on; others—just like Levin himself—merely shrugged their shoulders, enjoying the pleasant coolness of it.
突然，在他的劳作中，他不知道那是什么，也不知道它从何而来，他感到灼热潮湿的肩膀上有一股令人愉悦的寒意。在磨镰刀的间隙，他看了一眼天空。一片沉重的、低沉的暴风雨云已经吹起，大颗大颗的雨点落了下来。一些农民去把外套穿上；另一些则穿上了。其他人——就像莱文本人一样——只是耸耸肩，享受着令人愉快的凉爽。

Another row, and yet another row, followed—long rows and short rows, with good grass and with poor grass. Levin lost all sense of time, and could not have told whether it was late or early now. A change began to come over his work, which gave him immense satisfaction. In the midst of his toil there were moments during which he forgot what he was doing, and it came all easy to him, and at those same moments his row was almost as smooth and well cut as Tit’s. But so soon as he recollected what he was doing, and began trying to do better, he was at once conscious of all the difficulty of his task, and the row was badly mown.
接下来又是一排，又是一排——长排和短排，有好草的，也有不好草的。莱文完全失去了时间感，分不清现在是晚了还是早了。他的工作开始发生变化，这给他带来了巨大的满足感。在他辛勤劳作的过程中，有时他会忘记自己在做什么，而这对他来说一切都很容易，在同一时刻，他的划船几乎和蒂特的划船一样光滑、整齐。但当他回想起自己正在做的事情，并开始努力做得更好时，他立刻意识到自己的任务有多困难，而这行割得很严重。

On finishing yet another row he would have gone back to the top of the meadow again to begin the next, but Tit stopped, and going up to the old man said something in a low voice to him. They both looked at the sun. ‘What are they talking about, and why doesn’t he go back?’ thought Levin, not guessing that the peasants had been mowing no less than four hours without stopping, and it was time for their lunch.
当完成另一排时，他本来会再次回到草地顶部开始下一行，但蒂特停了下来，走到老人面前低声对他说了些什么。两人都看着太阳。 “他们在说什么，他为什么不回去？”莱文想道，没想到农民们已经不间断地割草了至少四个小时，现在该吃午饭了。

‘Lunch, sir,’ said the old man.
“吃午饭了，先生。”老人说道。

‘Is it really time? That’s right; lunch, then.’
‘真的到时间了吗？这是正确的;那么吃午饭吧。

Levin gave his scythe to Tit, and together with the peasants, who were crossing the long stretch of mown grass, slightly sprinkled with rain, to get their bread from the heap of coats, he went towards his house. Only then he suddenly awoke to the fact that he had been wrong about the weather and the rain was drenching his hay.
莱文把他的镰刀交给了蒂特，他和那些正在穿过长长的割过的草地、洒着雨水的农民一起，从大衣堆里取面包，向他的家走去。直到这时，他才猛然醒悟，原来自己对天气的判断是错误的，雨水正在淋湿他的干草​​。

‘The hay will be spoiled,’ he said.
“干草会变质的，”他说。

‘Not a bit of it, sir; mow in the rain, and you’ll rake in fine weather!’ said the old man.
“一点也没有，先生；雨中割草，晴天你就能耙草！”老人说道。

Levin untied his horse and rode home to his coffee. Sergey Ivanovitch was only just getting up. When he had drunk his coffee, Levin rode back again to the mowing before Sergey Ivanovitch had had time to dress and come down to the dining room.
莱文解开马匹，骑马回家喝咖啡。谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇才刚刚起床。喝完咖啡后，列文又骑马回到割草场，谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇还没来得及穿好衣服来到餐厅。

Chapter 5
第5章

After lunch Levin was not in the same place in the string of mowers as before, but stood between the old man who had accosted him jocosely, and now invited him to be his neighbor, and a young peasant, who had only been married in the autumn, and who was mowing this summer for the first time.
午饭后，莱文不再像以前那样在割草机中的同一个地方，而是站在一个老人和一个年轻的农民之间，老人曾和他开玩笑，现在邀请他做邻居，而年轻的农民则刚刚结婚。秋天，以及今年夏天第一次割草的人。

The old man, holding himself erect, moved in front, with his feet turned out, taking long, regular strides, and with a precise and regular action which seemed to cost him no more effort than swinging one’s arms in walking, as though it were in play, he laid down the high, even row of grass. It was as though it were not he but the sharp scythe of itself swishing through the juicy grass.
老人挺直身子，走在前面，双脚向外，迈着大步，整齐划一，动作精确而有规律，似乎不比摆臂走路更费力，仿佛在走路。玩耍时，他放下那排又高又平的草。就好像那不是他，而是一把锋利的镰刀在多汁的青草中嗖嗖作响。

Behind Levin came the lad Mishka. His pretty, boyish face, with a twist of fresh grass bound round his hair, was all working with effort; but whenever anyone looked at him he smiled. He would clearly have died sooner than own it was hard work for him.
莱文身后跟着小伙子米什卡。他那张漂亮的孩子气的脸，头发上缠着一缕新鲜的青草，看上去很努力。但每当有人看他时，他都会微笑。显然，他宁愿死也不愿承认这对他来说是艰苦的工作。

Levin kept between them. In the very heat of the day the mowing did not seem such hard work to him. The perspiration with which he was drenched cooled him, while the sun, that burned his back, his head, and his arms, bare to the elbow, gave a vigor and dogged energy to his labor; and more and more often now came those moments of unconsciousness, when it was possible not to think what one was doing. The scythe cut of itself. These were happy moments. Still more delightful were the moments when they reached the stream where the rows ended, and the old man rubbed his scythe with the wet, thick grass, rinsed its blade in the fresh water of the stream, ladled out a little in a tin dipper, and offered Levin a drink.
莱文挡在他们中间。在炎热的天气里，割草对他来说似乎并不那么辛苦。汗水湿透了他，使他感到凉爽，而阳光灼烧着他的背部、头部和赤裸到肘部的手臂，给他的劳动带来了活力和顽强的能量；现在越来越多地出现无意识的时刻，此时人们可能不去想一个人在做什么。镰刀自己割断了。这些都是快乐的时刻。更令人高兴的是，当他们到达行结束的小溪时，老人用湿漉漉的厚草摩擦他的镰刀，在小溪的淡水中冲洗刀片，用锡勺舀出一点，并请莱文喝了一杯。

‘What do you say to my home-brew, eh? Good, eh?’ said he, winking.
‘你对我的自酿啤酒有什么看法，嗯？很好，嗯？”他眨着眼睛说道。

And truly Levin had never drunk any liquor so good as this warm water with green bits floating in it, and a taste of rust from the tin dipper. And immediately after this came the delicious, slow saunter, with his hand on the scythe, during which he could wipe away the streaming sweat, take deep breaths of air, and look about at the long string of mowers and at what was happening around in the forest and the country.
莱文确实从来没有喝过比这温水更好喝的酒，水里漂浮着绿色的碎片，还有锡勺的铁锈味。紧接着，他手握着镰刀，开始了愉快、缓慢的漫步，在此期间，他可以擦去流淌的汗水，深吸一口气，环顾一长串割草机，看看周围发生的事情。森林和乡村。
