“啊，这一切是多么沉闷啊！”丽莎·梅尔卡洛娃说道。 “比赛结束后我们都开车回到我的住处。总是同样的人，总是一样的。总是同样的事情。我们整个晚上都在沙发上闲逛。这其中有什么可享受的呢？不;请告诉我你是如何做到永远不感到无聊的？”她再次对安娜说道。 “只要看着你，你就会发现，这是一个可能快乐或不快乐的女人，但她并不感到无聊。告诉我你是怎么做到的？

‘I do nothing,’ answered Anna, blushing at these searching questions.
“我什么也没做。”安娜回答道，面对这些尖锐的问题，脸红了。

‘That’s the best way,’ Stremov put in. Stremov was a man of fifty, partly gray, but still vigorous-looking, very ugly, but with a characteristic and intelligent face. Liza Merkalova was his wife’s niece, and he spent all his leisure hours with her. On meeting Anna Karenina, as he was Alexey Alexandrovitch’s enemy in the government, he tried, like a shrewd man and a man of the world, to be particularly cordial with her, the wife of his enemy.
“这是最好的办法，”斯特列莫夫插话道。斯特列莫夫是个五十岁的男人，头发有些灰白，但看上去仍然精力充沛，非常丑陋，但有一张独特而聪明的脸。丽莎·梅尔卡洛娃是他妻子的侄女，他所有的闲暇时间都和她一起度过。在见到安娜·卡列尼娜时，由于他是阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇在政府中的敌人，他像一个精明的人和一个世俗的人一样，试图对她这个敌人的妻子特别友善。

‘‘Nothing,’’ he put in with a subtle smile, ‘that’s the very best way. I told you long ago,’ he said, turning to Liza Merkalova, ‘that if you don’t want to be bored, you mustn’t think you’re going to be bored. It’s just as you mustn’t be afraid of not being able to fall asleep, if you’re afraid of sleeplessness. That’s just what Anna Arkadyevna has just said.’
“没什么，”他微笑着说道，“这是最好的办法。”我很久以前就告诉过你，”他转向丽莎·梅尔卡洛娃说道，“如果你不想感到无聊，你就不能认为自己会感到无聊。就像你害怕失眠就不必害怕睡不着一样。这正是安娜·阿尔卡季耶夫娜刚才所说的。

‘I should be very glad if I had said it, for it’s not only clever but true,’ said Anna, smiling.
“如果我这么说的话，我会很高兴，因为这不仅很聪明，而且很真实，”安娜微笑着说。

‘No, do tell me why it is one can’t go to sleep, and one can’t help being bored?’
“不，你告诉我为什么会睡不着，而且会忍不住感到无聊？”

‘To sleep well one ought to work, and to enjoy oneself one ought to work too.’
“要想睡得好，就应该工作；要想享受生活，就应该工作。”

‘What am I to work for when my work is no use to anybody? And I can’t and won’t knowingly make a pretense about it.’
‘当我的工作对任何人都没有用处时，我还要工作做什么？我不能也不会故意假装这一点。

‘You’re incorrigible,’ said Stremov, not looking at her, and he spoke again to Anna. As he rarely met Anna, he could say nothing but commonplaces to her, but he said those commonplaces as to when she was returning to Petersburg, and how fond Countess Lidia Ivanovna was of her, with an expression which suggested that he longed with his whole soul to please her and show his regard for her and even more than that.
“你已经无可救药了，”斯特列莫夫说，没有看她，然后他又对安娜说话。由于他很少见到安娜，所以他只能对她说一些平常的话，但他说了一些平常的话，比如她什么时候回到彼得堡，以及莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人对她的喜爱程度，他的表情表明他渴望与他的整个人在一起。灵魂取悦她并表达他对她的尊重，甚至更多。

Tushkevitch came in, announcing that the party were awaiting the other players to begin croquet.
图什克维奇进来了，宣布大家正在等待其他选手开始槌球比赛。

‘No, don’t go away, please don’t,’ pleaded Liza Merkalova, hearing that Anna was going. Stremov joined in her entreaties.
“不，不要走，请不要走，”丽莎·梅尔卡洛娃听到安娜要走后恳求道。斯特列莫夫也加入了她的恳求。

‘It’s too violent a transition,’ he said, ‘to go from such company to old Madame Vrede. And besides, you will only give her a chance for talking scandal, while here you arouse none but such different feelings of the highest and most opposite kind,’ he said to her.
“从这样的公司到老弗雷德夫人，这种转变太剧烈了，”他说。而且，你只会给她一个谈论丑闻的机会，而在这里你只会激起这种最高和最相反的不同感觉，”他对她说。

Anna pondered for an instant in uncertainty. This shrewd man’s flattering words, the naive, childlike affection shown her by Liza Merkalova, and all the social atmosphere she was used to,— it was all so easy, and what was in store for her was so difficult, that she was for a minute in uncertainty whether to remain, whether to put off a little longer the painful moment of explanation. But remembering what was in store for her alone at home, if she did not come to some decision, remembering that gesture—terrible even in memory—when she had clutched her hair in both hands—she said good-bye and went away.
安娜疑惑地沉思了片刻。这个精明男人的谄媚之言，莉莎·梅尔卡洛娃对她表现出的天真童心，还有她所习惯的一切社交氛围——这一切都是那么的容易，而等待她的却是那么的艰难，以至于她不确定是否要留下来，是否要推迟解释的痛苦时刻。但想起她一个人在家里等待着的是什么，如果她没有做出某种决定，想起她双手抓着头发时的那个姿势——即使在记忆中也很可怕——她说了再见就走了。

Chapter 19
第19章

In spite of Vronsky’s apparently frivolous life in society, he was a man who hated irregularity. In early youth in the Corps of Pages, he had experienced the humiliation of a refusal, when he had tried, being in difficulties, to borrow money, and since then he had never once put himself in the same position again.
尽管渥伦斯基的社会生活看似轻浮，但他却是一个痛恨不正规的人。年轻时，他在侍从军团中，曾在困难中尝试借钱，却遭到拒绝，这让他感到羞辱，从那以后，他再也没有陷入同样的​​境地。

In order to keep his affairs in some sort of order, he used about five times a year (more or less frequently, according to circumstances) to shut himself up alone and put all his affairs into definite shape. This he used to call his day of reckoning or faire la lessive.
为了让自己的事务保持某种秩序，他每年大约有五次（根据情况或多或少）将自己单独封闭起来，将所有事务都安排妥当。他常常将这一天称为“清算日”或“faire la lessive”。

On waking up the day after the races, Vronsky put on a white linen coat, and without shaving or taking his bath, he distributed about the table moneys, bills, and letters, and set to work. Petritsky, who knew he was ill-tempered on such occasions, on waking up and seeing his comrade at the writing-table, quietly dressed and went out without getting in his way.
赛后第二天醒来，渥伦斯基穿上一件白色亚麻外套，没有刮胡子，也没有洗澡，他把钱、账单和信件分发到桌子上，然后开始工作。佩特里茨基知道自己在这种情况下脾气暴躁，一觉醒来，看到他的战友坐在写字台前，他就安静地穿好衣服，出去了，没有妨碍他。

Every man who knows to the minutest details all the complexity of the conditions surrounding him, cannot help imagining that the complexity of these conditions, and the difficulty of making them clear, is something exceptional and personal, peculiar to himself, and never supposes that others are surrounded by just as complicated an array of personal affairs as he is. So indeed it seemed to Vronsky. And not without inward pride, and not without reason, he thought that any other man would long ago have been in difficulties, would have been forced to some dishonorable course, if he had found himself in such a difficult position. But Vronsky felt that now especially it was essential for him to clear up and define his position if he were to avoid getting into difficulties.
每一个对周围环境的复杂性了如指掌的人，都会情不自禁地想象，这些环境的复杂性，以及使它们变得清晰的困难，是一种特殊的、个人的、独特的东西，并且从不认为其他人也能做到这一点。和他一样被一系列复杂的个人事务所包围。在渥伦斯基看来确实如此。他并非没有内心的骄傲，也不是没有理由，他认为，如果其他人发现自己处于如此困难的境地，那么他早就陷入了困境，会被迫采取一些不光彩的做法。但渥伦斯基觉得，如果他想避免陷入困境，现在特别有必要澄清和明确自己的立场。

What Vronsky attacked first as being the easiest was his pecuniary position. Writing out on note paper in his minute hand all that he owed, he added up the amount and found that his debts amounted to seventeen thousand and some odd hundreds, which he left out for the sake of clearness. Reckoning up his money and his bank book, he found that he had left one thousand eight hundred roubles, and nothing coming in before the New Year. Reckoning over again his list of debts, Vronsky copied it, dividing it into three classes. In the first class he put the debts which he would have to pay at once, or for which he must in any case have the money ready so that on demand for payment there could not be a moment’s delay in paying. Such debts amounted to about four thousand: one thousand five hundred for a horse, and two thousand five hundred as surety for a young comrade, Venovsky, who had lost that sum to a cardsharper in Vronsky’s presence. Vronsky had wanted to pay the money at the time (he had that amount then), but Venovsky and Yashvin had insisted that they would pay and not Vronsky, who had not played. That was so far well, but Vronsky knew that in this dirty business, though his only share in it was undertaking by word of mouth to be surety for Venovsky, it was absolutely necessary for him to have the two thousand five hundred roubles so as to be able to fling it at the swindler, and have no more words with him. And so for this first and most important division he must have four thousand roubles. The second class—eight thousand roubles—consisted of less important debts. These were principally accounts owing in connection with his race horses, to the purveyor of oats and hay, the English saddler, and so on. He would have to pay some two thousand roubles on these debts too, in order to be quite free from anxiety. The last class of debts—to shops, to hotels, to his tailor—were such as need not be considered. So that he needed at least six thousand roubles for current expenses, and he only had one thousand eight hundred. For a man with one hundred thousand roubles of revenue, which was what everyone fixed as Vronsky’s income, such debts, one would suppose, could hardly be embarrassing; but the fact was that he was far from having one hundred thousand. His father’s immense property, which alone yielded a yearly income of two hundred thousand, was left undivided between the brothers. At the time when the elder brother, with a mass of debts, married Princess Varya Tchirkova, the daughter of a Decembrist without any fortune whatever, Alexey had given up to his elder brother almost the whole income from his father’s estate, reserving for himself only twenty-five thousand a year from it. Alexey had said at the time to his brother that that sum would be sufficient for him until he married, which he probably never would do. And his brother, who was in command of one of the most expensive regiments, and was only just married, could not decline the gift. His mother, who had her own separate property, had allowed Alexey every year twenty thousand in addition to the twenty-five thousand he had reserved, and Alexey had spent it all. Of late his mother, incensed with him on account of his love affair and his leaving Moscow, had given up sending him the money. And in consequence of this, Vronsky, who had been in the habit of living on the scale of forty-five thousand a year, having only received twenty thousand that year, found himself now in difficulties. To get out of these difficulties, he could not apply to his mother for money. Her last letter, which he had received the day before, had particularly exasperated him by the hints in it that she was quite ready to help him to succeed in the world and in the army, but not to lead a life which was a scandal to all good society. His mother’s attempt to buy him stung him to the quick and made him feel colder than ever to her. But he could not draw back from the generous word when it was once uttered, even though he felt now, vaguely foreseeing certain eventualities in his intrigue with Madame Karenina, that this generous word had been spoken thoughtlessly, and that even though he were not married he might need all the hundred thousand of income. But it was impossible to draw back. He had only to recall his brother’s wife, to remember how that sweet, delightful Varya sought, at every convenient opportunity, to remind him that she remembered his generosity and appreciated it, to grasp the impossibility of taking back his gift. It was as impossible as beating a woman, stealing, or lying. One thing only could and ought to be done, and Vronsky determined upon it without an instant’s hesitation: to borrow money from a money-lender, ten thousand roubles, a proceeding which presented no difficulty, to cut down his expenses generally, and to sell his race horses. Resolving on this, he promptly wrote a note to Rolandak, who had more than once sent to him with offers to buy horses from him. Then he sent for the Englishman and the money-lender, and divided what money he had according to the accounts he intended to pay. Having finished this business, he wrote a cold and cutting answer to his mother. Then he took out of his notebook three notes of Anna’s, read them again, burned them, and remembering their conversation on the previous day, he sank into meditation.
渥伦斯基首先攻击的最容易的就是他的金钱状况。他用分针在便条纸上写下自己所欠的一切，加起来，发现自己的债务有一万七千多百，为了清楚起见，他把这些数字省略了。他清点了一下自己的钱和银行存折，发现自己还剩下一千八百卢布，而且在新年之前什么也没有进账。渥伦斯基重新算了一下自己的债务清单，将其抄了下来，并将其分为三类。在第一类中，他把必须立即偿还的债务，或者在任何情况下都必须准备好钱的债务，以便在要求付款时，不能有片刻的拖延。这些债务大约有四千：一千五百是一匹马的债务，两千五百是年轻同志维诺夫斯基的担保人，他在渥伦斯基面前把这笔钱输给了一个玩牌的人。渥伦斯基当时想支付这笔钱（当时他有这笔钱），但维诺夫斯基和亚什文坚持认为他们会付钱，而不是没有参加比赛的渥伦斯基。到目前为止还不错，但是渥伦斯基知道，在这个肮脏的生意中，虽然他唯一的参与是通过口口相传为维诺夫斯基做担保，但他绝对有必要拥有两千五百卢布，以便可以把它扔给骗子，然后不再和他说话。因此，对于这第一个也是最重要的部分，他必须有四千卢布。第二类——八千卢布——包括不太重要的债务。这些记录主要与他的赛马、燕麦和干草的供应商、英国马具商等有关。 他还必须偿还这些债务大约两千卢布，才能完全摆脱焦虑。最后一类债务——欠商店、旅馆、裁缝的债务——无需考虑。这样一来，他的日常开支至少需要六千卢布，而他只有一千八百卢布。对于一个拥有十万卢布收入的人来说，这就是每个人都认为渥伦斯基的收入，人们会认为，这样的债务几乎不会令人尴尬；但事实是，他距离十万还差得很远。他父亲的巨额财产，仅此一项，每年就带来二十万的收入，没有被兄弟俩瓜分。当负债累累的哥哥娶了一位身无分文的十二月党人的女儿瓦里娅·奇尔科娃公主时，阿列克谢把他父亲的遗产几乎全部收入都交给了哥哥，只为自己保留。每年两万五千美元。阿列克谢当时对他的兄弟说，这笔钱足够他结婚为止，但他可能永远不会这样做。而他的哥哥指挥着最昂贵的军团之一，而且刚刚结婚，无法拒绝这份礼物。他的母亲有自己的财产，除了他保留的两万五千美元之外，每年还给阿列克谢两万美元，而阿列克谢已经花光了。最近，他的母亲因他的恋情和他离开莫斯科而对他感到愤怒，放弃了给他寄钱。结果，习惯了每年四万五千的生活的渥伦斯基，那一年只收到了两万，现在发现自己陷入了困境。 为了摆脱这些困难，他无法向母亲要钱。她前一天收到的最后一封信让他特别恼火，信中暗示她已经准备好帮助他在世界上和军队中取得成功，但不会过一种对他来说是丑闻的生活。一切美好社会。他母亲想要收买他的企图刺痛了他的心，让他对她感到前所未有的冷漠。但是，一旦说出这句慷慨的话，他就无法收回，尽管他现在隐约预见到了他与卡列尼娜夫人的阴谋中的某些可能性，这句慷慨的话是轻率地说出来的，尽管他还没有结婚。他可能需要全部的十万收入。但已经不可能退缩了。他只需要回忆起他兄弟的妻子，记住那个甜蜜、令人愉快的瓦里娅如何在每一个方便的机会提醒他，她记得他的慷慨并感激他，明白收回他的礼物是不可能的。这就像打女人、偷窃或撒谎一样不可能。只有一件事可以而且应该做，渥伦斯基毫不犹豫地决定了：向放债人借钱一万卢布，这一行动并不困难，总体上减少开支，并出售他的赛马。考虑到这一点，他立即给罗兰达克写了一张便条，罗兰达克不止一次向他发出了从他那里购买马匹的提议。然后他派人去叫来英国人和放债人，并根据他打算支付的账户分配他所拥有的钱。完成这件事后，他给母亲写了一封冷酷尖刻的回信。 然后他从笔记本里拿出安娜的三张笔记，又看了一遍，烧掉了，想起前一天他们的对话，他陷入了沉思。

Chapter 20
第20章

Vronsky’s life was particularly happy in that he had a code of principles, which defined with unfailing certitude what he ought and what he ought not to do. This code of principles covered only a very small circle of contingencies, but then the principles were never doubtful, and Vronsky, as he never went outside that circle, had never had a moment’s hesitation about doing what he ought to do. These principles laid down as invariable rules: that one must pay a cardsharper, but need not pay a tailor; that one must never tell a lie to a man, but one may to a woman; that one must never cheat anyone, but one may a husband; that one must never pardon an insult, but one may give one and so on. These principles were possibly not reasonable and not good, but they were of unfailing certainty, and so long as he adhered to them, Vronsky felt that his heart was at peace and he could hold his head up. Only quite lately in regard to his relations with Anna, Vronsky had begun to feel that his code of principles did not fully cover all possible contingencies, and to foresee in the future difficulties and perplexities for which he could find no guiding clue.
渥伦斯基的生活特别幸福，因为他有一套原则准则，明确规定了他应该做什么和不应该做什么。这套原则只涵盖了很小的一个范围，但原则却是不容置疑的，而渥伦斯基从来没有走出过这个范围，所以他在做他应该做的事情时从未有过片刻的犹豫。这些原则被定为不变的规则：必须付钱给打牌人，但不需要付钱给裁缝；绝对不能对男人说谎，但可以对女人说谎；一个人绝不能欺骗任何人，但一个人可以欺骗一个丈夫；一个人决不能原谅一种侮辱，但一个人可以给予一种侮辱，等等。这些原则也许不太合理，也不太好，但是却是绝对确定的，只要坚持下去，渥伦斯基就觉得心里踏实，可以昂首挺胸。直到最近，关于他与安娜的关系，渥伦斯基才开始感到他的原则准则并没有完全涵盖所有可能发生的意外情况，并预见到他无法找到指导线索的未来困难和困惑。

His present relation to Anna and to her husband was to his mind clear and simple. It was clearly and precisely defined in the code of principles by which he was guided.
在他看来，他目前与安娜和她丈夫的关系是清晰而简单的。它在他所遵循的原则准则中得到了明确而准确的定义。

She was an honorable woman who had bestowed her love upon him, and he loved her, and therefore she was in his eyes a woman who had a right to the same, or even more, respect than a lawful wife. He would have had his hand chopped off before he would have allowed himself by a word, by a hint, to humiliate her, or even to fall short of the fullest respect a woman could look for.
她是一个值得尊敬的女人，为他付出了爱，而他也爱她，因此她在他眼中是一个有权利得到与合法妻子同等甚至更多尊重的女人。在他允许自己通过一句话、一个暗示来羞辱她，甚至达不到一个女人所能寻求的最充分的尊重之前，他会被砍掉自己的手。

His attitude to society, too, was clear. Everyone might know, might suspect it, but no one might dare to speak of it. If any did so, he was ready to force all who might speak to be silent and to respect the non-existent honor of the woman he loved.
他对社会的态度也很明确。每个人都可能知道，可能怀疑，但可能没有人敢说。如果有人这样做，他准备迫使所有可能说话的人保持沉默，并尊重他所爱的女人不存在的荣誉。

His attitude to the husband was the clearest of all. From the moment that Anna loved Vronsky, he had regarded his own right over her as the one thing unassailable. Her husband was simply a superfluous and tiresome person. No doubt he was in a pitiable position, but how could that be helped? The one thing the husband had a right to was to demand satisfaction with a weapon in his hand, and Vronsky was prepared for this at any minute.
他对丈夫的态度是最清楚的。从安娜爱上渥伦斯基的那一刻起，他就将自己对她的权利视为无可争议的一件事。她的丈夫简直就是一个多余又令人厌烦的人。毫无疑问，他的处境很可怜，但又有什么办法呢？丈夫有权要求的一件事就是要求对他手中的武器感到满意，而渥伦斯基随时都为此做好了准备。

But of late new inner relations had arisen between him and her, which frightened Vronsky by their indefiniteness. Only the day before she had told him that she was with child. And he felt that this fact and what she expected of him called for something not fully defined in that code of principles by which he had hitherto steered his course in life. And he had been indeed caught unawares, and at the first moment when she spoke to him of her position, his heart had prompted him to beg her to leave her husband. He had said that, but now thinking things over he saw clearly that it would be better to manage to avoid that; and at the same time, as he told himself so, he was afraid whether it was not wrong.
但最近他和她之间出现了新的内在关系，这让渥伦斯基对他们的不确定性感到害怕。就在前一天，她才告诉他她怀孕了。他觉得这一事实以及她对他的期望要求一些尚未在他迄今指导其人生道路的原则准则中完全定义的东西。而他确实是措手不及，当她向他说出自己的立场的第一刻，他的心就促使他求她离开她的丈夫。他是这么说的，但现在想来，他清楚地意识到，最好还是设法避免这种情况发生。与此同时，正如他这样告诉自己的那样，他又担心这是否是错误的。

‘If I told her to leave her husband, that must mean uniting her life with mine; am I prepared for that? How can I take her away now, when I have no money? Supposing I could arrange.... But how can I take her away while I’m in the service? If I say that—I ought to be prepared to do it, that is, I ought to have the money and to retire from the army.’
“如果我告诉她离开她的丈夫，那一定意味着她的生活与我的生活结合在一起；我准备好了吗？我现在没钱了，怎么能把她带走呢？假设我可以安排……但是我在服役期间怎么能把她带走呢？如果我这么说——我应该做好准备，也就是说，我应该有钱并从军队退役。

And he grew thoughtful. The question whether to retire from the service or not brought him to the other and perhaps the chief though hidden interest of his life, of which none knew but he.
他开始沉思起来。是否退役的问题让他想到了另一个问题，也许是他生活中最隐秘的兴趣，除了他自己，没有人知道。

Ambition was the old dream of his youth and childhood, a dream which he did not confess even to himself, though it was so strong that now this passion was even doing battle with his love. His first steps in the world and in the service had been successful, but two years before he had made a great mistake. Anxious to show his independence and to advance, he had refused a post that had been offered him, hoping that this refusal would heighten his value; but it turned out that he had been too bold, and he was passed over. And having, whether he liked or not, taken up for himself the position of an independent man, he carried it off with great tact and good sense, behaving as though he bore no grudge against anyone, did not regard himself as injured in any way, and cared for nothing but to be left alone since he was enjoying himself. In reality he had ceased to enjoy himself as long ago as the year before, when he went away to Moscow. He felt that this independent attitude of a man who might have done anything, but cared to do nothing, was already beginning to pall, that many people were beginning to fancy that he was not really capable of anything but being a straightforward, good-natured fellow. His connection with Madame Karenina, by creating so much sensation and attracting general attention, had given him a fresh distinction which soothed his gnawing worm of ambition for a while, but a week before that worm had been roused up again with fresh force. The friend of his childhood, a man of the same set, of the same coterie, his comrade in the Corps of Pages, Serpuhovskoy, who had left school with him and had been his rival in class, in gymnastics, in their scrapes and their dreams of glory, had come back a few days before from Central Asia, where he had gained two steps up in rank, and an order rarely bestowed upon generals so young.
野心是他年轻时和童年时的古老梦想，他甚至没有向自己承认这个梦想，尽管它如此强烈，以至于现在这种激情甚至与他的爱情发生了冲突。他在世界和服务中的第一步是成功的，但两年前他犯了一个巨大的错误。由于急于表现自己的独立性和进步，他拒绝了向他提供的职位，希望这种拒绝能够提高他的价值。但事实证明他太大胆了，他被放过了。无论他愿意与否，他都以一个独立的人的身份，以极大的机智和明智的态度实现了这一目标，表现得好像他对任何人都没有怨恨，也不认为自己受到任何伤害。 ，因为他玩得很开心，所以什么也不关心，只关心一个人呆着。事实上，早在一年前他去莫斯科时，他就已经不再享受生活了。他觉得，这种本来可以做任何事情却又什么都不关心的人的独立态度已经开始令人厌烦，很多人开始认为他除了做一个直率、善良的人之外，什么都做不了。伙计。他与卡列尼娜夫人的关系引起了如此大的轰动，引起了普遍的关注，给了他一种新的区别，这暂时安抚了他那颗不断啃咬的野心之虫，但一周前，那条虫子又被新的力量唤醒了。 他儿时的朋友，同一批人，同一个小圈子，他在侍从军团的战友谢尔普霍夫斯科伊，他和他一起离开了学校，在课堂上、在体操上、在擦伤和比赛中都是他的对手。几天前，他从中亚回来，在那里，他的军衔提升了两级，并获得了很少授予如此年轻的将军的勋章。

As soon as he arrived in Petersburg, people began to talk about him as a newly risen star of the first magnitude. A schoolfellow of Vronsky’s and of the same age, he was a general and was expecting a command, which might have influence on the course of political events; while Vronsky, independent and brilliant and beloved by a charming woman though he was, was simply a cavalry captain who was readily allowed to be as independent as ever he liked. ‘Of course I don’t envy Serpuhovskoy and never could envy him; but his advancement shows me that one has only to watch one’s opportunity, and the career of a man like me may be very rapidly made. Three years ago he was in just the same position as I am. If I retire, I burn my ships. If I remain in the army, I lose nothing. She said herself she did not wish to change her position. And with her love I cannot feel envious of Serpuhovskoy.’ And slowly twirling his mustaches, he got up from the table and walked about the room. His eyes shone particularly brightly, and he felt in that confident, calm, and happy frame of mind which always came after he had thoroughly faced his position. Everything was straight and clear, just as after former days of reckoning. He shaved, took a cold bath, dressed and went out.
他一到彼得堡，人们就开始谈论他，称他为一颗新星。他是渥伦斯基的同学，同龄，是一名将军，正在等待指挥，这可能会影响政治事件的进程；而渥伦斯基虽然独立、才华横溢，深受一位迷人女人的喜爱，但他只是一名骑兵上尉，很容易被允许随心所欲地独立。 “当然，我不羡慕谢尔普霍夫斯科伊，也永远不会羡慕他；但他的进步告诉我，只要留意机会，像我这样的人的事业可能会很快取得成功。三年前，他的处境和我一样。如果我退休了，我就会烧毁我的船。如果我留在军队，我不会有任何损失。她自己表示，她不想改变自己的立场。有了她的爱，我就不会嫉妒谢尔普霍夫斯科伊了。”他慢慢地捻着胡子，从桌子上站起来，在房间里走来走去。他的眼睛特别明亮，感受到彻底正视自己的处境之后，才会有的那种自信、平静、愉悦的心情。一切都清晰明了，就像经过前几天的清算一样。他刮了胡子，洗了个冷水澡，穿好衣服就出去了。

Chapter 21
第21章

‘We’ve come to fetch you. Your lessive lasted a good time today,’ said Petritsky. ‘Well, is it over?’
‘我们是来接你的。你的孩子今天玩得很开心，”佩特里茨基说。 “怎么样，结束了吗？”

‘It is over,’ answered Vronsky, smiling with his eyes only, and twirling the tips of his mustaches as circumspectly as though after the perfect order into which his affairs had been brought any over-bold or rapid movement might disturb it.
“一切都结束了，”渥伦斯基回答道，他只用眼睛微笑着，小心翼翼地转动着胡子尖，仿佛在他的事务已经完美有序地进行之后，任何过于大胆或快速的动作都可能会扰乱它。

‘You’re always just as if you’d come out of a bath after it,’ said Petritsky. ‘I’ve come from Gritsky’s’ (that was what they called the colonel); ‘they’re expecting you.’
“你总是就像刚洗完澡一样，”佩特里茨基说。 “我来自格里茨基”（他们就是这么称呼上校的）； “他们在等你。”

Vronsky, without answering, looked at his comrade, thinking of something else.
渥伦斯基没有回答，只是看着他的战友，心里想着别的事情。

‘Yes; is that music at his place?’ he said, listening to the familiar sounds of polkas and waltzes floating across to him. ‘What’s the fete?’
'是的; “那是他家的音乐吗？”他一边说，一边听着熟悉的波尔卡舞和华尔兹的声音飘向他。 “什么节日？”

‘Serpuhovskoy’s come.’
“谢尔普霍夫斯科伊来了。”

‘Aha!’ said Vronsky, ‘why, I didn’t know.’
“啊哈！”渥伦斯基说，“为什么，我不知道。”

The smile in his eyes gleamed more brightly than ever.
他眼中的笑容比以往更加灿烂。

Having once made up his mind that he was happy in his love, that he sacrificed his ambition to it—having anyway taken up this position, Vronsky was incapable of feeling either envious of Serpuhovskoy or hurt with him for not coming first to him when he came to the regiment. Serpuhovskoy was a good friend, and he was delighted he had come.
渥伦斯基曾经下定决心，他在爱情中是幸福的，他为此牺牲了自己的野心——无论如何，既然采取了这个立场，渥伦斯基既不会嫉妒谢尔普霍夫斯科伊，也不会因为他没有先来找他而感到受伤。来到了团里。谢尔普霍夫斯科伊是一位好朋友，他很高兴他能来。

‘Ah, I’m very glad!’
“啊，我很高兴！”

The colonel, Demin, had taken a large country house. The whole party were in the wide lower balcony. In the courtyard the first objects that met Vronsky’s eyes were a band of singers in white linen coats, standing near a barrel of vodka, and the robust, good-humored figure of the colonel surrounded by officers. He had gone out as far as the first step of the balcony and was loudly shouting across the band that played Offenbach’s quadrille, waving his arms and giving some orders to a few soldiers standing on one side. A group of soldiers, a quartermaster, and several subalterns came up to the balcony with Vronsky. The colonel returned to the table, went out again onto the steps with a tumbler in his hand, and proposed the toast, ‘To the health of our former comrade, the gallant general, Prince Serpuhovskoy. Hurrah!’
德明上校租下了一座大乡间别墅。整个聚会都在宽敞的下层阳台上进行。在院子里，渥伦斯基首先映入眼帘的是一群穿着白色亚麻大衣的歌手，站在一桶伏特加旁边，还有被军官包围的上校健壮、幽默的身影。他一直走到阳台的第一级台阶，对着演奏奥芬巴赫四舞曲的乐队大声喊叫，挥舞着手臂，向站在一边的几个士兵发号施令。一群士兵、一名军需官和几名副官与渥伦斯基一起来到阳台上。上校回到餐桌旁，再次走到台阶上，手里拿着一个玻璃杯，敬酒道：“为我们的前同志、英勇的将军谢尔普霍夫斯科伊亲王的健康干杯。”欢呼！'

The colonel was followed by Serpuhovskoy, who came out onto the steps smiling, with a glass in his hand.
谢尔普霍夫斯科伊跟在上校后面，他手里拿着一个玻璃杯，微笑着走上台阶。

‘You always get younger, Bondarenko,’ he said to the rosy-checked, smart-looking quartermaster standing just before him, still youngish looking though doing his second term of service.
“邦达连科，你总是会变得更年轻。”他对站在他面前的面色红润、看上去很聪明的军需官说道，尽管他已经在履行第二个任期，但他看上去仍然很年轻。

It was three years since Vronsky had seen Serpuhovskoy. He looked more robust, had let his whiskers grow, but was still the same graceful creature, whose face and figure were even more striking from their softness and nobility than their beauty. The only change Vronsky detected in him was that subdued, continual radiance of beaming content which settles on the faces of men who are successful and are sure of the recognition of their success by everyone. Vronsky knew that radiant air, and immediately observed it in Serpuhovskoy.
渥伦斯基与谢尔普霍夫斯科伊见面已经三年了。他看起来更加健壮，胡须也长了起来，但依然是那个优雅的生物，脸庞和身材的柔和和高贵比他们的美丽更引人注目。渥伦斯基在他身上发现的唯一变化是，那些成功的人脸上洋溢着柔和的、持续不断的喜气洋洋的光芒，这些人都确信自己的成功得到了所有人的认可。渥伦斯基知道那种辐射空气，并立即在谢尔普霍夫斯科伊观察到它。

As Serpuhovskoy came down the steps he saw Vronsky. A smile of pleasure lighted up his face. He tossed his head upwards and waved the glass in his hand, greeting Vronsky, and showing him by the gesture that he could not come to him before the quartermaster, who stood craning forward his lips ready to be kissed.
当谢尔普霍夫斯科伊走下台阶时，他看到了渥伦斯基。他的脸上洋溢着喜悦的笑容。他仰起头，挥舞着手中的酒杯，向渥伦斯基打招呼，并用这个手势告诉他，他不能在军需官面前走到他面前，而军需官站在那儿，嘴唇向前伸长，准备被亲吻。

‘Here he is!’ shouted the colonel. ‘Yashvin told me you were in one of your gloomy tempers.’
“他在这里！”上校喊道。 “亚什文告诉我你的脾气很阴郁。”

Serpuhovskoy kissed the moist, fresh lips of the gallant-looking quartermaster, and wiping his mouth with his handkerchief, went up to Vronsky.
谢尔普霍夫斯科伊吻了一下看上去英勇的军需官湿润、清新的嘴唇，用手帕擦了擦嘴，然后走到渥伦斯基身边。

‘How glad I am!’ he said, squeezing his hand and drawing him on one side.
“我多么高兴啊！”他说，握紧他的手，把他拉到一侧。

‘You look after him,’ the colonel shouted to Yashvin, pointing to Vronsky; and he went down below to the soldiers.
“你照顾他，”上校指着渥伦斯基对亚什温喊道。他下到下面的士兵那里。

‘Why weren’t you at the races yesterday? I expected to see you there,’ said Vronsky, scrutinizing Serpuhovskoy.
“你昨天为什么没有参加比赛？ “我本来希望在那里见到你。”渥伦斯基一边说，一边打量着谢尔普霍夫斯科伊。

‘I did go, but late. I beg your pardon,’ he added, and he turned to the adjutant: ‘Please have this divided from me, each man as much as it runs to.’ And he hurriedly took notes for three hundred roubles from his pocketbook, blushing a little.
“我确实去了，但是晚了。请您原谅，”他补充道，然后转向副官：“请把这个分给我，每个人能分到多少就分多少。”他急忙从皮夹里掏出三百卢布的钞票，脸有点红了。 。

‘Vronsky! Have anything to eat or drink?’ asked Yashvin. ‘Hi, something for the count to eat! Ah, here it is: have a glass!’
渥伦斯基！有什么吃的或喝的吗？”亚什文问道。 ‘嗨，给伯爵吃点东西吧！啊，在这里：喝一杯！

The fete at the colonel’s lasted a long while. There was a great deal of drinking. They tossed Serpuhovskoy in the air and caught him again several times. Then they did the same to the colonel. Then, to the accompaniment of the band, the colonel himself danced with Petritsky. Then the colonel, who began to show signs of feebleness, sat down on a bench in the courtyard and began demonstrating to Yashvin the superiority of Russia over Poland, especially in cavalry attack, and there was a lull in the revelry for a moment. Serpuhovskoy went into the house to the bathroom to wash his hands and found Vronsky there; Vronsky was drenching his head with water. He had taken off his coat and put his sunburnt, hairy neck under the tap, and was rubbing it and his head with his hands. When he had finished, Vronsky sat down by Serpuhovskoy. They both sat down in the bathroom on a lounge, and a conversation began which was very interesting to both of them.
上校家的宴会持续了很长时间。喝了很多酒。他们将谢尔普霍夫斯科伊抛向空中，并多次将他抓住。然后他们对上校做了同样的事。然后，在乐队的伴奏下，上校本人与佩特里茨基一起跳舞。然后，开始显出虚弱迹象的上校在院子里的长凳上坐下，开始向亚什温展示俄罗斯相对于波兰的优势，特别是在骑兵进攻方面，狂欢暂时平静下来。谢尔普霍夫斯科伊进屋去浴室洗手，发现渥伦斯基就在那里。渥伦斯基正在用水淋湿他的头。他脱下外套，把晒黑、毛茸茸的脖子放在水龙头下，用手揉搓脖子和头。讲完后，渥伦斯基在谢尔普霍夫斯科伊身边坐下。他们俩在休息室的浴室里坐下，开始了一段对两人来说都很有趣的谈话。

‘I’ve always been hearing about you through my wife,’ said Serpuhovskoy. ‘I’m glad you’ve been seeing her pretty often.’
“我一直通过我的妻子听说过你，”谢尔普霍夫斯科伊说。 “我很高兴你经常见到她。”

‘She’s friendly with Varya, and they’re the only women in Petersburg I care about seeing,’ answered Vronsky, smiling. He smiled because he foresaw the topic the conversation would turn on, and he was glad of it.
“她对瓦里娅很友好，她们是彼得堡唯一我愿意见到的女人，”渥伦斯基微笑着回答。他笑了，因为他预见到了谈话的话题，而且他很高兴。

‘The only ones?’ Serpuhovskoy queried, smiling.
“唯一的吗？”谢尔普霍夫斯科伊微笑着问道。

‘Yes; and I heard news of you, but not only through your wife,’ said Vronsky, checking his hint by a stern expression of face. ‘I was greatly delighted to hear of your success, but not a bit surprised. I expected even more.’
'是的; “我听说了你的消息，但不仅仅是通过你的妻子。”渥伦斯基说道，脸上表情严肃，以证实他的暗示。 “听到你的成功我非常高兴，但并不感到惊讶。我期望更多。

Serpuhovskoy smiled. Such an opinion of him was obviously agreeable to him, and he did not think it necessary to conceal it.
谢尔普霍夫斯科伊笑了。对于他的这样的看法，他显然是认同的，他认为没有必要隐瞒。

‘Well, I on the contrary expected less—I’ll own frankly. But I’m glad, very glad. I’m ambitious; that’s my weakness, and I confess to it.’
“嗯，相反，我的期望更低——坦白说，我承认。但我很高兴，非常高兴。我雄心勃勃；这是我的弱点，我承认这一点。

‘Perhaps you wouldn’t confess to it if you hadn’t been successful,’ said Vronsky.
“如果你没有成功，也许你不会承认这一点，”渥伦斯基说。

‘I don’t suppose so,’ said Serpuhovskoy, smiling again. ‘I won’t say life wouldn’t be worth living without it, but it would be dull. Of course I may be mistaken, but I fancy I have a certain capacity for the line I’ve chosen, and that power of any sort in my hands, if it is to be, will be better than in the hands of a good many people I know,’ said Serpuhovskoy, with beaming consciousness of success; ‘and so the nearer I get to it, the better pleased I am.’
“我不这么认为，”谢尔普霍夫斯科伊再次微笑着说道。 “我不会说没有它生活就不值得过，但它会很乏味。当然，我可能是错的，但我想我对我所选择的路线有一定的能力，而且我手中的任何形式的力量，如果是的话，都会比很多人手中的更好。 “我认识的人，”谢尔普霍夫斯科伊说道，脸上洋溢着成功的喜悦。 “所以我越接近它，我就越高兴。”

‘Perhaps that is true for you, but not for everyone. I used to think so too, but here I live and think life worth living not only for that.’
“也许这对你来说是真的，但不是对所有人来说。我曾经也这么认为，但我生活在这里，并认为生活的价值不仅仅在于这一点。

‘There it’s out! here it comes!’ said Serpuhovskoy, laughing. ‘Ever since I heard about you, about your refusal, I began.... Of course, I approved of what you did. But there are ways of doing everything. And I think your action was good in itself, but you didn’t do it quite in the way you ought to have done.’
‘就这样出来了！来了！”谢尔普霍夫斯科伊笑着说。 ‘自从我听说你的事，听说你的拒绝，我就开始……当然，我赞成你所做的事情。但凡事都有办法。我认为你的行为本身是好的，但你没有完全按照你应该做的方式去做。

‘What’s done can’t be undone, and you know I never go back on what I’ve done. And besides, I’m very well off.’
“已经发生的事情无法挽回，你知道我永远不会后悔我所做的事情。而且，我的生活非常富裕。

‘Very well off—for the time. But you’re not satisfied with that. I wouldn’t say this to your brother. He’s a nice child, like our host here. There he goes!’ he added, listening to the roar of ‘hurrah!’—‘and he’s happy, but that does not satisfy you.’
“目前非常富裕。”但你对此并不满意。我不会对你兄弟说这些。他是一个好孩子，就像我们这里的主人一样。他走了！”他一边补充道，一边听着“万岁！”的欢呼声——“他很高兴，但这并不能让你满意。”

‘I didn’t say it did satisfy me.’
“我并没有说它确实让我满意。”

‘Yes, but that’s not the only thing. Such men as you are wanted.’
‘是的，但这不是唯一的事情。像你这样的人是需要的。

‘By whom?’
'通过谁？'

‘By whom? By society, by Russia. Russia needs men; she needs a party, or else everything goes and will go to the dogs.’
'通过谁？社会，俄罗斯。俄罗斯需要男人；她需要一个聚会，否则一切都会失败。

‘How do you mean? Bertenev’s party against the Russian communists?’
'你是什么意思？贝尔捷涅夫的政党反对俄罗斯共产党？

‘No,’ said Serpuhovskoy, frowning with vexation at being suspected of such an absurdity. ‘Tout ca est une blague. That’s always been and always will be. There are no communists. But intriguing people have to invent a noxious, dangerous party. It’s an old trick. No, what’s wanted is a powerful party of independent men like you and me.’
“不，”谢尔普霍夫斯科伊说，他因被怀疑如此荒谬而苦恼地皱起眉头。 “这就是一场瘟疫。”过去如此，将来也永远如此。没有共产党人。但有趣的人必须发明一个有毒、危险的政党。这是一个老把戏。不，我们需要的是一个由像你我这样的独立人士组成的强大政党。

‘But why so?’ Vronsky mentioned a few men who were in power. ‘Why aren’t they independent men?’
“但是为什么会这样呢？”渥伦斯基提到了一些当权者。 “为什么他们不是独立的人？”

‘Simply because they have not, or have not had from birth, an independent fortune; they’ve not had a name, they’ve not been close to the sun and center as we have. They can be bought either by money or by favor. And they have to find a support for themselves in inventing a policy. And they bring forward some notion, some policy that they don’t believe in, that does harm; and the whole policy is really only a means to a government house and so much income. Cela n’est pas plus fin que ca, when you get a peep at their cards. I may be inferior to them, stupider perhaps, though I don’t see why I should be inferior to them. But you and I have one important advantage over them for certain, in being more difficult to buy. And such men are more needed than ever.’
“仅仅因为他们没有，或者从出生起就没有独立的财富；它们没有名字，它们不像我们那样靠近太阳和中心。它们可以通过金钱或恩惠来购买。他们必须在制定政策时为自己找到支持。他们提出了一些他们不相信的观念和政策，这确实有害；整个政策实际上只是获得政府机构和大量收入的一种手段。 Cela n'est pas plus fin que ca，当你看到他们的牌时。我可能不如他们，也许更愚蠢，尽管我不明白为什么我应该不如他们。但你我肯定比它们有一个重要的优势，那就是更难购买。现在比以往任何时候都更需要这样的人。”

Vronsky listened attentively, but he was not so much interested by the meaning of the words as by the attitude of Serpuhovskoy who was already contemplating a struggle with the existing powers, and already had his likes and dislikes in that higher world, while his own interest in the governing world did not go beyond the interests of his regiment. Vronsky felt, too, how powerful Serpuhovskoy might become through his unmistakable faculty for thinking things out and for taking things in, through his intelligence and gift of words, so rarely met with in the world in which he moved. And, ashamed as he was of the feeling, he felt envious.
渥伦斯基聚精会神地听着，但他对这些话的含义不太感兴趣，而对谢尔普霍夫斯科伊的态度更感兴趣，谢尔普霍夫斯科伊已经在考虑与现有的权力进行斗争，并且已经在那个更高的世界里有了自己的好恶，而他自己的兴趣在统治世界中并没有超出他的军团的利益。渥伦斯基也感觉到，谢尔普霍夫斯科伊凭借他那无可挑剔的思考和吸收能力，通过他的智慧和语言天赋，可能会变得多么强大，这在他所生活的世界中是很少见的。尽管他对这种感觉感到羞愧，但他还是感到嫉妒。

‘Still I haven’t the one thing of most importance for that,’ he answered; ‘I haven’t the desire for power. I had it once, but it’s gone.’
“我还没有找到最重要的一件事，”他回答道。 ‘我没有对权力的渴望。我曾经拥有过它，但它消失了。

‘Excuse me, that’s not true,’ said Serpuhovskoy, smiling.
“对不起，这不是真的，”谢尔普霍夫斯科伊微笑着说道。

‘Yes, it is true, it is true...now!’ Vronsky added, to be truthful.
“是的，这是真的，这是真的……现在！”说实话，渥伦斯基补充道。

‘Yes, it’s true now, that’s another thing; but that now won’t last forever.’
“是的，现在确实如此，那是另一回事了；”但现在这种情况不会永远持续下去。

‘Perhaps,’ answered Vronsky.
“也许吧，”渥伦斯基回答。

‘You say perhaps,’ Serpuhovskoy went on, as though guessing his thoughts, ‘but I say for certain. And that’s what I wanted to see you for. Your action was just what it should have been. I see that, but you ought not to keep it up. I only ask you to give me carte blanche. I’m not going to offer you my protection...though, indeed, why shouldn’t I protect you?— you’ve protected me often enough! I should hope our friendship rises above all that sort of thing. Yes,’ he said, smiling to him as tenderly as a woman, ‘give me carte blanche, retire from the regiment, and I’ll draw you upwards imperceptibly.’
“你说也许，”谢尔普霍夫斯科伊继续说道，仿佛猜到了他的想法，“但我说肯定。”这就是我想见你的原因。你的行为本来就是应该的。我明白了，但你不应该继续这样。我只要求你全权委托我。我不会为你提供保护……不过，事实上，我为什么不应该保护你呢？——你已经足够频繁地保护我了！我希望我们的友谊超越所有此类事情。是的，”他像女人一样温柔地对他微笑，“给我全权委托，从军团退役，我会在不知不觉中把你拉上来。”

‘But you must understand that I want nothing,’ said Vronsky, ‘except that all should be as it is.’
“但你必须明白，我什么都不想要，”渥伦斯基说，“除了一切都应该保持原样。”

Serpuhovskoy got up and stood facing him.
谢尔普霍夫斯科伊站起来，面向他站着。

‘You say that all should be as it is. I understand what that means. But listen: we’re the same age, you’ve known a greater number of women perhaps than I have.’ Serpohovskoy’s smile and gestures told Vronsky that he mustn’t be afraid, that he would be tender and careful in touching the sore place. ‘But I’m married, and believe me, in getting to know thoroughly one’s wife, if one loves her, as someone has said, one gets to know all women better than if one knew thousands of them.’
‘你说一切都应该如此。我明白这意味着什么。但是听着：我们同龄，你认识的女人可能比我还多。”谢尔波霍夫斯科伊的微笑和手势告诉渥伦斯基，他不必害怕，他会温柔而小心地触摸疼痛处。地方。 “但我已经结婚了，相信我，在彻底了解自己的妻子时，如果一个人爱她，正如有人所说，一个人可以比认识成千上万的女人更好地了解所有的女人。”

‘We’re coming directly!’ Vronsky shouted to an officer, who looked into the room and called them to the colonel.
“我们直接来！”渥伦斯基对一名军官喊道，军官向房间里看了一眼，把他们叫到了上校。

Vronsky was longing now to hear to the end and know what Serpuhovskey would say to him.
渥伦斯基现在渴望听完最后，知道谢尔普霍夫斯基会对他说些什么。

‘And here’s my opinion for you. Women are the chief stumbling block in a man’s career. It’s hard to love a woman and do anything. There’s only one way of having love conveniently without its being a hindrance—that’s marriage. How, how am I to tell you what I mean?’ said Serpuhovskoy, who liked similes. ‘Wait a minute, wait a minute! Yes, just as you can only carry a fardeau and do something with your hands, when the fardeau is tied on your back, and that’s marriage. And that’s what I felt when I was married. My hands were suddenly set free. But to drag that fardeau about with you without marriage, your hands will always be so full that you can do nothing. Look at Mazankov, at Krupov. They’ve ruined their careers for the sake of women.’
“这是我对你的看法。女人是男人事业的最大绊脚石。爱一个女人并做任何事都很难。只有一种方式可以方便地拥有爱情而不成为阻碍，那就是婚姻。 “怎么样，我该如何告诉你我的意思呢？”喜欢明喻的谢尔普霍夫斯科伊说道。 ‘等一下，等一下！是的，就像你只能背着法杜，用手做事一样，当法杜绑在你的背上时，那就是婚姻。这就是我结婚时的感受。我的双手突然被解放了。但如果不结婚就拖着那个法多，你的双手总是忙得不可开交。看看马赞科夫，看看克鲁波夫。为了女性，他们毁了自己的事业。”

‘What women!’ said Vronsky, recalling the Frenchwoman and the actress with whom the two men he had mentioned were connected.
“什么女人啊！”渥伦斯基回忆起与他提到的两个男人有联系的法国女人和女演员时说道。

‘The firmer the woman’s footing in society, the worse it is. That’s much the same as—not merely carrying the fardeau in your arms—but tearing it away from someone else.’
“女人在社会中的立足点越稳固，情况就越糟糕。这与不仅仅是将法多抱在怀里，而且把它从别人手中夺走是一样的。

‘You have never loved,’ Vronsky said softly, looking straight before him and thinking of Anna.
“你从来没有爱过，”渥伦斯基轻声说道，他直视前方，想着安娜。

‘Perhaps. But you remember what I’ve said to you. And another thing, women are all more materialistic than men. We make something immense out of love, but they are always terre-a-terre.’
'也许。但你记得我对你说过的话。另一件事是，女性比男性更物质。我们出于爱创造了巨大的东西，但它们始终是陆地。”

‘Directly, directly!’ he cried to a footman who came in. But the footman had not come to call them again, as he supposed. The footman brought Vronsky a note.
“直接，直接！”他对进来的一个男仆喊道。但正如他所想，男仆并没有再来叫他们。男仆给渥伦斯基带来了一张纸条。

‘A man brought it from Princess Tverskaya.’
“一个男人从特维尔斯卡娅公主那里带来了它。”

Vronsky opened the letter, and flushed crimson.
渥伦斯基打开信，脸涨得通红。

‘My head’s begun to ache; I’m going home,’ he said to Serpuhovskoy.
“我的头开始疼；我要回家了，”他对谢尔普霍夫斯科伊说。

‘Oh, good-bye then. You give me carte blanche!’
‘哦，那么再见了。你给我全权委托！

‘We’ll talk about it later on; I’ll look you up in Petersburg.’
“我们稍后再讨论；我会去彼得堡找你。”

Chapter 22
第22章

It was six o’clock already, and so, in order to be there quickly, and at the same time not to drive with his own horses, known to everyone, Vronsky got into Yashvin’s hired fly, and told the driver to drive as quickly as possible. It was a roomy, old-fashioned fly, with seats for four. He sat in one corner, stretched his legs out on the front seat, and sank into meditation.
已经六点钟了，所以，为了尽快赶到，同时又不想用众所周知的自己的马开车，渥伦斯基上了亚什温雇来的飞机，并告诉司机尽快开车。尽可能。这是一架宽敞的老式飞机，可容纳四个人。他坐在角落里，把腿伸到前座上，陷入沉思。

A vague sense of the order into which his affairs had been brought, a vague recollection of the friendliness and flattery of Serpuhovskoy, who had considered him a man that was needed, and most of all, the anticipation of the interview before him—all blended into a general, joyous sense of life. This feeling was so strong that he could not help smiling. He dropped his legs, crossed one leg over the other knee, and taking it in his hand, felt the springy muscle of the calf, where it had been grazed the day before by his fall, and leaning back he drew several deep breaths.
对他的事务已进入有序状态的模糊感觉，对谢尔普霍夫斯科伊的友好和奉承的模糊回忆，谢尔普霍夫斯科伊认为他是一个需要的人，最重要的是，对他面前的采访的期待——所有这些都混合在一起进入一种普遍的、快乐的生活感觉。这种感觉太强烈了，让他忍不住笑了。他放下双腿，将一条腿交叉在另一只膝盖上，将它握在手中，感受小腿上富有弹性的肌肉，前一天跌倒时擦伤的地方，向后靠去，他深吸了几口气。

‘I’m happy, very happy!’ he said to himself. He had often before had this sense of physical joy in his own body, but he had never felt so fond of himself, of his own body, as at that moment. He enjoyed the slight ache in his strong leg, he enjoyed the muscular sensation of movement in his chest as he breathed. The bright, cold August day, which had made Anna feel so hopeless, seemed to him keenly stimulating, and refreshed his face and neck that still tingled from the cold water. The scent of brilliantine on his whiskers struck him as particularly pleasant in the fresh air. Everything he saw from the carriage window, everything in that cold pure air, in the pale light of the sunset, was as fresh, and gay, and strong as he was himself: the roofs of the houses shining in the rays of the setting sun, the sharp outlines of fences and angles of buildings, the figures of passers-by, the carriages that met him now and then, the motionless green of the trees and grass, the fields with evenly drawn furrows of potatoes, and the slanting shadows that fell from the houses, and trees, and bushes, and even from the rows of potatoes—everything was bright like a pretty landscape just finished and freshly varnished.
“我很高兴，非常高兴！”他对自己说。他以前经常在自己的身体上感受到这种肉体上的愉悦感，但他从来没有像此刻这样喜欢自己，喜欢自己的身体。他享受他强壮的腿上的轻微疼痛，他享受呼吸时胸部肌肉运动的感觉。八月的明媚寒冷的一天，曾让安娜感到如此绝望，但对他来说，却显得格外刺激，让他仍然被冷水刺痛的脸和脖子感到清爽。他胡须上散发着的光亮剂的香味在新鲜空气中显得格外宜人。他从车窗里看到的一切，在那寒冷纯净的空气中，在夕阳的苍白光芒下，一切都像他本人一样新鲜、快乐、坚强：房屋的屋顶在夕阳的光芒中闪闪发光栅栏和建筑物的棱角的轮廓，路人的身影，时不时遇到的马车，一动不动的绿色树木和草地，均匀地划出犁沟的田野，还有斜斜的影子。从房屋、树木、灌木丛，甚至从成排的土豆上掉下来——一切都很明亮，就像一幅刚刚完工、刚刷过漆的美丽风景。

‘Get on, get on!’ he said to the driver, putting his head out of the window, and pulling a three-rouble note out of his pocket he handed it to the man as he looked round. The driver’s hand fumbled with something at the lamp, the whip cracked, and the carriage rolled rapidly along the smooth highroad.
“上车，上车！”他把头伸出车窗外，对司机说道，从口袋里掏出一张三卢布的钞票，递给司机，同时环顾四周。车夫的手在车灯上摸索着什么，马鞭嘎吱作响，马车沿着平坦的大路飞速滚动。

‘I want nothing, nothing but this happiness,’ he thought, staring at the bone button of the bell in the space between the windows, and picturing to himself Anna just as he had seen her last time. ‘And as I go on, I love her more and more. Here’s the garden of the Vrede Villa. Whereabouts will she be? Where? How? Why did she fix on this place to meet me, and why does she write in Betsy’s letter?’ he thought, wondering now for the first time at it. But there was now no time for wonder. He called to the driver to stop before reaching the avenue, and opening the door, jumped out of the carriage as it was moving, and went into the avenue that led up to the house. There was no one in the avenue; but looking round to the right he caught sight of her. Her face was hidden by a veil, but he drank in with glad eyes the special movement in walking, peculiar to her alone, the slope of the shoulders, and the setting of the head, and at once a sort of electric shock ran all over him. With fresh force, he felt conscious of himself from the springy motions of his legs to the movements of his lungs as he breathed, and something set his lips twitching.
“我什么都不想要，除了这种幸福，什么都不想要。”他一边想，一边盯着窗户之间的铃铛的骨头纽扣，脑海里浮现出安娜上次见到她时的样子。 “随着我的生活，我越来越爱她。这里是Vrede别墅的花园。她会在哪里？在哪里？如何？为什么她会选择这个地方来见我，为什么她要写在贝特西的信里？”他想，现在第一次想知道。但现在没有时间惊叹了。还没到大道，他就招呼车夫停车，打开车门，在行驶中的马车上跳下车，走进了通往屋子的大道。大街上空无一人。但他向右一看，看到了她。她的脸被面纱遮住了，但他用高兴的目光欣赏着她独有的走路时的特殊动作、肩膀的倾斜度和头部的位置，顿时一种触电般的感觉袭遍全身。他。带着新鲜的力量，他从双腿的弹性动作到呼吸时肺部的运动，感觉到了自己的意识，有什么东西让他的嘴唇抽搐。

Joining him, she pressed his hand tightly.
她走到他身边，紧紧握住他的手。

‘You’re not angry that I sent for you? I absolutely had to see you,’ she said; and the serious and set line of her lips, which he saw under the veil, transformed his mood at once.
“我派人来找你，你不生气吗？ “我一定要见你，”她说。他在面纱下看到她严肃而坚定的嘴唇线条，立刻改变了他的心情。

‘I angry! But how have you come, where from?’
'我生气！但你是怎么来的，从哪里来？

‘Never mind,’ she said, laying her hand on his, ‘come along, I must talk to you.’
“没关系，”她把手放在他的手上，“来吧，我必须和你谈谈。”

He saw that something had happened, and that the interview would not be a joyous one. In her presence he had no will of his own: without knowing the grounds of her distress, he already felt the same distress unconsciously passing over him.
他看出发生了一些事情，这次采访不会是一件愉快的事。在她面前，他没有自己的意志：在不知道她痛苦的原因的情况下，他已经不自觉地感觉到同样的痛苦从他身上流过。

‘What is it? what?’ he asked her, squeezing her hand with his elbow, and trying to read her thoughts in her face.
'它是什么？什么？”他问她，用肘部捏住她的手，试图从她的脸上读出她的想法。

She walked on a few steps in silence, gathering up her courage; then suddenly she stopped.
她默默地走了几步，鼓起勇气；然后她突然停了下来。

‘I did not tell you yesterday,’ she began, breathing quickly and painfully, ‘that coming home with Alexey Alexandrovitch I told him everything...told him I could not be his wife, that...and told him everything.’
“我昨天没有告诉你，”她开始呼吸急促而痛苦，“我和阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇一起回家时告诉了他一切……告诉他我不能成为他的妻子，那……并告诉了他一切。”

He heard her, unconsciously bending his whole figure down to her as though hoping in this way to soften the hardness of her position for her. But directly she had said this he suddenly drew himself up, and a proud and hard expression came over his face.
他听到了她的声音，下意识地将整个身子向她俯下，仿佛希望以此来软化她的僵硬姿势。但她话音刚落，他就猛地站了起来，脸上浮现出骄傲而强硬的表情。

‘Yes, yes, that’s better, a thousand times better! I know how painful it was,’ he said. But she was not listening to his words, she was reading his thoughts from the expression of his face. She could not guess that that expression arose from the first idea that presented itself to Vronsky—that a duel was now inevitable. The idea of a duel had never crossed her mind, and so she put a different interpretation on this passing expression of hardness.
‘是的，是的，那更好了，好一千倍！我知道那有多痛苦，”他说。但她并不是在听他说话，而是从他的表情中读出他的想法。她猜不到渥伦斯基脑海中出现的第一个想法就是这种表情——一场决斗现在不可避免。她从来没有想过决斗的念头，所以她对这短暂的强硬表情有了不同的解释。

When she got her husband’s letter, she knew then at the bottom of her heart that everything would go on in the old way, that she would not have the strength of will to forego her position, to abandon her son, and to join her lover. The morning spent at Princess Tverskaya’s had confirmed her still more in this. But this interview was still of the utmost gravity for her. She hoped that this interview would transform her position, and save her. If on hearing this news he were to say to her resolutely, passionately, without an instant’s wavering: ‘Throw up everything and come with me!’ she would give up her son and go away with him. But this news had not produced what she had expected in him; he simply seemed as though he were resenting some affront.
当她收到丈夫的信时，她心底里就知道，一切都会照旧，她不会有坚强的意志去放弃自己的地位，抛弃儿子，去和爱人在一起。 。在特维尔斯卡娅公主家度过的那个早上让她更加确信了这一点。但这次采访对她来说仍然是最重要的。她希望这次采访能够改变她的处境，拯救她。如果他听到这个消息，坚决地、热情地、没有一丝动摇地对她说：“抛开一切，跟我走吧！”她就会放弃儿子，和他一起走。但这个消息并没有让他达到她所期望的那样。他看上去只是对某种侮辱感到不满。

‘It was not in the least painful to me. It happened of itself,’ she said irritably; ‘and see...’ she pulled her husband’s letter out of her glove.
“这对我来说一点也不痛苦。它自然而然地发生了，”她烦躁地说。 “你看……”她从手套里拿出丈夫的信。

‘I understand, I understand,’ he interrupted her, taking the letter, but not reading it, and trying to soothe her. ‘The one thing I longed for, the one thing I prayed for, was to cut short this position, so as to devote my life to your happiness.’
“我明白，我明白，”他打断了她的话，接过信，但没有读它，试图安抚她。 “我所渴望的一件事，我所祈祷的一件事，就是结束这个职位，以便为你的幸福奉献我的一生。”

‘Why do you tell me that?’ she said. ‘Do you suppose I can doubt it? If I doubted...’
“你为什么告诉我这个？”她说。 ‘你认为我可以怀疑吗？如果我怀疑的话……”

‘Who’s that coming?’ said Vronsky suddenly, pointing to two ladies walking towards them. ‘Perhaps they know us!’ and he hurriedly turned off, drawing her after him into a side path.
“谁来了？”渥伦斯基突然指着朝他们走来的两位女士问道。 “也许他们认识我们！”他赶紧转身，把她拉到一条小路上。

‘Oh, I don’t care!’ she said. Her lips were quivering. And he fancied that her eyes looked with strange fury at him from under the veil. ‘I tell you that’s not the point—I can’t doubt that; but see what he writes to me. Read it.’ She stood still again.
“哦，我不在乎！”她说。她的嘴唇在颤抖。他觉得她的眼睛从面纱下面带着奇怪的愤怒看着他。 “我告诉你这不是重点——我不能怀疑这一点；但看看他写给我的内容。读一下。”她又站了起来。

Again, just as at the first moment of hearing of her rupture with her husband, Vronsky, on reading the letter, was unconsciously carried away by the natural sensation aroused in him by his own relation to the betrayed husband. Now while he held his letter in his hands, he could not help picturing the challenge, which he would most likely find at home today or tomorrow, and the duel itself, in which, with the same cold and haughty expression that his face was assuming at this moment he would await the injured husband’s shot, after having himself fired into the air. And at that instant there flashed across his mind the thought of what Serpuhovskoy had just said to him, and what he had himself been thinking in the morning—that it was better not to bind himself —and he knew that this thought he could not tell her.
再次，就像第一次听到她与丈夫决裂的那一刻一样，渥伦斯基在读完这封信后，不自觉地被自己与被背叛的丈夫的关系所引起的自然感觉所吸引。现在，当他手里拿着信时，他情不自禁地想象着今天或明天他很可能会在家里遇到的挑战，以及决斗本身，在决斗中，他的脸上呈现出同样冷漠和傲慢的表情。此时此刻，他在向空中开枪后，正在等待受伤的丈夫开枪。就在那一刻，他的脑海中闪过谢尔普霍夫斯科伊刚才对他说的话，以及他自己早上一直在想的事情——最好不要束缚自己——他知道这个想法他无法说出来。她。

Having read the letter, he raised his eyes to her, and there was no determination in them. She saw at once that he had been thinking about it before by himself. She knew that whatever he might say to her, he would not say all he thought. And she knew that her last hope had failed her. This was not what she had been reckoning on.
读完信后，他抬眼看向她，眼神中没有坚定。她立刻看出他之前一直在自己思考这个问题。她知道，无论他对她说什么，他都不会说出他所想的一切。她知道她最后的希望落空了。这不是她所指望的。

‘You see the sort of man he is,’ she said, with a shaking voice; ‘he...’
“你看他是个什么样的人，”她声音颤抖地说。 '他...'

‘Forgive me, but I rejoice at it,’ Vronsky interrupted. ‘For God’s sake, let me finish!’ he added, his eyes imploring her to give him time to explain his words. ‘I rejoice, because things cannot, cannot possibly remain as he supposes.’
“请原谅，但我对此感到高兴，”渥伦斯基打断道。 “看在上帝的份上，让我说完！”他补充道，眼神恳求她给他时间解释他的话。 “我很高兴，因为事情不能、不可能像他想象的那样。”

‘Why can’t they?’ Anna said, restraining her tears, and obviously attaching no sort of consequence to what he said. She felt that her fate was sealed.
“为什么他们不能呢？”安娜强忍着泪水说道，显然并没有对他的话承担任何后果。她觉得自己的命运已经注定了。

Vronsky meant that after the duel—inevitable, he thought— things could not go on as before, but he said something different.
渥伦斯基的意思是，在决斗之后——他认为这是不可避免的——事情不能再像以前那样继续下去，但他说了不同的话。

‘It can’t go on. I hope that now you will leave him. I hope’— he was confused, and reddened—‘that you will let me arrange and plan our life. Tomorrow...’ he was beginning.
‘这不能再继续下去了。我希望你现在就离开他。我希望”——他感到困惑，脸红了——“你能让我安排和计划我们的生活。明天……”他开始说道。

She did not let him go on.
她没有让他继续说下去。

‘But my child!’ she shrieked. ‘You see what he writes! I should have to leave him, and I can’t and won’t do that.’
“但是我的孩子！”她尖叫道。 ‘你看他写的是什么！我应该离开他，但我不能也不会这么做。

‘But, for God’s sake, which is better?—leave your child, or keep up this degrading position?’
“但是，看在上帝的份上，哪个更好？——离开你的孩子，还是继续这种有辱人格的处境？”

‘To whom is it degrading?’
“这对谁来说是一种侮辱？”

‘To all, and most of all to you.’
“对所有人，尤其是对你。”

‘You say degrading...don’t say that. Those words have no meaning for me,’ she said in a shaking voice. She did not want him now to say what was untrue. She had nothing left her but his love, and she wanted to love him. ‘Don’t you understand that from the day I loved you everything has changed for me? For me there is one thing, and one thing only—your love. If that’s mine, I feel so exalted, so strong, that nothing can be humiliating to me. I am proud of my position, because...proud of being... proud....’ She could not say what she was proud of. Tears of shame and despair choked her utterance. She stood still and sobbed.
‘你说有辱人格……别这么说。这些话对我来说毫无意义，”她声音颤抖地说。她现在不想让他说出不真实的话。除了他的爱，她一无所有，她想爱他。 ‘你难道不明白，从我爱你的那天起，我的一切都改变了吗？对我来说只有一件事，而且只有一件事——你的爱。如果那是我的，我会感到如此崇高、如此坚强，没有什么可以羞辱我。我为自己的地位感到自豪，因为……为……自豪……”她说不出她为什么感到自豪。羞耻和绝望的泪水哽住了她的话语。她站着不动，抽泣着。

He felt, too, something swelling in his throat and twitching in his nose, and for the first time in his life he felt on the point of weeping. He could not have said exactly what it was touched him so. He felt sorry for her, and he felt he could not help her, and with that he knew that he was to blame for her wretchedness, and that he had done something wrong.
他还感到喉咙里有什么东西在肿胀，鼻子里在抽搐，这是他有生以来第一次感到快要哭了。他无法确切地说出是什么让他如此感动。他为她感到难过，他觉得自己帮不了她，因此他知道她的不幸是他造成的，他做错了事。

‘Is not a divorce possible?’ he said feebly. She shook her head, not answering. ‘Couldn’t you take your son, and still leave him?’
“离婚不可能吗？”他有气无力地说。她摇摇头，没有回答。 “你就不能带走你的儿子，然后离开他吗？”

‘Yes; but it all depends on him. Now I must go to him,’ she said shortly. Her presentiment that all would again go on in the old way had not deceived her.
'是的;但这一切都取决于他。现在我必须去找他了，”她简短地说。她预感到一切都会再次以旧方式继续下去，但她并没有欺骗她。

‘On Tuesday I shall be in Petersburg, and everything can be settled.’
“周二我将到达彼得堡，一切都可以解决。”

‘Yes,’ she said. ‘But don’t let us talk any more of it.’
“是的，”她说。 “但是别让我们再谈论这件事了。”

Anna’s carriage, which she had sent away, and ordered to come back to the little gate of the Vrede garden, drove up. Anna said good-bye to Vronsky, and drove home.
安娜送走并吩咐返回弗里德花园小门的马车又开过来了。安娜告别渥伦斯基，开车回家。

Chapter 23
第23章

On Monday there was the usual sitting of the Commission of the 2nd of June. Alexey Alexandrovitch walked into the hall where the sitting was held, greeted the members and the president, as usual, and sat down in his place, putting his hand on the papers laid ready before him. Among these papers lay the necessary evidence and a rough outline of the speech he intended to make. But he did not really need these documents. He remembered every point, and did not think it necessary to go over in his memory what he would say. He knew that when the time came, and when he saw his enemy facing him, and studiously endeavoring to assume an expression of indifference, his speech would flow of itself better than he could prepare it now. He felt that the import of his speech was of such magnitude that every word of it would have weight. Meantime, as he listened to the usual report, he had the most innocent and inoffensive air. No one, looking at his white hands, with their swollen veins and long fingers, so softly stroking the edges of the white paper that lay before him, and at the air of weariness with which his head drooped on one side, would have suspected that in a few minutes a torrent of words would flow from his lips that would arouse a fearful storm, set the members shouting and attacking one another, and force the president to call for order. When the report was over, Alexey Alexandrovitch announced in his subdued, delicate voice that he had several points to bring before the meeting in regard to the Commission for the Reorganization of the Native Tribes. All attention was turned upon him. Alexey Alexandrovitch cleared his throat, and not looking at his opponent, but selecting, as he always did while he was delivering his speeches, the first person sitting opposite him, an inoffensive little old man, who never had an opinion of any sort in the Commission, began to expound his views. When he reached the point about the fundamental and radical law, his opponent jumped up and began to protest. Stremov, who was also a member of the Commission, and also stung to the quick, began defending himself, and altogether a stormy sitting followed; but Alexey Alexandrovitch triumphed, and his motion was carried, three new commissions were appointed, and the next day in a certain Petersburg circle nothing else was talked of but this sitting. Alexey Alexandrovitch’s success had been even greater than he had anticipated.
周一，委员会于 6 月 2 日举行例行会议。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇走进举行会议的大厅，像往常一样向议员和主席致意，然后坐在自己的位置上，把手放在面前准备好的文件上。这些文件中有必要的证据和他打算发表的演讲的粗略提纲。但他并不真正需要这些文件。他记住了每一点，并且认为没有必要在他的记忆中回顾他要说的话。他知道，到了那个时候，当他看到敌人面对着他，并刻意表现出冷漠的表情时，他的演讲就会自然而然地比他现在准备得更好。他觉得他的演讲意义重大，每一个字都有分量。与此同时，他在听着平常的报告时，脸上露出了最天真无邪的神情。看着他白皙的双手，青肿的血管和修长的手指，如此轻柔地抚摸着面前白纸的边缘，看着他低垂着头的疲倦神情，没有人会怀疑几分钟之内，他的嘴里就会滔滔不绝地滔滔不绝，激起一场可怕的风暴，让成员们大喊大叫，互相攻击，并迫使总统要求维持秩序。报告结束后，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇用他柔和而微妙的声音宣布，他有几个关于土著部落重组委员会的要点要向会议提出。所有的注意力都集中在他身上。 阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇清了清嗓子，没有看他的对手，而是选择了坐在他对面的第一个人，他是一个无害的小老头，他在演讲中从来没有发表过任何意见。委员会开始阐述自己的观点。当他说到基本的、激进的法律时，他的对手跳了起来并开始抗议。斯特列莫夫也是该委员会的成员，同样受到了刺痛，他开始为自己辩护，随后，一场风暴席卷而来。但阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇获胜了，他的动议得到了通过，任命了三个新的委员会，第二天，在彼得堡的某个圈子里，除了这次会议之外，没有其他任何事情被谈论。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇的成功甚至超出了他的预期。

Next morning, Tuesday, Alexey Alexandrovitch, on waking up, recollected with pleasure his triumph of the previous day, and he could not help smiling, though he tried to appear indifferent, when the chief secretary of his department, anxious to flatter him, informed him of the rumors that had reached him concerning what had happened in the Commission.
第二天早上，星期二，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇醒来后，高兴地回忆起前一天的胜利，当他的部门的首席秘书急于奉承他时，他忍不住微笑，尽管他试图表现得漠不关心。他向他讲述了他收到的有关委员会发生的事情的谣言。

Absorbed in business with the chief secretary, Alexey Alexandrovitch had completely forgotten that it was Tuesday, the day fixed by him for the return of Anna Arkadyevna, and he was surprised and received a shock of annoyance when a servant came in to inform him of her arrival.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇全神贯注于首席秘书的事务，完全忘记了今天是星期二，他为安娜·阿尔卡季耶夫娜回来的日子定了。当一名仆人进来通知他她的情况时，他感到惊讶和恼怒到达。

Anna had arrived in Petersburg early in the morning; the carriage had been sent to meet her in accordance with her telegram, and so Alexey Alexandrovitch might have known of her arrival. But when she arrived, he did not meet her. She was told that he had not yet gone out, but was busy with his secretary. She sent word to her husband that she had come, went to her own room, and occupied herself in sorting out her things, expecting he would come to her. But an hour passed; he did not come. She went into the dining room on the pretext of giving some directions, and spoke loudly on purpose, expecting him to come out there; but he did not come, though she heard him go to the door of his study as he parted from the chief secretary. She knew that he usually went out quickly to his office, and she wanted to see him before that, so that their attitude to one another might be defined.
安娜一早就到达了彼得堡。马车是根据她的电报派来迎接她的，因此阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇可能知道她的到来。但当她到达时，他并没有见到她。得知他还没有出去，只是忙着陪秘书。她告诉丈夫她来了，然后就回到自己的房间，忙着整理自己的东西，期待他会来找她。但一个小时过去了；他没有来。她借口指路走进餐厅，故意大声说话，等他出来；但他没有来，尽管她听见他与首席秘书告别时走向书房门口。她知道他通常很快就去办公室，她想在那之前见见他，以便明确他们对彼此的态度。

She walked across the drawing room and went resolutely to him. When she went into his study he was in official uniform, obviously ready to go out, sitting at a little table on which he rested his elbows, looking dejectedly before him. She saw him before he saw her, and she saw that he was thinking of her.
她穿过客厅，毅然决然地走向他。当她走进他的书房时，他穿着官服，显然准备出去，坐在一张小桌子旁，胳膊肘搁在上面，沮丧地看着面前。在他看到她之前，她就看到了他，她看出他正在想念她。

On seeing her, he would have risen, but changed his mind, then his face flushed hotly—a thing Anna had never seen before, and he got up quickly and went to meet her, looking not at her eyes, but above them at her forehead and hair. He went up to her, took her by the hand, and asked her to sit down.
一看到她，他就想站起来，但他改变了主意，然后他的脸涨得通红——这是安娜以前从未见过的，他迅速站起来，迎向她，没有看她的眼睛，而是在眼睛上方看着她。额头和头发。他走到她面前，拉着她的手，请她坐下。

‘I am very glad you have come,’ he said, sitting down beside her, and obviously wishing to say something, he stuttered. Several times he tried to begin to speak, but stopped. In spite of the fact that, preparing herself for meeting him, she had schooled herself to despise and reproach him, she did not know what to say to him, and she felt sorry for him. And so the silence lasted for some time. ‘Is Seryozha quite well?’ he said, and not waiting for an answer, he added: ‘I shan’t be dining at home today, and I have got to go out directly.’
“我很高兴你能来，”他说道，在她旁边坐下，显然想要说什么，但他结巴了。他好几次想开口说话，但都停了下来。尽管在准备迎接他的时候，她已经训练自己鄙视他、责备他，但她不知道该对他说什么，她为他感到难过。于是沉默持续了一段时间。 “谢廖扎还好吗？”他不等回答就补充道，“我今天不在家吃饭，得直接出去。”

‘I had thought of going to Moscow,’ she said.
“我曾想过去莫斯科，”她说。

‘No, you did quite, quite right to come,’ he said, and was silent again.
“不，你来得非常非常正确，”他说，然后又沉默了。

Seeing that he was powerless to begin the conversation, she began herself.
看到他无力开口，她就自己开始了。

‘Alexey Alexandrovitch,’ she said, looking at him and not dropping her eyes under his persistent gaze at her hair, ‘I’m a guilty woman, I’m a bad woman, but I am the same as I was, as I told you then, and I have come to tell you that I can change nothing.’
“阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇，”她看着他说道，在他执着地注视着她的头发时，她的眼睛始终没有垂下来，“我是一个有罪的女人，我是一个坏女人，但我还是和以前一样，和我一样。”那时我就​​告诉过你，而我来是为了告诉你，我无法改变任何事情。”

‘I have asked you no question about that,’ he said, all at once, resolutely and with hatred looking her straight in the face; ‘that was as I had supposed.’ Under the influence of anger he apparently regained complete possession of all his faculties. ‘But as I told you then, and have written to you,’ he said in a thin, shrill voice, ‘I repeat now, that I am not bound to know this. I ignore it. Not all wives are so kind as you, to be in such a hurry to communicate such agreeable news to their husbands.’ He laid special emphasis on the word ‘agreeable.’ ‘I shall ignore it so long as the world knows nothing of it, so long as my name is not disgraced. And so I simply inform you that our relations must be just as they have always been, and that only in the event of your compromising me I shall be obliged to take steps to secure my honor.’
“关于这一点我没有问过你任何问题，”他突然说道，语气坚决，带着仇恨，直视着她的脸。 “正如我所料。”在愤怒的影响下，他显然完全恢复了所有的能力。 “但正如我当时告诉你的，也写信给你的，”他用尖细而尖利的声音说道，“我现在再说一遍，我没有义务知道这一点。我忽略它。不是所有的妻子都像你那么善良，这么急着把这么好的消息告诉自己的丈夫。”他特别强调“好”这个词。“只要全世界都一无所知，我就会忽略它。” ，只要我的名字不被玷污。因此，我只是告诉你，我们的关系必须像以前一样，只有在你损害我的情况下，我才有义务采取措施确保我的荣誉。

‘But our relations cannot be the same as always,’ Anna began in a timid voice, looking at him with dismay.
“但我们的关系不能再像以前那样了。”安娜惊愕地看着他，用胆怯的声音说道。

When she saw once more those composed gestures, heard that shrill, childish, and sarcastic voice, her aversion for him extinguished her pity for him, and she felt only afraid, but at all costs she wanted to make clear her position.
当她再次看到那些从容的姿态，听到那尖锐、幼稚、讽刺的声音时，她对他的厌恶浇灭了对他的怜悯，她只感到害怕，但无论如何她都想表明自己的立场。

‘I cannot be your wife while I...’ she began.
“我不能成为你的妻子，因为我……”她开始说道。

He laughed a cold and malignant laugh.
他笑得冷酷而恶毒。

‘The manner of life you have chosen is reflected, I suppose, in your ideas. I have too much respect or contempt, or both...I respect your past and despise your present...that I was far from the interpretation you put on my words.’
“我想，你选择的生活方式已经反映在你的想法中了。”我有太多的尊重或蔑视，或者两者兼而有之……我尊重你的过去，鄙视你的现在……我与你对我的话的解释相去甚远。

Anna sighed and bowed her head.
安娜叹了口气，低下了头。

‘Though indeed I fail to comprehend how, with the independence you show,’ he went on, getting hot, ‘—announcing your infidelity to your husband and seeing nothing reprehensible in it, apparently—you can see anything reprehensible in performing a wife’s duties in relation to your husband.’
“虽然我确实无法理解，以你所表现出的独立性，”他继续说，变得很热，“——宣布你对你丈夫的不忠，而且显然没有发现任何应受谴责的地方——你在履行妻子的职责时也能看到任何应受谴责的地方。”与你丈夫的关系。

‘Alexey Alexandrovitch! What is it you want of me?’
“阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇！你想要我做什么？

‘I want you not to meet that man here, and to conduct yourself so that neither the world nor the servants can reproach you...not to see him. That’s not much, I think. And in return you will enjoy all the privileges of a faithful wife without fulfilling her duties. That’s all I have to say to you. Now it’s time for me to go. I’m not dining at home.’ He got up and moved towards the door.
“我希望你不要在这里遇见那个人，并且要注意自己的行为，以便世界和仆人都不能责备你……不要见到他。我想这并不多。作为回报，你将享受忠实妻子的所有特权，而无需履行她的职责。这就是我要对你说的一切。现在我该走了。我不在家吃饭。”他起身朝门口走去。

Anna got up too. Bowing in silence, he let her pass before him.
安娜也起身了。他默默鞠了一躬，让她从自己面前走过。

Chapter 24
第24章

The night spent by Levin on the haycock did not pass without result for him. The way in which he had been managing his land revolted him and had lost all attraction for him. In spite of the magnificent harvest, never had there been, or, at least, never it seemed to him, had there been so many hindrances and so many quarrels between him and the peasants as that year, and the origin of these failures and this hostility was now perfectly comprehensible to him. The delight he had experienced in the work itself, and the consequent greater intimacy with the peasants, the envy he felt of them, of their life, the desire to adopt that life, which had been to him that night not a dream but an intention, the execution of which he had thought out in detail —all this had so transformed his view of the farming of the land as he had managed it, that he could not take his former interest in it, and could not help seeing that unpleasant relation between him and the workpeople which was the foundation of it all. The herd of improved cows such as Pava, the whole land ploughed over and enriched, the nine level fields surrounded with hedges, the two hundred and forty acres heavily manured, the seed sown in drills, and all the rest of it—it was all splendid if only the work had been done for themselves, or for themselves and comrades —people in sympathy with them. But he saw clearly now (his work on a book of agriculture, in which the chief element in husbandry was to have been the laborer, greatly assisted him in this) that the sort of farming he was carrying on was nothing but a cruel and stubborn struggle between him and the laborers, in which there was on one side—his side—a continual intense effort to change everything to a pattern he considered better; on the other side, the natural order of things. And in this struggle he saw that with immense expenditure of force on his side, and with no effort or even intention on the other side, all that was attained was that the work did not go to the liking of either side, and that splendid tools, splendid cattle and land were spoiled with no good to anyone. Worst of all, the energy expended on this work was not simply wasted. He could not help feeling now, since the meaning of this system had become clear to him, that the aim of his energy was a most unworthy one. In reality, what was the struggle about? He was struggling for every farthing of his share (and he could not help it, for he had only to relax his efforts, and he would not have had the money to pay his laborers’ wages), while they were only struggling to be able to do their work easily and agreeably, that is to say, as they were used to doing it. It was for his interests that every laborer should work as hard as possible, and that while doing so he should keep his wits about him, so as to try not to break the winnowing machines, the horse rakes, the thrashing machines, that he should attend to what he was doing. What the laborer wanted was to work as pleasantly as possible, with rests, and above all, carelessly and heedlessly, without thinking. That summer Levin saw this at every step. He sent the men to mow some clover for hay, picking out the worst patches where the clover was overgrown with grass and weeds and of no use for seed; again and again they mowed the best acres of clover, justifying themselves by the pretense that the bailiff had told them to, and trying to pacify him with the assurance that it would be splendid hay; but he knew that it was owing to those acres being so much easier to mow. He sent out a hay machine for pitching the hay—it was broken at the first row because it was dull work for a peasant to sit on the seat in front with the great wings waving above him. And he was told, ‘Don’t trouble, your honor, sure, the womenfolks will pitch it quick enough.’ The ploughs were practically useless, because it never occurred to the laborer to raise the share when he turned the plough, and forcing it round, he strained the horses and tore up the ground, and Levin was begged not to mind about it. The horses were allowed to stray into the wheat because not a single laborer would consent to be night-watchman, and in spite of orders to the contrary, the laborers insisted on taking turns for night duty, and Ivan, after working all day long, fell asleep, and was very penitent for his fault, saying, ‘Do what you will to me, your honor.’
莱文在干草堆上度过的这一夜对他来说并非没有收获。他管理土地的方式让他感到厌恶，并且对他失去了所有吸引力。尽管取得了丰收，但他和农民之间从来没有像那一年那样，或者至少在他看来从来没有像那一年那样，出现过如此多的障碍和如此多的争吵，以及这些失败和这次事件的根源。现在他完全可以理解敌意了。他在工作本身中体验到的快乐，以及随之而来的与农民更加亲密的关系，他对他们和他们的生活的嫉妒，对过那种生活的渴望，那天晚上这对他来说不是一个梦想，而是一个意图，他已经详细考虑过的执行情况——所有这一切都改变了他对土地耕种的看法，因为他管理它，他无法再恢复以前对它的兴趣，并且无法避免看到那种不愉快的关系。他和工人之间的关系是这一切的基础。像帕瓦这样的改良牛群，整片土地都被犁过，变得肥沃了，九块平坦的田地周围环绕着树篱，两百四十英亩的土地施了厚重的肥料，播种机里的种子，以及所有其他的东西——这一切都是如此。如果这项工作是为了他们自己，或者为了他们自己和同志们——同情他们的人们而完成的，那就太好了。 但他现在清楚地看到（他写的一本农业书，其中农业的主要要素是劳动者，在这方面对他有很大帮助），他所从事的农业只不过是一种残酷和顽固的农业。他和工人们之间的斗争，其中一方面——他的一方面——不断地努力将一切改变为他认为更好的模式；另一方面，事物的自然秩序。在这场斗争中，他看到，自己一方耗费了巨大的武力，而另一方却毫无努力，甚至没有任何意图，所得到的只是工作没有得到任何一方的喜欢，而那些出色的工具，美丽的牲畜和土地被破坏了，对任何人都没有好处。最糟糕的是，这项工作所花费的精力并没有被简单地浪费掉。他现在不禁感到，既然这个系统的意义对他来说已经很清楚了，他的精力的目的是最不值得的。事实上，这场斗争是为了什么？他正在为自己那一份的每一分钱而奋斗（他也无能为力，因为他只要放松努力，他就没有钱支付工人的工资），而他们只是为了能够轻松愉快地完成工作，也就是说，按照他们习惯的方式完成工作。为了自己的利益，每个劳动者都应该尽可能地努力工作，并且在工作的同时要保持头脑清醒，尽量不弄坏扬场机、马耙、打谷机，他应该关注他正在做的事情。劳动者想要的是尽可能愉快地工作，休息，最重要的是，粗心、漫不经心、不加思考。那年夏天，莱文的每一步都看到了这一点。 他派人去割一些三叶草当干草，挑出最差的一片，那里的三叶草长满了青草和杂草，对种子没有用处。他们一次又一次地割掉最好的几英亩三叶草，假装法警告诉他们这样做，为自己辩护，并试图安抚他，保证这将是极好的干草。但他知道这是因为那些土地更容易割草。他派出了一台干草机来撒干草——它在第一排就坏了，因为对于一个农民来说，坐在前面的座位上、巨大的翅膀在头顶上挥舞是一项乏味的工作。有人告诉他：“别麻烦了，法官大人，当然，女人们很快就会犁地。”犁实际上毫无用处，因为劳动者在转动犁时从来没有想到要提高犁铧，并且强迫犁犁。围绕着它，他拉紧了马匹，撕裂了地面，莱文被恳求不要介意。马匹被允许误入麦田，因为没有一个工人愿意当守夜人，尽管有相反的命令，工人们坚持轮流值夜，而伊万在工作了一整天后，睡着了，他为自己的过错深感悔恨，说道：“法官大人，你想怎样待我就怎样吧。”’

They killed three of the best calves by letting them into the clover aftermath without care as to their drinking, and nothing would make the men believe that they had been blown out by the clover, but they told him, by way of consolation, that one of his neighbors had lost a hundred and twelve head of cattle in three days. All this happened, not because anyone felt ill-will to Levin or his farm; on the contrary, he knew that they liked him, thought him a simple gentleman (their highest praise); but it happened simply because all they wanted was to work merrily and carelessly, and his interests were not only remote and incomprehensible to them, but fatally opposed to their most just claims. Long before, Levin had felt dissatisfaction with his own position in regard to the land. He saw where his boat leaked, but he did not look for the leak, perhaps purposely deceiving himself. (Nothing would be left him if he lost faith in it.) But now he could deceive himself no longer. The farming of the land, as he was managing it, had become not merely unattractive but revolting to him, and he could take no further interest in it.
他们杀死了三头最好的小牛，让他们进入三叶草的余波，不顾他们的饮酒，没有什么能让这些人相信他们是被三叶草吹倒的，但他们告诉他，作为安慰，一头他的邻居在三天内损失了一百一十二头牛。这一切的发生，并不是因为有人对莱文或他的农场怀有恶意；而是因为有人对他的农场抱有恶意。相反，他知道他们喜欢他，认为他是一个简单的绅士（他们的最高评价）；但这只是因为他们只想快乐而无忧无虑地工作，而他的利益对他们来说不仅遥远和难以理解，而且与他们最公正的主张致命地相反。很久以前，莱文就对自己在这片土地上的立场感到不满。他看到了他的船漏水的地方，但他没有去寻找漏水处，也许是故意欺骗自己。 （如果他对此失去信心，他将一无所有。） 但现在他不能再欺骗自己了。当他管理土地时，土地的耕作不仅变得没有吸引力，而且让他感到厌恶，他对它不再有兴趣。

To this now was joined the presence, only twenty-five miles off, of Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, whom he longed to see and could not see. Darya Alexandrovna Oblonskaya had invited him, when he was over there, to come; to come with the object of renewing his offer to her sister, who would, so she gave him to understand, accept him now. Levin himself had felt on seeing Kitty Shtcherbatskaya that he had never ceased to love her; but he could not go over to the Oblonskys’, knowing she was there. The fact that he had made her an offer, and she had refused him, had placed an insuperable barrier between her and him. ‘I can’t ask her to be my wife merely because she can’t be the wife of the man she wanted to marry,’ he said to himself. The thought of this made him cold and hostile to her. ‘I should not be able to speak to her without a feeling of reproach; I could not look at her without resentment; and she will only hate me all the more, as she’s bound to. And besides, how can I now, after what Darya Alexandrovna told me, go to see them? Can I help showing that I know what she told me? And me to go magnanimously to forgive her, and have pity on her! Me go through a performance before her of forgiving, and deigning to bestow my love on her!... What induced Darya Alexandrovna to tell me that? By chance I might have seen her, then everything would have happened of itself; but, as it is, it’s out of the question, out of the question!’
现在，距离他只有二十五英里的基蒂·谢尔巴茨卡娅（Kitty Shtcherbatskaya）也出现在了这里，他渴望见到她，却看不见。当他在那儿时，达里娅·亚历山德罗夫娜·奥布隆斯卡娅邀请他来。他来的目的是向她姐姐重申他的提议，她让他明白，她现在就会接受他。莱文本人在见到基蒂·谢尔巴茨卡娅时就感到自己从未停止过对她的爱。但他不能去奥布朗斯基家，因为他知道她在那里。他向她提出要约，而她拒绝了他，这一事实在她和他之间设置了不可逾越的障碍。 “我不能仅仅因为她不能成为她想结婚的男人的妻子而要求她成为我的妻子，”他对自己说。一想到这个，他就对她冷漠而充满敌意。 “我和她说话时不应该感到受责备；我无法不带着怨恨地看着她；她只会更加恨我，这是她注定的。此外，在达里娅·亚历山德罗夫娜告诉我之后，我现在怎么才能去看他们呢？我可以帮忙表明我知道她告诉我的事情吗？而我则要大度地去原谅她，怜悯她！我在她面前表现出宽恕，并屈尊向她表达我的爱！……是什么促使达里娅·亚历山德罗夫娜告诉我这些？碰巧我可能会见到她，那么一切就会自然而然地发生了；但事实上，这是不可能的，不可能的！”

Darya Alexandrovna sent him a letter, asking him for a side-saddle for Kitty’s use. ‘I’m told you have a side-saddle,’ she wrote to him; ‘I hope you will bring it over yourself.’
达里娅·亚历山德罗夫娜（Darya Alexandrovna）给他写了一封信，要求他提供一个供凯蒂使用的侧鞍。 “我听说你有一个侧鞍，”她写信给他； “我希望你能自己解决这个问题。”

This was more than he could stand. How could a woman of any intelligence, of any delicacy, put her sister in such a humiliating position! He wrote ten notes, and tore them all up, and sent the saddle without any reply. To write that he would go was impossible, because he could not go; to write that he could not come because something prevented him, or that he would be away, that was still worse. He sent the saddle without an answer, and with a sense of having done something shameful; he handed over all the now revolting business of the estate to the bailiff, and set off next day to a remote district to see his friend Sviazhsky, who had splendid marshes for grouse in his neighborhood, and had lately written to ask him to keep a long-standing promise to stay with him. The grouse-marsh, in the Surovsky district, had long tempted Levin, but he had continually put off this visit on account of his work on the estate. Now he was glad to get away from the neighborhood of the Shtcherbatskys, and still more from his farm work, especially on a shooting expedition, which always in trouble served as the best consolation.
这超出了他的承受能力。一个再聪明、再温柔的女人，怎么能让自己的妹妹落到如此屈辱的地步！他写了十张纸条，然后把它们全部撕碎，寄出马鞍，没有任何答复。要写他会去是不可能的，因为他不能去。如果写他不能来是因为有事阻止他，或者他要离开，那就更糟糕了。他送来马鞍，却没有得到任何答复，还带着一种做了什么可耻之事的感觉。他把庄园里现在所有令人反感的事务都交给了法警，第二天出发去一个偏僻的地区去见他的朋友斯维亚日斯基，他的附近有一片适合松鸡的美丽沼泽，最近还写信要求他保留一个长久以来的承诺，会和他在一起。苏罗夫斯基区的松鸡沼泽长期以来一直吸引着莱文，但由于他在庄园里的工作，他一直推迟这次访问。现在他很高兴能够离开谢尔巴茨基一家的邻居，更不用说他的农活了，尤其是在一次射击探险中，总是遇到麻烦是最好的安慰。

Chapter 25
第25章

In the Surovsky district there was no railway nor service of post horses, and Levin drove there with his own horses in his big, old-fashioned carriage.
苏罗夫斯基地区没有铁路，也没有邮政马匹服务，莱文用他自己的马匹开着他的老式大马车前往那里。

He stopped halfway at a well-to-do peasant’s to feed his horses. A bald, well-preserved old man, with a broad, red beard, gray on his cheeks, opened the gate, squeezing against the gatepost to let the three horses pass. Directing the coachman to a place under the shed in the big, clean, tidy yard, with charred, old-fashioned ploughs in it, the old man asked Levin to come into the parlor. A cleanly dressed young woman, with clogs on her bare feet, was scrubbing the floor in the new outer room. She was frightened of the dog, that ran in after Levin, and uttered a shriek, but began laughing at her own fright at once when she was told the dog would not hurt her. Pointing Levin with her bare arm to the door into the parlor, she bent down again, hiding her handsome face, and went on scrubbing.
他在一个富裕农民家中途停下来喂马。一个秃顶、保养得很好、留着宽大的红胡子、脸颊灰白的老人打开了大门，挤在门柱上让三匹马通过。老人把车夫引到干净整洁的大院子里的棚子下，里面放着烧焦的老式犁，请莱文进客厅。一个衣着干净的年轻女子，光着脚踩着木屐，正在新的外屋里擦地板。她害怕追着莱文跑来的狗，发出一声尖叫，但当她被告知狗不会伤害她时，她立即开始嘲笑自己的恐惧。她用赤裸的手臂指着莱文进入客厅的门，然后又弯下腰，遮住她英俊的脸，继续擦洗。

‘Would you like the samovar?’ she asked.
“你想要茶炊吗？”她问。

‘Yes, please.’
'是的，请。'

The parlor was a big room, with a Dutch stove, and a screen dividing it into two. Under the holy pictures stood a table painted in patterns, a bench, and two chairs. Near the entrance was a dresser full of crockery. The shutters were closed, there were few flies, and it was so clean that Levin was anxious that Laska, who had been running along the road and bathing in puddles, should not muddy the floor, and ordered her to a place in the corner by the door. After looking round the parlor, Levin went out in the back yard. The good-looking young woman in clogs, swinging the empty pails on the yoke, ran on before him to the well for water.
客厅很大，有一个荷兰炉子，还有一个屏风将它分成两部分。圣像下面放着一张画有图案的桌子、一张长凳和两把椅子。入口附近有一个装满陶器的梳妆台。百叶窗关着，苍蝇很少，而且干净得让莱文担心一直在路边跑步、在水坑里洗澡的拉斯卡不要弄脏地板，并命令她到角落里的一个地方。门。莱文环顾客厅后，走到后院。那个穿着木屐的漂亮年轻女子，甩着轭上的空桶，在他前面跑到井边打水。

‘Look sharp, my girl!’ the old man shouted after her, good-humoredly, and he went up to Levin. ‘Well, sir, are you going to Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky? His honor comes to us too,’ he began, chatting, leaning his elbows on the railing of the steps. In the middle of the old man’s account of his acquaintance with Sviazhsky, the gates creaked again, and laborers came into the yard from the fields, with wooden ploughs and harrows. The horses harnessed to the ploughs and harrows were sleek and fat. The laborers were obviously of the household: two were young men in cotton shirts and caps, the two others were hired laborers in homespun shirts, one an old man, the other a young fellow. Moving off from the steps, the old man went up to the horses and began unharnessing them.
“小心点，我的姑娘！”老人在她身后幽默地喊道，然后走到莱文跟前。 “那么，先生，您要去尼古拉·伊万诺维奇·斯维亚日斯基吗？他的荣誉也降临在我们身上，”他开始聊天，手肘靠在台阶的栏杆上。老人讲述他与斯维亚日斯基的相识时，大门再次嘎吱作响，工人们拿着木犁和耙子从地里来到院子里。犁地和耙子上套着的马匹又光滑又肥硕。那些劳工显然是家里人：两个是穿着棉衫、戴着帽子的年轻人，另外两个是穿着土布衫的雇工，一个是老人，一个是年轻人。老人下了台阶，走到马跟前，开始解马具。

‘What have they been ploughing?’ asked Levin.
“他们在耕什么？”莱文问。

‘Ploughing up the potatoes. We rent a bit of land too. Fedot, don’t let out the gelding, but take it to the trough, and we’ll put the other in harness.’
‘犁土豆。我们也租了一点土地。费多，别把那匹骟马放出来，把它带到马槽里，我们会把另一匹骟马套上挽具。”

‘Oh, father, the ploughshares I ordered, has he brought them along?’ asked the big, healthy-looking fellow, obviously the old man’s son.
“哦，父亲，我订购的犁头，他带来了吗？”那个看起来很健康的大个子问道，显然是老人的儿子。

‘There...in the outer room,’ answered the old man, bundling together the harness he had taken off, and flinging it on the ground. ‘You can put them on, while they have dinner.’
“那里……在外屋里。”老人回答道，把脱下来的挽具捆在一起，扔在地上。 “你可以在他们吃晚饭的时候穿上它们。”

The good-looking young woman came into the outer room with the full pails dragging at her shoulders. More women came on the scene from somewhere, young and handsome, middle-aged, old and ugly, with children and without children.
漂亮的少妇肩上拖着满满的水桶走进外屋。不知从什么地方涌来了更多的女人，有年轻漂亮的，有中年的，有老丑的，有孩子的，没有孩子的。

The samovar was beginning to sing; the laborers and the family, having disposed of the horses, came in to dinner. Levin, getting his provisions out of his carriage, invited the old man to take tea with him.
茶炊开始唱歌；工人和家人处理完马匹后，进来吃晚饭。列文从马车上拿出食物，邀请老人一起喝茶。

‘Well, I have had some today already,’ said the old man, obviously accepting the invitation with pleasure. ‘But just a glass for company.’
“嗯，我今天已经吃了一些了。”老人说道，显然很高兴地接受了邀请。 “但只是为公司喝一杯。”

Over their tea Levin heard all about the old man’s farming. Ten years before, the old man had rented three hundred acres from the lady who owned them, and a year ago he had bought them and rented another three hundred from a neighboring landowner. A small part of the land—the worst part—he let out for rent, while a hundred acres of arable land he cultivated himself with his family and two hired laborers. The old man complained that things were doing badly. But Levin saw that he simply did so from a feeling of propriety, and that his farm was in a flourishing condition.
