黎明来临了；病人的病情没有变化。莱文悄悄地收回了手，看也不看垂死的人，就回自己的房间去睡觉了。当他醒来时，并没有听到他所期待的哥哥去世的消息，而是得知病人已经恢复了之前的状态。他又开始坐起来，咳嗽，又开始吃东西，又说话，又不再谈论死亡，又开始表达康复的希望，而且变得比以前更烦躁、更阴郁。没有人，无论是他的兄弟还是凯蒂，都无法安抚他。他对每个人都很生气，对每个人都说难听的话，责备每个人所受的痛苦，并坚持要求他们从莫斯科给他找一位著名的医生。对于所有询问他感受如何的人，他都做出了同样的回答，表情充满报复和责备：“我正在遭受可怕的、难以忍受的痛苦！”

The sick man was suffering more and more, especially from bedsores, which it was impossible now to remedy, and grew more and more angry with everyone about him, blaming them for everything, and especially for not having brought him a doctor from Moscow. Kitty tried in every possible way to relieve him, to soothe him; but it was all in vain, and Levin saw that she herself was exhausted both physically and morally, though she would not admit it. The sense of death, which had been evoked in all by his taking leave of life on the night when he had sent for his brother, was broken up. Everyone knew that he must inevitably die soon, that he was half dead already. Everyone wished for nothing but that he should die as soon as possible, and everyone, concealing this, gave him medicines, tried to find remedies and doctors, and deceived him and themselves and each other. All this was falsehood, disgusting, irreverent deceit. And owing to the bent of his character, and because he loved the dying man more than anyone else did, Levin was most painfully conscious of this deceit.
病人的痛苦越来越大，尤其是褥疮，现在已经无法治愈，他对周围的每个人都越来越生气，将一切归咎于他们，尤其是没有从莫斯科给他带来医生。基蒂想尽各种办法来缓解他、安抚他。但这一切都是徒劳的，莱文看到她自己在身体上和精神上都已经疲惫不堪，尽管她不承认。当他派人去接弟弟的那天晚上，他告别生命所引发的死亡感被打破了。所有人都知道，他必死无疑，已经是半死不活了。每个人都别无他求，只求他尽快死去，每个人都隐瞒这一点，给他吃药，寻找药方和医生，欺骗他、欺骗自己、欺骗彼此。这一切都是谎言、令人厌恶、不敬的欺骗。由于他的性格倾向，也因为他比任何人都更爱这个垂死的人，莱文对这种欺骗感到非常痛苦。

Levin, who had long been possessed by the idea of reconciling his brothers, at least in face of death, had written to his brother, Sergey Ivanovitch, and having received an answer from him, he read this letter to the sick man. Sergey Ivanovitch wrote that he could not come himself, and in touching terms he begged his brother’s forgiveness.
列文长期以来一直想与他的兄弟和解，至少在死亡面前，他写信给他的兄弟谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇，收到他的答复后，他把这封信读给病人听。谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇写道，他自己不能来，并用感人的语言请求他哥哥的原谅。

The sick man said nothing.
病人什么也没说。

‘What am I to write to him?’ said Levin. ‘I hope you are not angry with him?’
“我该给他写些什么呢？”列文说。 “我希望你没有生他的气吗？”

‘No, not the least!’ Nikolay answered, vexed at the question. ‘Tell him to send me a doctor.’
“不，一点也不！”尼古拉回答道，对这个问题很恼火。 “让他给我派一名医生。”

Three more days of agony followed; the sick man was still in the same condition. The sense of longing for his death was felt by everyone now at the mere sight of him, by the waiters and the hotel-keeper and all the people staying in the hotel, and the doctor and Marya Nikolaevna and Levin and Kitty. The sick man alone did not express this feeling, but on the contrary was furious at their not getting him doctors, and went on taking medicine and talking of life. Only at rare moments, when the opium gave him an instant’s relief from the never-ceasing pain, he would sometimes, half asleep, utter what was ever more intense in his heart than in all the others: ‘Oh, if it were only the end!’ or: ‘When will it be over?’
接下来又是三天的痛苦。病人仍处于同样的状况。现在，每个人只要一看到他，就都感受到了对他死亡的渴望，包括服务员、旅馆老板和所有住在旅馆里的人，还有医生、玛丽亚·尼古拉耶芙娜、莱文和基蒂。唯独病人没有表达出这种感觉，反而对他们没有给他找医生感到愤怒，继续吃药，谈论人生。只有在极少数的时刻，当鸦片使他从永无休止的痛苦中得到片刻缓解时，他有时会在半睡半醒中说出他心中比其他人更强烈的话：“哦，如果只是这样就好了。”结束！”或者：“什么时候结束？”

His sufferings, steadily growing more intense, did their work and prepared him for death. There was no position in which he was not in pain, there was not a minute in which he was unconscious of it, not a limb, not a part of his body that did not ache and cause him agony. Even the memories, the impressions, the thoughts of this body awakened in him now the same aversion as the body itself. The sight of other people, their remarks, his own reminiscences, everything was for him a source of agony. Those about him felt this, and instinctively did not allow themselves to move freely, to talk, to express their wishes before him. All his life was merged in the one feeling of suffering and desire to be rid of it.
他的痛苦逐渐变得更加强烈，并为他的死亡做好了准备。没有一个姿势他不感到疼痛，没有一分钟他没有意识到这一点，他的肢体、身体的每一部分都在疼痛，给他带来痛苦。甚至连关于这个身体的记忆、印象、思想现在都在他心中唤醒了与身体本身同样的厌恶。别人的目光、别人的言论、自己的回忆，一切都让他痛苦不已。他周围的人也感受到了这一点，本能地不允许自己在他面前自由行动、说话、表达自己的愿望。他的一生都融入了一种痛苦的感觉和摆脱痛苦的渴望之中。

There was evidently coming over him that revulsion that would make him look upon death as the goal of his desires, as happiness. Hitherto each individual desire, aroused by suffering or privation, such as hunger, fatigue, thirst, had been satisfied by some bodily function giving pleasure. But now no physical craving or suffering received relief, and the effort to relieve them only caused fresh suffering. And so all desires were merged in one—the desire to be rid of all his sufferings and their source, the body. But he had no words to express this desire of deliverance, and so he did not speak of it, and from habit asked for the satisfaction of desires which could not now be satisfied. ‘Turn me over on the other side,’ he would say, and immediately after he would ask to be turned back again as before. ‘Give me some broth. Take away the broth. Talk of something: why are you silent?’ And directly they began to talk he would close his eyes, and would show weariness, indifference, and loathing.
显然，他感到一种厌恶，使他将死亡视为他欲望的目标，视为幸福。迄今为止，每个人的欲望，由痛苦或匮乏（例如饥​​饿、疲劳、口渴）引起的，都是通过某种带来快乐的身体机能来满足的。但现在，肉体的渴求或痛苦并没有得到缓解，而且为缓解它们而付出的努力只会带来新的痛苦。于是，所有的欲望都融合为一——摆脱所有痛苦及其根源——身体的欲望。但他没有言语来表达这种解脱的愿望，所以他没有说出它，而是出于习惯要求满足现在无法满足的愿望。 “把我翻到另一边，”他会说，然后他会立即要求像以前一样再转回来。 ‘给我点汤吧。把肉汤拿走。谈论一些事情：你为什么沉默？”当他们开始说话时，他就会闭上眼睛，并表现出疲倦、冷漠和厌恶。

On the tenth day from their arrival at the town, Kitty was unwell. She suffered from headache and sickness, and she could not get up all the morning.
他们到达小镇的第十天，基蒂就感觉不舒服。她头痛欲裂，整个早上都起不来。

The doctor opined that the indisposition arose from fatigue and excitement, and prescribed rest.
医生认为是由于劳累、兴奋引起的不适，建议休息。

After dinner, however, Kitty got up and went as usual with her work to the sick man. He looked at her sternly when she came in, and smiled contemptuously when she said she had been unwell. That day he was continually blowing his nose, and groaning piteously.
然而，晚饭后，基蒂起身，像往常一样去为病人做事。当她进来时，他严厉地看着她，当她说她身体不舒服时，他轻蔑地笑了笑。那天他不停地擤鼻涕，可怜兮兮地呻吟着。

‘How do you feel?’ she asked him.
“你感觉怎么样？”她问他。

‘Worse,’ he articulated with difficulty. ‘In pain!’
“更糟，”他艰难地说道。 '在疼痛！'

‘In pain, where?’
“哪里痛？”

‘Everywhere.’
'到处。'

‘It will be over today, you will see,’ said Marya Nikolaevna. Though it was said in a whisper, the sick man, whose hearing Levin had noticed was very keen, must have heard. Levin said hush to her, and looked round at the sick man. Nikolay had heard; but these words produced no effect on him. His eyes had still the same intense, reproachful look.
“今天就会结束，你会看到的，”玛丽亚·尼古拉耶夫娜说。虽然是小声说的，但莱文注意到病人的听力非常敏锐，他一定听到了。莱文对她说了一声“安静”，然后环视病人。尼古拉听到了；但这些话对他没有产生任何作用。他的眼神依然是那样的强烈、责备。

‘Why do you think so?’ Levin asked her, when she had followed him into the corridor.
“你为什么这么想？”当她跟着他走进走廊时，莱文问她。

‘He has begun picking at himself,’ said Marya Nikolaevna.
“他已经开始挑剔自己了，”玛丽亚·尼古拉耶夫娜说。

‘How do you mean?’
'你是什么意思？'

‘Like this,’ she said, tugging at the folds of her woolen skirt. Levin noticed, indeed, that all that day the patient pulled at himself, as it were, trying to snatch something away.
“就像这样，”她说，拉扯羊毛裙子的褶皱。事实上，莱文注意到，病人一整天都在拉扯自己，试图抢走什么东西。

Marya Nikolaevna’s prediction came true. Towards night the sick man was not able to lift his hands, and could only gaze before him with the same intensely concentrated expression in his eyes. Even when his brother or Kitty bent over him, so that he could see them, he looked just the same. Kitty sent for the priest to read the prayer for the dying.
玛丽亚·尼古拉耶芙娜的预言成真了。夜幕降临时，病人双手举不起来，只能凝视着前方，眼神同样专注。即使当他的兄弟或凯蒂弯下腰让他看到他们时，他看起来还是一样。基蒂派人请牧师为临终者宣读祈祷文。

While the priest was reading it, the dying man did not show any sign of life; his eyes were closed. Levin, Kitty, and Marya Nikolaevna stood at the bedside. The priest had not quite finished reading the prayer when the dying man stretched, sighed, and opened his eyes. The priest, on finishing the prayer, put the cross to the cold forehead, then slowly returned it to the stand, and after standing for two minutes more in silence, he touched the huge, bloodless hand that was turning cold.
当神父正在读这封信的时候，垂死的人已经没有任何生命迹象了。他的眼睛闭着。莱文、基蒂和玛丽亚·尼古拉耶芙娜站在床边。当神父还没读完祈祷文时，垂死的人伸了个懒腰，叹了口气，睁开了眼睛。神父做完祈祷，将十字架放在冰冷的额头上，然后缓缓放回架子上，默默地站了两分钟后，触碰了那只毫无血色、冰冷的巨手。

‘He is gone,’ said the priest, and would have moved away; but suddenly there was a faint stir in the mustaches of the dead man that seemed glued together, and quite distinctly in the hush they heard from the bottom of the chest the sharply defined sounds:
“他走了，”神父说，并想走开。但突然间，死者的胡须似乎粘在一起了，一阵微弱的骚动，在一片寂静中，他们清楚地听到从箱子底部传来尖锐的声音：

‘Not quite...soon.’
“不太……很快。”

And a minute later the face brightened, a smile came out under the mustaches, and the women who had gathered round began carefully laying out the corpse.
一分钟后，她的脸变得明亮起来，胡须下露出了笑容，聚集在周围的妇女们开始小心地安放尸体。

The sight of his brother, and the nearness of death, revived in Levin that sense of horror in face of the insoluble enigma, together with the nearness and inevitability of death, that had come upon him that autumn evening when his brother had come to him. This feeling was now even stronger than before; even less than before did he feel capable of apprehending the meaning of death, and its inevitability rose up before him more terrible than ever. But now, thanks to his wife’s presence, that feeling did not reduce him to despair. In spite of death, he felt the need of life and love. He felt that love saved him from despair, and that this love, under the menace of despair, had become still stronger and purer. The one mystery of death, still unsolved, had scarcely passed before his eyes, when another mystery had arisen, as insoluble, urging him to love and to life.
看到他的兄弟，以及死亡的临近，莱文在面对无法解决的谜团时的恐惧感，以及死亡的临近和不可避免，在那个秋天的晚上，当他的兄弟来到他身边时，他又恢复了这种恐惧感。 。这种感觉现在比之前还要强烈。他比以前更感觉自己无法理解死亡的意义，死亡的必然性在他面前比以往任何时候都更加可怕。但现在，多亏了妻子的存在，这种感觉并没有让他陷入绝望。尽管死亡，他仍然感到需要生命和爱。他觉得是爱将他从绝望中拯救了出来，而且这种爱在绝望的威胁下变得更加强烈和纯洁。死亡的一个谜团还没有解开，他刚刚从他眼前经过，另一个同样无法解开的谜团就出现了，催促他去爱和生活。

The doctor confirmed his suppositions in regard to Kitty. Her indisposition was a symptom that she was with child.
医生证实了他对基蒂的猜测。她的身体不适是她怀孕的征兆。

Chapter 21
第21章

From the moment when Alexey Alexandrovitch understood from his interviews with Betsy and with Stepan Arkadyevitch that all that was expected of him was to leave his wife in peace, without burdening her with his presence, and that his wife herself desired this, he felt so distraught that he could come to no decision of himself; he did not know himself what he wanted now, and putting himself in the hands of those who were so pleased to interest themselves in his affairs, he met everything with unqualified assent. It was only when Anna had left his house, and the English governess sent to ask him whether she should dine with him or separately, that for the first time he clearly comprehended his position, and was appalled by it. Most difficult of all in this position was the fact that he could not in any way connect and reconcile his past with what was now. It was not the past when he had lived happily with his wife that troubled him. The transition from that past to a knowledge of his wife’s unfaithfulness he had lived through miserably already; that state was painful, but he could understand it. If his wife had then, on declaring to him her unfaithfulness, left him, he would have been wounded, unhappy, but he would not have been in the hopeless position—incomprehensible to himself—in which he felt himself now. He could not now reconcile his immediate past, his tenderness, his love for his sick wife, and for the other man’s child with what was now the case, that is with the fact that, as it were, in return for all this he now found himself alone, put to shame, a laughing-stock, needed by no one, and despised by everyone.
当阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇从贝特西和斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇的采访中了解到，人们对他的期望就是让他的妻子平静地生活，而不让他的存在给她带来负担，而他的妻子本人也希望如此，从那一刻起，他感到非常心烦意乱。他自己无法做出决定；他不知道自己现在想要什么，而把自己交给那些乐于关心他的事情的人，他对一切都表示无条件的同意。直到安娜离开他的家，英国家庭女教师派人来问他是应该和他一起吃饭还是单独吃饭时，他才第一次清楚地理解了自己的立场，并为此感到震惊。在这个位置上最困难的是他无法以任何方式将过去与现在联系起来并调和起来。让他烦恼的并不是过去与妻子幸福的生活。从过去的经历到了解妻子的不忠，他已经痛苦地经历了这一转变。那种状态很痛苦，但他能理解。如果他的妻子当时向他宣布了她的不忠，就离开了他，他会受伤、不快乐，但他也不会处于他现在感到的那种绝望的境地——他自己也无法理解。他现在无法将他的过去、他的温柔、他对生病的妻子和另一个男人的孩子的爱与现在的情况调和起来，也就是说，作为对这一切的回报，他现在发现自己孤身一人，蒙羞受辱，成为笑柄，无人需要，人人鄙视。

For the first two days after his wife’s departure Alexey Alexandrovitch received applicants for assistance and his chief secretary, drove to the committee, and went down to dinner in the dining room as usual. Without giving himself a reason for what he was doing, he strained every nerve of his being for those two days, simply to preserve an appearance of composure, and even of indifference. Answering inquiries about the disposition of Anna Arkadyevna’s rooms and belongings, he had exercised immense self-control to appear like a man in whose eyes what had occurred was not unforeseen nor out of the ordinary course of events, and he attained his aim: no one could have detected in him signs of despair. But on the second day after her departure, when Korney gave him a bill from a fashionable draper’s shop, which Anna had forgotten to pay, and announced that the clerk from the shop was waiting, Alexey Alexandrovitch told him to show the clerk up.
在他妻子离开后的头两天，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇接待了援助申请者和他的首席秘书，开车去委员会，然后像往常一样去餐厅吃晚饭。他没有给自己解释这样做的理由，这两天他竭尽全力，只是为了保持一副镇定甚至冷漠的样子。在回答有关安娜·阿尔卡季耶夫娜的房间和财物的处置问题的询问时，他表现出极大的自制力，表现得像一个在他眼中所发生的事情并非不可预见或不寻常的人，他达到了他的目的：没有人可能在他身上发现了绝望的迹象。但在她离开后的第二天，当科尼给了他一张时尚布店的账单（安娜忘记付钱）并宣布店里的店员正在等待时，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇让他带店员来。

‘Excuse me, your excellency, for venturing to trouble you. But if you direct us to apply to her excellency, would you graciously oblige us with her address?’
“对不起，阁下，冒昧打扰您了。但如果您指示我们向她阁下提出申请，您会慷慨地向我们提供她的地址吗？

Alexey Alexandrovitch pondered, as it seemed to the clerk, and all at once, turning round, he sat down at the table. Letting his head sink into his hands, he sat for a long while in that position, several times attempted to speak and stopped short. Korney, perceiving his master’s emotion, asked the clerk to call another time. Left alone, Alexey Alexandrovitch recognized that he had not the strength to keep up the line of firmness and composure any longer. He gave orders for the carriage that was awaiting him to be taken back, and for no one to be admitted, and he did not go down to dinner.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇沉思着，正如店员所认为的那样，他突然转过身，在桌边坐下。他双手捂着头，在这个姿势上坐了好久，好几次想要说话，却又戛然而止。科尼察觉到了主人的情绪，请店员下次再打电话。只剩下阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇一个人，他意识到自己已经没有力气再保持坚定和镇定的态度了。他吩咐把等待他的马车收回，不让任何人进入，他也没有下楼去吃晚饭。

He felt that he could not endure the weight of universal contempt and exasperation, which he had distinctly seen in the face of the clerk and of Korney, and of everyone, without exception, whom he had met during those two days. He felt that he could not turn aside from himself the hatred of men, because that hatred did not come from his being bad (in that case he could have tried to be better), but from his being shamefully and repulsively unhappy. He knew that for this, for the very fact that his heart was torn with grief, they would be merciless to him. He felt that men would crush him as dogs strangle a torn dog yelping with pain. He knew that his sole means of security against people was to hide his wounds from them, and instinctively he tried to do this for two days, but now he felt incapable of keeping up the unequal struggle.
他觉得自己无法忍受普遍的轻蔑和愤怒，他在职员和科尼以及他这两天遇到的每个人的脸上都清楚地看到了这种轻蔑和愤怒。他觉得自己无法摆脱对人的仇恨，因为这种仇恨并非来自于他的坏（如果是这样的话，他本可以努力变得更好），而是来自于他可耻且令人厌恶的不快乐。他知道，为了这个，为了他心如刀绞的事实，他们就会对他毫不留情。他觉得男人会压垮他，就像狗勒死一只痛苦地嚎叫的撕裂的狗一样。他知道他对抗他人的唯一安全手段就是向他们隐藏自己的伤口，他本能地尝试这样做了两天，但现在他感到无法继续这种不平等的斗争。

His despair was even intensified by the consciousness that he was utterly alone in his sorrow. In all Petersburg there was not a human being to whom he could express what he was feeling, who would feel for him, not as a high official, not as a member of society, but simply as a suffering man; indeed he had not such a one in the whole world.
当他意识到自己独自一人在悲伤中时，他的绝望更加强烈。在整个彼得堡，没有一个人可以向他表达自己的感受，没有一个人会同情他，不是作为一个高级官员，不是作为一个社会成员，而只是作为一个受苦受难的人；确实，全世界他都没有这样的人。

Alexey Alexandrovitch grew up an orphan. There were two brothers. They did not remember their father, and their mother died when Alexey Alexandrovitch was ten years old. The property was a small one. Their uncle, Karenin, a government official of high standing, at one time a favorite of the late Tsar, had brought them up.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇是个孤儿。有两个兄弟。他们不记得他们的父亲，他们的母亲在阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇十岁时就去世了。房子很小。他们的叔叔卡列宁是一位地位很高的政府官员，曾一度受到已故沙皇的宠爱，将他们抚养长大。

On completing his high school and university courses with medals, Alexey Alexandrovitch had, with his uncle’s aid, immediately started in a prominent position in the service, and from that time forward he had devoted himself exclusively to political ambition. In the high school and the university, and afterwards in the service, Alexey Alexandrovitch had never formed a close friendship with anyone. His brother had been the person nearest to his heart, but he had a post in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and was always abroad, where he had died shortly after Alexey Alexandrovitch’s marriage.
在以奖牌完成高中和大学课程后，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇在叔叔的帮助下，立即开始在军队中担任要职，从那时起，他就完全致力于政治野心。在高中和大学，以及后来的服役中，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇从未与任何人建立过亲密的友谊。他的兄弟是他最亲近的人，但他在外交部任职，而且总是在国外，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇结婚后不久，他就去世了。

While he was governor of a province, Anna’s aunt, a wealthy provincial lady, had thrown him—middle-aged as he was, though young for a governor—with her niece, and had succeeded in putting him in such a position that he had either to declare himself or to leave the town. Alexey Alexandrovitch was not long in hesitation. There were at the time as many reasons for the step as against it, and there was no overbalancing consideration to outweigh his invariable rule of abstaining when in doubt. But Anna’s aunt had through a common acquaintance insinuated that he had already compromised the girl, and that he was in honor bound to make her an offer. He made the offer, and concentrated on his betrothed and his wife all the feeling of which he was capable.
当他担任一个省长时，安娜的姨妈，一位富有的省级女士，把他——尽管他已是中年，但对于省长来说还很年轻——把他和她的侄女扔到了一起，并成功地将他置于这样一个位置：要么宣布自己的身份，要么离开这座城镇。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇并没有犹豫太久。当时，采取这一措施的理由与反对采取这一措施的理由一样多，而且没有任何过度平衡的考虑可以压倒他在有疑问时投弃权票的不变规则。但安娜的姨妈通过一位熟人暗示他已经妥协了这个女孩，并且他有义务向她提出要约。他提出了请求，并把所有的感情都集中在他的未婚夫和他的妻子身上。

The attachment he felt to Anna precluded in his heart every need of intimate relations with others. And now among all his acquaintances he had not one friend. He had plenty of so-called connections, but no friendships. Alexey Alexandrovitch had plenty of people whom he could invite to dinner, to whose sympathy he could appeal in any public affair he was concerned about, whose interest he could reckon upon for anyone he wished to help, with whom he could candidly discuss other people’s business and affairs of state. But his relations with these people were confined to one clearly defined channel, and had a certain routine from which it was impossible to depart. There was one man, a comrade of his at the university, with whom he had made friends later, and with whom he could have spoken of a personal sorrow; but this friend had a post in the Department of Education in a remote part of Russia. Of the people in Petersburg the most intimate and most possible were his chief secretary and his doctor.
他对安娜的依恋使他内心排除了与他人建立亲密关系的一切需要。现在，在他所有的熟人中，他没有一个朋友。他有很多所谓的关系，但没有友谊。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇有很多人可以邀请他共进晚餐，他可以在他关心的任何公共事务中博取他们的同情，他可以考虑他们对他想要帮助的任何人的兴趣，他可以与他们坦诚地讨论其他人的事情和国家大事。但他与这些人的关系却局限于一个明确的渠道，并且有一定的惯例，无法脱离。有一个人，他在大学时的一位同志，后来与他成为了朋友，他可以与他谈论个人的悲伤；但他却没有。但这位朋友在俄罗斯偏远地区的教育部任职。在彼得堡的人中，最亲密、最可能的就是他的首席秘书和他的医生。

Mihail Vassilievitch Sludin, the chief secretary, was a straightforward, intelligent, good-hearted, and conscientious man, and Alexey Alexandrovitch was aware of his personal goodwill. But their five years of official work together seemed to have put a barrier between them that cut off warmer relations.
首席秘书米哈伊尔·瓦西里耶维奇·斯鲁丁是一个直率、聪明、心地善良、尽职尽责的人，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇也知道他的个人善意。但他们五年的正式合作似乎在他们之间设置了障碍，切断了温暖的关系。

After signing the papers brought him, Alexey Alexandrovitch had sat for a long while in silence, glancing at Mihail Vassilievitch, and several times he attempted to speak, but could not. He had already prepared the phrase: ‘You have heard of my trouble?’ But he ended by saying, as usual: ‘So you’ll get this ready for me?’ and with that dismissed him.
在签署了给他带来的文件后，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇沉默地坐了很长一段时间，看了一眼米哈伊尔·瓦西里耶维奇，好几次试图说话，但说不出来。他已经准备好了这句话：“你听说过我的麻烦了？”但最后他像往常一样说：“那么你会为我准备这个吗？”然后就打发走了他。

The other person was the doctor, who had also a kindly feeling for him; but there had long existed a taciturn understanding between them that both were weighed down by work, and always in a hurry.
另一个人是医生，对他也有好感。但他们之间早已存在着一种沉默的默契，两人都忙于工作，总是匆匆忙忙。

Of his women friends, foremost amongst them Countess Lidia Ivanovna, Alexey Alexandrovitch never thought. All women, simply as women, were terrible and distasteful to him.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇从未想到过他的女性朋友，其中最重要的是莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人。所有的女人，就像女人一样，对他来说都是可怕的和令人厌恶的。

Chapter 22
第22章

Alexey Alexandrovitch had forgotten the Countess Lidia Ivanovna, but she had not forgotten him. At the bitterest moment of his lonely despair she came to him, and without waiting to be announced, walked straight into his study. She found him as he was sitting with his head in both hands.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇忘记了莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人，但她并没有忘记他。在他最孤独绝望的时刻，她来到了他的身边，不等宣布，径直走进了他的书房。她发现他时，他双手抱头坐着。

‘J’ai force la consigne,’ she said, walking in with rapid steps and breathing hard with excitement and rapid exercise. ‘I have heard all! Alexey Alexandrovitch! Dear friend!’ she went on, warmly squeezing his hand in both of hers and gazing with her fine pensive eyes into his.
“J’ai force la consigne，”她说着，迈着快步走进来，因兴奋和快速运动而呼吸急促。 ‘我都听到了！阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇！亲爱的朋友！”她继续说道，用双手温暖地握着他的手，用她沉思的双眸凝视着他。

Alexey Alexandrovitch, frowning, got up, and disengaging his hand, moved her a chair.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇皱着眉头站起来，松开手，给她搬了一张椅子。

‘Won’t you sit down, countess? I’m seeing no one because I’m unwell, countess,’ he said, and his lips twitched.
“您不坐下吗，伯爵夫人？我没有见任何人，因为我身体不舒服，伯爵夫人。”他说道，嘴唇抽动着。

‘Dear friend!’ repeated Countess Lidia Ivanovna, never taking her eyes off his, and suddenly her eyebrows rose at the inner corners, describing a triangle on her forehead, her ugly yellow face became still uglier, but Alexey Alexandrovitch felt that she was sorry for him and was preparing to cry. And he too was softened; he snatched her plump hand and proceeded to kiss it.
“亲爱的朋友！”莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人重复道，眼睛始终没有离开过他的眼睛，突然，她的眉毛从内角升起，在额头上画出一个三角形，她丑陋的黄脸变得更加丑陋，但阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇觉得她很抱歉为了他，准备哭泣。他也软化了；他抓住她胖乎乎的手，开始亲吻。

‘Dear friend!’ she said in a voice breaking with emotion. ‘You ought not to give way to grief. Your sorrow is a great one, but you ought to find consolation.’
“亲爱的朋友！”她声音激动地说。 ‘你不应该屈服于悲伤。你的悲伤是巨大的，但你应该找到安慰。

‘I am crushed, I am annihilated, I am no longer a man!’ said Alexey Alexandrovitch, letting go her hand, but still gazing into her brimming eyes. ‘My position is so awful because I can find nowhere, I cannot find within me strength to support me.’
“我被压垮了，我被消灭了，我不再是一个男人了！”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇说，松开了手，但仍然凝视着她那双泛着泪光的眼睛。 “我的处境非常糟糕，因为我无处可去，我找不到内心的力量来支持我。”

‘You will find support; seek it—not in me, though I beseech you to believe in my friendship,’ she said, with a sigh. ‘Our support is love, that love that He has vouchsafed us. His burden is light,’ she said, with the look of ecstasy Alexey Alexandrovitch knew so well. ‘He will be your support and your succor.’
‘你会找到支持；寻求它——不是在我身上，尽管我恳求你相信我的友谊，”她叹了口气说。 ‘我们的支持是爱，是他赐予我们的爱。他的负担很轻。”她说道，脸上带着阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇熟悉的狂喜神情。 “他将成为你的支持和帮助。”

Although there was in these words a flavor of that sentimental emotion at her own lofty feelings, and that new mystical fervor which had lately gained ground in Petersburg, and which seemed to Alexey Alexandrovitch disproportionate, still it was pleasant to him to hear this now.
虽然这些话里有她自己的崇高感情的感伤情绪，还有最近在彼得堡流行起来的新的神秘热情，这在阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇看来是不相称的，但现在听到这些对他来说仍然很愉快。

‘I am weak. I am crushed. I foresaw nothing, and now I understand nothing.’
'我没有力气。我心碎了。我什么也没预见到，现在我什么也不明白。”

‘Dear friend,’ repeated Lidia Ivanovna.
“亲爱的朋友，”莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜重复道。

‘It’s not the loss of what I have not now, it’s not that!’ pursued Alexey Alexandrovitch. ‘I do not grieve for that. But I cannot help feeling humiliated before other people for the position I am placed in. It is wrong, but I can’t help it, I can’t help it.’
“这不是失去我现在所没有的东西，不是那个！”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇继续说道。 “我并不为此感到悲伤。但我不禁因为自己所处的位置而在其他人面前感到羞辱。这是错误的，但我无法控制，我无法控制。

‘Not you it was performed that noble act of forgiveness, at which I was moved to ecstasy, and everyone else too, but He, working within your heart,’ said Countess Lidia Ivanovna, raising her eyes rapturously, ‘and so you cannot be ashamed of your act.’
“不是你，而是他，在你的心里工作，”莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人兴奋地抬起眼睛，“所以你不能对你的行为感到羞耻。

Alexey Alexandrovitch knitted his brows, and crooking his hands, he cracked his fingers.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇皱起眉头，弯曲双手，打响了手指。

‘One must know all the facts,’ he said in his thin voice. ‘A man’s strength has its limits, countess, and I have reached my limits. The whole day I have had to be making arrangements, arrangements about household matters arising’ (he emphasized the word arising) ‘from my new, solitary position. The servants, the governess, the accounts.... These pinpricks have stabbed me to the heart, and I have not the strength to bear it. At dinner... yesterday, I was almost getting up from the dinner table. I could not bear the way my son looked at me. He did not ask me the meaning of it all, but he wanted to ask, and I could not bear the look in his eyes. He was afraid to look at me, but that is not all....’ Alexey Alexandrovitch would have referred to the bill that had been brought him, but his voice shook, and he stopped. That bill on blue paper, for a hat and ribbons, he could not recall without a rush of self-pity.
“一个人必须知道所有的事实，”他用微弱的声音说道。 “一个人的力量是有极限的，伯爵夫人，而我已经达到了极限。一整天我都必须做出安排，安排有关家庭事务的安排，这些事情是从我新的、孤独的位置上发生的（他强调了“发生”这个词）。仆人、家庭教师、账目……这些针刺都刺痛了我的心，我没有力气承受。昨天吃晚饭的时候……我差点就从餐桌上站了起来。我无法忍受儿子看我的眼神。他没有问我这一切的意义，但他想问，我无法忍受他的眼神。他不敢看我，但这还不是全部……”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇本想提到给他带来的账单，但他的声音颤抖着，他停了下来。蓝纸上的那张帽子和丝带的账单，他一想起就感到一阵自怜。

‘I understand, dear friend,’ said Lidia Ivanovna. ‘I understand it all. Succor and comfort you will find not in me, though I have come only to aid you if I can. If I could take from off you all these petty, humiliating cares...I understand that a woman’s word, a woman’s superintendence is needed. You will intrust it to me?’
“我明白，亲爱的朋友，”莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜说。 ‘我全都明白了。你不会在我身上找到帮助和安慰，尽管我来这里只是为了在可能的情况下帮助你。如果我能摆脱你所有这些琐碎的、羞辱性的关心……我明白需要一个女人的话语，一个女人的监督。你会把它托付给我吗？

Silently and gratefully Alexey Alexandrovitch pressed her hand.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇默默地、感激地握住了她的手。

‘Together we will take care of Seryozha. Practical affairs are not my strong point. But I will set to work. I will be your housekeeper. Don’t thank me. I do it not from myself...’
“我们将一起照顾谢廖扎。实际事务不是我的强项。但我会开始工作。我将成为你的管家。别谢我。我不是自己做的……”

‘I cannot help thanking you.’
“我忍不住要感谢你。”

‘But, dear friend, do not give way to the feeling of which you spoke—being ashamed of what is the Christian’s highest glory: he who humbles himself shall be exalted. And you cannot thank me. You must thank Him, and pray to Him for succor. In Him alone we find peace, consolation, salvation, and love,’ she said, and turning her eyes heavenwards, she began praying, as Alexey Alexandrovitch gathered from her silence.
‘但是，亲爱的朋友，不要屈服于你所说的感觉——为基督徒的最高荣耀感到羞耻：谦卑自己的人将被高举。你不能感谢我。你必须感谢他，并祈求他的帮助。唯有在他身上，我们才能找到平安、安慰、救赎和爱。”她说着，将目光转向天空，开始祈祷，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇从沉默中恢复过来。

Alexey Alexandrovitch listened to her now, and those expressions which had seemed to him, if not distasteful, at least exaggerated, now seemed to him natural and consolatory. Alexey Alexandrovitch had disliked this new enthusiastic fervor. He was a believer, who was interested in religion primarily in its political aspect, and the new doctrine which ventured upon several new interpretations, just because it paved the way to discussion and analysis, was in principle disagreeable to him. He had hitherto taken up a cold and even antagonistic attitude to this new doctrine, and with Countess Lidia Ivanovna, who had been carried away by it, he had never argued, but by silence had assiduously parried her attempts to provoke him into argument. Now for the first time he heard her words with pleasure, and did not inwardly oppose them.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇现在听着她说话，那些在他看来即使不是令人反感，至少是夸张的表情，现在对他来说似乎是自然而令人安慰的。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇不喜欢这种新的热情。他是一名信徒，对宗教的兴趣主要在于其政治方面，而新教义冒险提出几种新的解释，只是因为它为讨论和分析铺平了道路，原则上他是不同意的。迄今为止，他对这一新学说一直采取冷漠甚至敌对的态度，对于被新学说迷惑的莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人，他从未争论过，但通过沉默，刻意地阻止了她挑衅他争论的企图。现在他第一次听到她的话感到高兴，并没有内心反对。

‘I am very, very grateful to you, both for your deeds and for your words,’ he said, when she had finished praying.
当她祈祷完毕后，他说：“我非常非常感谢你，无论是你的行为还是你的言语。”

Countess Lidia Ivanovna once more pressed both her friend’s hands.
莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人再次握住了她朋友的双手。

‘Now I will enter upon my duties,’ she said with a smile after a pause, as she wiped away the traces of tears. ‘I am going to Seryozha. Only in the last extremity shall I apply to you.’ And she got up and went out.
“现在我要开始履行我的职责了。”停顿了一下，她擦去泪痕，微笑着说道。 “我要去谢廖扎。只有在最后的绝境中，我才会向你求助。”说完，她起身走了出去。

Countess Lidia Ivanovna went into Seryozha’s part of the house, and dropping tears on the scared child’s cheeks, she told him that his father was a saint and his mother was dead.
莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人走进谢廖扎的房子，泪水滴在了受惊的孩子的脸颊上，她告诉他，他的父亲是一位圣人，而他的母亲已经去世了。

Countess Lidia Ivanovna kept her promise. She did actually take upon herself the care of the organization and management of Alexey Alexandrovitch’s household. But she had not overstated the case when saying that practical affairs were not her strong point. All her arrangements had to be modified because they could not be carried out, and they were modified by Korney, Alexey Alexandrovitch’s valet, who, though no one was aware of the fact, now managed Karenin’s household, and quietly and discreetly reported to his master while he was dressing all it was necessary for him to know. But Lidia Ivanovna’s help was none the less real; she gave Alexey Alexandrovitch moral support in the consciousness of her love and respect for him, and still more, as it was soothing to her to believe, in that she almost turned him to Christianity—that is, from an indifferent and apathetic believer she turned him into an ardent and steadfast adherent of the new interpretation of Christian doctrine, which had been gaining ground of late in Petersburg. It was easy for Alexey Alexandrovitch to believe in this teaching. Alexey Alexandrovitch, like Lidia Ivanovna indeed, and others who shared their views, was completely devoid of vividness of imagination, that spiritual faculty in virtue of which the conceptions evoked by the imagination become so vivid that they must needs be in harmony with other conceptions, and with actual fact. He saw nothing impossible and inconceivable in the idea that death, though existing for unbelievers, did not exist for him, and that, as he was possessed of the most perfect faith, of the measure of which he was himself the judge, therefore there was no sin in his soul, and he was experiencing complete salvation here on earth.
莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人信守了她的诺言。她实际上承担了阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇家庭的组织和管理责任。但她说实际事务不是她的强项，这并没有夸大其词。她的所有安排都必须修改，因为它们无法执行，而这些安排是由阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇的男仆科尔尼修改的，虽然没有人知道这一事实，但他现在管理着卡列宁的家庭，并悄悄地、谨慎地向他的主人报告。当他穿衣服时，他需要知道的一切。但莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜的帮助仍然是真实的。她给了阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇道义上的支持，因为她意识到她对他的爱和尊重，更重要的是，她相信她几乎让他皈依了基督教——也就是说，她从一个冷漠和冷漠的信徒变成了基督教徒。他成为基督教教义新解释的热心而坚定的追随者，这种解释最近在彼得堡逐渐流行。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇很容易相信这一教导。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇，确实像莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜和其他分享他们观点的人一样，完全缺乏生动的想象力，凭借这种精神能力，想象所引发的概念变得如此生动，以至于它们必须与其他概念相协调，并以事实为依据。他认为，死亡虽然存在于非信徒身上，但对他来说并不存在，而且，由于他拥有最完美的信仰，他自己对信仰的程度有自己的判断，因此死亡对于他来说并不存在，这并不是什么不可能和不可思议的事情。他的灵魂中没有罪，他在地球上经历了完全的拯救。

It is true that the erroneousness and shallowness of this conception of his faith was dimly perceptible to Alexey Alexandrovitch, and he knew that when, without the slightest idea that his forgiveness was the action of a higher power, he had surrendered directly to the feeling of forgiveness, he had felt more happiness than now when he was thinking every instant that Christ was in his heart, and that in signing official papers he was doing His will. But for Alexey Alexandrovitch it was a necessity to think in that way; it was such a necessity for him in his humiliation to have some elevated standpoint, however imaginary, from which, looked down upon by all, he could look down on others, that he clung, as to his one salvation, to his delusion of salvation.
确实，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇隐隐约约地感觉到他的这种信仰观念的错误和肤浅，他知道，当他没有丝毫意识到他的宽恕是更高权力的行为时，他直接屈服于一种感觉当他每时每刻想到基督在他心里，在签署正式文件时，他正在遵行他的旨意时，他比现在感到更加幸福。但对于阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇来说，有必要以这种方式思考。他在屈辱中必须有某种崇高的立场，无论多么虚幻，在所有人都瞧不起的情况下，他可以从这个立场上看别人，因此他坚持认为自己只有一个救赎，坚持自己对救赎的幻想。 。

Chapter 23
第23章

The Countess Lidia Ivanovna had, as a very young and sentimental girl, been married to a wealthy man of high rank, an extremely good-natured, jovial, and extremely dissipated rake. Two months after marriage her husband abandoned her, and her impassioned protestations of affection he met with a sarcasm and even hostility that people knowing the count’s good heart, and seeing no defects in the sentimental Lidia, were at a loss to explain. Though they were divorced and lived apart, yet whenever the husband met the wife, he invariably behaved to her with the same malignant irony, the cause of which was incomprehensible.
莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人是个非常年轻、多愁善感的女孩，嫁给了一个地位很高的富翁，一个脾气非常好、快活、极其放荡的浪荡子。结婚两个月后，她的丈夫抛弃了她，而她慷慨激昂的爱意表达却遭到了讽刺甚至敌意，人们知道伯爵的善良心肠，也看不出多愁善感的莉迪亚身上没有任何缺陷，因此无法解释。虽然他们离婚分居，但丈夫每次见到妻子时，总是用同样恶毒的讽刺态度对待她，其原因令人费解。

Countess Lidia Ivanovna had long given up being in love with her husband, but from that time she had never given up being in love with someone. She was in love with several people at once, both men and women; she had been in love with almost everyone who had been particularly distinguished in any way. She was in love with all the new princes and princesses who married into the imperial family; she had been in love with a high dignitary of the Church, a vicar, and a parish priest; she had been in love with a journalist, three Slavophiles, with Komissarov, with a minister, a doctor, an English missionary and Karenin. All these passions constantly waning or growing more ardent, did not prevent her from keeping up the most extended and complicated relations with the court and fashionable society. But from the time that after Karenin’s trouble she took him under her special protection, from the time that she set to work in Karenin’s household looking after his welfare, she felt that all her other attachments were not the real thing, and that she was now genuinely in love, and with no one but Karenin. The feeling she now experienced for him seemed to her stronger than any of her former feelings. Analyzing her feeling, and comparing it with former passions, she distinctly perceived that she would not have been in love with Komissarov if he had not saved the life of the Tsar, that she would not have been in love with Ristitch-Kudzhitsky if there had been no Slavonic question, but that she loved Karenin for himself, for his lofty, uncomprehended soul, for the sweet—to her—high notes of his voice, for his drawling intonation, his weary eyes, his character, and his soft white hands with their swollen veins. She was not simply overjoyed at meeting him, but she sought in his face signs of the impression she was making on him. She tried to please him, not by her words only, but in her whole person. For his sake it was that she now lavished more care on her dress than before. She caught herself in reveries on what might have been, if she had not been married and he had been free. She blushed with emotion when he came into the room, she could not repress a smile of rapture when he said anything amiable to her.
莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人早已放弃了对丈夫的爱，但从那时起，她就从未放弃过爱一个人。她同时爱上了好几个人，有男人也有女人。她几乎爱上了所有在任何方面都特别杰出的人。她爱上了所有嫁入皇室的新王子和公主；她曾爱上一位教会高官、一位牧师和一位教区牧师。她爱上了一名记者、三个斯拉夫主义者、科米萨罗夫、一名牧师、一名医生、一名英国传教士和卡列宁。所有这些热情不断减弱或变得更加热烈，并没有阻止她与宫廷和上流社会保持着最广泛和最复杂的关系。但自从卡列宁出事之后，她把他置于自己的特殊保护之下，从她开始在卡列宁家里工作，照顾他的福利开始，她就觉得她所有的其他执着都不是真的，她现在是真心相爱，除了卡列宁以外谁也不爱。她现在对他的感觉似乎比她以前的任何感觉都强烈。通过分析自己的感受，并与以前的激情进行比较，她清楚地意识到，如果科米萨罗夫没有救沙皇的命，她就不会爱上他；如果有，她也不会爱上里斯蒂奇-库吉茨基。这不是斯拉夫式的问题，而是她爱卡列宁，因为他自己，因为他崇高而不被理解的灵魂，因为他甜美的高音调，因为他慢吞吞的语调，他疲倦的眼睛，他的性格，还有他柔软白皙的双手。和他们肿胀的静脉。 她不仅因为见到他而欣喜若狂，而且还从他的脸上寻找她给他留下的印象的迹象。她试图取悦他，不仅仅是用言语，而是用她的整个人。为了他，她现在对自己的衣着比以前更加用心了。她陷入了遐想，如果她没有结婚，而他没有自由的话，会发生什么。当他走进房间时，她激动得满脸通红，当他对她说些亲切的话时，她无法抑制住欣喜若狂的微笑。

For several days now Countess Lidia Ivanovna had been in a state of intense excitement. She had learned that Anna and Vronsky were in Petersburg. Alexey Alexandrovitch must be saved from seeing her, he must be saved even from the torturing knowledge that that awful woman was in the same town with him, and that he might meet her any minute.
几天来，莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人一直处于极度兴奋的状态。她得知安娜和渥伦斯基在彼得堡。必须避免阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇见到她，甚至必须避免让他知道那个可怕的女人和他在同一个城镇，而且他随时都可能见到她。

Lidia Ivanovna made inquiries through her friends as to what those infamous people, as she called Anna and Vronsky, intended doing, and she endeavored so to guide every movement of her friend during those days that he could not come across them. The young adjutant, an acquaintance of Vronsky, through whom she obtained her information, and who hoped through Countess Lidia Ivanovna to obtain a concession, told her that they had finished their business and were going away next day. Lidia Ivanovna had already begun to calm down, when the next morning a note was brought her, the handwriting of which she recognized with horror. It was the handwriting of Anna Karenina. The envelope was of paper as thick as bark; on the oblong yellow paper there was a huge monogram, and the letter smelt of agreeable scent.
莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜通过她的朋友询问那些臭名昭著的人，她称之为安娜和渥伦斯基，打算做什么，并且她努力引导她的朋友在那些日子里的一举一动，以免他遇到他们。这位年轻的副官是渥伦斯基的熟人，她通过他获得了情报，并希望通过莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人获得让步，告诉她他们已经完成了任务，第二天就要离开。第二天早上，莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜收到一张纸条，她已经开始平静下来，上面的笔迹让她惊恐万状。这是安娜·卡列尼娜的笔迹。信封是用像树皮一样厚的纸制成的。长方形的黄纸上有一个巨大的字母组合，信上散发着宜人的香味。

‘Who brought it?’
“谁带来的？”

‘A commissionaire from the hotel.’
“酒店的一名门卫。”

It was some time before Countess Lidia Ivanovna could sit down to read the letter. Her excitement brought on an attack of asthma, to which she was subject. When she had recovered her composure, she read the following letter in French:
过了一段时间，莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人才坐下来读这封信。她的兴奋导致了哮喘发作，她也因此患上了哮喘。当她恢复平静后，她读了下面的法语信：

‘Madame la Comtesse,
“伯爵夫人，

‘The Christian feelings with which your heart is filled give me the, I feel, unpardonable boldness to write to you. I am miserable at being separated from my son. I entreat permission to see him once before my departure. Forgive me for recalling myself to your memory. I apply to you and not to Alexey Alexandrovitch, simply because I do not wish to cause that generous man to suffer in remembering me. Knowing your friendship for him, I know you will understand me. Could you send Seryozha to me, or should I come to the house at some fixed hour, or will you let me know when and where I could see him away from home? I do not anticipate a refusal, knowing the magnanimity of him with whom it rests. You cannot conceive the craving I have to see him, and so cannot conceive the gratitude your help will arouse in me.
“我觉得，你内心充满的基督徒情感给了我不可原谅的勇气给你写信。我因与儿子分离而感到痛苦。我恳求他允许我在出发前见他一次。请原谅我让我想起了你的记忆。我向你提出请求，而不是向阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇提出请求，只是因为我不想让那个慷慨的人在记住我时遭受痛苦。知道你对他的友谊，我知道你会理解我。你能否派谢廖扎来见我，或者我应该在某个固定时间到你家来，或者你能让我知道何时何地我可以在外地见到他吗？我不认为他会拒绝，因为我知道他的宽宏大量。你无法想象我有多么渴望见到他，因此也无法想象你的帮助会激起我的感激之情。

Anna”
安娜”

Everything in this letter exasperated Countess Lidia Ivanovna: its contents and the allusion to magnanimity, and especially its free and easy—as she considered—tone.
这封信中的一切都激怒了莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人：它的内容和对宽宏大量的暗示，尤其是它自由和轻松的语气——正如她认为的那样。

‘Say that there is no answer,’ said Countess Lidia Ivanovna, and immediately opening her blotting-book, she wrote to Alexey Alexandrovitch that she hoped to see him at one o’clock at the levee.
“说没有答案，”莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人说，立即打开她的记事本，她写信给阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇，说她希望一点钟在堤坝见到他。

‘I must talk with you of a grave and painful subject. There we will arrange where to meet. Best of all at my house, where I will order tea as you like it. Urgent. He lays the cross, but He gives the strength to bear it,’ she added, so as to give him some slight preparation. Countess Lidia Ivanovna usually wrote some two or three letters a day to Alexey Alexandrovitch. She enjoyed that form of communication, which gave opportunity for a refinement and air of mystery not afforded by their personal interviews.
“我必须和你谈谈一个严肃而痛苦的话题。在那里我们将安排见面地点。最棒的是在我家，我会根据你的喜好点茶。紧迫的。他放下十字架，但他赐予力量来背负它，”她补充道，以便给他一些轻微的准备。莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人通常每天给阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇写两三封信。她喜欢这种交流方式，这种交流方式让她有机会感受到个人采访所没有的精致和神秘气氛。

Chapter 24
第24章

The levee was drawing to a close. People met as they were going away, and gossiped of the latest news, of the newly bestowed honors and the changes in the positions of the higher functionaries.
堤坝即将关闭。人们在离开时相聚，谈论最新的消息、新授予的荣誉和高级官员职位的变动。

‘If only Countess Marya Borissovna were Minister of War, and Princess Vatkovskaya were Commander-in-Chief,’ said a gray-headed, little old man in a gold-embroidered uniform, addressing a tall, handsome maid of honor who had questioned him about the new appointments.
“要是玛丽亚·鲍里索夫娜伯爵夫人当战争部长，瓦特科夫斯卡娅公主当总司令就好了。”一位身穿金绣制服、头发花白的小老头对一位高大英俊的伴娘说道。关于新的任命。

‘And me among the adjutants,’ said the maid of honor, smiling.
“我也在副官之中，”伴娘微笑着说道。

‘You have an appointment already. You’re over the ecclesiastical department. And your assistant’s Karenin.’
‘你已经有预约了。你是在教会部门。你的助手是卡列宁。

‘Good-day, prince!’ said the little old man to a man who came up to him.
“再见，王子！”小老头对一个向他走来的人说道。

‘What were you saying of Karenin?’ said the prince.
“你对卡列宁说了什么？”王子问道。

‘He and Putyatov have received the Alexander Nevsky.’
“他和普佳托夫收到了亚历山大·涅夫斯基号。”

‘I thought he had it already.’
“我以为他已经有了。”

‘No. Just look at him,’ said the little old man, pointing with his embroidered hat to Karenin in a court uniform with the new red ribbon across his shoulders, standing in the doorway of the hall with an influential member of the Imperial Council. ‘Pleased and happy as a brass farthing,’ he added, stopping to shake hands with a handsome gentleman of the bedchamber of colossal proportions.
'不。看看他，”小老头用绣花帽子指着穿着宫廷制服、肩上系着新红丝带的卡列宁说，卡列宁和一位帝国议会中颇有影响力的成员站在大厅门口。 “高兴极了，”他补充道，停下来与卧室里一位身材魁梧的英俊绅士握手。

‘No; he’s looking older,’ said the gentleman of the bedchamber.
'不; “他看上去老了。”寝室的绅士说道。

‘From overwork. He’s always drawing up projects nowadays. He won’t let a poor devil go nowadays till he’s explained it all to him under heads.’
‘由于过度劳累。他现在总是在制定项目。如今他不会放过一个可怜的家伙，除非他在头下向他解释清楚这一切。”

‘Looking older, did you say? Il fait des passions. I believe Countess Lidia Ivanovna’s jealous now of his wife.’
‘你说看起来更老了？ Il fait des 激情。我相信莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人现在嫉妒他的妻子。

‘Oh, come now, please don’t say any harm of Countess Lidia Ivanovna.’
“噢，得了吧，请不要说莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人的坏话。”

‘Why, is there any harm in her being in love with Karenin?’
“为什么，她爱上卡列宁有什么坏处吗？”

‘But is it true Madame Karenina’s here?’
“但是卡列尼娜夫人真的在这里吗？”

‘Well, not here in the palace, but in Petersburg. I met her yesterday with Alexey Vronsky, bras dessous, bras dessous, in the Morsky.’
“嗯，不是在皇宫，而是在彼得堡。昨天我和阿列克谢·渥伦斯基（Alexey Vronsky）在莫斯基（Morsky）见过她。

‘C’est un homme qui n’a pas...’ the gentleman of the bedchamber was beginning, but he stopped to make room, bowing, for a member of the Imperial family to pass.
“C'est un homme qui n'a pas...”这位寝宫绅士刚开始说，但他停下来，鞠躬，让出空间，让一位皇室成员通过。

Thus people talked incessantly of Alexey Alexandrovitch, finding fault with him and laughing at him, while he, blocking up the way of the member of the Imperial Council he had captured, was explaining to him point by point his new financial project, never interrupting his discourse for an instant for fear he should escape.
因此，人们不断地谈论阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇，找他的毛病，嘲笑他，而他却挡住了他抓获的帝国议会成员的去路，向他逐条解释他的新金融计划，从不打断他的谈话。谈话片刻，生怕他会逃跑。

Almost at the same time that his wife left Alexey Alexandrovitch there had come to him that bitterest moment in the life of an official—the moment when his upward career comes to a full stop. This full stop had arrived and everyone perceived it, but Alexey Alexandrovitch himself was not yet aware that his career was over. Whether it was due to his feud with Stremov, or his misfortune with his wife, or simply that Alexey Alexandrovitch had reached his destined limits, it had become evident to everyone in the course of that year that his career was at an end. He still filled a position of consequence, he sat on many commissions and committees, but he was a man whose day was over, and from whom nothing was expected. Whatever he said, whatever he proposed, was heard as though it were something long familiar, and the very thing that was not needed. But Alexey Alexandrovitch was not aware of this, and, on the contrary, being cut off from direct participation in governmental activity, he saw more clearly than ever the errors and defects in the action of others, and thought it his duty to point out means for their correction. Shortly after his separation from his wife, he began writing his first note on the new judicial procedure, the first of the endless series of notes he was destined to write in the future.
几乎在他的妻子离开阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇的同时，他也迎来了官员生涯中最痛苦的时刻——他的上升生涯完全停止的时刻。这个句号已经到来，每个人都意识到了这一点，但阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇本人还没有意识到他的职业生涯已经结束。无论是因为他与斯特列莫夫的不和，还是他与妻子的不幸，或者仅仅是阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇已经达到了他注定的极限，在那一年里，每个人都清楚地意识到他的职业生涯已经结束了。他仍然担任着重要的职务，担任过许多委员会的职务，但他的日子已经结束了，人们对他没有任何期望。无论他说什么，无论他提出什么建议，人们听上去都像是早已熟悉的事情，而且根本不需要。但阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇并没有意识到这一点，相反，由于无法直接参与政府活动，他比以往任何时候都更清楚地看到其他人行为中的错误和缺陷，并认为他有责任指出方法供他们纠正。与妻子分居后不久，他开始写关于新司法程序的第一篇笔记，这是他将来注定要写的无数笔记中的第一篇。

Alexey Alexandrovitch did not merely fail to observe his hopeless position in the official world, he was not merely free from anxiety on this head, he was positively more satisfied than ever with his own activity.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇不仅没有看到他在官方世界中的绝望处境，他不仅没有在这方面的焦虑，而且他对自己的活动比以往任何时候都更加满意。

‘He that is unmarried careth for the things that belong to the Lord, how he may please the Lord: But he that is married careth for the things that are of the world, how he may please his wife,’ says the Apostle Paul, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, who was now guided in every action by Scripture, often recalled this text. It seemed to him that ever since he had been left without a wife, he had in these very projects of reform been serving the Lord more zealously than before.
使徒保罗说：“未婚的，思虑主的事，如何叫主喜悦；已婚的，思虑属世的事，如何叫妻子喜悦。”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇现在的每一个行动都以圣经为指导，经常回忆起这段经文。在他看来，自从他失去妻子以来，他在这些改革计划中似乎比以前更加热心地侍奉主。

The unmistakable impatience of the member of the Council trying to get away from him did not trouble Alexey Alexandrovitch; he gave up his exposition only when the member of the Council, seizing his chance when one of the Imperial family was passing, slipped away from him.
委员会成员试图摆脱他的明显不耐烦并没有困扰阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇；直到一名枢密院成员趁一位皇室成员经过时趁机从他身边溜走时，他才放弃了阐述。

Left alone, Alexey Alexandrovitch looked down, collecting his thoughts, then looked casually about him and walked towards the door, where he hoped to meet Countess Lidia Ivanovna.
只剩下阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇低下头，整理思绪，然后漫不经心地环视四周，朝门口走去，他希望在那里见到莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人。

‘And how strong they all are, how sound physically,’ thought Alexey Alexandrovitch, looking at the powerfully built gentleman of the bedchamber with his well-combed, perfumed whiskers, and at the red neck of the prince, pinched by his tight uniform. He had to pass them on his way. ‘Truly is it said that all the world is evil,’ he thought, with another sidelong glance at the calves of the gentleman of the bedchamber.
“他们都多么强壮，身体多么健康啊，”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇一边想，一边看着这位身材魁梧、留着精心梳理、散发着香味的胡须的寝室绅士，又看着王子被紧身制服掐着的红脖子。他必须在路上经过他们。 “确实是说，全世界都是邪恶的。”他一边想，一边又斜眼看了一眼寝宫绅士的小腿。

Moving forward deliberately, Alexey Alexandrovitch bowed with his customary air of weariness and dignity to the gentleman who had been talking about him, and looking towards the door, his eyes sought Countess Lidia Ivanovna.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇小心翼翼地向前走去，以他一贯的疲倦和尊严的神情向那位正在谈论他的绅士鞠了一躬，他的目光望向门口，目光寻找着莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人。

‘Ah! Alexey Alexandrovitch!’ said the little old man, with a malicious light in his eyes, at the moment when Karenin was on a level with them, and was nodding with a frigid gesture, ‘I haven’t congratulated you yet,’ said the old man, pointing to his newly received ribbon.
'啊！阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇！”正当卡列宁和他们平起平坐，冷冷地点头的时候，小老头说道，眼里闪着恶意的光芒，“我还没有向你表示祝贺呢，”老人指着他新收到的丝带。

‘Thank you,’ answered Alexey Alexandrovitch. ‘What an exquisite day to-day,’ he added, laying emphasis in his peculiar way on the word exquisite.
“谢谢你，”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇回答。 “今天真是美好的一天，”他补充道，并以他独特的方式强调了“精致”这个词。

That they laughed at him he was well aware, but he did not expect anything but hostility from them; he was used to that by now.
他很清楚他们在嘲笑他，但他没想到他们除了敌意之外还有别的什么。他现在已经习惯了。

Catching sight of the yellow shoulders of Lidia Ivanovna jutting out above her corset, and her fine pensive eyes bidding him to her, Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled, revealing untarnished white teeth, and went towards her.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇看到莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜黄色的肩膀从她的紧身胸衣上突出来，她那双沉思的漂亮眼睛向她招呼着他，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇微笑着，露出洁白的牙齿，朝她走去。

Lidia Ivanovna’s dress had cost her great pains, as indeed all her dresses had done of late. Her aim in dress was now quite the reverse of that she had pursued thirty years before. Then her desire had been to adorn herself with something, and the more adorned the better. Now, on the contrary, she was perforce decked out in a way so inconsistent with her age and her figure, that her one anxiety was to contrive that the contrast between these adornments and her own exterior should not be too appalling. And as far as Alexey Alexandrovitch was concerned she succeeded, and was in his eyes attractive. For him she was the one island not only of goodwill to him, but of love in the midst of the sea of hostility and jeering that surrounded him.
莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜的这件衣服让她付出了巨大的努力，事实上她最近所有的衣服都是如此。她现在的着装目标与她三十年前所追求的目标完全相反。然后她的愿望就是用一些东西来装饰自己，而且装饰得越多越好。现在，相反，她的打扮被迫与她的年龄和身材如此不相称，以至于她唯一的焦虑就是设法使这些装饰与她自己的外表之间的对比不至于太令人震惊。就阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇而言，她成功了，并且在他眼中很有吸引力。对他来说，她不仅是对他善意的一座岛屿，而且是在他周围的敌意和嘲笑的海洋中唯一的一座爱之岛。

Passing through rows of ironical eyes, he was drawn as naturally to her loving glance as a plant to the sun.
穿过一排排讽刺的眼睛，他自然地被她充满爱意的目光吸引，就像植物被阳光吸引一样。

‘I congratulate you,’ she said to him, her eyes on his ribbon.
“我祝贺你，”她对他说，眼睛盯着他的丝带。

Suppressing a smile of pleasure, he shrugged his shoulders, closing his eyes, as though to say that that could not be a source of joy to him. Countess Lidia Ivanovna was very well aware that it was one of his chief sources of satisfaction, though he never admitted it.
他强忍住一抹愉悦的微笑，耸了耸肩，闭上了眼睛，仿佛在说这不能成为他快乐的源泉。莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人非常清楚，这是他满足的主要来源之一，尽管他从未承认这一点。

‘How is our angel?’ said Countess Lidia Ivanovna, meaning Seryozha.
“我们的天使怎么样？”莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人说，指的是谢廖扎。

‘I can’t say I was quite pleased with him,’ said Alexey Alexandrovitch, raising his eyebrows and opening his eyes. ‘And Sitnikov is not satisfied with him.’ (Sitnikov was the tutor to whom Seryozha’s secular education had been intrusted.) ‘As I have mentioned to you, there’s a sort of coldness in him towards the most important questions which ought to touch the heart of every man and every child....’ Alexey Alexandrovitch began expounding his views on the sole question that interested him besides the service—the education of his son.
“我不能说我对他很满意，”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇扬起眉毛，睁开眼睛说道。 “西特尼科夫对他并不满意。”（西特尼科夫是谢廖扎的世俗教育的导师。）“正如我向你提到的，他对最重要的问题有一种冷漠，这些问题应该触及到每个男人和每个孩子的心……”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇开始阐述他对除了服务之外唯一让他感兴趣的问题的看法——他儿子的教育。

When Alexey Alexandrovitch with Lidia Ivanovna’s help had been brought back anew to life and activity, he felt it his duty to undertake the education of the son left on his hands. Having never before taken any interest in educational questions, Alexey Alexandrovitch devoted some time to the theoretical study of the subject. After reading several books on anthropology, education, and didactics, Alexey Alexandrovitch drew up a plan of education, and engaging the best tutor in Petersburg to superintend it, he set to work, and the subject continually absorbed him.
当阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇在莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜的帮助下重新恢复生机和活动时，他觉得自己有责任承担起教育他手上儿子的责任。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇以前从未对教育问题感兴趣，但他花了一些时间对该主题进行理​​论研究。在阅读了几本关于人类学、教育学和教学法的书籍后，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇制定了一个教育计划，并聘请了彼得堡最好的导师来监督该计划，他开始工作，这个主题不断地吸引着他。

‘Yes, but the heart. I see in him his father’s heart, and with such a heart a child cannot go far wrong,’ said Lidia Ivanovna with enthusiasm.
‘是的，但是心。我在他身上看到了他父亲的心，有了这样的心，孩子就不会走得太远。”莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜热情地说。

‘Yes, perhaps.... As for me, I do my duty. It’s all I can do.’
“是的，也许……至于我，我尽我的职责。”这就是我所能做的。

‘You’re coming to me,’ said Countess Lidia Ivanovna, after a pause; ‘we have to speak of a subject painful for you. I would give anything to have spared you certain memories, but others are not of the same mind. I have received a letter from her. She is here in Petersburg.’
“你来找我了，”莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人停顿了一下后说道。 “我们必须谈论一个让你痛苦的话题。我愿意付出一切来让你免受某些记忆的困扰，但其他人却并不这么想。我收到了她的来信。她在彼得堡。”

Alexey Alexandrovitch shuddered at the allusion to his wife, but immediately his face assumed the deathlike rigidity which expressed utter helplessness in the matter.
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇一提到他的妻子，就浑身发抖，但他的脸立刻呈现出死一般的僵硬，表明他对这件事完全无能为力。

‘I was expecting it,’ he said.
“我早就料到了，”他说。

Countess Lidia Ivanovna looked at him ecstatically, and tears of rapture at the greatness of his soul came into her eyes.
莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人欣喜若狂地看着他，眼中流下了因他灵魂的伟大而欣喜若狂的泪水。

Chapter 25
第25章

When Alexey Alexandrovitch came into the Countess Lidia Ivanovna’s snug little boudoir, decorated with old china and hung with portraits, the lady herself had not yet made her appearance.
当阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇走进莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人舒适的小闺房时，她的闺房里装饰着旧瓷器，挂着肖像，而这位女士本人还没有出现。

She was changing her dress.
她正在换衣服。

A cloth was laid on a round table, and on it stood a china tea service and a silver spirit-lamp and tea kettle. Alexey Alexandrovitch looked idly about at the endless familiar portraits which adorned the room, and sitting down to the table, he opened a New Testament lying upon it. The rustle of the countess’s silk skirt drew his attention off.
圆桌上铺着一块布，上面放着瓷制茶具、银制酒精灯和茶壶。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇漫不经心地看着装饰房间的无数熟悉的肖像，然后坐在桌边，打开了放在上面的一本新约圣经。伯爵夫人丝绸裙子的沙沙声转移了他的注意力。

‘Well now, we can sit quietly,’ said Countess Lidia Ivanovna, slipping hurriedly with an agitated smile between the table and the sofa, ‘and talk over our tea.’
“好了，现在我们可以安静地坐着了，”莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人带着焦躁的微笑匆匆溜进桌子和沙发之间，“一边喝茶一边聊天。”

After some words of preparation, Countess Lidia Ivanovna, breathing hard and flushing crimson, gave into Alexey Alexandrovitch’s hands the letter she had received.
一番准备之后，莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人气喘吁吁，脸色涨得通红，把她收到的信交给了阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇。

After reading the letter, he sat a long while in silence.
读完信后，他沉默地坐了良久。

‘I don’t think I have the right to refuse her,’ he said, timidly lifting his eyes.
“我认为我没有权利拒绝她，”他胆怯地抬起眼睛说道。

‘Dear friend, you never see evil in anyone!’
“亲爱的朋友，你永远看不到任何人的邪恶！”

‘On the contrary, I see that all is evil. But whether it is just...’
‘相反，我看到一切都是邪恶的。但是否只是……”

His face showed irresolution, and a seeking for counsel, support, and guidance in a matter he did not understand.
他的脸上表现出优柔寡断，并在他不理解的事情上寻求建议、支持和指导。

‘No,’ Countess Lidia Ivanovna interrupted him; ‘there are limits to everything. I can understand immorality,’ she said, not quite truthfully, since she never could understand that which leads women to immorality; ‘but I don’t understand cruelty: to whom? to you! How can she stay in the town where you are? No, the longer one lives the more one learns. And I’m learning to understand your loftiness and her baseness.’
“不，”莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人打断了他。 ‘凡事都有限度。我可以理解不道德，”她说，但并不完全真实，因为她永远无法理解是什么导致了女人不道德。 “但我不明白残酷：对谁？给你！她怎么能留在你所在的小镇呢？不，人活得越久，学到的东西就越多。我正在学习理解你的崇高和她的卑鄙。

‘Who is to throw a stone?’ said Alexey Alexandrovitch, unmistakably pleased with the part he had to play. ‘I have forgiven all, and so I cannot deprive her of what is exacted by love in her—by her love for her son....’
“谁来扔石头？”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇说道，他对自己所扮演的角色显然很满意。 “我已经原谅了一切，所以我不能剥夺她因爱而付出的一切——她对儿子的爱……”

‘But is that love, my friend? Is it sincere? Admitting that you have forgiven—that you forgive—have we the right to work on the feelings of that angel? He looks on her as dead. He prays for her, and beseeches God to have mercy on her sins. And it is better so. But now what will he think?’
“但这就是爱吗，我的朋友？是真诚的吗？承认你已经宽恕了——你宽恕了——我们有权利去影响那个天使的感受吗？他看她就像死了一样。他为她祈祷，恳求上帝怜悯她的罪孽。这样做更好。但现在他会怎么想？

‘I had not thought of that,’ said Alexey Alexandrovitch, evidently agreeing.
“我没想到这一点，”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇说道，显然同意这一点。

Countess Lidia Ivanovna hid her face in her hands and was silent. she was praying.
莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人用手捂住脸，一声不吭。她正在祈祷。

‘If you ask my advice,’ she said, having finished her prayer and uncovered her face, ‘I do not advise you to do this. Do you suppose I don’t see how you are suffering, how this has torn open your wounds? But supposing that, as always, you don’t think of yourself, what can it lead to?—to fresh suffering for you, to torture for the child. If there were a trace of humanity left in her, she ought not to wish for it herself. No, I have no hesitation in saying I advise not, and if you will intrust it to me, I will write to her.’
“如果你征求我的建议，”她完成祈祷并揭开脸说道，“我不建议你这样做。”你以为我没有看到你正在受苦，这如何撕开你的伤口吗？但假设你一如既往地不考虑自己，这会导致什么？——给你带来新的痛苦，给孩子带来折磨。如果她身上还有一丝人性的话，她自己也不应该希望有。不，我会毫不犹豫地说我不建议，如果你愿意把这件事交给我，我会写信给她。

And Alexey Alexandrovitch consented, and Countess Lidia Ivanovna sent the following letter in French:
阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇同意了，莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人用法语寄出了以下信：

‘Dear Madame,
'亲爱的夫人，

‘To be reminded of you might have results for your son in leading to questions on his part which could not be answered without implanting in the child’s soul a spirit of censure towards what should be for him sacred, and therefore I beg you to interpret your husband’s refusal in the spirit of Christian love. I pray to Almighty God to have mercy on you. Countess Lidia”
“提醒你可能会给你的儿子带来一些结果，导致他提出一些问题，如果不在孩子的灵魂中植入一种对他来说神圣的事物的谴责精神，这些问题就无法得到回答，因此我请求你解释一下你的想法。”丈夫本着基督教之爱的精神拒绝了。我祈求全能的上帝怜悯你。莉迪亚伯爵夫人”

This letter attained the secret object which Countess Lidia Ivanovna had concealed from herself. It wounded Anna to the quick.
这封信达到了莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人向自己隐瞒的秘密目的。安娜受了重伤。

For his part, Alexey Alexandrovitch, on returning home from Lidia Ivanovna’s, could not all that day concentrate himself on his usual pursuits, and find that spiritual peace of one saved and believing which he had felt of late.
就阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇而言，从莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜家回家后，一整天他都无法集中精力于他平常的追求，也无法找到他最近感受到的得救和相信的精神平安。

The thought of his wife, who had so greatly sinned against him, and towards whom he had been so saintly, as Countess Lidia Ivanovna had so justly told him, ought not to have troubled him; but he was not easy; he could not understand the book he was reading; he could not drive away harassing recollections of his relations with her, of the mistake which, as it now seemed, he had made in regard to her. The memory of how he had received her confession of infidelity on their way home from the races (especially that he had insisted only on the observance of external decorum, and had not sent a challenge) tortured him like a remorse. He was tortured too by the thought of the letter he had written her; and most of all, his forgiveness, which nobody wanted, and his care of the other man’s child made his heart burn with shame and remorse.
他的妻子对他犯下了如此大的罪，而他对她又是那么圣洁，正如莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人公正地告诉他的那样，一想到她，他不应该感到困扰；因为她对他犯下了如此大的罪，而他对她又是那么圣洁，正如莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人公正地告诉他的那样。但他并不容易；他无法理解他正在读的书；他无法驱散对他与她的关系以及他对她犯下的错误的痛苦回忆。回想起在比赛结束回家的路上，他如何收到她对不忠的坦白（尤其是他坚持只遵守外在礼仪，并没有发出挑战），就像悔恨一样折磨着他。想到自己写给她的那封信，他也感到很痛苦。最重要的是，他的宽恕（没人想要），以及他对对方孩子的照顾，让他的心因羞愧和悔恨而燃烧。

And just the same feeling of shame and regret he felt now, as he reviewed all his past with her, recalling the awkward words in which, after long wavering, he had made her an offer.
当他回顾与她的所有过去，回想起他在长期犹豫之后向她提出要约时的尴尬话语时，他现在也感到同样的羞耻和遗憾。

‘But how have I been to blame?’ he said to himself. And this question always excited another question in him—whether they felt differently, did their loving and marrying differently, these Vronskys and Oblonskys...these gentlemen of the bedchamber, with their fine calves. And there passed before his mind a whole series of these mettlesome, vigorous, selfconfident men, who always and everywhere drew his inquisitive attention in spite of himself. He tried to dispel these thoughts, he tried to persuade himself that he was not living for this transient life, but for the life of eternity, and that there was peace and love in his heart.
“但是我该受什么责备呢？”他自言自语道。这个问题总是在他心中激起另一个问题——他们的感受是否不同，他们的爱情和婚姻是否不同，这些渥伦斯基和奥布隆斯基……这些卧室里的绅士，有着他们漂亮的小腿。他的脑海中浮现出一系列勇敢、充满活力、自信的人，他们时时处处不由自主地吸引着他好奇的注意力。他试图驱散这些念头，他试图说服自己，他活着不是为了这短暂的生命，而是为了永恒的生命，他的心中有平安和爱。

But the fact that he had in this transient, trivial life made, as it seemed to him, a few trivial mistakes tortured him as though the eternal salvation in which he believed had no existence. But this temptation did not last long, and soon there was reestablished once more in Alexey Alexandrovitch’s soul the peace and the elevation by virtue of which he could forget what he did not want to remember.
但在他看来，在这短暂而琐碎的生活中，他犯了一些微不足道的错误，这一事实折磨着他，仿佛他所相信的永恒救赎并不存在。但这种诱惑并没有持续多久，不久，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇的灵魂中再次恢复了平静和崇高，凭借这种平静和提升，他可以忘记他不想记住的事情。

Chapter 26
第26章

‘Well, Kapitonitch?’ said Seryozha, coming back rosy and goodhumored from his walk the day before his birthday, and giving his overcoat to the tall old hall porter, who smiled down at the little person from the height of his long figure. ‘Well, has the bandaged clerk been here today? Did papa see him?’
“怎么样，卡皮托内奇？”谢廖扎说，他从生日前一天散步回来，脸色红润，心情愉快，他把大衣递给高个子的老门房，门房从高高的身材上朝这个小个子微笑。 “嗯，今天那个缠着绷带的店员来过吗？爸爸看到他了吗？

‘He saw him. The minute the chief secretary came out, I announced him,’ said the hall porter with a good-humored wink. ‘Here, I’ll take it off.’
‘他看见了他。首席秘书一出来，我就宣布了他的到来。”大厅搬运工幽默地眨了眨眼说道。 “给，我把它脱下来。”

‘Seryozha!’ said the tutor, stopping in the doorway leading to the inner rooms. ‘Take it off yourself.’ But Seryozha, though he heard his tutor’s feeble voice, did not pay attention to it. He stood keeping hold of the hall porter’s belt, and gazing into his face.
“谢廖扎！”导师停在通往内室的门口说道。 “你自己把它摘下来。”但是谢廖扎虽然听到了导师微弱的声音，却没有在意。他站在那里，抓住门房的腰带，凝视着他的脸。

‘Well, and did papa do what he wanted for him?’
“嗯，爸爸为他做了他想要的事吗？”

The hall porter nodded his head affirmatively. The clerk with his face tied up, who had already been seven times to ask some favor of Alexey Alexandrovitch, interested both Seryozha and the hall porter. Seryozha had come upon him in the hall, and had heard him plaintively beg the hall porter to announce him, saying that he and his children had death staring them in the face.
门房肯定地点点头。那个绑着脸的店员已经七次向阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇求救了，他引起了谢廖扎和门房的兴趣。谢廖扎在大厅里遇见了他，听到他哀怨地请求大厅看门人通知他，说他和他的孩子们正面临着死亡。

Since then Seryozha, having met him a second time in the hall, took great interest in him.
从那时起，谢廖扎在大厅里第二次见到他，就对他产生了极大的兴趣。

‘Well, was he very glad?’ he asked.
“嗯，他很高兴吗？”他问道。

‘Glad? I should think so! Almost dancing as he walked away.’
'高兴的？我应该这么想吧！他走开时几乎跳舞。

‘And has anything been left?’ asked Seryozha, after a pause.
“还剩下什么吗？”停顿了一下，谢廖扎问道。

‘Come, sir,’ said the hall-porter; then with a shake of his head he whispered, ‘Something from the countess.’
“来吧，先生。”门房说道。然后他摇了摇头，低声说道：“伯爵夫人的事。”

Seryozha understood at once that what the hall porter was speaking of was a present from Countess Lidia Ivanovna for his birthday.
谢廖扎立刻明白，门房所说的是莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人送给他的生日礼物。

‘What do you say? Where?’
'你怎么说？在哪里？'

‘Korney took it to your papa. A fine plaything it must be too!’
“科尼把它拿给你爸爸了。它一定也是一个很好的玩具！

‘How big? Like this?’
'多大？像这样？'

‘Rather small, but a fine thing.’
“虽然很小，但很好。”

‘A book.’
'一本书。'

‘No, a thing. Run along, run along, Vassily Lukitch is calling you,’ said the porter, hearing the tutor’s steps approaching, and carefully taking away from his belt the little hand in the glove half pulled off, he signed with his head towards the tutor.
‘不，是一件事。快跑，快跑，瓦西里·卢基奇在叫你。”门房听到导师的脚步声走近，小心翼翼地把戴着手套的小手从腰带上拿开，头朝导师打了个手势。

‘Vassily Lukitch, in a tiny minute!’ answered Seryozha with that gay and loving smile which always won over the conscientious Vassily Lukitch.
“瓦西里·卢基奇，一会儿就到！”谢廖扎回答道，脸上带着愉快而充满爱意的微笑，这总是赢得了认真负责的瓦西里·卢基奇的青睐。

Seryozha was too happy, everything was too delightful for him to be able to help sharing with his friend the porter the family good fortune of which he had heard during his walk in the public gardens from Lidia Ivanovna’s niece. This piece of good news seemed to him particularly important from its coming at the same time with the gladness of the bandaged clerk and his own gladness at toys having come for him. It seemed to Seryozha that this was a day on which everyone ought to be glad and happy.
谢廖扎太高兴了，一切都太令人愉快了，他无法帮助他的看门人朋友分享他在公共花园散步时从莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜的侄女那里听到的家庭幸福。这个好消息对他来说显得特别重要，因为它的到来与缠着绷带的店员的高兴和他自己对玩具送来的高兴同时到来。在谢廖扎看来，这是每个人都应该感到高兴和幸福的一天。

‘You know papa’s received the Alexander Nevsky today?’
“你知道爸爸今天收到了亚历山大涅夫斯基号吗？”

‘To be sure I do! People have been already to congratulate him.’
“我当然愿意！”人们已经向他表示祝贺。

‘And is he glad?’
“他高兴吗？”

‘Glad at the Tsar’s gracious favor! I should think so! It’s a proof he’s deserved it,’ said the porter severely and seriously.
“很高兴得到沙皇的恩惠！我应该这么想吧！这是他应得的证明。”搬运工严肃认真地说道。

Seryozha fell to dreaming, gazing up at the face of the porter, which he had thoroughly studied in every detail, especially the chin that hung down between the gray whiskers, never seen by anyone but Seryozha, who saw him only from below.
谢廖扎陷入了梦乡，抬头凝视着搬运工的脸，他对这张脸的每一个细节都进行了彻底的研究，尤其是灰色胡须之间垂下的下巴，除了谢廖扎之外，其他人都没有见过，谢廖扎只能从下面看到他。

‘Well, and has your daughter been to see you lately?’
“嗯，你女儿最近来看过你吗？”

The porter’s daughter was a ballet dancer.
搬运工的女儿是一名芭蕾舞演员。

‘When is she to come on week-days? They’ve their lessons to learn too. And you’ve your lesson, sir; run along.’
“她工作日什么时候来？他们也有自己的教训要学习。先生，你已经得到教训了；一起跑。

On coming into the room, Seryozha, instead of sitting down to his lessons, told his tutor of his supposition that what had been brought him must be a machine. ‘What do you think?’ he inquired.
进入房间后，谢廖扎没有坐下来听课，而是告诉他的导师，他的假设是给他带来的一定是一台机器。 “你觉得怎么样？”他问道。

But Vassily Lukitch was thinking of nothing but the necessity of learning the grammar lesson for the teacher, who was coming at two.
但瓦西里·卢基奇只想着为两点就要来的老师学习语法课的必要性。

‘No, do just tell me, Vassily Lukitch,’ he asked suddenly, when he was seated at their work table with the book in his hands, ‘what is greater than the Alexander Nevsky? You know papa’s received the Alexander Nevsky?’
“不，瓦西里·卢基奇，请告诉我，”当他坐在他们的工作桌旁，手里拿着书时，他突然问道，“还有什么比《亚历山大·涅夫斯基》更伟大的呢？”你知道爸爸收到了亚历山大·涅夫斯基号吗？

Vassily Lukitch replied that the Vladimir was greater than the Alexander Nevsky.
瓦西里·卢基奇回答说，弗拉基米尔号比亚历山大·涅夫斯基号更伟大。

‘And higher still?’
“还有更高的吗？”

‘Well, highest of all is the Andrey Pervozvanny.’
“嗯，其中最高的是安德烈·佩尔沃兹瓦尼。”

‘And higher than the Andrey?’
“比安德烈号还高？”

‘I don’t know.’
'我不知道。'

‘What, you don’t know?’ and Seryozha, leaning on his elbows, sank into deep meditation.
“什么，你不知道？”谢廖扎用手肘撑着，陷入了沉思。

His meditations were of the most complex and diverse character. He imagined his father’s having suddenly been presented with both the Vladimir and the Andrey today, and in consequence being much better tempered at his lesson, and dreamed how, when he was grown up, he would himself receive all the orders, and what they might invent higher than the Andrey. Directly any higher order were invented, he would win it. They would make a higher one still, and he would immediately win that too.
他的冥想具有最复杂和多样的特征。他想象着他的父亲今天突然遇到了弗拉基米尔和安德烈，因此在他的教训中脾气好多了，并梦想着当他长大后，他将如何亲自接受所有命令，以及他们可能会做什么发明比安德烈更高。一旦发明了任何更高的秩序，他就会赢得它。他们还会做出更高的分数，而他也会立即获胜。

The time passed in such meditations, and when the teacher came, the lesson about the adverbs of place and time and manner of action was not ready, and the teacher was not only displeased, but hurt. This touched Seryozha. He felt he was not to blame for not having learned the lesson; however much he tried, he was utterly unable to do that. As long as the teacher was explaining to him, he believed him and seemed to comprehend, but as soon as he was left alone, he was positively unable to recollect and to understand that the short and familiar word ‘suddenly’ is an adverb of manner of action. Still he was sorry that he had disappointed the teacher.
时间就这样沉思过去，老师来的时候，关于地点、时间副词和动作方式的课还没有准备好，老师不仅不高兴，而且很受伤。这触动了谢廖扎。他觉得自己没有吸取教训并不应该受到责备。无论他如何努力，他都完全无法做到这一点。只要老师给他讲解，他就相信，似乎听懂了，但一离开他，他就完全想不起来，无法理解“突然”这个简短而熟悉的词是一个方式副词。的行动。但他还是很抱歉让老师失望了。

He chose a moment when the teacher was looking in silence at the book.
他选择了老师静静地看书的时刻。

‘Mihail Ivanitch, when is your birthday?’ he asked all, of a sudden.
“米哈伊尔·伊万内奇，你的生日是什么时候？”他突然问道。

‘You’d much better be thinking about your work. Birthdays are of no importance to a rational being. It’s a day like any other on which one has to do one’s work.’
“你最好考虑一下你的工作。生日对于理性的人来说并不重要。这一天就像其他任何一天一样，人们必须完成自己的工作。

Seryozha looked intently at the teacher, at his scanty beard, at his spectacles, which had slipped down below the ridge on his nose, and fell into so deep a reverie that he heard nothing of what the teacher was explaining to him. He knew that the teacher did not think what he said; he felt it from the tone in which it was said. ‘But why have they all agreed to speak just in the same manner always the dreariest and most useless stuff? Why does he keep me off; why doesn’t he love me?’ he asked himself mournfully, and could not think of an answer.
谢廖扎全神贯注地看着老师，看着他稀疏的胡须，看着他的眼镜，眼镜已经滑落到鼻梁以下，他陷入了深深的沉思，以至于他没有听到老师向他解释什么。他知道老师并没有想到他所说的话；他从说话的语气中感觉到了这一点。 “但是为什么他们都同意以同样的方式谈论最沉闷和最无用的东西？他为什么不让我靠近？他为什么不爱我？”他悲伤地问自己，却想不出答案。

Chapter 27
第27章

After the lesson with the grammar teacher came his father’s lesson. While waiting for his father, Seryozha sat at the table playing with a penknife, and fell to dreaming. Among Seryozha’s favorite occupations was searching for his mother during his walks. He did not believe in death generally, and in her death in particular, in spite of what Lidia Ivanovna had told him and his father had confirmed, and it was just because of that, and after he had been told she was dead, that he had begun looking for her when out for a walk. Every woman of full, graceful figure with dark hair was his mother. At the sight of such a woman such a feeling of tenderness was stirred within him that his breath failed him, and tears came into his eyes. And he was on the tiptoe of expectation that she would come up to him, would lift her veil. All her face would be visible, she would smile, she would hug him, he would sniff her fragrance, feel the softness of her arms, and cry with happiness, just as he had one evening lain on her lap while she tickled him, and he laughed and bit her white, ring-covered fingers. Later, when he accidentally learned from his old nurse that his mother was not dead, and his father and Lidia Ivanovna had explained to him that she was dead to him because she was wicked (which he could not possibly believe, because he loved her), he went on seeking her and expecting her in the same way. That day in the public gardens there had been a lady in a lilac veil, whom he had watched with a throbbing heart, believing it to be she as she came towards them along the path. The lady had not come up to them, but had disappeared somewhere. That day, more intensely than ever, Seryozha felt a rush of love for her, and now, waiting for his father, he forgot everything, and cut all round the edge of the table with his penknife, staring straight before him with sparkling eyes and dreaming of her.
语法老师的课结束后，是他父亲的课。在等待父亲的时候，谢廖扎坐在桌边玩着小刀，陷入了梦乡。谢廖扎最喜欢的事情之一就是在散步时寻找他的母亲。他一般不相信死亡，特别是她的死，尽管莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜告诉过他，他的父亲也证实了这一点，也正是因为如此，在他被告知她死了之后，他出去散步时开始寻找她。每一个身材丰满、优美、黑发的女人都是他的母亲。看到这样的女人，他心中涌起一股温柔的感觉，他呼吸困难，泪水涌上眼眶。他踮着脚尖期待着她会走到他身边，揭开面纱。她的整张脸都清晰可见，她会微笑，她会拥抱他，他会闻她的芬芳，感受她手臂的柔软，幸福地哭泣，就像有一天晚上，他躺在她的腿上，她给他挠痒痒，他笑着咬了咬她戴着戒指的白手指。后来，当他无意中从老护士那里得知他的母亲没有死，而他的父亲和莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜向他解释说，她对他来说已经死了，因为她很邪恶（他不可能相信，因为他爱她） ，他继续寻找她，并以同样的方式期待着她。那天，在公共花园里，有一位戴着淡紫色面纱的女士，当她沿着小路向他们走来时，他的心在跳动，他相信那就是她。那位女士并没有走到他们面前，而是消失在了某处。 那天，谢廖扎对她的爱比以往任​​何时候都更加强烈，现在，在等待他的父亲，他忘记了一切，用他的小刀在桌子的边缘上划了一圈，眼睛直直地盯着他，眼睛闪闪发亮。梦见她。

‘Here is your papa!’ said Vassily Lukitch, rousing him.
“这是你的爸爸！”瓦西里·卢基奇叫醒了他。

Seryozha jumped up and went up to his father, and kissing his hand, looked at him intently, trying to discover signs of his joy at receiving the Alexander Nevsky.
谢廖扎跳起来，走到他父亲面前，亲吻他的手，专注地看着他，试图找出他收到亚历山大·涅夫斯基奖章时的喜悦迹象。

‘Did you have a nice walk?’ said Alexey Alexandrovitch, sitting down in his easy chair, pulling the volume of the Old Testament to him and opening it. Although Alexey Alexandrovitch had more than once told Seryozha that every Christian ought to know Scripture history thoroughly, he often referred to the Bible himself during the lesson, and Seryozha observed this.
“你散步愉快吗？”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇说道，他坐在安乐椅上，把《旧约全书》拉到面前打开。尽管阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇不止一次告诉谢廖扎，每个基督徒都应该彻底了解圣经历史，但他在课上经常提到圣经，谢廖扎也注意到了这一点。

‘Yes, it was very nice indeed, papa,’ said Seryozha, sitting sideways on his chair and rocking it, which was forbidden. ‘I saw Nadinka’ (Nadinka was a niece of Lidia Ivanovna’s who was being brought up in her house). ‘She told me you’d been given a new star. Are you glad, papa?’
“是的，这确实非常好，爸爸，”谢廖扎说，一边坐在椅子上，一边摇晃椅子，但这是被禁止的。 “我看到了纳丁卡”（纳丁卡是莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜的侄女，在她家里长大）。 “她告诉我你被授予了一颗新星。爸爸，你高兴吗？

‘First of all, don’t rock your chair, please,’ said Alexey Alexandrovitch. ‘And secondly, it’s not the reward that’s precious, but the work itself. And I could have wished you understood that. If you now are going to work, to study in order to win a reward, then the work will seem hard to you; but when you work’ (Alexey Alexandrovitch, as he spoke, thought of how he had been sustained by a sense of duty through the wearisome labor of the morning, consisting of signing one hundred and eighty papers), ‘loving your work, you will find your reward in it.’
“首先，请不要摇动你的椅子，”阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇说。 “其次，珍贵的不是报酬，而是工作本身。我真希望你能理解这一点。如果你现在去工作、学习是为了获得报酬，那么工作对你来说会显得很辛苦；但是，当你工作时”（阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇在讲话时想到，他是如何通过一上午的繁重劳动（包括签署一百八十份文件）而被一种责任感支撑着的），“热爱你的工作，你就会从中找到你的奖励。

Seryozha’s eyes, that had been shining with gaiety and tenderness, grew dull and dropped before his father’s gaze. This was the same long-familiar tone his father always took with him, and Seryozha had learned by now to fall in with it. His father always talked to him—so Seryozha felt—as though he were addressing some boy of his own imagination, one of those boys that exist in books, utterly unlike himself. And Seryozha always tried with his father to act being the story-book boy.
谢廖扎原本闪烁着欢乐和温柔的眼睛变得暗淡，在父亲的注视下垂了下来。这是他父亲长期以来所熟悉的语气，而谢廖扎现在已经学会了融入这种语气。他的父亲总是对他说话——谢廖扎觉得——就好像他在对自己想象中的某个男孩说话，一个存在于书中的男孩，与他自己完全不同。谢廖扎总是试图和他的父亲一起扮演故事书男孩的角色。

‘You understand that, I hope?’ said his father.
“我希望你明白这一点吗？”他的父亲说道。

‘Yes, papa,’ answered Seryozha, acting the part of the imaginary boy.
“是的，爸爸，”谢廖扎回答道，扮演着想象中的男孩的角色。

The lesson consisted of learning by heart several verses out of the Gospel and the repetition of the beginning of the Old Testament. The verses from the Gospel Seryozha knew fairly well, but at the moment when he was saying them he became so absorbed in watching the sharply protruding, bony knobbiness of his father’s forehead, that he lost the thread, and he transposed the end of one verse and the beginning of another. So it was evident to Alexey Alexandrovitch that he did not understand what he was saying, and that irritated him.
该课程包括背诵福音书中的几节经文以及重复旧约的开头部分。谢廖扎对《福音书》中的诗句了如指掌，但当他说这些诗句的时候，他全神贯注地注视着他父亲额头上突出的骨节，以至于失去了线索，他把一节经文的结尾调换了位置。以及另一个的开始。因此，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇显然不明白自己在说什么，这让他很恼火。

He frowned, and began explaining what Seryozha had heard many times before and never could remember, because he understood it too well, just as that ‘suddenly’ is an adverb of manner of action. Seryozha looked with scared eyes at his father, and could think of nothing but whether his father would make him repeat what he had said, as he sometimes did. And this thought so alarmed Seryozha that he now understood nothing. But his father did not make him repeat it, and passed on to the lesson out of the Old Testament. Seryozha recounted the events themselves well enough, but when he had to answer questions as to what certain events prefigured, he knew nothing, though he had already been punished over this lesson. The passage at which he was utterly unable to say anything, and began fidgeting and cutting the table and swinging his chair, was where he had to repeat the patriarchs before the Flood. He did not know one of them, except Enoch, who had been taken up alive to heaven. Last time he had remembered their names, but now he had forgotten them utterly, chiefly because Enoch was the personage he liked best in the whole of the Old Testament, and Enoch’s translation to heaven was connected in his mind with a whole long train of thought, in which he became absorbed now while he gazed with fascinated eyes at his father’s watch-chain and a half-unbuttoned button on his waistcoat.
他皱起眉头，开始解释谢廖扎以前听过很多次却始终记不起来的话，因为他太了解了，就像“突然”是行为方式的副词一样。谢廖扎用惊恐的眼神看着父亲，脑子里只想着父亲是否会让他重复说过的话，就像他有时做的那样。这个念头让谢廖扎大吃一惊，现在他什么也不明白了。但他的父亲并没有让他重复，而是继续从旧约圣经中吸取教训。谢廖扎把这些事件本身叙述得足够清楚，但当他必须回答有关某些事件预示什么的问题时，他什么也不知道，尽管他已经因为这堂课而受到了惩罚。在这段话中，他完全说不出话来，开始坐立不安，砍桌子，摇椅子，这就是他不得不重复洪水前的族​​长的地方。除了被活着提到天上的以诺以外，他不认识其中任何一个人。上次他还记得他们的名字，现在却完全忘记了，主要是因为以诺是整部旧约中他最喜欢的人物，而以诺升天的事在他的脑海里连着一长串的思绪。他全神贯注地看着父亲的表链和背心上一颗半解开的纽扣。

In death, of which they talked to him so often, Seryozha disbelieved entirely. He did not believe that those he loved could die, above all that he himself would die. That was to him something utterly inconceivable and impossible. But he had been told that all men die; he had asked people, indeed, whom he trusted, and they too, had confirmed it; his old nurse, too, said the same, though reluctantly. But Enoch had not died, and so it followed that everyone did not die. ‘And why cannot anyone else so serve God and be taken alive to heaven?’ thought Seryozha. Bad people, that is those Seryozha did not like, they might die, but the good might all be like Enoch.
他们经常跟谢廖扎谈论死亡，但他完全不相信死亡。他不相信他所爱的人会死，尤其是他自己会死。这对于他来说，是完全不可思议、不可能的事情。但有人告诉他，所有人都会死；事实上，他曾询问过他信任的人，他们也证实了这一点。他的老保姆也说了同样的话，尽管很不情愿。但以诺并没有死，因此每个人都没有死。 “为什么其他人不能如此侍奉上帝并被活着带到天堂呢？”谢廖扎想。坏人，就是谢廖扎不喜欢的人，他们可能会死，但好人可能都像以诺一样。

‘Well, what are the names of the patriarchs?’
“那么，族长的名字是什么？”

‘Enoch, Enos—‘
“以诺，以诺斯——”

‘But you have said that already. This is bad, Seryozha, very bad. If you don’t try to learn what is more necessary than anything for a Christian,’ said his father, getting up, ‘whatever can interest you? I am displeased with you, and Piotr Ignatitch’ (this was the most important of his teachers) ‘is displeased with you.... I shall have to punish you.’
‘但你已经说过了。这很糟糕，谢廖扎，非常糟糕。如果你不努力学习对基督徒来说最重要的事情，”他的父亲站起来说道，“那么你对什么感兴趣呢？我对你感到不满，彼得·伊格纳蒂奇（这是他最重要的老师）“对你感到不满……我将不得不惩罚你。”

His father and his teacher were both displeased with Seryozha, and he certainly did learn his lessons very badly. But still it could not be said he was a stupid boy. On the contrary, he was far cleverer than the boys his teacher held up as examples to Seryozha. In his father’s opinion, he did not want to learn what he was taught. In reality he could not learn that. He could not, because the claims of his own soul were more binding on him than those claims his father and his teacher made upon him. Those claims were in opposition, and he was in direct conflict with his education. He was nine years old; he was a child; but he knew his own soul, it was precious to him, he guarded it as the eyelid guards the eye, and without the key of love he let no one into his soul. His teachers complained that he would not learn, while his soul was brimming over with thirst for knowledge. And he learned from Kapitonitch, from his nurse, from Nadinka, from Vassily Lukitch, but not from his teachers. The spring his father and his teachers reckoned upon to turn their mill-wheels had long dried up at the source, but its waters did their work in another channel.
他的父亲和老师都对谢廖扎感到不满，而且他的功课确实学得非常糟糕。但也不能说他是个傻孩子。相反，他比他的老师为谢廖扎树立的榜样的男孩们聪明得多。在他父亲看来，他不想学习别人教给他的东西。事实上他无法学到这一点。他不能，因为他自己灵魂的要求比他父亲和老师对他的要求更有约束力。这些主张是对立的，他与他所受的教育有直接冲突。那年他九岁；他还是个孩子；但他了解自己的灵魂，它对他来说很珍贵，他保护它就像眼皮保护眼睛一样，没有爱的钥匙，他不让任何人进入他的灵魂。他的老师抱怨他不肯学习，而他的灵魂却充满了求知欲。他向卡皮托内奇、他的护士、纳丁卡、瓦西里·卢基奇学习，但不是从他的老师那里学习。他的父亲和他的老师们指望用来转动水车的泉水早已在源头干涸了，但它的水却在另一个渠道中发挥了作用。

His father punished Seryozha by not letting him go to see Nadinka, Lidia Ivanovna’s niece; but this punishment turned out happily for Seryozha. Vassily Lukitch was in a good humor, and showed him how to make windmills. The whole evening passed over this work and in dreaming how to make a windmill on which he could turn himself—clutching at the sails or tying himself on and whirling round.
