Of his mother Seryozha did not think all the evening, but when he had gone to bed, he suddenly remembered her, and prayed in his own words that his mother tomorrow for his birthday might leave off hiding herself and come to him.
他的父亲惩罚谢廖扎，不让他去见莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜的侄女纳丁卡。但这个惩罚对谢廖扎来说却是幸福的。瓦西里·卢基奇心情很好，向他展示了如何制作风车。整个晚上都在思考这项工作，梦想着如何制作一个风车，他可以在风车上转动——抓着船帆，或者把自己绑在上面旋转。谢廖沙整个晚上都没有想到他的母亲，但当他上床睡觉时，他突然想起了她，并用自己的话祈祷，希望他的母亲明天在他生日时不要躲藏起来，来到他身边。

‘Vassily Lukitch, do you know what I prayed for tonight extra besides the regular things?’
“瓦西里·卢基奇，你知道我今晚除了常规的事情之外还额外祈祷了什么吗？”

‘That you might learn your lessons better?’
“这样你就能更好地吸取教训？”

‘No.’
'不。'

‘Toys?’
'玩具？'

‘No. You’ll never guess. A splendid thing; but it’s a secret! When it comes to pass I’ll tell you. Can’t you guess!’
'不。你永远猜不到。一件了不起的事；但这是一个秘密！当事情发生时我会告诉你。你猜不出来吗！

‘No, I can’t guess. You tell me,’ said Vassily Lukitch with a smile, which was rare with him. ‘Come, lie down, I’m putting out the candle.’
‘不，我猜不出来。你告诉我吧，”瓦西里·卢基奇微笑着说道，这对他来说是罕见的。 “来吧，躺下，我正在熄灭蜡烛。”

‘Without the candle I can see better what I see and what I prayed for. There! I was almost telling the secret!’ said Seryozha, laughing gaily.
“没有蜡烛，我可以更好地看到我所看到的和我祈祷的东西。那里！我差点就要说出这个秘密了！”谢廖扎高兴地笑着说道。

When the candle was taken away, Seryozha heard and felt his mother. She stood over him, and with loving eyes caressed him. But then came windmills, a knife, everything began to be mixed up, and he fell asleep.
当蜡烛被拿走时，谢廖扎听到并感觉到了他的母亲。她站在他身边，用充满爱意的目光爱抚着他。但后来风车、刀子来了，一切开始变得混乱，他睡着了。

Chapter 28
第28章

On arriving in Petersburg, Vronsky and Anna stayed at one of the best hotels; Vronsky apart in a lower story, Anna above with her child, its nurse, and her maid, in a large suite of four rooms.
抵达彼得堡后，渥伦斯基和安娜住在最好的酒店之一；渥伦斯基住在楼下，安娜和她的孩子、护士和女仆住在楼上的一间有四个房间的大套房里。

On the day of his arrival Vronsky went to his brother’s. There he found his mother, who had come from Moscow on business. His mother and sister-in-law greeted him as usual: they asked him about his stay abroad, and talked of their common acquaintances, but did not let drop a single word in allusion to his connection with Anna. His brother came the next morning to see Vronsky, and of his own accord asked him about her, and Alexey Vronsky told him directly that he looked upon his connection with Madame Karenina as marriage; that he hoped to arrange a divorce, and then to marry her, and until then he considered her as much a wife as any other wife, and he begged him to tell their mother and his wife so.
抵达当天，渥伦斯基去了他哥哥家。在那里，他找到了从莫斯科出差而来的母亲。他的母亲和嫂子像往常一样向他打招呼，询问他在国外的情况，谈论他们共同的熟人，但没有提及他与安娜的关系。第二天早上，他的兄弟来看望渥伦斯基，并主动向他询问了她的情况，阿列克谢·渥伦斯基直接告诉他，他将与卡列尼娜夫人的联系视为婚姻；他希望安排离婚，然后娶她，在那之前他认为她和其他妻子一样是妻子，他恳求他把这一点告诉他们的母亲和他的妻子。

‘If the world disapproves, I don’t care,’ said Vronsky; ‘but if my relations want to be on terms of relationship with me, they will have to be on the same terms with my wife.’
“如果世界不赞成，我不在乎，”渥伦斯基说； “但如果我的亲戚想与我建立良好的关系，他们就必须与我的妻子建立同样的关系。”

The elder brother, who had always a respect for his younger brother’s judgment, could not well tell whether he was right or not till the world had decided the question; for his part he had nothing against it, and with Alexey he went up to see Anna.
哥哥一向尊重弟弟的判断，直到全世界都决定了这个问题之后，他才能清楚地判断自己的判断是否正确。就他而言，他并不反对，他和阿列克谢一起去见安娜。

Before his brother, as before everyone, Vronsky addressed Anna with a certain formality, treating her as he might a very intimate friend, but it was understood that his brother knew their real relations, and they talked about Anna’s going to Vronsky’s estate.
在他的兄弟面前，就像在所有人面前一样，渥伦斯基以某种正式的方式称呼安娜，将她视为非常亲密的朋友，但据了解，他的兄弟知道他们真正的关系，他们谈论了安娜要去渥伦斯基庄园的事情。

In spite of all his social experience Vronsky was, in consequence of the new position in which he was placed, laboring under a strange misapprehension. One would have thought he must have understood that society was closed for him and Anna; but now some vague ideas had sprung up in his brain that this was only the case in old-fashioned days, and that now with the rapidity of modern progress (he had unconsciously become by now a partisan of every sort of progress) the views of society had changed, and that the question whether they would be received in society was not a foregone conclusion. ‘Of course,’ he thought, ‘she would not be received at court, but intimate friends can and must look at it in the proper light.’ One may sit for several hours at a stretch with one’s legs crossed in the same position, if one knows that there’s nothing to prevent one’s changing one’s position; but if a man knows that he must remain sitting so with crossed legs, then cramps come on, the legs begin to twitch and to strain towards the spot to which one would like to draw them. This was what Vronsky was experiencing in regard to the world. Though at the bottom of his heart he knew that the world was shut on them, he put it to the test whether the world had not changed by now and would not receive them. But he very quickly perceived that though the world was open for him personally, it was closed for Anna. Just as in the game of cat and mouse, the hands raised for him were dropped to bar the way for Anna.
尽管渥伦斯基拥有丰富的社会经验，但由于他所处的新职位，他仍处于一种奇怪的误解之中。人们可能会认为他一定明白社会对他和安娜来说是封闭的；但事实上，他并没有意识到社会对他和安娜来说是封闭的。但现在他的脑子里突然出现了一些模糊的想法，认为这只是在老式时代的情况，而现在随着现代进步的迅速发展（他已经不知不觉地成为了各种进步的拥护者），过去的观点已经不再是过去的观点了。社会已经发生了变化，他们是否会被社会接受的问题并不是已成定局。 “当然，”他想，“她不会在法庭上受到接待，但亲密的朋友可以而且必须以适当的眼光看待它。”一个人可能会以同样的姿势盘腿一坐几个小时，如果一个人知道没有什么可以阻止他改变自己的立场；但是，如果一个人知道他必须保持双腿交叉的姿势，那么就会出现抽筋，双腿开始抽搐，并向人们想要将其拉到的地方用力。这就是渥伦斯基对于世界的体验。虽然他内心深处知道这个世界对他们关闭了，但他还是在考验这个世界是否已经改变，不会接受他们。但他很快意识到，虽然世界对他个人来说是开放的，但对安娜来说却是关闭的。就像猫捉老鼠的游戏一样，为他举起的手又垂了下来，挡住了安娜的路。

One of the first ladies of Petersburg society whom Vronsky saw was his cousin Betsy.
渥伦斯基见到的彼得堡上流社会的第一夫人之一是他的表妹贝齐。

‘At last!’ she greeted him joyfully. ‘And Anna? How glad I am! Where are you stopping? I can fancy after your delightful travels you must find our poor Petersburg horrid. I can fancy your honeymoon in Rome. How about the divorce? Is that all over?’
“终于！”她高兴地向他打招呼。 ‘安娜呢？我多么高兴啊！你在哪里停下来？我想，在您愉快的旅行之后，您一定会发现我们可怜的彼得堡很可怕。我很喜欢你在罗马度蜜月。离婚又怎样？一切都结束了吗？

Vronsky noticed that Betsy’s enthusiasm waned when she learned that no divorce had as yet taken place.
渥伦斯基注意到，当贝特西得知还没有离婚时，她的热情就减退了。

‘People will throw stones at me, I know,’ she said, ‘but I shall come and see Anna; yes, I shall certainly come. You won’t be here long, I suppose?’
“我知道人们会向我扔石头，”她说，“但我会来看安娜；是的，我一定会来。我想你不会在这里呆太久吧？

And she did certainly come to see Anna the same day, but her tone was not at all the same as in former days. She unmistakably prided herself on her courage, and wished Anna to appreciate the fidelity of her friendship. She only stayed ten minutes, talking of society gossip, and on leaving she said:
而她当天确实是来看安娜的，但语气却与往日完全不一样。她毫无疑问地为自己的勇气感到自豪，并希望安娜能够欣赏她友谊的忠诚。她只待了十分钟，谈论社会八卦，离开时她说：

‘You’ve never told me when the divorce is to be? Supposing I’m ready to fling my cap over the mill, other starchy people will give you the cold shoulder until you’re married. And that’s so simple nowadays. Ca se fait. So you’re going on Friday? Sorry we shan’t see each other again.’
“你从来没有告诉过我什么时候离婚吗？”假设我准备好把我的帽子扔到工厂里，其他顽固的人会冷落你，直到你结婚。如今这太简单了。事实如此。那你星期五去吗？抱歉，我们再也见不到对方了。”

From Betsy’s tone Vronsky might have grasped what he had to expect from the world; but he made another effort in his own family. His mother he did not reckon upon. He knew that his mother, who had been so enthusiastic over Anna at their first acquaintance, would have no mercy on her now for having ruined her son’s career. But he had more hope of Varya, his brother’s wife. He fancied she would not throw stones, and would go simply and directly to see Anna, and would receive her in her own house.
从贝特西的语气中，渥伦斯基也许已经明白了他对这个世界的期望。但他在自己的家庭中又做出了努力。他没有想到他的母亲。他知道，他的母亲在他们第一次相识时就对安娜如此热情，现在不会因为她毁了儿子的事业而对她有任何怜悯。但他对他兄长的妻子瓦莉亚（Varya）抱有更多的希望。他以为她不会扔石头，会简单直接地去见安娜，并在自己家里接待她。

The day after his arrival Vronsky went to her, and finding her alone, expressed his wishes directly.
到达的第二天，渥伦斯基去找她，发现她独自一人，就直接表达了他的愿望。

‘You know, Alexey,’ she said after hearing him, ‘how fond I am of you, and how ready I am to do anything for you; but I have not spoken, because I knew I could be of no use to you and to Anna Arkadyevna,’ she said, articulating the name ‘Anna Arkadyevna’ with particular care. ‘Don’t suppose, please, that I judge her. Never; perhaps in her place I should have done the same. I don’t and can’t enter into that,’ she said, glancing timidly at his gloomy face. ‘But one must call things by their names. You want me to go and see her, to ask her here, and to rehabilitate her in society; but do understand that I cannot do so. I have daughters growing up, and I must live in the world for my husband’s sake. Well, I’m ready to come and see Anna Arkadyevna: she will understand that I can’t ask her here, or I should have to do so in such a way that she would not meet people who look at things differently; that would offend her. I can’t raise her...’
“你知道，阿列克谢，”她听完他的话后说道，“我多么喜欢你，我多么愿意为你做任何事；但我没有说话，因为我知道我对你和安娜·阿尔卡季耶夫娜没有任何用处，”她说，特别小心地说出“安娜·阿尔卡季耶夫娜”这个名字。 “请不要以为我会评判她。绝不;也许如果我处在她的位置，也应该这样做。我不会也不能参与其中，”她说道，胆怯地看着他阴沉的脸。 “但人们必须直呼其名。你要我去看看她，请她​​到这里来，让她重新回到社会上来；但请明白我不能这样做。我有女儿长大，我必须为了丈夫而活在世上。好吧，我准备好去见安娜·阿尔卡季耶夫娜了：她会明白我不能在这里问她，否则我就得这样做，这样她就不会遇到对事物有不同看法的人；那会冒犯她。我养不起她……”

‘Oh, I don’t regard her as fallen more than hundreds of women you do receive!’ Vronsky interrupted her still more gloomily, and he got up in silence, understanding that his sister-in-law’s decision was not to be shaken.
“哦，我不认为她比你接待的数百个女人更堕落！”渥伦斯基更加沮丧地打断了她的话，然后他默默地站了起来，明白他嫂子的决定不能动摇。

‘Alexey! don’t be angry with me. Please understand that I’m not to blame,’ began Varya, looking at him with a timid smile.
‘阿列克谢！别生我的气。请理解，我不应该受到责备。”瓦里亚开始说道，带着胆怯的微笑看着他。

‘I’m not angry with you,’ he said still as gloomily; ‘but I’m sorry in two ways. I’m sorry, too, that this means breaking up our friendship—if not breaking up, at least weakening it. You will understand that for me, too, it cannot be otherwise.’
“我没有生你的气，”他仍然阴郁地说。 “但我从两方面感到抱歉。我也很抱歉，这意味着我们的友谊会破裂——如果不是破裂，至少会削弱它。你会明白，对我来说，情况也是如此。

And with that he left her.
说完他就离开了她。

Vronsky knew that further efforts were useless, and that he had to spend these few days in Petersburg as though in a strange town, avoiding every sort of relation with his own old circle in order not to be exposed to the annoyances and humiliations which were so intolerable to him. One of the most unpleasant features of his position in Petersburg was that Alexey Alexandrovitch and his name seemed to meet him everywhere. He could not begin to talk of anything without the conversation turning on Alexey Alexandrovitch; he could not go anywhere without risk of meeting him. So at least it seemed to Vronsky, just as it seems to a man with a sore finger that he is continually, as though on purpose, grazing his sore finger on everything.
渥伦斯基知道再多的努力都是无用的，他必须在彼得堡度过这几天，就像在一个陌生的小镇一样，避免与自己的老圈子发生任何关系，以免遭受到如此多的烦恼和羞辱。让他无法忍受。他在彼得堡的地位最令人不快的特点之一是阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇和他的名字似乎到处都能见到他。如果话题不转向阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇，他就无法开始谈论任何事情。他去任何地方都不可能遇到他。至少在渥伦斯基看来，就像一个手指酸痛的人似乎是故意的，他不断地用酸痛的手指擦过一切。

Their stay in Petersburg was the more painful to Vronsky that he perceived all the time a sort of new mood that he could not understand in Anna. At one time she would seem in love with him, and then she would become cold, irritable, and impenetrable. She was worrying over something, and keeping something back from him, and did not seem to notice the humiliations which poisoned his existence, and for her, with her delicate intuition, must have been still more unbearable.
他们在彼得堡的逗留对渥伦斯基来说更加痛苦，因为他一直在安娜身上感受到一种他无法理解的新情绪。有一段时间她似乎很爱他，然后她就会变得冷漠、易怒、难以捉摸。她正在为某事担心，对他有所隐瞒，似乎没有注意到那些毒害他存在的羞辱，而对于她来说，以她敏锐的直觉，一定更难以忍受。

Chapter 29
第29章

One of Anna’s objects in coming back to Russia had been to see her son. From the day she left Italy the thought of it had never ceased to agitate her. And as she got nearer to Petersburg, the delight and importance of this meeting grew ever greater in her imagination. She did not even put to herself the question how to arrange it. It seemed to her natural and simple to see her son when she should be in the same town with him. But on her arrival in Petersburg she was suddenly made distinctly aware of her present position in society, and she grasped the fact that to arrange this meeting was no easy matter.
安娜返回俄罗斯的目的之一就是看望她的儿子。从她离开意大利的那天起，这个想法就一直让她心烦意乱。随着距离彼得堡越来越近，这次会面的乐趣和重要性在她的想象中越来越强烈。她甚至没有向自己提出如何安排的问题。在她看来，当她应该和儿子在同一个城镇时，见到他似乎是很自然和简单的事。但到达彼得堡后，她突然清楚地意识到自己目前的社会地位，她意识到安排这次会面并不是一件容易的事。

She had now been two days in Petersburg. The thought of her son never left her for a single instant, but she had not yet seen him. To go straight to the house, where she might meet Alexey Alexandrovitch, that she felt she had no right to do. She might be refused admittance and insulted. To write and so enter into relations with her husband—that it made her miserable to think of doing; she could only be at peace when she did not think of her husband. To get a glimpse of her son out walking, finding out where and when he went out, was not enough for her; she had so looked forward to this meeting, she had so much she must say to him, she so longed to embrace him, to kiss him. Seryozha’s old nurse might be a help to her and show her what to do. But the nurse was not now living in Alexey Alexandrovitch’s house. In this uncertainty, and in efforts to find the nurse, two days had slipped by.
她已经在彼得堡呆了两天了。对儿子的思念一刻也没有离开过她，但她还没有见到他。直接去她可能会见阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇的房子，她觉得自己没有权利这样做。她可能会被拒绝入场并受到侮辱。写信并与她的丈夫建立关系——这让她一想到这样做就感到痛苦；只有当她不去想她的丈夫时，她才能感到平静。对她来说，仅仅瞥见儿子外出散步的样子，了解他外出的地点和时间，还不够。她是如此期待这次会面，她有太多话要对他说，她如此渴望拥抱他，亲吻他。谢廖扎的老护士可能会帮助她并告诉她该怎么做。但护士现在并不住在阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇的家里。在这种不确定性中，在努力寻找护士的过程中，两天的时间就这样过去了。

Hearing of the close intimacy between Alexey Alexandrovitch and Countess Lidia Ivanovna, Anna decided on the third day to write to her a letter, which cost her great pains, and in which she intentionally said that permission to see her son must depend on her husband’s generosity. She knew that if the letter were shown to her husband, he would keep up his character of magnanimity, and would not refuse her request.
听说阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇和莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜伯爵夫人关系亲密，安娜决定在第三天给她写一封信，这封信费了她很大的力气，她在信中故意说，要允许她见儿子，必须取决于她丈夫的慷慨。 。她知道，如果这封信拿给她丈夫看，他一定会保持大度的性格，不会拒绝她的请求。

The commissionaire who took the letter had brought her back the most cruel and unexpected answer, that there was no answer. She had never felt so humiliated as at the moment when, sending for the commissionaire, she heard from him the exact account of how he had waited, and how afterwards he had been told there was no answer. Anna felt humiliated, insulted, but she saw that from her point of view Countess Lidia Ivanovna was right. Her suffering was the more poignant that she had to bear it in solitude. She could not and would not share it with Vronsky. She knew that to him, although he was the primary cause of her distress, the question of her seeing her son would seem a matter of very little consequence. She knew that he would never be capable of understanding all the depth of her suffering, that for his cool tone at any allusion to it she would begin to hate him. And she dreaded that more than anything in the world, and so she hid from him everything that related to her son. Spending the whole day at home she considered ways of seeing her son, and had reached a decision to write to her husband. She was just composing this letter when she was handed the letter from Lidia Ivanovna. The countess’s silence had subdued and depressed her, but the letter, all that she read between the lines in it, so exasperated her, this malice was so revolting beside her passionate, legitimate tenderness for her son, that she turned against other people and left off blaming herself.
接过信的看门人给她带回了最残酷、最出乎意料的答案：没有任何答复。当她派人去找看门人时，她从他那里听到了他如何等待的确切描述，以及后来他如何被告知没有答复的那一刻，她从未感到如此屈辱。安娜感到羞辱、侮辱，但她看到，从她的角度来看，莉迪亚·伊万诺夫娜伯爵夫人是对的。她的痛苦更加令人心酸，她必须独自承受。她不能也不会与渥伦斯基分享。她知道，对他来说，虽然他是她痛苦的主要原因，但她见儿子的问题似乎无关紧要。她知道他永远无法理解她所受的痛苦的全部深度，因为他在任何暗示时都表现出冷静的语气，她会开始恨他。她最害怕的是这个，所以她向他隐瞒了与她儿子有关的一切。她在家里待了一整天，考虑如何见到儿子，并决定给丈夫写信。她刚写完这封信，就收到了莉迪亚·伊万诺芙娜的信。伯爵夫人的沉默使她感到压抑和沮丧，但这封信，以及她从字里行间读到的一切，让她非常恼怒，这种恶意与她对儿子的热情、合理的温柔相比，是如此令人反感，以至于她转而反对其他人并离开了。不再责备自己。

‘This coldness—this pretense of feeling!’ she said to herself. ‘They must needs insult me and torture the child, and I am to submit to it! Not on any consideration! She is worse than I am. I don’t lie, anyway.’ And she decided on the spot that next day, Seryozha’s birthday, she would go straight to her husband’s house, bribe or deceive the servants, but at any cost see her son and overturn the hideous deception with which they were encompassing the unhappy child.
“这种冷漠——这种假装的感觉！”她对自己说。 ‘他们一定需要侮辱我，折磨孩子，我就只能屈服！没有任何考虑！她比我还糟糕。无论如何，我不会撒谎。”她当场决定，第二天，即谢廖扎的生日，她将直接前往她丈夫的家，贿赂或欺骗仆人，但不惜一切代价见到她的儿子，并推翻这个可怕的欺骗。他们正在包围那个不幸的孩子。

She went to a toy shop, bought toys and thought over a plan of action. She would go early in the morning at eight o’clock, when Alexey Alexandrovitch would be certain not to be up. She would have money in her hand to give the hall porter and the footman, so that they should let her in, and not raising her veil, she would say that she had come from Seryozha’s godfather to congratulate him, and that she had been charged to leave the toys at his bedside. She had prepared everything but the words she should say to her son. Often as she had dreamed of it, she could never think of anything.
她去了一家玩具店，买了玩具，并考虑了一个行动计划。她会在早上八点钟去，那时阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇肯定不会起床。她手里有钱，可以给门房和男仆，让他们让她进去，而不是揭开面纱，她会说，她是谢廖扎教父来祝贺他的，她是被指控的。把玩具留在他的床边。她已经准备好了一切，除了要对儿子说的话。很多时候，尽管她梦想着，但她却什么也想不起来。

The next day, at eight o’clock in the morning, Anna got out of a hired sledge and rang at the front entrance of her former home.
第二天早上八点，安娜下了一辆租来的雪橇，按响了她以前家的前门。

‘Run and see what’s wanted. Some lady,’ said Kapitonitch, who, not yet dressed, in his overcoat and galoshes, had peeped out of the window and seen a lady in a veil standing close up to the door. His assistant, a lad Anna did not know, had no sooner opened the door to her than she came in, and pulling a three-rouble note out of her muff put it hurriedly into his hand.
‘跑去看看有什么需要。 “有位女士，”卡皮托内奇说，他还没有穿好大衣和套鞋，就向窗外望去，看到一位戴着面纱的女士站在靠近门的地方。他的助手，一个安娜不认识的小伙子，刚给她开门，她就进来了，从手筒里掏出一张三卢布的钞票，急忙塞到他手里。

‘Seryozha—Sergey Alexeitch,’ she said, and was going on. Scrutinizing the note, the porter’s assistant stopped her at the second glass door.
“谢廖扎——谢尔盖·阿列克谢伊奇，”她说道，然后继续说下去。搬运工的助手仔细查看了纸条，在第二扇玻璃门前拦住了她。

‘Whom do you want?’ he asked.
“你想要谁？”他问道。

She did not hear his words and made no answer.
她没有听到他的话，也没有回答。

Noticing the embarrassment of the unknown lady, Kapitonitch went out to her, opened the second door for her, and asked her what she was pleased to want.
卡皮托内奇注意到这位陌生女士的尴尬，便走到她面前，为她打开第二扇门，问她想要什么。

‘From Prince Skorodumov for Sergey Alexeitch,’ she said.
“斯科罗杜莫夫王子为谢尔盖·阿列克谢伊奇写的，”她说。

‘His honor’s not up yet,’ said the porter, looking at her attentively.
“他的名誉还没有到。”门房专注地看着她说道。

Anna had not anticipated that the absolutely unchanged hall of the house where she had lived for nine years would so greatly affect her. Memories sweet and painful rose one after another in her heart, and for a moment she forgot what she was here for.
安娜没想到，她住了九年的房子，一成不变的大厅会对她产生如此大的影响。甜蜜与痛苦的记忆在她心头接连升起，一时间她忘记了自己来这里的目的。

‘Would you kindly wait?’ said Kapitonitch, taking off her fur cloak.
“请稍等一下好吗？”卡皮托内奇脱下毛皮斗篷说道。

As he took off the cloak, Kapitonitch glanced at her face, recognized her, and made her a low bow in silence.
当卡皮托内奇脱下斗篷时，他瞥了一眼她的脸，认出了她，默默地向她深深鞠了一躬。

‘Please walk in, your excellency,’ he said to her.
“请进，阁下，”他对她说。

She tried to say something, but her voice refused to utter any sound; with a guilty and imploring glance at the old man she went with light, swift steps up the stairs. Bent double, and his galoshes catching in the steps, Kapitonitch ran after her, trying to overtake her.
她想说什么，但她的声音却发不出声音；她愧疚而恳求地看了老人一眼，迈着轻快的步伐走上楼梯。卡皮托内奇弯着腰，胶鞋踩住了脚步，追赶着她，想要追上她。

‘The tutor’s there; maybe he’s not dressed. I’ll let him know.’
‘导师在那儿；也许他没穿衣服。我会让他知道的。

Anna still mounted the familiar staircase, not understanding what the old man was saying.
安娜依然走上熟悉的楼梯，不明白老人在说什么。

‘This way, to the left, if you please. Excuse its not being tidy. His honor’s in the old parlor now,’ the hall porter said, panting. ‘Excuse me, wait a little, your excellency; I’ll just see,’ he said, and overtaking her, he opened the high door and disappeared behind it. Anna stood still waiting. ‘He’s only just awake,’ said the hall porter, coming out. And at the very instant the porter said this, Anna caught the sound of a childish yawn. From the sound of this yawn alone she knew her son and seemed to see him living before her eyes.
“请这边走，往左边走。”原谅它不整洁。现在他的荣誉在旧客厅里，”门房气喘吁吁地说。 “对不起，请稍等一下，阁下；我去看看，”他说，然后超越了她，打开了高门，消失在门后。安娜静静地站着等待。 “他才刚刚醒。”门房走出来说道。而就在门房说这句话的同时，安娜听到了孩子气的哈欠声。仅凭这个哈欠的声音，她就认出了她的儿子，似乎看到他就活在她的眼前。

‘Let me in; go away!’ she said, and went in through the high doorway. On the right of the door stood a bed, and sitting up in the bed was the boy. His little body bent forward with his nightshirt unbuttoned, he was stretching and still yawning. The instant his lips came together they curved into a blissfully sleepy smile, and with that smile he slowly and deliciously rolled back again.
'让我进去;走开！”她说着，就从高高的门口走了进去。门的右边放着一张床，床上坐着的是男孩。他小小的身子向前倾着，睡衣扣子解开，伸了个懒腰，还在打哈欠。他的嘴唇一合上，就弯成了一个幸福的睡意微笑，带着这个微笑，他又慢慢地、美味地卷了回来。

‘Seryozha!’ she whispered, going noiselessly up to him.
“谢廖扎！”她低声说道，悄无声息地走到他面前。

When she was parted from him, and all this latter time when she had been feeling a fresh rush of love for him, she had pictured him as he was at four years old, when she had loved him most of all. Now he was not even the same as when she had left him; he was still further from the four-year-old baby, more grown and thinner. How thin his face was, how short his hair was! What long hands! How he had changed since she left him! But it was he with his head, his lips, his soft neck and broad little shoulders.
当她与他分开时，当她对他感到一股新的爱的冲动时，她想象着他四岁时的样子，那时她最爱他。现在他已经和她离开时不一样了。他离四岁的婴儿还很远，更长大了，也更瘦了。他的脸多瘦，头发多短！手多长啊！自从她离开他之后，他发生了多么大的变化啊！但这是他的头、嘴唇、柔软的脖子和宽阔的小肩膀。

‘Seryozha!’ she repeated just in the child’s ear.
“谢廖扎！”她在孩子耳边重复道。

He raised himself again on his elbow, turned his tangled head from side to side as though looking for something, and opened his eyes. Slowly and inquiringly he looked for several seconds at his mother standing motionless before him, then all at once he smiled a blissful smile, and shutting his eyes, rolled not backwards but towards her into her arms.
他再次用肘部撑起身子，把纠结的头从一边转到另一边，好像在寻找什么，然后睁开了眼睛。他慢慢地、好奇地看了几秒钟，一动不动地站在他面前的母亲，然后突然露出幸福的微笑，闭上眼睛，不是向后滚动，而是朝她的怀里滚去。

‘Seryozha! my darling boy!’ she said, breathing hard and putting her arms round his plump little body. ‘Mother!’ he said, wriggling about in her arms so as to touch her hands with different parts of him.
‘谢廖扎！我亲爱的孩子！”她喘着粗气，用双臂搂住他丰满的小身体。 “妈妈！”他一边说，一边在她怀里扭动着，用自己身体的不同部位触碰她的手。

Smiling sleepily still with closed eyes, he flung fat little arms round her shoulders, rolled towards her, with the delicious sleepy warmth and fragrance that is only found in children, and began rubbing his face against her neck and shoulders.
他闭着眼睛，睡眼惺忪地微笑着，用肥胖的小手臂搂住她的肩膀，向她滚动，带着只有孩子才能找到的美味的睡意温暖和香味，然后开始用脸在她的脖子和肩膀上摩擦。

‘I know,’ he said, opening his eyes; ‘it’s my birthday today. I knew you’d come. I’ll get up directly.’
“我知道，”他睁开眼睛说。 '今天​​是我的生日。我就知道你会来。我会直接起床。

And saying that he dropped asleep.
并说着就睡着了。

Anna looked at him hungrily; she saw how he had grown and changed in her absence. She knew, and did not know, the bare legs so long now, that were thrust out below the quilt, those short-cropped curls on his neck in which she had so often kissed him. She touched all this and could say nothing; tears choked her.
安娜饥渴地看着他。她看到他在她不在的时候如何成长和改变。她知道，又不知道，那双裸露的腿现在那么长，伸到被子下面，脖子上那些她经常亲吻他的短卷发。她摸着这一切，却什么也说不出来；泪水噎住了她。

‘What are you crying for, mother?’ he said, waking completely up. ‘Mother, what are you crying for?’ he cried in a tearful voice.
“你哭什么，妈妈？”他完全醒了过来，问道。 “妈妈，你哭什么？”他泪流满面地喊道。

‘I won’t cry...I’m crying for joy. It’s so long since I’ve seen you. I won’t, I won’t,’ she said, gulping down her tears and turning away. ‘Come, it’s time for you to dress now,’ she added, after a pause, and, never letting go his hands, she sat down by his bedside on the chair, where his clothes were put ready for him.
“我不会哭……我是因为高兴而哭。”我已经很久没有见到你了。我不会，我不会。”她说着，咽下泪水，转身走开。 “来吧，现在你该穿衣服了。”停顿了一下，她补充道，并没有放开他的手，她在他床边的椅子上坐下，那里已经为他准备好了衣服。

‘How do you dress without me? How...’ she tried to begin talking simply and cheerfully, but she could not, and again she turned away.
‘没有我你怎么穿？怎么……”她试图简单而愉快地说话，但她做不到，于是她再次转过身去。

‘I don’t have a cold bath, papa didn’t order it. And you’ve not seen Vassily Lukitch? He’ll come in soon. Why, you’re sitting on my clothes!’
“我没有洗冷水澡，爸爸没有吩咐。”你还没见过瓦西里·卢基奇吗？他很快就会进来。为什么，你坐在我的衣服上！

And Seryozha went off into a peal of laughter. She looked at him and smiled.
谢廖扎哈哈大笑起来。她看着他，微笑着。

‘Mother, darling, sweet one!’ he shouted, flinging himself on her again and hugging her. It was as though only now, on seeing her smile, he fully grasped what had happened.
“妈妈，亲爱的，亲爱的！”他喊道，再次扑向她并拥抱她。仿佛直到现在，看到她的笑容，他才完全明白发生了什么事。

‘I don’t want that on,’ he said, taking off her hat. And as it were, seeing her afresh without her hat, he fell to kissing her again.
“我不想戴上它，”他说着，摘下了她的帽子。就好像，当他再次看到她没戴帽子时，他又开始亲吻她了。

‘But what did you think about me? You didn’t think I was dead?’
‘但是你觉得我怎么样？你以为我没死吗？

‘I never believed it.’
“我从来不相信。”

‘You didn’t believe it, my sweet?’
“你不相信吗，亲爱的？”

‘I knew, I knew!’ he repeated his favorite phrase, and snatching the hand that was stroking his hair, he pressed the open palm to his mouth and kissed it.
“我知道，我知道！”他重复着他最喜欢的一句话，然后抓住抚摸着他头发的手，将张开的手掌按在嘴上，吻了吻它。

Chapter 30
第30章

Meanwhile Vassily Lukitch had not at first understood who this lady was, and had learned from their conversation that it was no other person than the mother who had left her husband, and whom he had not seen, as he had entered the house after her departure. He was in doubt whether to go in or not, or whether to communicate with Alexey Alexandrovitch. Reflecting finally that his duty was to get Seryozha up at the hour fixed, and that it was therefore not his business to consider who was there, the mother or anyone else, but simply to do his duty, he finished dressing, went to the door and opened it.
与此同时，瓦西里·卢基奇一开始并不明白这位女士是谁，从他们的谈话中得知，不是别人，正是离开她丈夫的母亲，而他在她离开后进入了房子，所以他没有见过她。 。他犹豫着是否要进去，或者是否要与阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇沟通。最后，他想到自己的职责是在规定的时间叫谢廖扎起床，因此，他不需要考虑谁在场，是母亲还是其他任何人，而只是履行自己的职责，他穿好衣服，走到门口。并打开它。

But the embraces of the mother and child, the sound of their voices, and what they were saying, made him change his mind.
但母子俩的拥抱、他们的声音、他们的谈话，让他改变了主意。

He shook his head, and with a sigh he closed the door. ‘I’ll wait another ten minutes,’ he said to himself, clearing his throat and wiping away tears.
他摇摇头，叹了一口气，关上了门。 “我再等十分钟，”他自言自语道，清了清嗓子，擦去了眼泪。

Among the servants of the household there was intense excitement all this time. All had heard that their mistress had come, and that Kapitonitch had let her in, and that she was even now in the nursery, and that their master always went in person to the nursery at nine o’clock, and every one fully comprehended that it was impossible for the husband and wife to meet, and that they must prevent it. Korney, the valet, going down to the hall porter’s room, asked who had let her in, and how it was he had done so, and ascertaining that Kapitonitch had admitted her and shown her up, he gave the old man a talking-to. The hall porter was doggedly silent, but when Korney told him he ought to be sent away, Kapitonitch darted up to him, and waving his hands in Korney’s face, began:
家里的仆人们心中一直充满着强烈的兴奋。大家都听说他们的女主人来了，卡皮托内奇让她进来了，而且她现在还在育婴室里，而且他们的主人总是在九点钟亲自去育婴室，每个人都充分理解了这一点。夫妻俩不可能见面，必须阻止。仆人科尔尼走到门房的房间，问谁让她进来的，他是怎么做到的，并确定卡皮托内奇已经接纳了她并带她进来，他对老人进行了交谈。 。门房顽固地保持沉默，但是当科尼告诉他应该被送走时，卡皮托内奇冲到他面前，在科尼脸上挥舞着双手，开始说道：

‘Oh yes, to be sure you’d not have let her in! After ten years’ service, and never a word but of kindness, and there you’d up and say, ‘Be off, go along, get away with you!’ Oh yes, you’re a shrewd one at politics, I dare say! You don’t need to be taught how to swindle the master, and to filch fur coats!’
‘哦，是的，你肯定不会让她进来的！经过十年的服务，除了善意之外，从来没有说过一句话，然后你会站起来说：“走吧，走吧，走开！”哦，是的，你在政治上是个精明的人，我敢说说！不用教你怎么骗主子，怎么偷皮大衣！

‘Soldier!’ said Korney contemptuously, and he turned to the nurse who was coming in. ‘Here, what do you think, Marya Efimovna: he let her in without a word to anyone,’ Korney said addressing her. ‘Alexey Alexandrovitch will be down immediately—and go into the nursery!’
“士兵！”科尼轻蔑地说，然后转向进来的护士。“看，你觉得怎么样，玛丽亚·埃菲莫夫娜：他没有对任何人说一句话就让她进来了，”科尼对她说道。 “阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇马上就下来——去育婴室！”

‘A pretty business, a pretty business!’ said the nurse. ‘You, Korney Vassilievitch, you’d best keep him some way or other, the master, while I’ll run and get her away somehow. A pretty business!’
“真是一桩好事，一桩好事！”护士说。 “你，科尔尼·瓦西里耶维奇，你最好以某种方式留住他，主人，而我会跑去想办法把她带走。生意不错！

When the nurse went into the nursery, Seryozha was telling his mother how he and Nadinka had had a fall in sledging downhill, and had turned over three times. She was listening to the sound of his voice, watching his face and the play of expression on it, touching his hand, but she did not follow what he was saying. She must go, she must leave him,—this was the only thing she was thinking and feeling. She heard the steps of Vassily Lukitch coming up to the door and coughing; she heard, too, the steps of the nurse as she came near; but she sat like one turned to stone, incapable of beginning to speak or to get up.
当护士走进育婴室时，谢廖扎正在告诉他的母亲，他和纳丁卡在下坡雪橇时摔倒了，翻了三次。她听着他的声音，看着他的脸和脸上的表情，抚摸着他的手，但她没有听懂他在说什么。她必须走，她必须离开他——这是她唯一的想法和感受。她听到瓦西里·卢基奇走到门口咳嗽的脚步声。当护士走近时，她也听到了脚步声。但她像石化一样坐着，无法说话，也无法起身。

‘Mistress, darling!’ began the nurse, going up to Anna and kissing her hands and shoulders. ‘God has brought joy indeed to our boy on his birthday. You aren’t changed one bit.’
“女主人，亲爱的！”护士走到安娜面前，亲吻她的手和肩膀。 “上帝确实在我们儿子的生日那天给他带来了欢乐。你一点也没有改变。

‘Oh, nurse dear, I didn’t know you were in the house,’ said Anna, rousing herself for a moment.
“噢，亲爱的护士，我不知道你在屋子里。”安娜一下子清醒过来说道。

‘I’m not living here, I’m living with my daughter. I came for the birthday, Anna Arkadyevna, darling!’
“我不住在这里，我和我女儿住在一起。我是来过生日的，安娜·阿尔卡季耶夫娜，亲爱的！

The nurse suddenly burst into tears, and began kissing her hand again.
护士突然泪流满面，又开始亲吻她的手。

Seryozha, with radiant eyes and smiles, holding his mother by one hand and his nurse by the other, pattered on the rug with his fat little bare feet. The tenderness shown by his beloved nurse to his mother threw him into an ecstasy.
谢廖扎眼睛闪闪发亮，笑容满面，一只手牵着母亲，另一只手牵着保姆，肥肥的小赤脚在地毯上啪嗒啪嗒地走着。他心爱的护士对母亲表现出的温柔让他欣喜若狂。

‘Mother! She often comes to see me, and when she comes...’ he was beginning, but he stopped, noticing that the nurse was saying something in a whisper to his mother, and that in his mother’s face there was a look of dread and something like shame, which was so strangely unbecoming to her.
'母亲！她经常来看我，当她来的时候……”他正要开口，但他停了下来，注意到护士正在小声地对他母亲说着什么，而他母亲的脸上露出了恐惧和恐惧的表情。像是羞耻之类的东西，这对她来说是多么奇怪的不合适。

She went up to him.
她走到他身边。

‘My sweet!’ she said.
“我的宝贝！”她说。

She could not say good-bye, but the expression on her face said it, and he understood. ‘Darling, darling Kootik!’ she used the name by which she had called him when he was little, ‘you won’t forget me? You...’ but she could not say more.
她无法说再见，但她脸上的表情已经说明了这一点，他明白了。 “亲爱的，亲爱的库提克！”她用了他小时候的名字，“你不会忘记我吧？你……”但她无法再说更多。

How often afterwards she thought of words she might have said. But now she did not know how to say it, and could say nothing. But Seryozha knew all she wanted to say to him. He understood that she was unhappy and loved him. He understood even what the nurse had whispered. He had caught the words ‘always at nine o’clock,’ and he knew that this was said of his father, and that his father and mother could not meet. That he understood, but one thing he could not understand—why there should be a look of dread and shame in her face?... She was not in fault, but she was afraid of him and ashamed of something. He would have liked to put a question that would have set at rest this doubt, but he did not dare; he saw that she was miserable, and he felt for her. Silently he pressed close to her and whispered, ‘Don’t go yet. He won’t come just yet.’
事后她常常想起自己可能说过的话。但现在她不知道该怎么说，什么也说不出来。但谢廖扎知道她想对他说的一切。他明白她不快乐，也爱他。他甚至听懂了护士低声说的话。他听出了‘总是九点钟’这几个字，他知道这是对他父亲说的，而且他的父亲和母亲不能见面。他明白，但有一件事他无法理解——为什么她的脸上要露出恐惧和羞愧的表情？他本想提出一个问题来消除这个疑虑，但他不敢；他看到她很痛苦，他为她感到难过。他默默地贴近她，低声道：“你别走。”他还不会来。

The mother held him away from her to see what he was thinking, what to say to him, and in his frightened face she read not only that he was speaking of his father, but, as it were, asking her what he ought to think about his father.
母亲把他拉开，看看他在想什么，对他说什么，从他惊恐的脸上，她不仅看出他在谈论他的父亲，而且可以说是在问她他应该怎么想。关于他的父亲。

‘Seryozha, my darling,’ she said, ‘love him; he’s better and kinder than I am, and I have done him wrong. When you grow up you will judge.’
“谢廖扎，亲爱的，”她说，“爱他；他比我更好、更友善，但我错待了他。等你长大了，你就会做出判断。”

‘There’s no one better than you!...’ he cried in despair through his tears, and, clutching her by the shoulders, he began squeezing her with all his force to him, his arms trembling with the strain.
“没有人比你更好了！……”他泪流满面，绝望地喊道，然后抓住她的肩膀，开始用尽全力挤压她，双臂因用力而颤抖。

‘My sweet, my little one!’ said Anna, and she cried as weakly and childishly as he.
“我的宝贝，我的小宝贝！”安娜说道，她的哭声和他一样虚弱而幼稚。

At that moment the door opened. Vassily Lukitch came in.
就在这时，门开了。瓦西里·卢基奇进来了。

At the other door there was the sound of steps, and the nurse in a scared whisper said, ‘He’s coming,’ and gave Anna her hat.
另一扇门传来脚步声，护士惊恐地低声说道：“他来了。”然后把帽子递给了安娜。

Seryozha sank onto the bed and sobbed, hiding his face in his hands. Anna removed his hands, once more kissed his wet face, and with rapid steps went to the door. Alexey Alexandrovitch walked in, meeting her. Seeing her, he stopped short and bowed his head.
谢廖扎倒在床上抽泣，双手捂住脸。安娜松开手，再次吻了一下他湿漉漉的脸，快步向门口走去。阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇走进来迎接她。看到她，他突然停了下来，低下了头。

Although she had just said he was better and kinder than she, in the rapid glance she flung at him, taking in his whole figure in all its details, feelings of repulsion and hatred for him and jealousy over her son took possession of her. With a swift gesture she put down her veil, and, quickening her pace, almost ran out of the room.
虽然她刚刚还说他比她优秀、善良，但是当她快速地扫了他一眼，将他的整个身形、细节都看清的时候，一种对他的厌恶和仇恨以及对儿子的嫉妒占据了她的心。她飞快地放下了面纱，加快了脚步，几乎是跑出了房间。

She had not time to undo, and so carried back with her, the parcel of toys she had chosen the day before in a toy shop with such love and sorrow.
她来不及拆开，于是带着她前一天在玩具店里带着如此爱和悲伤挑选的那包玩具回来了。

Chapter 31
第31章

As intensely as Anna had longed to see her son, and long as she had been thinking of it and preparing herself for it, she had not in the least expected that seeing him would affect her so deeply. On getting back to her lonely rooms in the hotel she could not for a long while understand why she was there. ‘Yes, it’s all over, and I am again alone,’ she said to herself, and without taking off her hat she sat down in a low chair by the hearth. Fixing her eyes on a bronze clock standing on a table between the windows, she tried to think.
尽管安娜非常渴望见到她的儿子，尽管她一直在思考并为此做好准备，但她丝毫没有想到见到他会对她产生如此深远的影响。回到旅馆里她孤独的房间后，她很长一段时间都不明白自己为什么会在那里。 “是的，一切都结束了，我又孤身一人了。”她自言自语道，然后没有摘下帽子，就在炉边的一张矮椅子上坐了下来。她盯着窗户之间桌子上的青铜钟，试图思考。

The French maid brought from abroad came in to suggest she should dress. She gazed at her wonderingly and said, ‘Presently.’ A footman offered her coffee. ‘Later on,’ she said.
从国外带来的法国女佣进来建议她穿好衣服。她疑惑地看着她，说道：“现在。”一名男仆给她递了咖啡。 “稍后再说吧，”她说。

The Italian nurse, after having taken the baby out in her best, came in with her, and brought her to Anna. The plump, well-fed little baby, on seeing her mother, as she always did, held out her fat little hands, and with a smile on her toothless mouth, began, like a fish with a float, bobbing her fingers up and down the starched folds of her embroidered skirt, making them rustle. It was impossible not to smile, not to kiss the baby, impossible not to hold out a finger for her to clutch, crowing and prancing all over; impossible not to offer her a lip which she sucked into her little mouth by way of a kiss. And all this Anna did, and took her in her arms and made her dance, and kissed her fresh little cheek and bare little elbows; but at the sight of this child it was plainer than ever to her that the feeling she had for her could not be called love in comparison with what she felt for Seryozha. Everything in this baby was charming, but for some reason all this did not go deep to her heart. On her first child, though the child of an unloved father, had been concentrated all the love that had never found satisfaction. Her baby girl had been born in the most painful circumstances and had not had a hundredth part of the care and thought which had been concentrated on her first child. Besides, in the little girl everything was still in the future, while Seryozha was by now almost a personality, and a personality dearly loved. In him there was a conflict of thought and feeling; he understood her, he loved her, he judged her, she thought, recalling his words and his eyes. And she was forever—not physically only but spiritually—divided from him, and it was impossible to set this right.
意大利护士在尽力把婴儿抱出来后，陪着她进来，把她带到了安娜身边。那个吃得饱饱的胖乎乎的小宝贝，一看到妈妈，一如既往地伸出胖胖的小手，没牙的嘴上带着微笑，开始像一条浮在水面上的鱼一样，手指上下摆动。绣花裙子浆过的褶皱发出沙沙声。不可能不微笑，不亲吻婴儿，不可能不伸出一根手指让她抓着，浑身啼叫，腾跃；不可能不给她一个嘴唇，她以吻的方式把它吸进她的小嘴里。安娜做了这一切，把她抱在怀里，让她跳舞，亲吻她新鲜的小脸颊和裸露的小肘部；但一看到这个孩子，她就比以往更加清楚地意识到，与她对谢廖扎的感情相比，她对她的感情不能称为爱。这个婴儿的一切都是迷人的，但不知为何这一切并没有深入她的内心。她的第一个孩子，虽然是一个不被爱的父亲的孩子，但却集中了所有从未得到满足的爱。她的女婴是在最痛苦的情况下出生的，没有得到她第一个孩子百分之一的关心和思考。此外，对于这个小女孩来说，一切都还停留在未来，而谢廖扎现在几乎已经是一个有个性的人了，而且是一个深受喜爱的人。他的思想和感情之间存在着冲突。他理解她，他爱她，他评判她，她想，回想起他的话语和眼睛。她永远地——不仅是身体上的，而且是精神上的——与他分离，而且不可能纠正这种情况。

She gave the baby back to the nurse, let her go, and opened the locket in which there was Seryozha’s portrait when he was almost of the same age as the girl. She got up, and, taking off her hat, took up from a little table an album in which there were photographs of her son at different ages. She wanted to compare them, and began taking them out of the album. She took them all out except one, the latest and best photograph. In it he was in a white smock, sitting astride a chair, with frowning eyes and smiling lips. It was his best, most characteristic expression. With her little supple hands, her white, delicate fingers, that moved with a peculiar intensity today, she pulled at a corner of the photograph, but the photograph had caught somewhere, and she could not get it out. There was no paper knife on the table, and so, pulling out the photograph that was next to her son’s (it was a photograph of Vronsky taken at Rome in a round hat and with long hair), she used it to push out her son’s photograph. ‘Oh, here is he!’ she said, glancing at the portrait of Vronsky, and she suddenly recalled that he was the cause of her present misery. She had not once thought of him all the morning. But now, coming all at once upon that manly, noble face, so familiar and so dear to her, she felt a sudden rush of love for him.
她把孩子还给护士，让她走，然后打开挂坠盒，里面有谢廖扎的肖像，当时他几乎和女孩同龄。她站起来，摘下帽子，从小桌子上拿起一本相册，里面有她儿子不同年龄段的照片。她想对它们进行比较，并开始将它们从相册中取出。她把所有照片都拿出来，只留下一张，最新最好的照片。照片中，他穿着一件白色罩衫，跨坐在椅子上，眉头紧锁，嘴唇微笑。这是他最好的、最有特色的表情。她用她那双柔软的小手，她白皙细腻的手指，今天以一种奇特的力度，拉着照片的一角，但照片卡在了某个地方，她拿不出来。桌子上没有裁纸刀，于是，她拿出儿子旁边的照片（这是一张渥伦斯基在罗马拍摄的照片，戴着圆帽，留着长发），用它推出了儿子的照片。照片。 “哦，他在这里！”她说，看了一眼渥伦斯基的肖像，她突然想起他是她目前痛苦的根源。整个上午她都没有想起过他。但现在，当她突然看到那张充满男子气概、高贵的脸庞时，她是如此熟悉，如此亲切，她突然对他产生了一股爱意。

‘But where is he? How is it he leaves me alone in my misery?’ she thought all at once with a feeling of reproach, forgetting she had herself kept from him everything concerning her son. She sent to ask him to come to her immediately; with a throbbing heart she awaited him, rehearsing to herself the words in which she would tell him all, and the expressions of love with which he would console her. The messenger returned with the answer that he had a visitor with him, but that he would come immediately, and that he asked whether she would let him bring with him Prince Yashvin, who had just arrived in Petersburg. ‘He’s not coming alone, and since dinner yesterday he has not seen me,’ she thought; ‘he’s not coming so that I could tell him everything, but coming with Yashvin.’ And all at once a strange idea came to her: what if he had ceased to love her?
‘可是他在哪儿呢？他怎么把我一个人留在痛苦之中呢？”她立刻带着一种责备的心情想道，忘记了她自己向他隐瞒了有关她儿子的一切。她派人请他立即来找她。她怀着一颗悸动的心等待着他，心里默念着要告诉他一切的话，以及他要安慰她的爱的表达。信使回来后回答说，他有一位访客，但他会立即赶来，并询问她是否允许他带上刚刚抵达彼得堡的亚什温王子。 “他不是一个人来的，自从昨天吃晚饭后，他就没有见过我了，”她想。 “他来不是为了让我告诉他一切，而是和亚什文一起来。”突然，她想到了一个奇怪的想法：如果他不再爱她了怎么办？

And going over the events of the last few days, it seemed to her that she saw in everything a confirmation of this terrible idea. The fact that he had not dined at home yesterday, and the fact that he had insisted on their taking separate sets of rooms in Petersburg, and that even now he was not coming to her alone, as though he were trying to avoid meeting her face to face.
回顾过去几天发生的事情，她觉得一切都证实了这个可怕的想法。事实上他昨天没有在家吃饭，事实上他坚持要他们在彼得堡分房，而且即使现在他也没有单独来找她，就好像他在努力避免见到她的脸一样。面对。

‘But he ought to tell me so. I must know that it is so. If I knew it, then I know what I should do,’ she said to herself, utterly unable to picture to herself the position she would be in if she were convinced of his not caring for her. She thought he had ceased to love her, she felt close upon despair, and consequently she felt exceptionally alert. She rang for her maid and went to her dressing room. As she dressed, she took more care over her appearance than she had done all those days, as though he might, if he had grown cold to her, fall in love with her again because she had dressed and arranged her hair in the way most becoming to her.
“但他应该这样告诉我。我必须知道确实如此。如果我知道这一点，那么我就知道我应该做什么，”她对自己说，完全无法想象如果她确信他不关心她，她会处于什么境地。她以为他已经不再爱她了，她感到濒临绝望，因而感到格外警觉。她按铃叫来女仆，然后去了更衣室。当她穿衣服时，她比这些天更加注意自己的外表，仿佛如果他对她冷淡了，他可能会再次爱上她，因为她把自己的穿着和头发打理得最漂亮。成为她。

She heard the bell ring before she was ready. When she went into the drawing room it was not he, but Yashvin, who met her eyes. Vronsky was looking through the photographs of her son, which she had forgotten on the table, and he made no haste to look round at her.
还没等她准备好，她就听到铃声响起。当她走进客厅时，映入眼帘的不是他，而是亚什文。渥伦斯基正在翻阅她儿子的照片，她把照片忘在桌子上了，他并没有急着回头看她。

‘We have met already,’ she said, putting her little hand into the huge hand of Yashvin, whose bashfulness was so queerly out of keeping with his immense frame and coarse face. ‘We met last year at the races. Give them to me,’ she said, with a rapid movement snatching from Vronsky the photographs of her son, and glancing significantly at him with flashing eyes. ‘Were the races good this year? Instead of them I saw the races in the Corso in Rome. But you don’t care for life abroad,’ she said with a cordial smile. ‘I know you and all your tastes, though I have seen so little of you.’
“我们已经见过面了，”她说着，把小手放进了亚什文的大手里，亚什文的羞涩与他巨大的身躯和粗糙的脸格格不入。 “我们去年在比赛中见过面。把它们给我，”她说，动作迅速地从渥伦斯基手中夺过她儿子的照片，并用闪烁的眼睛意味深长地看了他一眼。 “今年的比赛顺利吗？我没有看到他们，而是在罗马的科尔索看到了比赛。但你不关心国外的生活。”她亲切地微笑着说道。 “我了解你和你所有的品味，尽管我很少见到你。”

‘I’m awfully sorry for that, for my tastes are mostly bad,’ said Yashvin, gnawing at his left mustache.
“我对此感到非常抱歉，因为我的品味大多很差，”亚什文咬着左胡子说道。

Having talked a little while, and noticing that Vronsky glanced at the clock, Yashvin asked her whether she would be staying much longer in Petersburg, and unbending his huge figure reached after his cap.
聊了一会儿，亚什温注意到渥伦斯基看了一眼时钟，就问她是否会在彼得堡待得更久，然后挺直了他巨大的身躯，伸手去够帽子。

‘Not long, I think,’ she said hesitatingly, glancing at Vronsky.
“我想不会太久，”她犹豫地说，看了一眼渥伦斯基。

‘So then we shan’t meet again?’
“那么我们就不会再见面了？”

‘Come and dine with me,’ said Anna resolutely, angry it seemed with herself for her embarrassment, but flushing as she always did when she defined her position before a fresh person. ‘The dinner here is not good, but at least you will see him. There is no one of his old friends in the regiment Alexey cares for as he does for you.’
“来和我一起吃饭吧，”安娜坚决地说，她似乎因为自己的尴尬而生气，但她脸红了，就像她在一个陌生的人面前明确自己的立场时一样。 ‘这里的晚餐不好，但至少你会见到他。阿列克谢在团里没有一个老朋友像他对你那样关心。

‘Delighted,’ said Yashvin with a smile, from which Vronsky could see that he liked Anna very much.
“很高兴。”亚什文微笑着说道，从渥伦斯基的表情中可以看出他非常喜欢安娜。

Yashvin said good-bye and went away; Vronsky stayed behind.
亚什温说了再见就走了。渥伦斯基留在后面。

‘Are you going too?’ she said to him.
“你也去吗？”她对他说。

‘I’m late already,’ he answered. ‘Run along! I’ll catch you up in a moment,’ he called to Yashvin.
“我已经迟到了，”他回答道。 ‘快跑吧！我一会儿就来接你，”他对亚什文喊道。

She took him by the hand, and without taking her eyes off him, gazed at him while she ransacked her mind for the words to say that would keep him.
她握住他的手，目光没有离开他，凝视着他，同时在脑海中搜寻着能留住他的话。

‘Wait a minute, there’s something I want to say to you,’ and taking his broad hand she pressed it on her neck. ‘Oh, was it right my asking him to dinner?’
“等一下，我有件事想对你说，”她握住他宽阔的手，按在自己的脖子上。 “哦，我请他吃饭对吗？”

‘You did quite right,’ he said with a serene smile that showed his even teeth, and he kissed her hand.
“你做得很对，”他带着平静的微笑说，露出整齐的牙齿，然后吻了吻她的手。

‘Alexey, you have not changed to me?’ she said, pressing his hand in both of hers. ‘Alexey, I am miserable here. When are we going away?’
“阿列克谢，你对我没有改变吗？”她说，把他的手按在她的两只手上。 “阿列克谢，我在这里很痛苦。我们什么时候走？

‘Soon, soon. You wouldn’t believe how disagreeable our way of living here is to me too,’ he said, and he drew away his hand.
‘很快，很快。你不会相信我们在这里的生活方式对我来说也是多么不舒服。”他说着，把手抽开了。

‘Well, go, go!’ she said in a tone of offense, and she walked quickly away from him.
“好吧，走吧，走吧！”她用一种冒犯的语气说，然后快步从他身边走开。

Chapter 32
第32章

When Vronsky returned home, Anna was not yet home. Soon after he had left, some lady, so they told him, had come to see her, and she had gone out with her. That she had gone out without leaving word where she was going, that she had not yet come back, and that all the morning she had been going about somewhere without a word to him—all this, together with the strange look of excitement in her face in the morning, and the recollection of the hostile tone with which she had before Yashvin almost snatched her son’s photographs out of his hands, made him serious. He decided he absolutely must speak openly with her. And he waited for her in her drawing room. But Anna did not return alone, but brought with her her old unmarried aunt, Princess Oblonskaya. This was the lady who had come in the morning, and with whom Anna had gone out shopping. Anna appeared not to notice Vronsky’s worried and inquiring expression, and began a lively account of her morning’s shopping. He saw that there was something working within her; in her flashing eyes, when they rested for a moment on him, there was an intense concentration, and in her words and movements there was that nervous rapidity and grace which, during the early period of their intimacy, had so fascinated him, but which now so disturbed and alarmed him.
当渥伦斯基回到家时，安娜还没有回家。他们告诉他，他离开后不久，一位女士来看她，她也跟着出去了。她出去了，没有留下任何消息，她还没有回来，整个早上她都在某个地方走来走去，没有跟他说一句话——这一切，再加上她脸上那种奇怪的兴奋表情。亚什温差点从他手中抢走她儿子的照片时，她的敌意语气让他严肃起来。他决定绝对必须与她开诚布公地交谈。他在她的客厅里等她。但安娜并不是独自一人回来，而是带着她未婚的老姨妈奥布隆斯卡娅公主。这是早上来的那位女士，安娜和她一起出去购物。安娜似乎没有注意到渥伦斯基担忧和询问的表情，并开始生动地讲述她早上的购物。他看到她体内有某种东西在起作用；当他们在他身上停留片刻时，在她闪烁的眼睛里，有一种强烈的专注，在她的言语和动作中，有一种神经质的快速和优雅，在他们亲密关系的早期，这让他如此着迷，但现在他感到如此不安和惊慌。

The dinner was laid for four. All were gathered together and about to go into the little dining room when Tushkevitch made his appearance with a message from Princess Betsy. Princess Betsy begged her to excuse her not having come to say good-bye; she had been indisposed, but begged Anna to come to her between half-past six and nine o’clock. Vronsky glanced at Anna at the precise limit of time, so suggestive of steps having been taken that she should meet no one; but Anna appeared not to notice it.
晚餐是四人份的。所有人都聚集在一起，正要进入小餐厅时，图什克维奇带着贝特西公主的口信出现了。贝特西公主恳求她原谅她没有来告别。她身体不太舒服，但恳求安娜在六点半到九点之间来找她。渥伦斯基在精确的时间限制上看了安娜一眼，暗示她已经采取了措施，不应该遇到任何人。但安娜似乎没有注意到这一点。

‘Very sorry that I can’t come just between half-past six and nine,’ she said with a faint smile.
“非常抱歉，我不能在六点半到九点之间来，”她微笑着说道。

‘The princess will be very sorry.’
“公主会非常抱歉的。”

‘And so am I.’
'我也是。'

‘You’re going, no doubt, to hear Patti?’ said Tushkevitch.
“毫无疑问，你要去听帕蒂的演讲？”图什克维奇说。

‘Patti? You suggest the idea to me. I would go if it were possible to get a box.’
‘帕蒂？你向我提出这个想法。如果可以的话我会去的。

‘I can get one,’ Tushkevitch offered his services.
“我可以得到一个，”图什克维奇提供了他的服务。

‘I should be very, very grateful to you,’ said Anna. ‘But won’t you dine with us?’
“我应该非常非常感谢你，”安娜说。 “但是你不和我们一起吃饭吗？”

Vronsky gave a hardly perceptible shrug. He was at a complete loss to understand what Anna was about. What had she brought the old Princess Oblonskaya home for, what had she made Tushkevitch stay to dinner for, and, most amazing of all, why was she sending him for a box? Could she possibly think in her position of going to Patti’s benefit, where all the circle of her acquaintances would be? He looked at her with serious eyes, but she responded with that defiant, half-mirthful, half-desperate look, the meaning of which he could not comprehend. At dinner Anna was in aggressively high spirits—she almost flirted both with Tushkevitch and with Yashvin. When they got up from dinner and Tushkevitch had gone to get a box at the opera, Yashvin went to smoke, and Vronsky went down with him to his own rooms. After sitting there for some time he ran upstairs. Anna was already dressed in a low-necked gown of light silk and velvet that she had had made in Paris, and with costly white lace on her head, framing her face, and particularly becoming, showing up her dazzling beauty.
渥伦斯基几乎不可察觉地耸耸肩。他完全不明白安娜的意思。她带老公主奥布隆斯卡娅回家干什么，她让图什克维奇留下来吃晚饭干什么，最令人惊奇的是，她为什么要派他去拿一个盒子？她可能会站在她的立场去考虑帕蒂的利益，她所有的熟人都在哪里？他用严肃的眼神看着她，但她却用一种挑衅、半欣喜、半绝望的眼神回应，他无法理解其中的含义。晚餐时，安娜情绪非常高涨——她几乎同时和图什克维奇和亚什文调情。当他们吃完晚饭起床时，图什克维奇已经去歌剧院买包厢了，亚什文去抽烟了，渥伦斯基和他一起下楼回了自己的房间。坐了一会儿，他就跑上楼了。安娜已经穿上了一件她在巴黎做的轻丝绒低领礼服，头上戴着昂贵的白色蕾丝，将她的脸庞衬托得格外合身，将她那耀眼的美丽展现得淋漓尽致。

‘Are you really going to the theater?’ he said, trying not to look at her.
“你真的要去剧院吗？”他说，尽量不看她。

‘Why do you ask with such alarm?’ she said, wounded again at his not looking at her. ‘Why shouldn’t I go?’
“你为什么这么惊慌地问？”她说，因为他没有看她，她再次受伤。 “我为什么不应该去？”

She appeared not to understand the motive of his words.
她似乎不明白他这句话的动机。

‘Oh, of course, there’s no reason whatever,’ he said, frowning.
“哦，当然，没有任何理由，”他皱着眉头说道。

‘That’s just what I say,’ she said, willfully refusing to see the irony of his tone, and quietly turning back her long, perfumed glove.
“我就是这么说的，”她说，故意不肯看出他语气中的讽刺，并悄悄地把长长的、散发着香味的手套转回去。

‘Anna, for God’s sake! what is the matter with you?’ he said, appealing to her exactly as once her husband had done.
‘安娜，看在上帝的份上！你怎么了？”他问道，就像她丈夫以前那样向她求助。

‘I don’t understand what you are asking.’
“我不明白你在问什么。”

‘You know that it’s out of the question to go.’
“你知道去是不可能的。”

‘Why so? I’m not going alone. Princess Varvara has gone to dress, she is going with me.’
'为什么这样？我不会一个人去。瓦尔瓦拉公主已经穿好衣服了，她要和我一起去。

He shrugged his shoulders with an air of perplexity and despair.
他耸了耸肩，神情中充满了困惑和绝望。

‘But do you mean to say you don’t know?...’ he began.
“但是你的意思是说你不知道吗？……”他开始说道。

‘But I don’t care to know!’ she almost shrieked. ‘I don’t care to. Do I regret what I have done? No, no, no! If it were all to do again from the beginning, it would be the same. For us, for you and for me, there is only one thing that matters, whether we love each other. Other people we need not consider. Why are we living here apart and not seeing each other? Why can’t I go? I love you, and I don’t care for anything,’ she said in Russian, glancing at him with a peculiar gleam in her eyes that he could not understand. ‘If you have not changed to me, why don’t you look at me?’
“但我不想知道！”她几乎尖叫起来。 ‘我不在乎。我后悔我所做的事吗？不不不！如果一切从头再来一次，结果还是一样。对于我们，对于你，对于我，只有一件事是重要的，那就是我们是否彼此相爱。其他人我们不需要考虑。为什么我们分居在这里却见不到面？为什么我不能去？我爱你，我什么都不关心。”她用俄语说道，眼睛里闪烁着他无法理解的奇特光芒。 “如果你对我没有改变，为什么不看看我呢？”

He looked at her. He saw all the beauty of her face and full dress, always so becoming to her. But now her beauty and elegance were just what irritated him.
他看着她。他看到她美丽的脸庞和盛装，总是那么适合她。但现在她的美丽和优雅却让他恼火。

‘My feeling cannot change, you know, but I beg you, I entreat you,’ he said again in French, with a note of tender supplication in his voice, but with coldness in his eyes.
“你知道，我的感觉不会改变，但我请求你，我恳求你，”他又用法语说道，声音里带着温柔的恳求，但眼神却冰冷。

She did not hear his words, but she saw the coldness of his eyes, and answered with irritation:
她没有听到他的话，却看到了他眼中的冰冷，恼怒地回答道：

‘And I beg you to explain why I should not go.’
“我请求你解释一下为什么我不应该去。”

‘Because it might cause you...’ he hesitated.
“因为这可能会导致你……”他犹豫道。

‘I don’t understand. Yashvin n’est pas compromettant, and Princess Varvara is no worse than others. Oh, here she is!’
'我不明白。亚什文并不比其他人差，而瓦尔瓦拉公主也不比其他人差。哦，她在这里！

Chapter 33
第33章

Vronsky for the first time experienced a feeling of anger against Anna, almost a hatred for her willfully refusing to understand her own position. This feeling was aggravated by his being unable to tell her plainly the cause of his anger. If he had told her directly what he was thinking, he would have said:
渥伦斯基第一次对安娜产生了愤怒的感觉，几乎是对她故意拒绝理解自己的立场的仇恨。由于他无法清楚地告诉她他愤怒的原因，这种感觉更加强烈。如果他直接告诉她自己的想法，他会说：

‘In that dress, with a princess only too well known to everyone, to show yourself at the theater is equivalent not merely to acknowledging your position as a fallen woman, but is flinging down a challenge to society, that is to say, cutting yourself off from it forever.’
“穿着那件裙子，以一位众所周知的公主的身份出现在剧院，不仅等于承认自己作为一个堕落女人的地位，而且是向社会发起挑战，也就是说，割伤自己永远远离它。

He could not say that to her. ‘But how can she fail to see it, and what is going on in her?’ he said to himself. He felt at the same time that his respect for her was diminished while his sense of her beauty was intensified.
他不能对她说这些。 “但她怎么可能看不到这一点，她身上发生了什么？”他自言自语道。他同时感到自己对她的尊重减少了，而对她美貌的感觉却增强了。

He went back scowling to his rooms, and sitting down beside Yashvin, who, with his long legs stretched out on a chair, was drinking brandy and seltzer water, he ordered a glass of the same for himself.
他皱起眉头回到自己的房间，坐在亚什文旁边，亚什文把长腿伸在椅子上，喝着白兰地和苏打水，他给自己点了一杯同样的酒。

‘You were talking of Lankovsky’s Powerful. That’s a fine horse, and I would advise you to buy him,’ said Yashvin, glancing at his comrade’s gloomy face. ‘His hind-quarters aren’t quite first-rate, but the legs and head—one couldn’t wish for anything better.’
“你刚才谈论的是兰科夫斯基的《Powerful》。那是一匹好马，我建议你买它。”亚什文看着他战友阴沉的脸说道。 “他的后躯不是一流的，但腿和头——没有比这更好的了。”

‘I think I will take him,’ answered Vronsky.
“我想我会带他去，”渥伦斯基回答道。

Their conversation about horses interested him, but he did not for an instant forget Anna, and could not help listening to the sound of steps in the corridor and looking at the clock on the chimney piece.
他们关于马的谈话让他很感兴趣，但他一刻也没有忘记安娜，忍不住听着走廊里的脚步声，看着烟囱上的时钟。

‘Anna Arkadyevna gave orders to announce that she has gone to the theater.’
“安娜·阿尔卡季耶夫娜下令宣布她去了剧院。”

Yashvin, tipping another glass of brandy into the bubbling water, drank it and got up, buttoning his coat.
亚什文又倒了一杯白兰地到冒泡的水中，喝了它，然后站起来，扣上外套的扣子。

‘Well, let’s go,’ he said, faintly smiling under his mustache, and showing by this smile that he knew the cause of Vronsky’s gloominess, and did not attach any significance to it.
“好吧，我们走吧，”他说，胡子下微微一笑，这笑容表明他知道渥伦斯基心情郁闷的原因，而且并不认为它有任何意义。

‘I’m not going,’ Vronsky answered gloomily.
“我不去。”渥伦斯基阴郁地回答。

‘Well, I must, I promised to. Good-bye, then. If you do, come to the stalls; you can take Kruzin’s stall,’ added Yashvin as he went out.
“好吧，我必须，我答应过。那么再见。如果你这样做，就到摊位来； “你可以占领克鲁津的摊位。”亚什文出去时补充道。

‘No, I’m busy.’
'不能，我现在很忙。'

‘A wife is a care, but it’s worse when she’s not a wife,’ thought Yashvin, as he walked out of the hotel.
“妻子是一种关怀，但当她不是妻子时，情况会更糟，”亚什文走出酒店时想。

Vronsky, left alone, got up from his chair and began pacing up and down the room.
渥伦斯基独自一人从椅子上站起来，开始在房间里来回踱步。

‘And what’s today? The fourth night.... Yegor and his wife are there, and my mother, most likely. Of course all Petersburg’s there. Now she’s gone in, taken off her cloak and come into the light. Tushkevitch, Yashvin, Princess Varvara,’ he pictured them to himself.... ‘What about me? Either that I’m frightened or have given up to Tushkevitch the right to protect her? From every point of view—stupid, stupid!... And why is she putting me in such a position?’ he said with a gesture of despair.
‘今天是什么日子？第四天晚上……叶戈尔和他的妻子都在那里，我的母亲也很可能在那里。当然，整个彼得堡都在那里。现在她进去了，脱掉斗篷，来到光亮之中。图什克维奇、亚什文、瓦尔瓦拉公主，”他心里想象着他们……“那我呢？要么是我害怕了，要么是我放弃了图什克维奇保护她的权利？从各个角度来看——愚蠢，愚蠢！……她为什么要把我置于这样的境地？”他带着绝望的表情说道。

With that gesture he knocked against the table, on which there was standing the seltzer water and the decanter of brandy, and almost upset it. He tried to catch it, let it slip, and angrily kicked the table over and rang.
就这样，他撞到了桌子上，桌子上放着苏打水和白兰地酒瓶，差点把桌子打翻。他试图抓住它，但它却滑落了，然后愤怒地踢翻了桌子并按响了门铃。

‘If you care to be in my service,’ he said to the valet who came in, ‘you had better remember your duties. This shouldn’t be here. You ought to have cleared away.’
“如果你愿意为我服务，”他对进来的男仆说，“你最好记住你的职责。这不应该在这里。你应该走开的。

The valet, conscious of his own innocence, would have defended himself, but glancing at his master, he saw from his face that the only thing to do was to be silent, and hurriedly threading his way in and out, dropped down on the carpet and began gathering up the whole and broken glasses and bottles.
男仆自知清白，本想为自己辩解，但看了一眼主人，从他的表情中看出，只能保持沉默，连忙进进出出，倒在地毯上。并开始收集整个和破碎的玻璃杯和瓶子。

‘That’s not your duty; send the waiter to clear away, and get my dress coat out.’
‘那不是你的职责；让服务员走开，把我的礼服拿出来。

Vronsky went into the theater at half-past eight. The performance was in full swing. The little old box-keeper, recognizing Vronsky as he helped him off with his fur coat, called him ‘Your Excellency,’ and suggested he should not take a number but should simply call Fyodor. In the brightly lighted corridor there was no one but the box-opener and two attendants with fur cloaks on their arms listening at the doors. Through the closed doors came the sounds of the discreet staccato accompaniment of the orchestra, and a single female voice rendering distinctly a musical phrase. The door opened to let the box-opener slip through, and the phrase drawing to the end reached Vronsky’s hearing clearly. But the doors were closed again at once, and Vronsky did not hear the end of the phrase and the cadence of the accompaniment, though he knew from the thunder of applause that it was over. When he entered the hall, brilliantly lighted with chandeliers and gas jets, the noise was still going on. On the stage the singer, bowing and smiling, with bare shoulders flashing with diamonds, was, with the help of the tenor who had given her his arm, gathering up the bouquets that were flying awkwardly over the footlights. Then she went up to a gentleman with glossy pomaded hair parted down the center, who was stretching across the footlights holding out something to her, and all the public in the stalls as well as in the boxes was in excitement, craning forward, shouting and clapping. The conductor in his high chair assisted in passing the offering, and straightened his white tie. Vronsky walked into the middle of the stalls, and, standing still, began looking about him. That day less than ever was his attention turned upon the familiar, habitual surroundings, the stage, the noise, all the familiar, uninteresting, particolored herd of spectators in the packed theater.
渥伦斯基八点半走进剧院。演出进行得如火如荼。当渥伦斯基帮他脱下皮大衣时，小个子的老箱子看门人认出了他，称他为“阁下”，并建议他不要拿电话号码，而应该直接给费奥多尔打电话。灯火通明的走廊里，除了开箱的人和两个胳膊上披着毛皮斗篷的侍从在门口听着外，没有人。紧闭的门外传来管弦乐队谨慎的断奏伴奏声，以及一个清晰地演绎出乐句的女声。门打开，开箱器溜了进来，渥伦斯基清楚地听到了最后那句话。但门立刻又关上了，渥伦斯基没有听到乐句的结束和伴奏的节奏，尽管他从雷鸣般的掌声中知道一切都结束了。当他走进吊灯和煤气喷嘴灯火辉煌的大厅时，喧闹声仍在继续。舞台上，歌手微笑着鞠躬，裸露的肩膀上闪烁着钻石，在挽着她手臂的男高音的帮助下，收集着笨拙地飞过脚灯的花束。然后她走到一位头发油光发亮、头发中分的绅士面前，他正伸着懒腰，跨过脚灯，向她递出一样东西，摊位上和包厢里的所有公众都兴奋不已，伸长脖子，大喊大叫。鼓掌。坐在高脚椅上的售票员协助传递祭品，并拉直了他的白领带。渥伦斯基走进摊位中间，站着不动，开始环顾四周。 那天，他的注意力比以往任何时候都少，集中在熟悉的、习惯的环境、舞台、噪音、拥挤的剧院里所有熟悉的、无趣的、色彩斑斓的观众群上。

There were, as always, the same ladies of some sort with officers of some sort in the back of the boxes; the same gaily dressed women—God knows who—and uniforms and black coats; the same dirty crowd in the upper gallery; and among the crowd, in the boxes and in the front rows, were some forty of the real people. And to those oases Vronsky at once directed his attention, and with them he entered at once into relation.
一如既往，包厢后面坐着同样的女士和军官。同样是穿着华丽的女人——天知道是谁——以及制服和黑色外套；上层画廊里同样肮脏的人群；在人群中，包厢里和前排，大约有四十个真正的人。渥伦斯基立即将注意力转向那些绿洲，并立即与它们建立了联系。

The act was over when he went in, and so he did not go straight to his brother’s box, but going up to the first row of stalls stopped at the footlights with Serpuhovskoy, who, standing with one knee raised and his heel on the footlights, caught sight of him in the distance and beckoned to him, smiling.
当他进去时，演出已经结束了，所以他没有直接走向他兄弟的包厢，而是走到第一排摊位，​​谢尔普霍夫斯科伊在脚灯处停了下来，谢尔普霍夫斯科伊单膝抬起，脚后跟踩在脚灯上。远远地看见了他，微笑着向他招手。

Vronsky had not yet seen Anna. He purposely avoided looking in her direction. But he knew by the direction of people’s eyes where she was. He looked round discreetly, but he was not seeking her; expecting the worst, his eyes sought for Alexey Alexandrovitch. To his relief Alexey Alexandrovitch was not in the theater that evening.
渥伦斯基还没有见过安娜。他故意不看她的方向。但他通过人们目光的方向知道她在哪里。他小心翼翼地环顾四周，但并不是在寻找她。他做好了最坏的打算，目光投向阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇。令他松了口气的是，阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇那天晚上没有在剧院。

‘How little of the military man there is left in you!’ Serpuhovskoy was saying to him. ‘A diplomat, an artist, something of that sort, one would say.’
“你身上只剩下多少军人气概了！”谢尔普霍夫斯科伊对他说。 “有人会说，他是一名外交官，一名艺术家，诸如此类的人。”

‘Yes, it was like going back home when I put on a black coat,’ answered Vronsky, smiling and slowly taking out his opera glass.
“是的，当我穿上黑色外套时，就像回到家一样，”渥伦斯基微笑着回答，慢慢地拿出他的望远镜。

‘Well, I’ll own I envy you there. When I come back from abroad and put on this,’ he touched his epaulets, ‘I regret my freedom.’
‘好吧，我承认我很羡慕你。当我从国外回来并穿上这件衣服时，”他摸了摸自己的肩章，“我对自己的自由感到后悔。”

Serpuhovskoy had long given up all hope of Vronsky’s career, but he liked him as before, and was now particularly cordial to him.
谢尔普霍夫斯科伊早已对渥伦斯基的事业失去了一切希望，但他还是一如既往地喜欢他，现在对他特别亲切。

‘What a pity you were not in time for the first act!’
“可惜你没能及时观看第一幕！”

Vronsky, listening with one ear, moved his opera glass from the stalls and scanned the boxes. Near a lady in a turban and a bald old man, who seemed to wave angrily in the moving opera glass, Vronsky suddenly caught sight of Anna’s head, proud, strikingly beautiful, and smiling in the frame of lace. She was in the fifth box, twenty paces from him. She was sitting in front, and slightly turning, was saying something to Yashvin. The setting of her head on her handsome, broad shoulders, and the restrained excitement and brilliance of her eyes and her whole face reminded him of her just as he had seen her at the ball in Moscow. But he felt utterly different towards her beauty now. In his feeling for her now there was no element of mystery, and so her beauty, though it attracted him even more intensely than before, gave him now a sense of injury. She was not looking in his direction, but Vronsky felt that she had seen him already.
渥伦斯基用一只耳朵听着，从隔间上移开望远镜，扫视着盒子。靠近一位戴头巾的女士和一位秃头老人，他们似乎在移动的歌剧玻璃中愤怒地挥手，渥伦斯基突然看到了安娜的头，她骄傲，美丽得惊人，在蕾丝框里微笑。她在第五个包厢里，距离他二十步。她坐在前面，微微转身，正在对亚什文说着什么。她的头靠在她英俊、宽阔的肩膀上，她的眼睛和整张脸都克制着兴奋和光彩，这让他想起了她，就像他在莫斯科的舞会上见过她一样。但现在他对她的美貌有了截然不同的感觉。他现在对她的感情已经没有了神秘的成分，所以她的美貌虽然比以前更吸引他，但现在却给了他一种受伤的感觉。她没有看向他的方向，但渥伦斯基觉得她已经看到了他。

When Vronsky turned the opera glass again in that direction, he noticed that Princess Varvara was particularly red, and kept laughing unnaturally and looking round at the next box. Anna, folding her fan and tapping it on the red velvet, was gazing away and did not see, and obviously did not wish to see, what was taking place in the next box. Yashvin’s face wore the expression which was common when he was losing at cards. Scowling, he sucked the left end of his mustache further and further into his mouth, and cast sidelong glances at the next box.
当渥伦斯基再次将望远镜转向那个方向时，他发现瓦尔瓦拉公主脸色特别红，不停地不自然地笑，并环视着旁边的包厢。安娜折起扇子，敲打着红色天鹅绒，她凝视着别处，没有看到，而且显然也不想看到，下一个盒子里发生了什么。亚什文脸上的表情是他输牌时常见的表情。他皱着眉头，把胡子的左端深深地吸进嘴里，斜眼看了一眼旁边的盒子。

In that box on the left were the Kartasovs. Vronsky knew them, and knew that Anna was acquainted with them. Madame Kartasova, a thin little woman, was standing up in her box, and, her back turned upon Anna, she was putting on a mantle that her husband was holding for her. Her face was pale and angry, and she was talking excitedly. Kartasov, a fat, bald man, was continually looking round at Anna, while he attempted to soothe his wife. When the wife had gone out, the husband lingered a long while, and tried to catch Anna’s eye, obviously anxious to bow to her. But Anna, with unmistakable intention, avoided noticing him, and talked to Yashvin, whose cropped head was bent down to her. Kartasov went out without making his salutation, and the box was left empty.
左边的包厢里住的是卡尔塔索夫一家。渥伦斯基认识他们，也知道安娜也认识他们。卡塔索娃夫人是个瘦小的女人，她站在包厢里，背对着安娜，穿上她丈夫为她拿着的斗篷。她脸色苍白，气愤不已，说起话来激动不已。卡尔塔索夫是个胖秃顶的男人，他一边试图安抚妻子，一边不停地看着安娜。妻子出去后，丈夫逗留了好一会儿，试图吸引安娜的目光，显然急于向她鞠躬。但安娜显然有意避免注意到他，而是与亚什文交谈，而亚什文的短头正向她低下。卡尔塔索夫没有行礼就出去了，箱子里空空如也。

Vronsky could not understand exactly what had passed between the Kartasovs and Anna, but he saw that something humiliating for Anna had happened. He knew this both from what he had seen, and most of all from the face of Anna, who, he could see, was taxing every nerve to carry through the part she had taken up. And in maintaining this attitude of external composure she was completely successful. Anyone who did not know her and her circle, who had not heard all the utterances of the women expressive of commiseration, indignation, and amazement, that she should show herself in society, and show herself so conspicuously with her lace and her beauty, would have admired the serenity and loveliness of this woman without a suspicion that she was undergoing the sensations of a man in the stocks.
渥伦斯基无法理解卡尔塔索夫一家和安娜之间究竟发生了什么，但他看到发生了令安娜羞辱的事情。他从所见所闻，尤其是从安娜的脸上知道了这一点，他可以看到，安娜正竭尽全力地完成她所承担的角色。在保持这种外在镇定的态度方面，她完全成功了。任何不了解她和她的圈子的人，没有听过女人们对她在社会上展示自己，用她的蕾丝和美丽如此引人注目地展示自己的妇女们表达同情、愤慨和惊讶的所有言论，都会我钦佩这个女人的宁静和可爱，而不怀疑她正在经历一个男人的感觉。

Knowing that something had happened, but not knowing precisely what, Vronsky felt a thrill of agonizing anxiety, and hoping to find out something, he went towards his brother’s box. Purposely choosing the way round furthest from Anna’s box, he jostled as he came out against the colonel of his old regiment talking to two acquaintances. Vronsky heard the name of Madame Karenina, and noticed how the colonel hastened to address Vronsky loudly by name, with a meaning glance at his companions.
渥伦斯基知道发生了什么事，但不知道到底发生了什么，他感到一阵痛苦的焦虑，他希望能查出什么情况，于是他走向哥哥的包厢。他特意选择了距离安娜包厢最远的路线，当他出来时，他撞到了正在与两个熟人交谈的老团的上校。渥伦斯基听到了卡列尼娜夫人的名字，注意到上校赶紧大声喊出渥伦斯基的名字，并意味深长地看了他的同伴一眼。

‘Ah, Vronsky! When are you coming to the regiment? We can’t let you off without a supper. You’re one of the old set,’ said the colonel of his regiment.
‘啊，渥伦斯基！你什么时候来部队？我们不能让你不吃晚饭就走。你是老一辈人，”他所在团的上校说。

‘I can’t stop, awfully sorry, another time,’ said Vronsky, and he ran upstairs towards his brother’s box.
“我无法停下来，非常抱歉，下次吧。”渥伦斯基说道，然后他跑上楼，朝他哥哥的包厢走去。

The old countess, Vronsky’s mother, with her steel-gray curls, was in his brother’s box. Varya with the young Princess Sorokina met him in the corridor.
老伯爵夫人，渥伦斯基的母亲，有着钢灰色的卷发，就在他哥哥的包厢里。瓦莉亚和年轻的索罗基娜公主在走廊里遇见了他。

Leaving the Princess Sorokina with her mother, Varya held out her hand to her brother-in-law, and began immediately to speak of what interested him. She was more excited than he had ever seen her.
瓦里娅把索罗基娜公主留给了她的母亲，她向她的姐夫伸出了手，并立即开始谈论他感兴趣的事情。她比他见过的任何时候都更加兴奋。

‘I think it’s mean and hateful, and Madame Kartasova had no right to do it. Madame Karenina...’ she began.
“我认为这是卑鄙和可恨的，卡尔塔索娃夫人没有权利这样做。卡列尼娜夫人……”她开始说道。

‘But what is it? I don’t know.’
‘但是那是什么？我不知道。'

‘What? you’ve not heard?’
'什么？你没听说过吗？

‘You know I should be the last person to hear of it.’
“你知道我应该是最后一个听到这件事的人。”

‘There isn’t a more spiteful creature than that Madame Kartasova!’
“没有比卡尔塔索娃夫人更恶毒的生物了！”

‘But what did she do?’
“但是她做了什么？”

‘My husband told me.... She has insulted Madame Karenina. Her husband began talking to her across the box, and Madame Kartasova made a scene. She said something aloud, he says, something insulting, and went away.’
“我丈夫告诉我……她侮辱了卡列尼娜夫人。她的丈夫开始在包厢对面和她说话，卡尔塔索娃夫人大吵了一架。他说，她大声说了一些侮辱性的话，然后就走了。

‘Count, your maman is asking for you,’ said the young Princess Sorokina, peeping out of the door of the box.
“伯爵，你的妈妈正在找你。”年轻的索罗基娜公主从包厢门里向外张望说道。

‘I’ve been expecting you all the while,’ said his mother, smiling sarcastically. ‘You were nowhere to be seen.’
“我一直在等你。”他的母亲讽刺地微笑着说道。 “你无处可见。”

Her son saw that she could not suppress a smile of delight.
儿子看到她，忍不住露出欣喜的笑容。

‘Good evening, maman. I have come to you,’ he said coldly.
‘晚上好，妈妈。我来找你了。”他冷冷地说。

‘Why aren’t you going to faire la cour a Madame Karenina?’ she went on, when Princess Sorokina had moved away. ‘Elle fait sensation. On oublie la Patti pour elle.’
“你为什么不去招待卡列尼娜夫人呢？”当索罗基娜公主走开时，她继续说道。 ‘Elle fait 感觉。 On oublie la Patti pour elle。

‘Maman, I have asked you not to say anything to me of that,’ he answered, scowling.
“妈妈，我已经请你不要对我说这件事了，”他皱着眉头回答道。

‘I’m only saying what everyone’s saying.’
“我只是说大家都在说的话。”

Vronsky made no reply, and saying a few words to Princess Sorokina, he went away. At the door he met his brother.
渥伦斯基没有回答，只是跟索罗基娜公主说了几句话，就走了。在门口他遇见了他的兄弟。

‘Ah, Alexey!’ said his brother. ‘How disgusting! Idiot of a woman, nothing else.... I wanted to go straight to her. Let’s go together.’
“啊，阿列克谢！”他的兄弟说。 '真恶心！一个白痴女人，仅此而已……我想直接去找她。咱们一起去吧。'

Vronsky did not hear him. With rapid steps he went downstairs; he felt that he must do something, but he did not know what. Anger with her for having put herself and him in such a false position, together with pity for her suffering, filled his heart. He went down, and made straight for Anna’s box. At her box stood Stremov, talking to her.
渥伦斯基没有听见他的话。他迈着快步下了楼。他觉得他必须做点什么，但他不知道做什么。他心中充满了对她把自己和他置于如此错误的境地的愤怒，以及对她所受痛苦的怜悯。他下去，径直走向安娜的包厢。斯特雷莫夫站在她的包厢旁，正在和她说话。

‘There are no more tenors. Le moule en est brise!’
‘不再有男高音了。 Le moule en est brise！’

Vronsky bowed to her and stopped to greet Stremov.
渥伦斯基向她鞠了一躬，并停下来迎接斯特列莫夫。

‘You came in late, I think, and have missed the best song,’ Anna said to Vronsky, glancing ironically, he thought, at him.
“我想你来晚了，错过了最好的歌曲，”安娜对渥伦斯基说道，他想，她讽刺地看了他一眼。

‘I am a poor judge of music,’ he said, looking sternly at her.
“我对音乐的判断能力很差，”他严厉地看着她说道。

‘Like Prince Yashvin,’ she said smiling, ‘who considers that Patti sings too loud.’
“就像亚什文王子一样，”她微笑着说，“他认为帕蒂唱歌太大声了。”

‘Thank you,’ she said, her little hand in its long glove taking the playbill Vronsky picked up, and suddenly at that instant her lovely face quivered. She got up and went into the interior of the box.
“谢谢你，”她说，她戴着长手套的小手接过渥伦斯基捡起的节目单，在那一刻，她可爱的脸突然颤抖起来。她起身，走进包厢内部。

Noticing in the next act that her box was empty, Vronsky, rousing indignant ‘hushes’ in the silent audience, went out in the middle of a solo and drove home.
在下一幕中，渥伦斯基注意到她的包厢是空的，引起了沉默的观众愤怒的“嘘声”，她在独奏中出去开车回家。

Anna was already at home. When Vronsky went up to her, she was in the same dress as she had worn at the theater. She was sitting in the first armchair against the wall, looking straight before her. She looked at him, and at once resumed her former position.
安娜已经在家了。当渥伦斯基走到她面前时，她穿着和在剧院时穿的一样的衣服。她坐在第一张靠墙的扶手椅上，直视前方。她看了他一眼，立刻又恢复了原来的姿势。

‘Anna,’ he said.
“安娜，”他说。

‘You, you are to blame for everything!’ she cried, with tears of despair and hatred in her voice, getting up.
“你，一切都要怪罪你！”她站了起来，声音里充满了绝望和仇恨的泪水。

‘I begged, I implored you not to go, I knew it would be unpleasant....’
“我恳求过，我恳求你不要去，我知道那会很不愉快……”

‘Unpleasant!’ she cried—‘hideous! As long as I live I shall never forget it. She said it was a disgrace to sit beside me.’
“令人不快！”她喊道，“太可怕了！只要我活着，我就永远不会忘记它。她说坐在我旁边是一种耻辱。

‘A silly woman’s chatter,’ he said: ‘but why risk it, why provoke?...’
“一个愚蠢女人的喋喋不休，”他说：“但为什么要冒这个险，为什么要挑衅呢？……”

‘I hate your calm. You ought not to have brought me to this. If you had loved me...’
‘我讨厌你的冷静。你不应该把我带到这个地步。如果你爱过我的话……”

‘Anna! How does the question of my love come in?’
‘安娜！我的爱情问题是怎么来的？

‘Oh, if you loved me, as I love, if you were tortured as I am!...’ she said, looking at him with an expression of terror.
“哦，如果你像我一样爱我，如果你像我一样受到折磨！……”她说道，一脸恐惧地看着他。

He was sorry for her, and angry notwithstanding. He assured her of his love because he saw that this was the only means of soothing her, and he did not reproach her in words, but in his heart he reproached her.
他为她感到难过，尽管如此，他还是很生气。他向她保证他的爱，因为他看到这是抚慰她的唯一方法，他没有在言语上责备她，但在心里却在责备她。

And the asseverations of his love, which seemed to him so vulgar that he was ashamed to utter them, she drank in eagerly, and gradually became calmer. The next day, completely reconciled, they left for the country.
而他对爱情的表白，在他看来是那么粗俗，以至于羞于说出口，她却热切地听着，渐渐地变得平静了。第二天，他们完全和解了，启程回国了。

PART 6
第 6 部分

Chapter 1
第1章

Darya Alexandrovna spent the summer with her children at Pokrovskoe, at her sister Kitty Levin’s. The house on her own estate was quite in ruins, and Levin and his wife had persuaded her to spend the summer with them. Stepan Arkadyevitch greatly approved of the arrangement. He said he was very sorry his official duties prevented him from spending the summer in the country with his family, which would have been the greatest happiness for him; and remaining in Moscow, he came down to the country from time to time for a day or two. Besides the Oblonskys, with all their children and their governess, the old princess too came to stay that summer with the Levins, as she considered it her duty to watch over her inexperienced daughter in her interesting condition. Moreover, Varenka, Kitty’s friend abroad, kept her promise to come to Kitty when she was married, and stayed with her friend. All of these were friends or relations of Levin’s wife. And though he liked them all, he rather regretted his own Levin world and ways, which was smothered by this influx of the ‘Shtcherbatsky element,’ as he called it to himself. Of his own relations there stayed with him only Sergey Ivanovitch, but he too was a man of the Koznishev and not the Levin stamp, so that the Levin spirit was utterly obliterated.
达里娅·亚历山德罗芙娜 (Darya Alexandrovna) 和孩子们在波克罗夫斯科 (Pokrovskoe) 她姐姐基蒂·莱文 (Kitty Levin) 家度过了夏天。她自己庄园里的房子已经成了废墟，莱文和他的妻子说服她和他们一起度过夏天。斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇非常赞同这个安排。他说，他非常遗憾自己的公务使他无法与家人一起去乡下度过夏天，这对他来说是最大的幸福；他留在莫斯科，时不时地到乡下去住一两天。那年夏天，除了奥布朗斯基夫妇、他们的孩子和家庭教师之外，老公主也来到了莱文夫妇家里，因为她认为照顾她缺乏经验的女儿的有趣状况是她的责任。而且，基蒂在国外的朋友瓦伦卡也兑现了她结婚时来到基蒂身边的承诺，和她的朋友住在一起。所有这些都是莱文妻子的朋友或亲戚。尽管他喜欢所有这些，但他对自己的莱文世界和方式感到相当遗憾，因为他自称是“谢尔巴茨基元素”的涌入，他的世界和方式被窒息了。在他自己的亲戚中，只有谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇留在他身边，但他也是科兹尼舍夫的人，而不是列文的印记，因此列文精神被彻底抹杀了。

In the Levins’ house, so long deserted, there were now so many people that almost all the rooms were occupied, and almost every day it happened that the old princess, sitting down to table, counted them all over, and put the thirteenth grandson or granddaughter at a separate table. And Kitty, with her careful housekeeping, had no little trouble to get all the chickens, turkeys, and geese, of which so many were needed to satisfy the summer appetites of the visitors and children.
莱文家已经荒废了许久，现在人太多了，几乎所有的房间都被占满了，几乎每天都会发生这样的事：老公主坐在桌前，清点人数，把十三孙子放进去。或孙女在单独的桌子上。基蒂在她细心的家务管理下，不费吹灰之力就得到了所有的鸡、火鸡和鹅，这些鸡、火鸡和鹅需要很多来满足游客和孩子们夏天的胃口。

The whole family were sitting at dinner. Dolly’s children, with their governess and Varenka, were making plans for going to look for mushrooms. Sergey Ivanovitch, who was looked up to by all the party for his intellect and learning, with a respect that almost amounted to awe, surprised everyone by joining in the conversation about mushrooms.
全家人坐在一起吃晚饭。多莉的孩子们和他们的家庭教师以及瓦伦卡正在计划去寻找蘑菇。谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇（Sergey Ivanovitch）因其才智和学识而受到全党人士的尊敬，他的尊敬近乎敬畏，但他加入有关蘑菇的谈话，令所有人感到惊讶。

‘Take me with you. I am very fond of picking mushrooms,’ he said, looking at Varenka; ‘I think it’s a very nice occupation.’
'带我一起走。我非常喜欢采蘑菇，”他看着瓦伦卡说道。 “我认为这是一个非常好的职业。”

‘Oh, we shall be delighted,’ answered Varenka, coloring a little. Kitty exchanged meaningful glances with Dolly. The proposal of the learned and intellectual Sergey Ivanovitch to go looking for mushrooms with Varenka confirmed certain theories of Kitty’s with which her mind had been very busy of late. She made haste to address some remark to her mother, so that her look should not be noticed. After dinner Sergey Ivanovitch sat with his cup of coffee at the drawing-room window, and while he took part in a conversation he had begun with his brother, he watched the door through which the children would start on the mushroom-picking expedition. Levin was sitting in the window near his brother.
“哦，我们会很高兴的，”瓦伦卡回答道，脸色有点红。基蒂和多莉交换了一个意味深长的眼神。博学多才的谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇提议和瓦伦卡一起去寻找蘑菇，这证实了基蒂最近一直在思考的某些理论。她赶紧跟母亲说了几句话，免得别人注意到她的样子。晚饭后，谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇端着咖啡坐在客厅的窗前，一边参加他和弟弟开始的谈话，一边看着那扇门，孩子们将通过这扇门开始采蘑菇之旅。莱文坐在他哥哥旁边的窗边。

Kitty stood beside her husband, evidently awaiting the end of a conversation that had no interest for her, in order to tell him something.
基蒂站在她丈夫身边，显然是在等待一场她不感兴趣的谈话结束，以便告诉他一些事情。

‘You have changed in many respects since your marriage, and for the better,’ said Sergey Ivanovitch, smiling to Kitty, and obviously little interested in the conversation, ‘but you have remained true to your passion for defending the most paradoxical theories.’
“自从结婚以来，你在很多方面都发生了变化，而且变得更好了，”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇对基蒂微笑着说，显然对谈话不感兴趣，“但你仍然忠于捍卫最自相矛盾的理论的热情。”

‘Katya, it’s not good for you to stand,’ her husband said to her, putting a chair for her and looking significantly at her.
“卡蒂亚，你站着不好。”她的丈夫一边给她放了一把椅子，一边意味深长地看着她。

‘Oh, and there’s no time either,’ added Sergey Ivanovitch, seeing the children running out.
“哦，也没有时间了，”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇补充道，看到孩子们已经跑完了。

At the head of them all Tanya galloped sideways, in her tightlydrawn stockings, and waving a basket and Sergey Ivanovitch’s hat, she ran straight up to him.
塔尼娅在他们的最前头，侧身疾驰，穿着紧紧拉紧的长袜，挥舞着篮子和谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇的帽子，径直跑向他。

Boldly running up to Sergey Ivanovitch with shining eyes, so like her father’s fine eyes, she handed him his hat and made as though she would put it on for him, softening her freedom by a shy and friendly smile.
她勇敢地跑到谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇面前，眼睛闪闪发亮，就像她父亲那双漂亮的眼睛一样，她把帽子递给他，做出一副要替他戴上的样子，害羞而友好的微笑软化了她的自由。

‘Varenka’s waiting,’ she said, carefully putting his hat on, seeing from Sergey Ivanovitch’s smile that she might do so.
“瓦伦卡正在等着。”她小心翼翼地给他戴上帽子，从谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇的微笑中看出她可能会这么做。

Varenka was standing at the door, dressed in a yellow print gown, with a white kerchief on her head.
瓦伦卡站在门口，穿着黄色印花长袍，头上戴着白色头巾。

‘I’m coming, I’m coming, Varvara Andreevna,’ said Sergey Ivanovitch, finishing his cup of coffee, and putting into their separate pockets his handkerchief and cigar-case.
“我来了，我来了，瓦尔瓦拉·安德烈耶夫娜。”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇喝完咖啡，把手帕和雪茄盒分别放进各自的口袋里。

‘And how sweet my Varenka is! eh?’ said Kitty to her husband, as soon as Sergey Ivanovitch rose. She spoke so that Sergey Ivanovitch could hear, and it was clear that she meant him to do so. ‘And how good-looking she is—such a refined beauty! Varenka!’ Kitty shouted. ‘Shall you be in the mill copse? We’ll come out to you.’
‘我的瓦莲卡多么可爱啊！嗯？”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇一站起来，基蒂就对她的丈夫说道。她说话的方式是让谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇听得见，显然她是想让他这么做。 ‘而且她长得多么漂亮啊——多么精致的美人啊！瓦伦卡！”基蒂喊道。 “你要去磨坊树林里吗？我们会来找你的。

‘You certainly forget your condition, Kitty,’ said the old princess, hurriedly coming out at the door. ‘You mustn’t shout like that.’
“你肯定忘记了自己的处境，基蒂。”老公主说着，急匆匆地从门口走了出来。 “你不可以那样喊叫。”

Varenka, hearing Kitty’s voice and her mother’s reprimand, went with light, rapid steps up to Kitty. The rapidity of her movement, her flushed and eager face, everything betrayed that something out of the common was going on in her. Kitty knew what this was, and had been watching her intently. She called Varenka at that moment merely in order mentally to give her a blessing for the important event which, as Kitty fancied, was bound to come to pass that day after dinner in the wood.
瓦莲卡听到凯蒂的声音和母亲的训斥，迈着轻快的步伐走到凯蒂面前。她的动作之快，她的脸色通红而热切，一切都表明她身上正在发生一些不寻常的事情。凯蒂知道这是什么，一直专注地看着她。她当时打电话给瓦伦卡只是为了在心里为她的重要事件祝福，正如基蒂想象的那样，那天在树林里吃完晚饭后，这件事注定会发生。

‘Varenka, I should be very happy if a certain something were to happen,’ she whispered as she kissed her.
“瓦伦卡，如果发生某件事，我会很高兴，”她在亲吻她时低声说道。

‘And are you coming with us?’ Varenka said to Levin in confusion, pretending not to have heard what had been said.
“你要和我们一起去吗？”瓦伦卡困惑地对莱文说，假装没有听到他们所说的话。

‘I am coming, but only as far as the threshing-floor, and there I shall stop.’
“我来了，但只到了打谷场，我就停在那里。”

‘Why, what do you want there?’ said Kitty.
“为什么，你想在那里做什么？”基蒂说。

‘I must go to have a look at the new wagons, and to check the invoice,’ said Levin; ‘and where will you be?’
“我必须去看看新货车，并检查发票，”莱文说。 “你会在哪里？”

‘On the terrace.’
“在露台上。”

Chapter 2
第2章

On the terrace were assembled all the ladies of the party. They always liked sitting there after dinner, and that day they had work to do there too.
