Next, a whole crowd of country gentlemen, surrounding a stout general, hurriedly came near Levin. These persons were unmistakably seeking a place where they could talk without being overheard.
接下来，一大群乡村绅士，围着一位身材魁梧的将军，急忙来到了莱文身边。毫无疑问，这些人正在寻找一个可以说话而不被偷听的地方。

‘How dare he say I had his breeches stolen! Pawned them for drink, I expect. Damn the fellow, prince indeed! He’d better not say it, the beast!’
“他怎么敢说我把他的马裤偷了！”我想，是把它们当了酒的。该死的家伙，确实是王子！他最好别说出来，野兽！”

‘But excuse me! They take their stand on the act,’ was being said in another group; ‘the wife must be registered as noble.’
'但是请原谅！他们对这一行为采取了自己的立场。”另一个群体中有人这样说道。 “妻子必须登记为贵族。”

‘Oh, damn your acts! I speak from my heart. We’re all gentlemen, aren’t we? Above suspicion.’
‘哦，该死的你的行为！我发自内心地说。我们都是绅士，不是吗？无可怀疑。

‘Shall we go on, your excellency, fine champagne?’
“我们继续吧，阁下，上等香槟吗？”

Another group was following a nobleman, who was shouting something in a loud voice; it was one of the three intoxicated gentlemen.
另一群人跟踪着一位贵族，他大声喊着什么。那是三位醉酒先生之一。

‘I always advised Marya Semyonovna to let for a fair rent, for she can never save a profit,’ he heard a pleasant voice say. The speaker was a country gentleman with gray whiskers, wearing the regimental uniform of an old general staff-officer. It was the very landowner Levin had met at Sviazhsky’s. He knew him at once. The landowner too stared at Levin, and they exchanged greetings.
“我总是建议玛丽亚·谢苗诺夫娜以公平的租金出租，因为她永远无法节省利润，”他听到一个愉快的声音说道。说话的人是一位留着灰色胡须的乡村绅士，穿着一位老总参谋长的团服。这就是列文在斯维亚日斯基家遇见的那位地主。他立刻就认出了他。地主也盯着莱文，两人寒暄了几声。

‘Very glad to see you! To be sure! I remember you very well. Last year at our district marshal, Nikolay Ivanovitch’s.’
‘很高兴见到你！为了确定！我记得你很清楚。去年在我们的地区元帅尼古拉·伊万诺维奇那里。

‘Well, and how is your land doing?’ asked Levin.
“那么，你的土地怎么样了？”莱文问道。

‘Oh, still just the same, always at a loss,’ the landowner answered with a resigned smile, but with an expression of serenity and conviction that so it must be. ‘And how do you come to be in our province?’ he asked. ‘Come to take part in our coup d’etat?’ he said, confidently pronouncing the French words with a bad accent. ‘All Russia’s here—gentlemen of the bedchamber, and everything short of the ministry.’ He pointed to the imposing figure of Stepan Arkadyevitch in white trousers and his court uniform, walking by with a general.
“噢，还是一样，总是不知所措。”地主带着无奈的微笑回答道，但脸上却带着平静和确信，事情一定是这样的。 “你怎么会来到我们省？”他问道。 “来参加我们的政变吗？”他说道，自信地用糟糕的口音发音着法语单词。 “整个俄罗斯都在这儿——内室的先生们，还有除了内阁以外的一切人。”他指着身穿白裤子和宫廷制服的斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇威风凛凛的身影，正和一位将军走过。

‘I ought to own that I don’t very well understand the drift of the provincial elections,’ said Levin.
“我应该承认，我不太了解省级选举的走向，”莱文说。

The landowner looked at him.
地主看着他。

‘Why, what is there to understand? There’s no meaning in it at all. It’s a decaying institution that goes on running only by the force of inertia. Just look, the very uniforms tell you that it’s an assembly of justices of the peace, permanent members of the court, and so on, but not of noblemen.’
‘为什么，有什么好理解的？这根本没有任何意义。这是一个腐朽的机构，仅靠惯性力继续运转。只要看，制服就告诉你，这是一个由太平绅士、法院常任成员等组成的集会，但不是贵族的集会。

‘Then why do you come?’ asked Levin.
“那你为什么来？”莱文问道。

‘From habit, nothing else. Then, too, one must keep up connections. It’s a moral obligation of a sort. And then, to tell the truth, there’s one’s own interests. My son-in-law wants to stand as a permanent member; they’re not rich people, and he must be brought forward. These gentlemen, now, what do they come for?’ he said, pointing to the malignant gentleman, who was talking at the high table.
‘出于习惯，没有别的。然后，人们还必须保持联系。这是某种道德义务。然后，说实话，还有自己的利益。我的女婿想成为常任理事国；他们不是富人，他必须被提拔。现在，这些先生们来干什么？”他指着在高桌旁说话的那位恶毒的先生说道。

‘That’s the new generation of nobility.’
“那是新一代的贵族。”

‘New it may be, but nobility it isn’t. They’re proprietors of a sort, but we’re the landowners. As noblemen, they’re cutting their own throats.’
“它可能是新的，但它不是高贵的。他们是某种业主，但我们是土地所有者。作为贵族，他们正在割断自己的喉咙。

‘But you say it’s an institution that’s served its time.’
“但你说这是一个已经过时的机构了。”

‘That it may be, but still it ought to be treated a little more respectfully. Snetkov, now...We may be of use, or we may not, but we’re the growth of a thousand years. If we’re laying out a garden, planning one before the house, you know, and there you’ve a tree that’s stood for centuries in the very spot.... Old and gnarled it may be, and yet you don’t cut down the old fellow to make room for the flowerbeds, but lay out your beds so as to take advantage of the tree. You won’t grow him again in a year,’ he said cautiously, and he immediately changed the conversation. ‘Well, and how is your land doing?’
“也许是这样，但仍然应该受到更尊重的对待。斯涅特科夫，现在……我们可能有用，也可能没用，但我们是一千年的成长。如果我们正在布置一个花园，在房子之前规划一个花园，你知道，那里有一棵树已经在原地矗立了几个世纪了……它可能又老又粗糙，但你却没有砍倒老家伙，为花坛腾出空间，但布置你的花坛，以便充分利用这棵树。一年之内你就不会再让他长大了。”他小心翼翼地说，然后他立即改变了话题。 “那么，你的土地怎么样了？”

‘Oh, not very well. I make five per cent.’
‘哦，不太好。我赚百分之五。

‘Yes, but you don’t reckon your own work. Aren’t you worth something too? I’ll tell you my own case. Before I took to seeing after the land, I had a salary of three hundred pounds from the service. Now I do more work than I did in the service, and like you I get five per cent. on the land, and thank God for that. But one’s work is thrown in for nothing.’
‘是的，但你不计算你自己的工作。你不也有价值吗？我给你讲一下我自己的案例。在我开始照管土地之前，我从这项服务中获得了三百英镑的工资。现在我做的工作比在军队里做的还要多，而且和你一样，我的工资是百分之五。在这片土地上，并为此感谢上帝。但一个人的工作却白费了。”

‘Then why do you do it, if it’s a clear loss?’
“那你为什么要这样做，如果这是明显的损失呢？”

‘Oh, well, one does it! What would you have? It’s habit, and one knows it’s how it should be. And what’s more,’ the landowner went on, leaning his elbows on the window and chatting on, ‘my son, I must tell you, has no taste for it. There’s no doubt he’ll be a scientific man. So there’ll be no one to keep it up. And yet one does it. Here this year I’ve planted an orchard.’
‘哦，好吧，有人做到了！你想要什么？这是一种习惯，人们知道它应该是这样的。更重要的是，”地主继续说，把胳膊肘靠在窗户上，继续聊天，“我必须告诉你，我的儿子不喜欢它。毫无疑问，他将成为一名科学家。所以不会有人坚持下去。然而有人做到了。今年我在这里种植了一个果园。

‘Yes, yes,’ said Levin, ‘that’s perfectly true. I always feel there’s no real balance of gain in my work on the land, and yet one does it.... It’s a sort of duty one feels to the land.’
“是的，是的，”莱文说，“完全正确。我总觉得我在这片土地上的工作没有真正的收益平衡，但人们还是这么做了……这是一种人们对土地的责任。

‘But I tell you what,’ the landowner pursued; ‘a neighbor of mine, a merchant, was at my place. We walked about the fields and the garden. ‘No,’ said he, ‘Stepan Vassilievitch, everything’s well looked after, but your garden’s neglected.’ But, as a fact, it’s well kept up. ‘To my thinking, I’d cut down that lime-tree. Here you’ve thousands of limes, and each would make two good bundles of bark. And nowadays that bark’s worth something. I’d cut down the lot.’’
“但我告诉你什么，”地主继续说道。 “我的一个邻居，一个商人，在我家。我们在田野和花园里散步。 “不，”他说，“斯捷潘·瓦西里耶维奇，一切都照顾得很好，但你的花园却被忽视了。”但是，事实上，它维护得很好。 “按照我的想法，我会砍掉那棵椴树。这里有数千个酸橙，每个酸橙都可以制成两捆上等的树皮。如今，那树皮还是有价值的。我会砍掉很多。”

‘And with what he made he’d increase his stock, or buy some land for a trifle, and let it out in lots to the peasants,’ Levin added, smiling. He had evidently more than once come across those commercial calculations. ‘And he’d make his fortune. But you and I must thank God if we keep what we’ve got and leave it to our children.’
“用他赚到的钱，他会增加库存，或者花一点钱买一些土地，然后分批分给农民，”莱文微笑着补充道。这些商业算计他显然不止一次遇到过。 “他会发财的。”但如果我们保留我们所拥有的并将其留给我们的孩子，你和我必须感谢上帝。”

‘You’re married, I’ve heard?’ said the landowner.
“我听说你结婚了？”地主问道。

‘Yes,’ Levin answered, with proud satisfaction. ‘Yes, it’s rather strange,’ he went on. ‘So we live without making anything, as though we were ancient vestals set to keep in a fire.’
“是的，”莱文满意地回答。 “是的，这很奇怪，”他继续说道。 “所以我们生活中不制造任何东西，就好像我们是被放在火里的古代贞女一样。”

The landowner chuckled under his white mustaches.
地主在白胡子下咯咯笑。

‘There are some among us, too, like our friend Nikolay Ivanovitch, or Count Vronsky, that’s settled here lately, who try to carry on their husbandry as though it were a factory; but so far it leads to nothing but making away with capital on it.’
“我们当中也有一些人，比如我们的朋友尼古拉·伊万诺维奇，或者最近定居在这里的渥伦斯基伯爵，他们试图像工厂一样继续他们的畜牧业；但到目前为止，除了掠夺资本之外，什么也没有。”

‘But why is it we don’t do like the merchants? Why don’t we cut down our parks for timber?’ said Levin, returning to a thought that had struck him.
“但是为什么我们不像商人那样呢？我们为什么不砍伐我们的公园来获取木材呢？”莱文说道，回到了他突然想到的一个想法。

‘Why, as you said, to keep the fire in. Besides that’s not work for a nobleman. And our work as noblemen isn’t done here at the elections, but yonder, each in our corner. There’s a class instinct, too, of what one ought and oughtn’t to do. There’s the peasants, too, I wonder at them sometimes; any good peasant tries to take all the land he can. However bad the land is, he’ll work it. Without a return too. At a simple loss.’
“为什么，正如你所说，要把火关起来。而且这不是贵族的工作。”作为贵族，我们的工作不是在选举中完成的，而是在远处，在我们每个角落里完成的。还有一种阶级本能，即人们应该做什么和不应该做什么。还有农民，我有时对他们感到奇怪；任何一个好农民都会尽力夺取所有他能拥有的土地。无论土地多么糟糕，他都会耕种。亦无回报。简单的损失。

‘Just as we do,’ said Levin. ‘Very, very glad to have met you,’ he added, seeing Sviazhsky approaching him.
“就像我们一样，”莱文说。 “非常非常高兴见到你，”他补充道，看到斯维亚日斯基向他走来。

‘And here we’ve met for the first time since we met at your place,’ said the landowner to Sviazhsky, ‘and we’ve had a good talk too.’
“自从我们在你家见面以来，这是我们第一次见面，”地主对斯维亚日斯基说，“我们也聊得很开心。”

‘Well, have you been attacking the new order of things?’ said Sviazhsky with a smile.
“嗯，你一直在攻击新秩序吗？”斯维亚日斯基微笑着说道。

‘That we’re bound to do.’
“这是我们必须做的。”

‘You’ve relieved your feelings?’
“你的心情缓解了吗？”

Chapter 30
第30章

Sviazhsky took Levin’s arm, and went with him to his own friends. This time there was no avoiding Vronsky. He was standing with Stepan Arkadyevitch and Sergey Ivanovitch, and looking straight at Levin as he drew near.
斯维亚日斯基挽着列文的手臂，和他一起去见他自己的朋友们。这一次，渥伦斯基无法回避。他和斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇和谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇站在一起，当列文走近时，他直视着他。

‘Delighted! I believe I’ve had the pleasure of meeting you...at Princess Shtcherbatskaya’s,’ he said, giving Levin his hand.
'高兴极了！我想我很高兴在谢尔巴茨卡娅公主家里见到你。”他一边说，一边向莱文伸出了手。

‘Yes, I quite remember our meeting,’ said Levin, and blushing crimson, he turned away immediately, and began talking to his brother.
“是的，我清楚地记得我们的会面，”莱文脸红了，立即转过身去，开始和他的兄弟说话。

With a slight smile Vronsky went on talking to Sviazhsky, obviously without the slightest inclination to enter into conversation with Levin. But Levin, as he talked to his brother, was continually looking round at Vronsky, trying to think of something to say to him to gloss over his rudeness.
渥伦斯基微微一笑，继续和斯维亚日斯基说话，显然没有丝毫想和列文交谈的意思。但列文在与他的兄弟交谈时，不断地看着渥伦斯基，试图想出一些话来对他说些什么，以掩饰他的粗鲁。

‘What are we waiting for now?’ asked Levin, looking at Sviazhsky and Vronsky.
“我们现在还等什么？”列文看着斯维亚日斯基和渥伦斯基问道。

‘For Snetkov. He has to refuse or to consent to stand,’ answered Sviazhsky.
“为了斯涅特科夫。”他必须拒绝或同意起立，”斯维亚日斯基回答道。

‘Well, and what has he done, consented or not?’
“那么，他做了什么，同意与否？”

‘That’s the point, that he’s done neither,’ said Vronsky.
“这就是重点，他两者都没有做到，”渥伦斯基说。

‘And if he refuses, who will stand then?’ asked Levin, looking at Vronsky.
“如果他拒绝，那么谁会站出来呢？”列文看着渥伦斯基问道。

‘Whoever chooses to,’ said Sviazhsky.
“无论谁选择，”斯维亚日斯基说。

‘Shall you?’ asked Levin.
“你愿意吗？”莱文问道。

‘Certainly not I,’ said Sviazhsky, looking confused, and turning an alarmed glance at the malignant gentleman, who was standing beside Sergey Ivanovitch.
“当然不是我，”斯维亚日斯基说道，他一脸困惑，转过头警惕地看了一眼站在谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇旁边的恶毒的绅士。

‘Who then? Nevyedovsky?’ said Levin, feeling he was putting his foot into it.
‘那是谁呢？涅维耶多夫斯基？”列文说道，感觉自己正在踏入其中。

But this was worse still. Nevyedovsky and Sviazhsky were the two candidates.
但这更糟。涅维耶多夫斯基和斯维亚日斯基是两名候选人。

‘I certainly shall not, under any circumstances,’ answered the malignant gentleman.
“无论如何，我当然不会，”恶毒的绅士回答道。

This was Nevyedovsky himself. Sviazhsky introduced him to Levin.
这就是涅维耶多夫斯基本人。斯维亚日斯基把他介绍给莱文。

‘Well, you find it exciting too?’ said Stepan Arkadyevitch, winking at Vronsky. ‘It’s something like a race. One might bet on it.’
“嗯，你也觉得这很令人兴奋吗？”斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇对渥伦斯基挤挤眼，说道。 ‘这就像一场比赛。人们可能会打赌。

‘Yes, it is keenly exciting,’ said Vronsky. ‘And once taking the thing up, one’s eager to see it through. It’s a fight!’ he said, scowling and setting his powerful jaws.
“是的，这非常令人兴奋，”渥伦斯基说。 “一旦接手这件事，人们就会渴望把它看完。”这是一场战斗！”他皱起眉头，咬紧牙关说道。

‘What a capable fellow Sviazhsky is! Sees it all so clearly.’
‘斯维亚日斯基真是个能干的家伙！一切都看得如此清楚。

‘Oh, yes!’ Vronsky assented indifferently.
“哦，是的！”渥伦斯基漠然地答应道。

A silence followed, during which Vronsky—since he had to look at something—looked at Levin, at his feet, at his uniform, then at his face, and noticing his gloomy eyes fixed upon him, he said, in order to say something:
接下来是一阵沉默，在此期间渥伦斯基——因为他必须看什么东西——看看莱文，看看他的脚，看看他的制服，然后看看他的脸，注意到他阴沉的眼睛盯着他，他说，为了说些什么：

‘How is it that you, living constantly in the country, are not a justice of the peace? You are not in the uniform of one.’
‘你常年生活在乡下，怎么就不是治安法官呢？你不穿制服。

‘It’s because I consider that the justice of the peace is a silly institution,’ Levin answered gloomily. He had been all the time looking for an opportunity to enter into conversation with Vronsky, so as to smooth over his rudeness at their first meeting.
“因为我认为治安法官是一个愚蠢的机构，”莱文阴沉地回答道。他一直在寻找机会与渥伦斯基交谈，以平息第一次见面时的无礼行为。

‘I don’t think so, quite the contrary,’ Vronsky said, with quiet surprise.
“我不这么认为，恰恰相反，”渥伦斯基带着平静的惊讶说道。

‘It’s a plaything,’ Levin cut him short. ‘We don’t want justices of the peace. I’ve never had a single thing to do with them during eight years. And what I have had was decided wrongly by them. The justice of the peace is over thirty miles from me. For some matter of two roubles I should have to send a lawyer, who costs me fifteen.’
“这是一个玩具，”莱文打断他的话。 “我们不需要太平绅士。八年来我从来没有和他们做过任何事。而我所拥有的一切都是他们错误的决定。治安法官距离我有三十多英里。为了两卢布的事情，我必须派一名律师，花费我十五卢布。

And he related how a peasant had stolen some flour from the miller, and when the miller told him of it, had lodged a complaint for slander. All this was utterly uncalled for and stupid, and Levin felt it himself as he said it.
他还讲述了一个农民如何从磨坊主那里偷了一些面粉，当磨坊主告诉他这件事时，他提出了诽谤投诉。这一切都是毫无道理和愚蠢的，莱文说这话时自己也感觉到了。

‘Oh, this is such an original fellow!’ said Stepan Arkadyevitch with his most soothing, almond-oil smile. ‘But come along; I think they’re voting....’
“哦，这真是一个很有创意的家伙！”斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇带着他最令人安心的杏仁油微笑说道。 “但是来吧；我认为他们正在投票……”

And they separated.
他们分开了。

‘I can’t understand,’ said Sergey Ivanovitch, who had observed his brother’s clumsiness, ‘I can’t understand how anyone can be so absolutely devoid of political tact. That’s where we Russians are so deficient. The marshal of the province is our opponent, and with him you’re ami cochon, and you beg him to stand. Count Vronsky, now ...I’m not making a friend of him; he’s asked me to dinner, and I’m not going; but he’s one of our side—why make an enemy of him? Then you ask Nevyedovsky if he’s going to stand. That’s not a thing to do.’
“我无法理解，”谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇（Sergey Ivanovitch）观察到了他哥哥的笨拙，说道，“我无法理解一个人怎么会如此缺乏政治机智。”这就是我们俄罗斯人的不足之处。省元帅是我们的对手，和他在一起你就是阿米科琼，你求他站起来。渥伦斯基伯爵，现在……我不是要和他交朋友；我不是要和他交朋友。他请我吃饭，我不去；但他是我们这边的一员——为什么要与他为敌呢？然后你问涅维耶多夫斯基他是否会站起来。这不是一件该做的事。

‘Oh, I don’t understand it at all! And it’s all such nonsense,’ Levin answered gloomily.
‘哎呀，我根本不明白！这都是胡说八道。”莱文阴沉地回答道。

‘You say it’s all such nonsense, but as soon as you have anything to do with it, you make a muddle.’
“你说这些都是废话，但一扯上关系，你就糊涂了。”

Levin did not answer, and they walked together into the big room.
莱文没有回答，两人一起走进了大房间。

The marshal of the province, though he was vaguely conscious in the air of some trap being prepared for him, and though he had not been called upon by all to stand, had still made up his mind to stand. All was silence in the room. The secretary announced in a loud voice that the captain of the guards, Mihail Stepanovitch Snetkov, would now be balloted for as marshal of the province.
省元帅虽然隐隐约约感觉到有人在为他准备陷阱，虽然没有人叫他站起来，但他还是决定站起来。房间里一片寂静。秘书大声宣布，卫队队长米哈伊尔·斯捷潘诺维奇·斯涅特科夫现在将被选为该省元帅。

The district marshals walked carrying plates, on which were balls, from their tables to the high table, and the election began.
地区执法官们端着盘子，上面放着球，从他们的桌子走到高桌，选举开始了。

‘Put it in the right side,’ whispered Stepan Arkadyevitch, as with his brother Levin followed the marshal of his district to the table. But Levin had forgotten by now the calculations that had been explained to him, and was afraid Stepan Arkadyevitch might be mistaken in saying ‘the right side.’ Surely Snetkov was the enemy. As he went up, he held the ball in his right hand, but thinking he was wrong, just at the box he changed to the left hand, and undoubtedly put the ball to the left. An adept in the business, standing at the box and seeing by the mere action of the elbow where each put his ball, scowled with annoyance. It was no good for him to use his insight.
“把它放在右边，”斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇低声说道，他和他的兄弟列文一起跟随他所在地区的元帅来到桌子旁。但列文现在已经忘记了向他解释过的计算，并且担心斯捷潘·阿尔卡季维奇可能会错误地说“右侧”。斯涅特科夫肯定是敌人。当他上前时，他右手拿球，但他以为自己错了，刚到禁区他就换成了左手，毫无疑问把球推到了左边。一个行家，站在包厢前，仅仅通过肘部的动作就能看到每个人把球放在哪里，恼怒地皱起眉头。运用他的洞察力对他来说是没有好处的。

Everything was still, and the counting of the balls was heard. Then a single voice rose and proclaimed the numbers for and against. The marshal had been voted for by a considerable majority. All was noise and eager movement towards the doors. Snetkov came in, and the nobles thronged round him, congratulating him.
一切都很安静，数球的声音也能听见。然后一个声音响起，宣布支持和反对的人数。这位元帅是由绝大多数人投票选出的。一切都是噪音和急切的走向门口的动作。斯涅特科夫进来了，贵族们簇拥在他周围，向他表示祝贺。

‘Well, now is it over?’ Levin asked Sergey Ivanovitch.
“好了，现在结束了吗？”列文问谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇。

‘It’s only just beginning,’ Sviazhsky said, replying for Sergey Ivanovitch with a smile. ‘Some other candidate may receive more votes than the marshal.’
“这才刚刚开始，”斯维亚日斯基笑着回答谢尔盖·伊万诺维奇。 “其他一些候选人可能会比元帅获得更多的选票。”

Levin had quite forgotten about that. Now he could only remember that there was some sort of trickery in it, but he was too bored to think what it was exactly. He felt depressed, and longed to get out of the crowd.
莱文已经完全忘记了这一点。现在他只记得其中有某种诡计，但他太无聊了，无法思考到底是什么。他感到沮丧，渴望离开人群。

As no one was paying any attention to him, and no one apparently needed him, he quietly slipped away into the little room where the refreshments were, and again had a great sense of comfort when he saw the waiters. The little old waiter pressed him to have something, and Levin agreed. After eating a cutlet with beans and talking to the waiters of their former masters, Levin, not wishing to go back to the hall, where it was all so distasteful to him, proceeded to walk through the galleries. The galleries were full of fashionably dressed ladies, leaning over the balustrade and trying not to lose a single word of what was being said below. With the ladies were sitting and standing smart lawyers, high school teachers in spectacles, and officers. Everywhere they were talking of the election, and of how worried the marshal was, and how splendid the discussions had been. In one group Levin heard his brother’s praises. One lady was telling a lawyer:
由于没有人理睬他，显然也没有人需要他，他就悄悄溜进了放茶点的小房间里，看到服务员的时候，再次感到一种莫大的安慰。小个子老服务员催促他要点东西，莱文答应了。吃完一份豆子炸肉排并与前任主人的侍者交谈后，莱文不想再回到大厅，因为那里的一切对他来说都是如此令人厌恶，于是他开始穿过画廊。画廊里挤满了衣着时尚的女士，她们靠在栏杆上，努力不漏掉下面所说的话。女士们坐着或站着，有聪明的律师、戴眼镜的高中老师和官员。他们到处都在谈论选举，谈论元帅是多么担心，以及讨论是多么精彩。在一群人中，莱文听到了他哥哥的赞扬。一位女士告诉律师：

‘How glad I am I heard Koznishev! It’s worth losing one’s dinner. He’s exquisite! So clear and distinct all of it! There’s not one of you in the law courts that speaks like that. The only one is Meidel, and he’s not so eloquent by a long way.’
“我很高兴听到科兹尼舍夫的声音！失去晚餐是值得的。他很精致！一切都那么清晰明了！法庭上没有人会这样说话。唯一的一个就是梅德尔，而且他远没有那么能言善道。

Finding a free place, Levin leaned over the balustrade and began looking and listening.
莱文找到一个空闲的地方，靠在栏杆上，开始观察和倾听。

All the noblemen were sitting railed off behind barriers according to their districts. In the middle of the room stood a man in a uniform, who shouted in a loud, high voice:
所有的贵族都根据自己的地区坐在栅栏后面。房间中央站着一名穿着制服的男子，他大声喊道：

‘As a candidate for the marshalship of the nobility of the province we call upon staff-captain Yevgeney Ivanovitch Apuhtin!’ A dead silence followed, and then a weak old voice was heard: ‘Declined!’
“作为该省贵族元帅的候选人，我们请参谋上尉叶夫根尼·伊万诺维奇·阿普金！”接着是死一般的寂静，然后听到一个微弱而苍老的声音：“拒绝！”

‘We call upon the privy councilor Pyotr Petrovitch Bol,’ the voice began again.
“我们请枢密院议员彼得·彼得罗维奇·波尔来，”那个声音又开始了。

‘Declined!’ a high boyish voice replied.
“拒绝！”一个高亢的孩子气的声音回答道。

Again it began, and again ‘Declined.’ And so it went on for about an hour. Levin, with his elbows on the balustrade, looked and listened. At first he wondered and wanted to know what it meant; then feeling sure that he could not make it out he began to be bored. Then recalling all the excitement and vindictiveness he had seen on all the faces, he felt sad; he made up his mind to go, and went downstairs. As he passed through the entry to the galleries he met a dejected high school boy walking up and down with tired-looking eyes. On the stairs he met a couple—a lady running quickly on her high heels and the jaunty deputy prosecutor.
又开始了，又是“拒绝”。就这样持续了大约一个小时。莱文把胳膊肘撑在栏杆上，一边看一边听。起初他很想知道这意味着什么。然后他确信自己听不懂，他开始感到无聊。然后想起他在每个人脸上看到的兴奋和斗气，他感到悲伤；他打定主意要走，便下了楼。当他穿过画廊的入口时，他遇到了一个沮丧的高中男孩，带着疲倦的眼神来回走动。在楼梯上，他遇到了一对情侣——一位踩着高跟鞋飞快奔跑的女士和一位神气十足的副检察官。

‘I told you you weren’t late,’ the deputy prosecutor was saying at the moment when Levin moved aside to let the lady pass.
“我告诉过你，你没有迟到。”当莱文闪到一边让那位女士通过时，副检察官正在说。

Levin was on the stairs to the way out, and was just feeling in his waistcoat pocket for the number of his overcoat, when the secretary overtook him.
莱文正在通向出口的楼梯上，正要在背心口袋里摸索大衣的号码，这时秘书追上了他。

‘This way, please, Konstantin Dmitrievitch; they are voting.’
“请这边走，康斯坦丁·德米特里耶维奇；他们正在投票。

The candidate who was being voted on was Nevyedovsky, who had so stoutly denied all idea of standing. Levin went up to the door of the room; it was locked. The secretary knocked, the door opened, and Levin was met by two red-faced gentlemen, who darted out.
接受投票的候选人是涅维耶多夫斯基，他坚决否认任何参选的想法。莱文走到房间门口。它被锁了。秘书敲了敲门，门开了，莱文遇到了两位红脸先生，他们冲了出去。

‘I can’t stand any more of it,’ said one red-faced gentleman.
“我再也受不了了，”一位红脸先生说道。

After them the face of the marshal of the province was poked out. His face was dreadful-looking from exhaustion and dismay.
在他们身后，省元帅的脸被探了出来。他的脸色因疲惫和沮丧而显得可怕。

‘I told you not to let any one out!’ he cried to the doorkeeper.
“我告诉过你不要放任何人出去！”他对门卫喊道。

‘I let someone in, your excellency!’
“我让人进来了，阁下！”

‘Mercy on us!’ and with a heavy sigh the marshal of the province walked with downcast head to the high table in the middle of the room, his legs staggering in his white trousers.
“可怜我们吧！”省元帅重重地叹了口气，低着头走向房间中央的高桌，双腿在白色长裤中踉踉跄跄地走去。

Nevyedovsky had scored a higher majority, as they had planned, and he was the new marshal of the province. Many people were amused, many were pleased and happy, many were in ecstasies, many were disgusted and unhappy. The former marshal of the province was in a state of despair, which he could not conceal. When Nevyedovsky went out of the room, the crowd thronged round him and followed him enthusiastically, just as they had followed the governor who had opened the meetings, and just as they had followed Snetkov when he was elected.
正如他们计划的那样，涅维耶多夫斯基获得了更高的多数票，他成为了该省的新元帅。许多人被逗乐了，许多人高兴、高兴，许多人狂喜，许多人厌恶、不高兴。这位前省元帅的心情是无法掩饰的绝望。当涅维耶多夫斯基走出房间时，人群簇拥在他周围，热情地跟随他，就像他们跟随宣布会议开幕的州长，就像他们跟随斯涅特科夫当选时一样。

Chapter 31
第31章

The newly elected marshal and many of the successful party dined that day with Vronsky.
当天，新当选的元帅和许多成功人士与渥伦斯基共进晚餐。

Vronsky had come to the elections partly because he was bored in the country and wanted to show Anna his right to independence, and also to repay Sviazhsky by his support at the election for all the trouble he had taken for Vronsky at the district council election, but chiefly in order strictly to perform all those duties of a nobleman and landowner which he had taken upon himself. But he had not in the least expected that the election would so interest him, so keenly excite him, and that he would be so good at this kind of thing. He was quite a new man in the circle of the nobility of the province, but his success was unmistakable, and he was not wrong in supposing that he had already obtained a certain influence. This influence was due to his wealth and reputation, the capital house in the town lent him by his old friend Shirkov, who had a post in the department of finances and was director of a flourishing bank in Kashin; the excellent cook Vronsky had brought from the country, and his friendship with the governor, who was a schoolfellow of Vronsky’s—a schoolfellow he had patronized and protected indeed. But what contributed more than all to his success was his direct, equable manner with everyone, which very quickly made the majority of the noblemen reverse the current opinion of his supposed haughtiness. He was himself conscious that, except that whimsical gentleman married to Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, who had a propos de bottes poured out a stream of irrelevant absurdities with such spiteful fury, every nobleman with whom he had made acquaintance had become his adherent. He saw clearly, and other people recognized it, too, that he had done a great deal to secure the success of Nevyedovsky. And now at his own table, celebrating Nevyedovsky’s election, he was experiencing an agreeable sense of triumph over the success of his candidate. The election itself had so fascinated him that, if he could succeed in getting married during the next three years, he began to think of standing himself—much as after winning a race ridden by a jockey, he had longed to ride a race himself.
渥伦斯基参加选举的部分原因是他在乡下感到无聊，想向安娜展示他的独立权利，同时也通过他在选举中的支持来报答斯维亚日斯基在区议会选举中给渥伦斯基带来的麻烦，但主要是为了严格履行他自己承担的贵族和地主的所有职责。但他丝毫没有想到，这次选举会让他如此感兴趣，如此激动，如此擅长这种事情。他在省里的贵族圈子里还是个新人，但他的成功却是毋庸置疑的，他认为自己已经获得了一定的影响力也没有错。这种影响力来自于他的财富和声誉，镇上的首府大宅是他的老朋友希尔科夫借给他的，希尔科夫在财务部门任职，是卡申一家生意兴隆的银行的董事；渥伦斯基从乡下带来的优秀厨师，以及他与州长的友谊，州长是渥伦斯基的同学——他确实资助和保护了一位同学。但对他的成功最重要的是他对每个人的直接、平等的态度，这很快就使大多数贵族改变了目前对他所谓的傲慢的看法。他自己也意识到，除了那位与基蒂·谢尔巴茨卡娅结婚的异想天开的绅士，他的提案充满恶意地狂吐出一连串无关紧要的荒唐话之外，他所认识的每一个贵族都成了他的追随者。他清楚地看到，其他人也认识到，他为确保涅维多夫斯基的成功做了很多事情。 现在，他在自己的餐桌上庆祝涅维耶多夫斯基的当选，他对自己的候选人的成功感到一种愉快的胜利感。选举本身让他如此着迷，以至于如果他能在未来三年内成功结婚，他就开始考虑自己站起来——就像在赢得一场由骑师骑马的比赛后，他渴望自己参加一场比赛一样。

Today he was celebrating the success of his jockey. Vronsky sat at the head of the table, on his right hand sat the young governor, a general of high rank. To all the rest he was the chief man in the province, who had solemnly opened the elections with his speech, and aroused a feeling of respect and even of awe in many people, as Vronsky saw; to Vronsky he was little Katka Maslov—that had been his nickname in the Pages’ Corps—whom he felt to be shy and tried to mettre a son aise. On the left hand sat Nevyedovsky with his youthful, stubborn, and malignant face. With him Vronsky was simple and deferential.
今天他正在庆祝他的骑师的成功。渥伦斯基坐在桌子的一头，他的右手边坐着年轻的总督，一位高级将军。对于其他人来说，他是该省的主要人物，他以演讲庄严地拉开了选举的序幕，并引起了许多人的尊重甚至敬畏，正如渥伦斯基所见；对渥伦斯基来说，他是小卡卡·马斯洛夫——这是他在佩吉军团中的绰号——他觉得她很害羞，并试图结识一个儿子艾斯。左手边坐着涅维耶多夫斯基，他的脸年轻、顽固、恶毒。渥伦斯基对他态度简单而恭敬。

Sviazhsky took his failure very light-heartedly. It was indeed no failure in his eyes, as he said himself, turning, glass in hand, to Nevyedovsky; they could not have found a better representative of the new movement, which the nobility ought to follow. And so every honest person, as he said, was on the side of today’s success and was rejoicing over it.
斯维亚日斯基对自己的失败表现得很轻松。正如他自己所说，在他眼里这确实不是失败，他手里拿着玻璃，转向涅维耶多夫斯基。他们不可能找到新运动的更好代表，贵族们应该追随这一运动。因此，正如他所说，每个诚实的人都站在今天的成功一边，并为此感到高兴。

Stepan Arkadyevitch was glad, too, that he was having a good time, and that everyone was pleased. The episode of the elections served as a good occasion for a capital dinner. Sviazhsky comically imitated the tearful discourse of the marshal, and observed, addressing Nevyedovsky, that his excellency would have to select another more complicated method of auditing the accounts than tears. Another nobleman jocosely described how footmen in stockings had been ordered for the marshal’s ball, and how now they would have to be sent back unless the new marshal would give a ball with footmen in stockings.
斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇也很高兴，因为他玩得很开心，每个人都很高兴。选举期间是举行首都晚宴的好时机。斯维亚日斯基滑稽地模仿了元帅含泪的话语，并对涅维耶多夫斯基说，大人必须选择另一种比眼泪更复杂的审计账目方法。另一位贵族开玩笑地描述了如何命令穿着长袜的男仆参加元帅的舞会，以及现在他们将不得不被送回去，除非新任元帅愿意与穿长袜的男仆一起举办舞会。

Continually during dinner they said of Nevyedovsky: ‘our marshal,’ and ‘your excellency.’
晚餐时，他们不断地提到涅维多夫斯基：“我们的元帅”和“阁下”。

This was said with the same pleasure with which a bride is called ‘Madame’ and her husband’s name. Nevyedovsky affected to be not merely indifferent but scornful of this appellation, but it was obvious that he was highly delighted, and had to keep a curb on himself not to betray the triumph which was unsuitable to their new liberal tone.
说这句话的时候，就像称呼新娘为“夫人”和称呼她丈夫的名字一样。涅维耶多夫斯基假装对这个称谓不仅漠不关心，而且蔑视，但显然他非常高兴，并且必须克制自己，不要暴露胜利，这与他们新的自由主义语气不相称。

After dinner several telegrams were sent to people interested in the result of the election. And Stepan Arkadyevitch, who was in high good humor, sent Darya Alexandrovna a telegram: ‘Nevyedovsky elected by twenty votes. Congratulations. Tell people.’ He dictated it aloud, saying: ‘We must let them share our rejoicing.’ Darya Alexandrovna, getting the message, simply sighed over the rouble wasted on it, and understood that it was an after-dinner affair. She knew Stiva had a weakness after dining for faire jouer le telegraphe.
晚餐后，几封电报被发送给对选举结果感兴趣的人们。心情很好的斯捷潘·阿尔卡季奇给达里娅·亚历山德罗芙娜发了一封电报：“涅维耶多夫斯基以二十票当选。”恭喜。告诉人们。”他大声口述道：“我们必须让他们分享我们的喜悦。” 达里娅·亚历山德罗夫娜明白了这一点，只是为浪费的卢布叹了口气，并明白这是晚饭后的事情。在为《faire jouer le telegraphe》用餐后，她知道斯蒂瓦有一个弱点。

Everything, together with the excellent dinner and the wine, not from Russian merchants, but imported direct from abroad, was extremely dignified, simple, and enjoyable. The party—some twenty—had been selected by Sviazhsky from among the more active new liberals, all of the same way of thinking, who were at the same time clever and well bred. They drank, also half in jest, to the health of the new marshal of the province, of the governor, of the bank director, and of ‘our amiable host.’
一切，加上精美的晚餐和美酒，不是来自俄罗斯商人，而是从国外直接进口的，非常端庄、简单、令人愉快。该党约有二十人，是斯维亚日斯基从较为活跃的新自由主义者中挑选出来的，他们都具有相同的思维方式，同时又聪明又受过良好的教养。他们半开玩笑地为该省新任元帅、省长、银行董事和“我们可爱的东道主”的健康干杯。

Vronsky was satisfied. He had never expected to find so pleasant a tone in the provinces.
渥伦斯基很满意。他没想到在外省会发现如此愉快的语气。

Towards the end of dinner it was still more lively. The governor asked Vronsky to come to a concert for the benefit of the Servians which his wife, who was anxious to make his acquaintance, had been getting up.
晚饭快结束时，气氛更加热闹。总督邀请渥伦斯基来参加一场为塞尔维亚人举办的音乐会，他的妻子急于结识他，已经起床了。

‘There’ll be a ball, and you’ll see the belle of the province. Worth seeing, really.’
“会有一个舞会，你会见到这个省的美女。真的值得一看。

‘Not in my line,’ Vronsky answered. He liked that English phrase. But he smiled, and promised to come.
“不符合我的路线，”渥伦斯基回答道。他喜欢那个英语短语。但他微笑着，答应会来。

Before they rose from the table, when all of them were smoking, Vronsky’s valet went up to him with a letter on a tray.
在他们从桌子上站起来之前，当他们都在抽烟时，渥伦斯基的男仆走到他面前，托盘上放着一封信。

‘From Vozdvizhenskoe by special messenger,’ he said with a significant expression.
“特使从沃兹德维任斯科派来的，”他表情意味深长地说。

‘Astonishing! how like he is to the deputy prosecutor Sventitsky,’ said one of the guests in French of the valet, while Vronsky, frowning, read the letter.
'惊人！ “他对副检察官斯文提茨基有多像。”一位客人用法语对贴身男仆说道，而渥伦斯基则皱着眉头读着这封信。

The letter was from Anna. Before he read the letter, he knew its contents. Expecting the elections to be over in five days, he had promised to be back on Friday. Today was Saturday, and he knew that the letter contained reproaches for not being back at the time fixed. The letter he had sent the previous evening had probably not reached her yet.
这封信是安娜寄来的。在读信之前，他就知道信的内容了。他预计选举将在五天内结束，因此承诺周五回来。今天是星期六，他知道信中包含着对没有按时回来的责备。他前一天晚上寄出的信可能还没有到达她的手中。

The letter was what he had expected, but the form of it was unexpected, and particularly disagreeable to him. ‘Annie is very ill, the doctor says it may be inflammation. I am losing my head all alone. Princess Varvara is no help, but a hindrance. I expected you the day before yesterday, and yesterday, and now I am sending to find out where you are and what you are doing. I wanted to come myself, but thought better of it, knowing you would dislike it. Send some answer, that I may know what to do.’
这封信是他所预料的，但它的形式却出乎他的意料，而且让他特别不舒服。 ‘安妮病得很重，医生说可能是炎症。我独自一人失去了理智。瓦尔瓦拉公主不但没有帮助，反而是一个障碍。我前天和昨天都在等你，现在我派人去看看你在哪里、在做什么。我本来想自己来，但又考虑了一下，因为我知道你会不喜欢它。请发送一些答案，以便我知道该怎么做。

The child ill, yet she had thought of coming herself. Their daughter ill, and this hostile tone.
孩子病了，她却想自己来。他们的女儿生病了，而且语气充满敌意。

The innocent festivities over the election, and this gloomy, burdensome love to which he had to return struck Vronsky by their contrast. But he had to go, and by the first train that night he set off home.
选举期间天真无邪的庆祝活动和他不得不回归的这种阴郁、沉重的爱情形成了鲜明的对比，这让渥伦斯基感到震惊。但他必须走，当晚他就乘第一班火车回家了。

Chapter 32
第32章

Before Vronsky’s departure for the elections, Anna had reflected that the scenes constantly repeated between them each time he left home, might only make him cold to her instead of attaching him to her, and resolved to do all she could to control herself so as to bear the parting with composure. But the cold, severe glance with which he had looked at her when he came to tell her he was going had wounded her, and before he had started her peace of mind was destroyed.
在渥伦斯基出发去参加选举之前，安娜就想到，每次他离家时，她们之间不断重复的场景，可能只会让他对她冷淡，而不是依恋他，并决心尽一切努力控制自己，以便平静地承受离别。但当他来告诉她他要走时，他用冷酷、严厉的眼神伤害了她，在他开始之前，她内心的平静就被破坏了。

In solitude afterwards, thinking over that glance which had expressed his right to freedom, she came, as she always did, to the same point—the sense of her own humiliation. ‘He has the right to go away when and where he chooses. Not simply to go away, but to leave me. He has every right, and I have none. But knowing that, he ought not to do it. What has he done, though?... He looked at me with a cold, severe expression. Of course that is something indefinable, impalpable, but it has never been so before, and that glance means a great deal,’ she thought. ‘That glance shows the beginning of indifference.’
后来在孤独中，回想起那一瞥，那眼神表达了他的自由权利，她像往常一样，想到了同样的一点——她自己的屈辱感。 “他有权选择何时何地离开。不仅仅是离开，而是离开我。他有一切权利，而我却没有。但既然知道这一点，他就不应该这么做。但他做了什么？……他用冷酷严厉的表情看着我。当然，那是一种难以定义、难以捉摸的东西，但以前从未如此，而那一瞥意义重大，”她想。 “那眼神表明了冷漠的开始。”

And though she felt sure that a coldness was beginning, there was nothing she could do, she could not in any way alter her relations to him. Just as before, only by love and by charm could she keep him. And so, just as before, only by occupation in the day, by morphine at night, could she stifle the fearful thought of what would be if he ceased to love her. It is true there was still one means; not to keep him—for that she wanted nothing more than his love—but to be nearer to him, to be in such a position that he would not leave her. That means was divorce and marriage. And she began to long for that, and made up her mind to agree to it the first time he or Stiva approached her on the subject.
尽管她确信冷漠正在开始，但她无能为力，她无法以任何方式改变她与他的关系。和以前一样，只有爱情和魅力，她才能留住他。因此，就像以前一样，只有白天的忙碌，晚上的吗啡，她才能抑制住对如果他不再爱她将会发生的可怕想法。确实，还有一种办法，那就是：不是为了留住他——因为她想要的只是他的爱——而是为了离他更近，让他不会离开她。这意味着离婚和结婚。她开始渴望这一点，并在他或斯蒂瓦第一次就这个话题与她接触时就决定同意。

Absorbed in such thoughts, she passed five days without him, the five days that he was to be at the elections.
她全神贯注于这样的想法，在没有他的情况下度过了五天，这五天是他参加选举的五天。

Walks, conversation with Princess Varvara, visits to the hospital, and, most of all, reading—reading of one book after another—filled up her time. But on the sixth day, when the coachman came back without him, she felt that now she was utterly incapable of stifling the thought of him and of what he was doing there, just at that time her little girl was taken ill. Anna began to look after her, but even that did not distract her mind, especially as the illness was not serious. However hard she tried, she could not love this little child, and to feign love was beyond her powers. Towards the evening of that day, still alone, Anna was in such a panic about him that she decided to start for the town, but on second thoughts wrote him the contradictory letter that Vronsky received, and without reading it through, sent it off by a special messenger. The next morning she received his letter and regretted her own. She dreaded a repetition of the severe look he had flung at her at parting, especially when he knew that the baby was not dangerously ill. But still she was glad she had written to him. At this moment Anna was positively admitting to herself that she was a burden to him, that he would relinquish his freedom regretfully to return to her, and in spite of that she was glad he was coming. Let him weary of her, but he would be here with her, so that she would see him, would know of every action he took.
散步、与瓦尔瓦拉公主交谈、拜访医院，以及最重要的是，阅读——一本又一本地阅读——占据了她的时间。但第六天，当车夫回来时，他却没有带回来，她觉得现在她完全无法抑制对他和他在那里所做的事情的思考，就在那时，她的小女儿病了。安娜开始照顾她，但即便如此，她也没有分心，尤其是她的病并不严重。无论她如何努力，她都无法爱这个小孩子，假装爱也超出了她的能力。那天晚上，安娜仍然独自一人，对他感到如此恐慌，以至于她决定出发去城里，但转念一想，她给他写了一封渥伦斯基收到的矛盾的信，没有读完，就寄给了他。一个特殊的使者。第二天早上，她收到了他的信，并对自己的信感到后悔。她害怕再次看到他临别时向她投来的严厉目光，尤其是当他知道孩子并没有病得很严重时。但她仍然很高兴给他写信。此时安娜正在积极地向自己承认她是他的负担，他会遗憾地放弃自由回到她身边，尽管如此，她还是很高兴他能来。让他厌倦她吧，但他会在她身边，这样她就能看到他，知道他所做的每一个举动。

She was sitting in the drawing room near a lamp, with a new volume of Taine, and as she read, listening to the sound of the wind outside, and every minute expecting the carriage to arrive. Several times she had fancied she heard the sound of wheels, but she had been mistaken. At last she heard not the sound of wheels, but the coachman’s shout and the dull rumble in the covered entry. Even Princess Varvara, playing patience, confirmed this, and Anna, flushing hotly, got up; but instead of going down, as she had done twice before, she stood still. She suddenly felt ashamed of her duplicity, but even more she dreaded how he might meet her. All feeling of wounded pride had passed now; she was only afraid of the expression of his displeasure. She remembered that her child had been perfectly well again for the last two days. She felt positively vexed with her for getting better from the very moment her letter was sent off. Then she thought of him, that he was here, all of him, with his hands, his eyes. She heard his voice. And forgetting everything, she ran joyfully to meet him.
她坐在客厅里，靠近一盏灯，手里拿着泰纳的新卷，一边读，一边听着外面的风声，每一分钟都在等待着马车的到来。有好几次她以为自己听到了车轮的声音，但她错了。最后，她听到的不是车轮的声音，而是车夫的喊叫声和有顶棚的入口处沉闷的隆隆声。就连装着耐心的瓦尔瓦拉公主也证实了这一点，安娜满脸通红地站了起来。但她并没有像以前两次那样倒下，而是站着不动。她突然为自己的口是心非感到羞愧，但更害怕他会以什么样的方式遇见她。所有受伤的自尊心现在都已经过去了；她只是害怕他流露出不悦的表情。她记得过去两天她的孩子已经完全康复了。从信寄出的那一刻起，她就对她的病情好转感到非常恼火。然后她想到了他，他就在这里，他的整个人，他的手，他的眼睛。她听到了他的声音。她忘记了一切，高兴地跑去迎接他。

‘Well, how is Annie?’ he said timidly from below, looking up to Anna as she ran down to him.
“嗯，安妮怎么样？”他在下面胆怯地说，当安娜跑向他时，他抬头看着她。

He was sitting on a chair, and a footman was pulling off his warm over-boot.
他坐在椅子上，一名男仆正在脱掉他温暖的大统靴。

‘Oh, she is better.’
“哦，她好多了。”

‘And you?’ he said, shaking himself.
“那你呢？”他摇晃着身子说道。

She took his hand in both of hers, and drew it to her waist, never taking her eyes off him.
她用双手握住他的手，将它拉到腰间，目光始终没有离开过他。

‘Well, I’m glad,’ he said, coldly scanning her, her hair, her dress, which he knew she had put on for him. All was charming, but how many times it had charmed him! And the stern, stony expression that she so dreaded settled upon his face.
“嗯，我很高兴，”他说道，冷冷地扫视着她、她的头发、她的衣服，他知道这是她为他穿上的。一切都很迷人，但这多少次让他着迷！她所害怕的严厉、冷酷的表情出现在他脸上。

‘Well, I’m glad. And are you well?’ he said, wiping his damp beard with his handkerchief and kissing her hand.
‘嗯，我很高兴。你还好吗？”他一边说，一边用手帕擦着湿漉漉的胡须，亲吻了她的手。

‘Never mind,’ she thought, ‘only let him be here, and so long as he’s here he cannot, he dare not, cease to love me.’
“没关系，”她想，“只要让他在这里，只要他在这里，他就不能、他不敢停止爱我。”

The evening was spent happily and gaily in the presence of Princess Varvara, who complained to him that Anna had been taking morphine in his absence.
瓦尔瓦拉公主在场，大家度过了愉快而愉快的夜晚，瓦尔瓦拉公主向他抱怨安娜在他不在的时候服用吗啡。

‘What am I to do? I couldn’t sleep.... My thoughts prevented me. When he’s here I never take it—hardly ever.’
'我是什么做的？我无法入睡……我的思绪阻止了我。当他在这里时，我从不接受——几乎从来不接受。

He told her about the election, and Anna knew how by adroit questions to bring him to what gave him most pleasure—his own success. She told him of everything that interested him at home; and all that she told him was of the most cheerful description.
他告诉她选举的事，安娜知道如何通过巧妙的问题让他了解最让他高兴的事情——他自己的成功。她告诉他家里所有他感兴趣的事情。她告诉他的一切都是最令人愉快的描述。

But late in the evening, when they were alone, Anna, seeing that she had regained complete possession of him, wanted to erase the painful impression of the glance he had given her for her letter. She said:
但到了深夜，当他们独处时，安娜发现自己已经完全占据了他，想要抹去他在写信时向她投来的目光所留下的痛苦印象。她说：

‘Tell me frankly, you were vexed at getting my letter, and you didn’t believe me?’
“坦白告诉我，你收到我的信很烦恼，而且不相信我？”

As soon as she had said it, she felt that however warm his feelings were to her, he had not forgiven her for that.
话一出口，她就觉得，不管他对她的感情有多热烈，他都没有原谅她。

‘Yes,’ he said, ‘the letter was so strange. First, Annie ill, and then you thought of coming yourself.’
“是的，”他说，“这封信太奇怪了。首先，安妮病了，然后你想到自己来。

‘It was all the truth.’
“这都是事实。”

‘Oh, I don’t doubt it.’
“哦，我毫不怀疑。”

‘Yes, you do doubt it. You are vexed, I see.’
‘是的，你确实怀疑这一点。我明白，你很烦恼。

‘Not for one moment. I’m only vexed, that’s true, that you seem somehow unwilling to admit that there are duties...’
” “一刻也没有。我只是生气，确实如此，你似乎不愿意承认有职责……”

‘The duty of going to a concert...’
“去听音乐会的义务……”

‘But we won’t talk about it,’ he said.
“但我们不会谈论它，”他说。

‘Why not talk about it?’ she said.
“为什么不谈谈呢？”她说。

‘I only meant to say that matters of real importance may turn up. Now, for instance, I shall have to go to Moscow to arrange about the house.... Oh, Anna, why are you so irritable? Don’t you know that I can’t live without you?’
“我只是想说，真正重要的事情可能会出现。比如说，现在我得去莫斯科安排房子的事情了……哦，安娜，你为什么这么烦躁？你难道不知道没有你我就活不下去吗？

‘If so,’ said Anna, her voice suddenly changing, ‘it means that you are sick of this life.... Yes, you will come for a day and go away, as men do...’
“如果是这样，”安娜的声音突然变了，“那就说明你厌倦了这种生活……是的，你会来一天然后走开，就像男人一样……”

‘Anna, that’s cruel. I am ready to give up my whole life.’
‘安娜，这太残忍了。我已经准备好放弃我的一生了。

But she did not hear him.
但她没有听到他的声音。

‘If you go to Moscow, I will go too. I will not stay here. Either we must separate or else live together.’
“如果你去莫斯科，我也会去。我不会留在这里。我们要么必须分开，要么住在一起。

‘Why, you know, that’s my one desire. But for that...’
‘为什么，你知道，这是我的唯一愿望。但为此……”

‘We must get a divorce. I will write to him. I see I cannot go on like this.... But I will come with you to Moscow.’
‘我们必须离婚。我会写信给他。我知道我不能再这样下去了……但我会和你一起去莫斯科。

‘You talk as if you were threatening me. But I desire nothing so much as never to be parted from you,’ said Vronsky, smiling.
‘你说得好像在威胁我一样。但我最渴望的就是永远不要与你分开。”渥伦斯基微笑着说道。

But as he said these words there gleamed in his eyes not merely a cold look, but the vindictive look of a man persecuted and made cruel.
但他说这句话的时候，眼中闪烁的不仅仅是冰冷的目光，还有一种被迫害、被残忍的人的怨恨眼神。

She saw the look and correctly divined its meaning.
她看到了这个表情并正确地猜出了它的含义。

‘If so, it’s a calamity!’ that glance told her. It was a moment’s impression, but she never forgot it.
“如果是这样，那就是一场灾难！”那一瞥告诉她。这是一瞬间的印象，但她永远不会忘记。

Anna wrote to her husband asking him about a divorce, and towards the end of November, taking leave of Princess Varvara, who wanted to go to Petersburg, she went with Vronsky to Moscow. Expecting every day an answer from Alexey Alexandrovitch, and after that the divorce, they now established themselves together like married people.
安娜写信给丈夫询问离婚事宜，11月底，她告别了想去彼得堡的瓦尔瓦拉公主，与渥伦斯基一起去了莫斯科。每天都期待阿列克谢·亚历山德罗维奇的答复，离婚后，他们现在像已婚人士一样在一起生活。

PART 7
第 7 部分

Chapter 1
第1章

The Levins had been three months in Moscow. The date had long passed on which, according to the most trustworthy calculations of people learned in such matters, Kitty should have been confined. But she was still about, and there was nothing to show that her time was any nearer than two months ago. The doctor, the monthly nurse, and Dolly and her mother, and most of all Levin, who could not think of the approaching event without terror, began to be impatient and uneasy. Kitty was the only person who felt perfectly calm and happy.
莱文夫妇在莫斯科已经三个月了。根据了解此类事情的人们最可靠的计算，基蒂应该被监禁的日期早已过去。但她仍然在，没有任何迹象表明她的时间比两个月前更近了。医生、每月的护士、多莉和她的母亲，尤其是莱文，一想到即将发生的事情就感到恐惧，开始不耐烦和不安。凯蒂是唯一感到完全平静和快乐的人。

She was distinctly conscious now of the birth of a new feeling of love for the future child, for her to some extent actually existing already, and she brooded blissfully over this feeling. He was not by now altogether a part of herself, but sometimes lived his own life independently of her. Often this separate being gave her pain, but at the same time she wanted to laugh with a strange new joy.
她现在清楚地意识到，对未来的孩子产生了一种新的爱的感觉，因为她在某种程度上实际上已经存在了，她幸福地沉思着这种感觉。他现在已经不完全是她的一部分了，但有时却独立于她而过着自己的生活。这种分离的存在常常给她带来痛苦，但同时她又想带着一种奇怪的新快乐大笑。

All the people she loved were with her, and all were so good to her, so attentively caring for her, so entirely pleasant was everything presented to her, that if she had not known and felt that it must all soon be over, she could not have wished for a better and pleasanter life. The only thing that spoiled the charm of this manner of life was that her husband was not here as she loved him to be, and as he was in the country.
所有她爱的人都和她在一起，所有人都对她那么好，那么用心地照顾她，呈现在她面前的一切都是那么令人愉快，如果她不知道并觉得这一切很快就会结束，她可以不希望过上更好、更愉快的生活。唯一破坏这种生活方式的魅力的是，她的丈夫并不像她所爱的那样在这里，也不像他在乡下一样。

She liked his serene, friendly, and hospitable manner in the country. In the town he seemed continually uneasy and on his guard, as though he were afraid someone would be rude to him, and still more to her. At home in the country, knowing himself distinctly to be in his right place, he was never in haste to be off elsewhere. He was never unoccupied. Here in town he was in a continual hurry, as though afraid of missing something, and yet he had nothing to do. And she felt sorry for him. To others, she knew, he did not appear an object of pity. On the contrary, when Kitty looked at him in society, as one sometimes looks at those one loves, trying to see him as if he were a stranger, so as to catch the impression he must make on others, she saw with a panic even of jealous fear that he was far indeed from being a pitiable figure, that he was very attractive with his fine breeding, his rather old-fashioned, reserved courtesy with women, his powerful figure, and striking, as she thought, and expressive face. But she saw him not from without, but from within; she saw that here he was not himself; that was the only way she could define his condition to herself. Sometimes she inwardly reproached him for his inability to live in the town; sometimes she recognized that it was really hard for him to order his life here so that he could be satisfied with it.
她喜欢他在乡下的平静、友善和好客的态度。在城里，他似乎总是感到不安和警惕，好像他害怕有人对他无礼，对她更是如此。在乡下的家里，他清楚地知道自己处于正确的位置，因此从不急于前往其他地方。他从来都没有闲着。在城里，他总是匆匆忙忙，好像生怕错过什么，但又无事可做。她为他感到难过。她知道，对于其他人来说，他并不是一个值得怜悯的对象。相反，当基蒂在社会上看着他时，就像人们有时看着自己所爱的人一样，试图把他当作一个陌生人来看待，以便抓住他必须给别人留下的印象，她甚至看到了一种惊慌的感觉。嫉妒的恐惧，他远非一个可怜的人物，他的优良教养，他对女性相当老式的、保守的礼貌，他强大的身材，以及她所认为的引人注目的和富有表情的脸，非常有吸引力。但她不是从外面看到他，而是从里面看到他。她看出他已经不再是他自己了。这是她可以自己定义他的状况的唯一方式。有时她会在心里责备他无法在城里生活。有时她意识到，他很难在这里安排自己的生活，让自己满意。

What had he to do, indeed? He did not care for cards; he did not go to a club. Spending the time with jovial gentlemen of Oblonsky’s type—she knew now what that meant...it meant drinking and going somewhere after drinking. She could not think without horror of where men went on such occasions. Was he to go into society? But she knew he could only find satisfaction in that if he took pleasure in the society of young women, and that she could not wish for. Should he stay at home with her, her mother and her sisters? But much as she liked and enjoyed their conversations forever on the same subjects—‘Aline-Nadine,’ as the old prince called the sisters’ talks—she knew it must bore him. What was there left for him to do? To go on writing at his book he had indeed attempted, and at first he used to go to the library and make extracts and look up references for his book. But, as he told her, the more he did nothing, the less time he had to do anything. And besides, he complained that he had talked too much about his book here, and that consequently all his ideas about it were muddled and had lost their interest for him.
事实上，他必须做什么？他不喜欢纸牌。他没有去俱乐部。和奥布隆斯基这种快活的绅士们一起度过时光——她现在知道这意味着什么……这意味着喝酒，酒后去某个地方。她一想到男人在这种场合去哪里就感到恐惧。他要走向社会吗？但她知道，只有当他在年轻女子的交往中感到快乐时，他才能从中找到满足，而这是她所不希望的。他应该留在家里和她、她的母亲和她的姐妹们在一起吗？但尽管她很喜欢并享受她们永远就同一主题进行的谈话——老王子把姐妹俩的谈话称为“艾琳-纳丁”——但她知道这一定会让他感到厌烦。他还有什么可做的呢？为了继续写他的书，他确实尝试过，一开始他常常去图书馆为他的书摘录并查找参考资料。但是，正如他告诉她的那样，他越什么都不做，他做任何事情的时间就越少。此外，他还抱怨自己在这里谈论了太多关于他的书的事情，结果他对这本书的所有想法都变得混乱，失去了兴趣。

One advantage in this town life was that quarrels hardly ever happened between them here in town. Whether it was that their conditions were different, or that they had both become more careful and sensible in that respect, they had no quarrels in Moscow from jealousy, which they had so dreaded when they moved from the country.
小镇生活的一个优点是，他们之间在镇上几乎不发生争吵。无论是他们的条件不同，还是他们在这方面都变得更加谨慎和明智，他们在莫斯科并没有因为嫉妒而发生争吵，这是他们从国外搬来时所害怕的。

One event, an event of great importance to both from that point of view, did indeed happen—that was Kitty’s meeting with Vronsky.
有一件事情确实发生了，从这个角度来看，这件事对双方来说都非常重要——那就是基蒂与渥伦斯基的会面。

The old Princess Marya Borissovna, Kitty’s godmother, who had always been very fond of her, had insisted on seeing her. Kitty, though she did not go into society at all on account of her condition, went with her father to see the venerable old lady, and there met Vronsky.
基蒂的教母老公主玛丽亚·鲍里索夫娜一直很喜欢她，坚持要见她。基蒂虽然因为身体原因根本没有踏入社会，但她还是和父亲一起去见了那位德高望重的老太太，在那里遇见了渥伦斯基。

The only thing Kitty could reproach herself for at this meeting was that at the instant when she recognized in his civilian dress the features once so familiar to her, her breath failed her, the blood rushed to her heart, and a vivid blush—she felt it— overspread her face. But this lasted only a few seconds. Before her father, who purposely began talking in a loud voice to Vronsky, had finished, she was perfectly ready to look at Vronsky, to speak to him, if necessary, exactly as she spoke to Princess Marya Borissovna, and more than that, to do so in such a way that everything to the faintest intonation and smile would have been approved by her husband, whose unseen presence she seemed to feel about her at that instant.
在这次见面中，基蒂唯一可以责备自己的就是，当她认出他穿着便服的那一刻，她曾经那么熟悉的容貌，她呼吸困难，血液涌上心头，脸红了——她感到它——覆盖了她的脸。但这只持续了几秒钟。在她父亲故意开始大声跟渥伦斯基说话之前，她完全准备好看着渥伦斯基，如果有必要的话，就跟他说话，就像她对玛丽亚·鲍里索夫娜公主说话一样，不仅如此，这样做的方式是，一切，哪怕是最微弱的语调和微笑，都会得到她丈夫的认可，在那一刻，她似乎感觉到了他看不见的存在。

She said a few words to him, even smiled serenely at his joke about the elections, which he called ‘our parliament.’ (She had to smile to show she saw the joke.) But she turned away immediately to Princess Marya Borissovna, and did not once glance at him till he got up to go; then she looked at him, but evidently only because it would be uncivil not to look at a man when he is saying good-bye.
她对他说了几句话，甚至对他关于选举的笑话平静地微笑着，他称之为“我们的议会”。（她必须微笑以表明她看到了这个笑话。）但她立即转向玛丽亚·鲍里索夫娜公主，然后直到他起身要走时，他才看他一眼。然后她看着他，但显然只是因为当一个男人说再见时不看他是不礼貌的。

She was grateful to her father for saying nothing to her about their meeting Vronsky, but she saw by his special warmth to her after the visit during their usual walk that he was pleased with her. She was pleased with herself. She had not expected she would have had the power, while keeping somewhere in the bottom of her heart all the memories of her old feeling for Vronsky, not only to seem but to be perfectly indifferent and composed with him.
她很感激她的父亲没有对她提及他们会见渥伦斯基的事，但在他们平常散步时，她从父亲对她特别的热情中看出，他对她很满意。她对自己很满意。她没想到自己竟然拥有这样的力量，同时在心底的某个地方保留着她对渥伦斯基旧日感情的所有记忆，不仅表现出对他漠不关心，而且表现得很镇定。

Levin flushed a great deal more than she when she told him she had met Vronsky at Princess Marya Borissovna’s. It was very hard for her to tell him this, but still harder to go on speaking of the details of the meeting, as he did not question her, but simply gazed at her with a frown.
当她告诉莱文她在玛丽亚·鲍里索夫娜公主家遇见了渥伦斯基时，莱文脸红得比她更厉害。她很难告诉他这些，但更难继续说起见面的细节，因为他没有追问她，只是皱着眉头看着她。

‘I am very sorry you weren’t there,’ she said. ‘Not that you weren’t in the room...I couldn’t have been so natural in your presence...I am blushing now much more, much, much more,’ she said, blushing till the tears came into her eyes. ‘But that you couldn’t see through a crack.’
“我很遗憾你不在场，”她说。 “并不是说你不在房间里……我不可能在你面前表现得如此自然……我现在脸红得更红了，更红了，”她说着，脸红得泪流满面。眼睛。 “但你无法透过裂缝看到。”

The truthful eyes told Levin that she was satisfied with herself, and in spite of her blushing he was quickly reassured and began questioning her, which was all she wanted. When he had heard everything, even to the detail that for the first second she could not help flushing, but that afterwards she was just as direct and as much at her ease as with any chance acquaintance, Levin was quite happy again and said he was glad of it, and would not now behave as stupidly as he had done at the election, but would try the first time he met Vronsky to be as friendly as possible.
那双真诚的眼睛告诉莱文，她对自己很满意，尽管她脸红了，但他很快就放心了，开始质问她，这就是她想要的。当他听完所有的事情，甚至听到她在第一秒忍不住脸红，但后来她就像任何偶然的熟人一样直接和轻松的细节时，莱文又很高兴，说他是很高兴，现在不会像选举时那样愚蠢，而是会在第一次见到渥伦斯基时尽量表现得友好。

‘It’s so wretched to feel that there’s a man almost an enemy whom it’s painful to meet,’ said Levin. ‘I’m very, very glad.’
莱文说：“感觉有一个人几乎是敌人，见到他很痛苦，真是太悲惨了。” “我非常非常高兴。”

Chapter 2
第2章

‘Go, please, go then and call on the Bols,’ Kitty said to her husband, when he came in to see her at eleven o’clock before going out. ‘I know you are dining at the club; papa put down your name. But what are you going to do in the morning?’
“走吧，拜托，那就去拜访一下波尔一家吧，”当她丈夫十一点出门前来看望她时，基蒂对他说道。 “我知道你在俱乐部用餐；爸爸记下你的名字。但是你早上要做什么呢？

‘I am only going to Katavasov,’ answered Levin.
“我只是去卡塔瓦索夫，”列文回答道。

‘Why so early?’
'为什么这么早？'

‘He promised to introduce me to Metrov. I wanted to talk to him about my work. He’s a distinguished scientific man from Petersburg,’ said Levin.
“他答应把我介绍给梅特洛夫。我想和他谈谈我的工作。他是一位来自彼得堡的杰出科学家。”莱文说。

‘Yes; wasn’t it his article you were praising so? Well, and after that?’ said Kitty.
'是的;你称赞的不是他的文章吗？好吧，那之后呢？”基蒂说。

‘I shall go to the court, perhaps, about my sister’s business.’
“也许我会因为我姐姐的事去法庭。”

‘And the concert?’ she queried.
“那音乐会呢？”她问道。

‘I shan’t go there all alone.’
“我不会一个人去那里。”

‘No? do go; there are going to be some new things.... That interested you so. I should certainly go.’
'不？走吧;将会有一些新的事情......这让你很感兴趣。我当然应该去。

‘Well, anyway, I shall come home before dinner,’ he said, looking at his watch.
“好吧，无论如何，我会在晚饭前回家，”他看了看手表说道。

‘Put on your frock coat, so that you can go straight to call on Countess Bola.’
“穿上礼服大衣，你就可以直接去拜访博拉伯爵夫人了。”

‘But is it absolutely necessary?’
“但这绝对有必要吗？”

‘Oh, absolutely! He has been to see us. Come, what is it? You go in, sit down, talk for five minutes of the weather, get up and go away.’
‘噢，绝对是这样！他已经来看我们了。来吧，这是什么？你进去，坐下来，谈论五分钟的天气，然后起身离开。

‘Oh, you wouldn’t believe it! I’ve got so out of the way of all this that it makes me feel positively ashamed. It’s such a horrible thing to do! A complete outsider walks in, sits down, stays on with nothing to do, wastes their time and worries himself, and walks away!’
‘噢，你不会相信的！我已经摆脱了这一切，这让我感到非常羞愧。这是一件多么可怕的事情啊！一个完全的局外人走进来，坐下来，无所事事，浪费时间，担心自己，然后走开！

Kitty laughed.
基蒂笑了。

‘Why, I suppose you used to pay calls before you were married, didn’t you?’
“为什么，我想你在结婚前常常打电话，不是吗？”

‘Yes, I did, but I always felt ashamed, and now I’m so out of the way of it that, by Jove! I’d sooner go two days running without my dinner than pay this call! One’s so ashamed! I feel all the while that they’re annoyed, that they’re saying, ‘What has he come for?’’
“是的，我做到了，但我总是感到羞愧，现在我已经不再妨碍它了，天哪！我宁愿连续两天不吃晚饭，也不愿打这个电话！一个人真是太羞耻了！我一直觉得他们很生气，他们在说，‘他来干什么？’”

‘No, they won’t. I’ll answer for that,’ said Kitty, looking into his face with a laugh. She took his hand. ‘Well, good-bye.... Do go, please.’
‘不，他们不会。我会回答这个问题的。”基蒂笑着看着他的脸说道。她握住他的手。 “好吧，再见……请走吧。”

He was just going out after kissing his wife’s hand, when she stopped him.
他亲吻妻子的手后正要出去，她阻止了他。

‘Kostya, do you know I’ve only fifty roubles left?’
“克斯特亚，你知道我只剩下五十卢布了吗？”

‘Oh, all right, I’ll go to the bank and get some. How much?’ he said, with the expression of dissatisfaction she knew so well.
“噢，好吧，我去银行取点。” “多少钱？”他问道，脸上带着她非常熟悉的不满表情。

‘No, wait a minute.’ She held his hand. ‘Let’s talk about it, it worries me. I seem to spend nothing unnecessary, but money seems to fly away simply. We don’t manage well, somehow.’
“不，等一下。”她握着他的手。 “我们来谈谈吧，这让我很担心。我似乎没有花任何不必要的钱，但钱似乎很快就飞走了。不知何故，我们管理得不好。

‘Oh, it’s all right,’ he said with a little cough, looking at her from under his brows.
“哦，没关系，”他咳嗽了一声，从眉下看着她。

That cough she knew well. It was a sign of intense dissatisfaction, not with her, but with himself. He certainly was displeased not at so much money being spent, but at being reminded of what he, knowing something was unsatisfactory, wanted to forget.
那种咳嗽她很熟悉。这是强烈不满的表现，不是对她，而是对他自己。他当然不是因为花了这么多钱而感到不满，而是因为有人提醒他，他知道有些事情不令人满意，想要忘记什么。

‘I have told Sokolov to sell the wheat, and to borrow an advance on the mill. We shall have money enough in any case.’
“我已经告诉索科洛夫卖掉小麦，并借入磨坊的预付款。无论如何我们都会有足够的钱。

‘Yes, but I’m afraid that altogether...’
“是的，但我恐怕完全……”

‘Oh, it’s all right, all right,’ he repeated. ‘Well, good-bye, darling.’
“哦，没关系，没关系，”他重复道。 “好吧，再见，亲爱的。”

‘No, I’m really sorry sometimes that I listened to mamma. How nice it would have been in the country! As it is, I’m worrying you all, and we’re wasting our money.’
“不，有时候我真的很抱歉我听了妈妈的话。如果在乡下该多好啊！事实上，我让你们大家担心，而且我们在浪费钱。”

‘Not at all, not at all. Not once since I’ve been married have I said that things could have been better than they are....’
‘一点也不，一点也不。自从我结婚以来，我从来没有说过事情本来可以比现在更好……”

‘Truly?’ she said, looking into his eyes.
“真的吗？”她看着他的眼睛说道。

He had said it without thinking, simply to console her. But when he glanced at her and saw those sweet truthful eyes fastened questioningly on him, he repeated it with his whole heart. ‘I was positively forgetting her,’ he thought. And he remembered what was before them, so soon to come.
他不假思索地说出这句话，只是为了安慰她。但当他瞥了她一眼，看到那双甜美而真实的眼睛疑惑地盯着他时，他全心全意地重复了一遍。 “我确实忘记了她，”他想。他还记得他们即将面临的事情。

‘Will it be soon? How do you feel?’ he whispered, taking her two hands.
‘会很快吗？你感觉怎么样？”他拉着她的两只手低声说道。

‘I have so often thought so, that now I don’t think about it or know anything about it.’
“我经常这么想，但现在我不再考虑它，也不知道任何事情了。”

‘And you’re not frightened?’
“你不害怕吗？”

She smiled contemptuously.
她轻蔑地笑了笑。

‘Not the least little bit,’ she said.
“一点也不，”她说。

‘Well, if anything happens, I shall be at Katavasov’s.’
“好吧，如果发生什么事，我会去卡塔瓦索夫那里。”

‘No, nothing will happen, and don’t think about it. I’m going for a walk on the boulevard with papa. We’re going to see Dolly. I shall expect you before dinner. Oh, yes! Do you know that Dolly’s position is becoming utterly impossible? She’s in debt all round; she hasn’t a penny. We were talking yesterday with mamma and Arseny’ (this was her sister’s husband Lvov), ‘and we determined to send you with him to talk to Stiva. It’s really unbearable. One can’t speak to papa about it.... But if you and he...’
‘不，不会有什么事情发生的，你别想了。我要和爸爸一起在林荫大道上散步。我们要去见多莉。我会在晚饭前等你。哦是的！你知道多莉的地位已经变得完全不可能了吗？她负债累累；她一分钱都没有。昨天我们正在和妈妈和阿尔谢尼谈话”（这是她姐姐的丈夫利沃夫），“我们决定派你和他一起去见斯蒂瓦。实在是难以忍受。一个人不能和爸爸谈论这件事……但如果你和他……”

‘Why, what can we do?’ said Levin.
“为什么，我们能做什么呢？”莱文说。

‘You’ll be at Arseny’s, anyway; talk to him, he will tell what we decided.’
“不管怎样，你都会去阿尔森尼；”和他谈谈，他会告诉我们我们的决定。”

‘Oh, I agree to everything Arseny thinks beforehand. I’ll go and see him. By the way, if I do go to the concert, I’ll go with Natalia. Well, good-bye.’
‘哦，我同意阿尔森之前的一切想法。我去看看他。顺便说一句，如果我真的去听音乐会，我会和娜塔莉亚一起去。那再见吧;好吧再见。'

On the steps Levin was stopped by his old servant Kouzma, who had been with him before his marriage, and now looked after their household in town.
列文在台阶上被他的老仆人库兹马拦住了，库兹马在他结婚前一直和他在一起，现在在城里照顾他们的家人。

‘Beauty’ (that was the left shaft-horse brought up from the country) ‘has been badly shod and is quite lame,’ he said. ‘What does your honor wish to be done?’
他说，“美人”（那匹从乡下运来的左辕马）“蹄子很烂，而且很跛”。 “法官大人希望做什么？”

During the first part of their stay in Moscow, Levin had used his own horses brought up from the country. He had tried to arrange this part of their expenses in the best and cheapest way possible; but it appeared that their own horses came dearer than hired horses, and they still hired too.
在莫斯科逗留的第一段时间，莱文使用了他自己从乡下饲养的马匹。他试图以尽可能最好、最便宜的方式安排这部分费用；但他并没有这么做。但看来他们自己的马比租来的马更贵，而且他们也还是租的。

‘Send for the veterinary, there may be a bruise.’
“请兽医检查，可能有瘀伤。”

‘And for Katerina Alexandrovna?’ asked Kouzma.
“那么卡特琳娜·亚历山德罗芙娜呢？”库兹马问道。

Levin was not by now struck as he had been at first by the fact that to get from one end of Moscow to the other he had to have two powerful horses put into a heavy carriage, to take the carriage three miles through the snowy slush and to keep it standing there four hours, paying five roubles every time.
列文现在并没有像最初那样感到震惊，因为要从莫斯科的一端到达另一端，他必须将两匹强大的马放在一辆重型马车上，使马车在雪泥中行驶三英里，然后让它在那里呆四个小时，每次付五卢布。

Now it seemed quite natural.
现在看来很自然。

‘Hire a pair for our carriage from the jobmaster,’ said he.
“从工头那里租一辆来装我们的马车，”他说。

‘Yes, sir.’
'是的先生。'

And so, simply and easily, thanks to the facilities of town life, Levin settled a question which, in the country, would have called for so much personal trouble and exertion, and going out onto the steps, he called a sledge, sat down, and drove to Nikitsky. On the way he thought no more of money, but mused on the introduction that awaited him to the Petersburg savant, a writer on sociology, and what he would say to him about his book.
就这样，莱文凭借城镇生活的便利，简单而轻松地解决了一个在乡下需要费很大的个人功夫和精力的问题，然后他走到台阶上，叫了一辆雪橇，坐下来。 ，然后驱车前往尼基茨基。路上，他不再考虑金钱，而是沉思着等待着他认识这位彼得堡学者、一位社会学作家的介绍，以及他会对他的书说些什么。

Only during the first days of his stay in Moscow Levin had been struck by the expenditure, strange to one living in the country, unproductive but inevitable, that was expected of him on every side. But by now he had grown used to it. That had happened to him in this matter which is said to happen to drunkards—the first glass sticks in the throat, the second flies down like a hawk, but after the third they’re like tiny little birds. When Levin had changed his first hundred-rouble note to pay for liveries for his footmen and hall-porter he could not help reflecting that these liveries were of no use to anyone—but they were indubitably necessary, to judge by the amazement of the princess and Kitty when he suggested that they might do without liveries,—that these liveries would cost the wages of two laborers for the summer, that is, would pay for about three hundred working days from Easter to Ash Wednesday, and each a day of hard work from early morning to late evening—and that hundred-rouble note did stick in his throat. But the next note, changed to pay for providing a dinner for their relations, that cost twenty-eight roubles, though it did excite in Levin the reflection that twenty-eight roubles meant nine measures of oats, which men would with groans and sweat have reaped and bound and thrashed and winnowed and sifted and sown,—this next one he parted with more easily. And now the notes he changed no longer aroused such reflections, and they flew off like little birds. Whether the labor devoted to obtaining the money corresponded to the pleasure given by what was bought with it, was a consideration he had long ago dismissed. His business calculation that there was a certain price below which he could not sell certain grain was forgotten too. The rye, for the price of which he had so long held out, had been sold for fifty kopecks a measure cheaper than it had been fetching a month ago. Even the consideration that with such an expenditure he could not go on living for a year without debt, that even had no force. Only one thing was essential: to have money in the bank, without inquiring where it came from, so as to know that one had the wherewithal to buy meat for tomorrow. And this condition had hitherto been fulfilled; he had always had the money in the bank. But now the money in the bank had gone, and he could not quite tell where to get the next installment. And this it was which, at the moment when Kitty had mentioned money, had disturbed him; but he had no time to think about it. He drove off, thinking of Katavasov and the meeting with Metrov that was before him.
只是在他在莫斯科逗留的头几天里，列文才对开支感到震惊，这对住在乡下的人来说很奇怪，虽然没有什么成效，但却是不可避免的，这是各方对他的期望。但现在他已经习惯了。在这件事情上，他就遇到了这种情况，据说酒鬼也会发生这样的事——第一块玻璃卡在喉咙里，第二块像鹰一样飞下来，但第三块之后它们就像小鸟一样。当莱文兑换了他的第一张百卢布钞票来支付他的男仆和门房的制服时，他不禁想到这些制服对任何人都没有用处——但从公主的惊讶来看，它们无疑是必要的。当基蒂建议他们可以不用制服时，这些制服将花费两名工人夏季的工资，也就是说，将支付从复活节到圣灰星期三大约三百个工作日的费用，每个工作日都是辛苦的一天。从清晨工作到深夜——那张一百卢布的钞票确实卡在了他的喉咙里。但是下一张纸条却变成了为他们的亲戚提供晚餐的费用，花费了二十八卢布，尽管它确实让莱文兴奋地思考，二十八卢布意味着九份燕麦，人们会在呻吟和汗水中吃到这些燕麦。收割、捆扎、捶打、扬尘、筛分、播种，——他更容易与下一个分开。而现在他改变的音符不再引起这样的思考，它们像小鸟一样飞走了。为获得金钱而付出的劳动是否与用金钱购买的东西所带来的快乐相对应，这是他早已排除的一个考虑因素。他的商业计算也被忘记了，即有一个特定的价格，低于该价格他就无法出售某些谷物。 他一直坚持的黑麦价格现在比一个月前便宜了五十戈比。即使考虑到这样的支出他无法在没有债务的情况下生活一年，那也没有任何力量。只有一件事是必要的：银行里有钱，不用问钱从哪里来，这样就知道自己有钱买明天的肉。而这个条件目前已经满足了；他的钱一直存在银行里。但现在银行里的钱已经花光了，他也不知道该去哪里取下一期的钱。正是这一点，在基蒂提到钱的时候，让他感到不安。但他没有时间去想。他开车离开，想着卡塔瓦索夫和眼前与梅特洛夫的会面。

Chapter 3
第3章

Levin had on this visit to town seen a great deal of his old friend at the university, Professor Katavasov, whom he had not seen since his marriage. He liked in Katavasov the clearness and simplicity of his conception of life. Levin thought that the clearness of Katavasov’s conception of life was due to the poverty of his nature; Katavasov thought that the disconnectedness of Levin’s ideas was due to his lack of intellectual discipline; but Levin enjoyed Katavasov’s clearness, and Katavasov enjoyed the abundance of Levin’s untrained ideas, and they liked to meet and to discuss.
莱文在这次镇上之行中见到了很多他大学里的老朋友卡塔瓦索夫教授，自从结婚以来他就没有见过他了。他喜欢卡塔瓦索夫清晰而简单的生活观念。莱文认为，卡塔瓦索夫的人生观之所以清晰，是因为他本性的贫乏；卡塔瓦索夫认为莱文思想的脱节是由于他缺乏知识纪律造成的。但莱文喜欢卡塔瓦索夫的清晰，卡塔瓦索夫也喜欢莱文丰富的未经训练的想法，他们喜欢见面和讨论。

Levin had read Katavasov some parts of his book, and he had liked them. On the previous day Katavasov had met Levin at a public lecture and told him that the celebrated Metrov, whose article Levin had so much liked, was in Moscow, that he had been much interested by what Katavasov had told him about Levin’s work, and that he was coming to see him tomorrow at eleven, and would be very glad to make Levin’s acquaintance.
莱文读过卡塔瓦索夫书中的某些部分，并且很喜欢它们。前一天，卡塔瓦索夫在一次公开演讲中见到了列文，并告诉他，列文非常喜欢他的文章的著名梅特洛夫正在莫斯科，他对卡塔瓦索夫告诉他的有关列文作品的内容很感兴趣，而且他明天十一点要来看他，并且很高兴认识莱文。

‘You’re positively a reformed character, I’m glad to see,’ said Katavasov, meeting Levin in the little drawing room. ‘I heard the bell and thought: Impossible that it can be he at the exact time!... Well, what do you say to the Montenegrins now? They’re a race of warriors.’
“我很高兴看到你确实是一个改过自新的人，”卡塔瓦索夫在小客厅里见到莱文时说道。 “我听到钟声，心想：不可能是他在准确的时间！……好吧，你现在对黑山人说什么？他们是战士的种族。

‘Why, what’s happened?’ asked Levin.
“为什么，发生了什么事？”莱文问道。

Katavasov in a few words told him the last piece of news from the war, and going into his study, introduced Levin to a short, thick-set man of pleasant appearance. This was Metrov. The conversation touched for a brief space on politics and on how recent events were looked at in the higher spheres in Petersburg. Metrov repeated a saying that had reached him through a most trustworthy source, reported as having been uttered on this subject by the Tsar and one of the ministers. Katavasov had heard also on excellent authority that the Tsar had said something quite different. Levin tried to imagine circumstances in which both sayings might have been uttered, and the conversation on that topic dropped.
卡塔瓦索夫简短地告诉了他战争中的最后一条消息，然后走进他的书房，向列文介绍了一个身材矮小、身材粗壮、外表令人愉快的男人。这是梅特罗夫。谈话简短地涉及了政治以及彼得堡高层如何看待最近发生的事件。梅特洛夫重复了他通过最值得信赖的消息来源得知的一句话，据报道沙皇和一位大臣就这个问题说过这样的话。卡塔瓦索夫还从权威那里听说沙皇说了一些完全不同的话。莱文试图想象两种说法可能被说出的情况，然后关于这个话题的谈话就停止了。

‘Yes, here he’s written almost a book on the natural conditions of the laborer in relation to the land,’ said Katavasov; ‘I’m not a specialist, but I, as a natural science man, was pleased at his not taking mankind as something outside biological laws; but, on the contrary, seeing his dependence on his surroundings, and in that dependence seeking the laws of his development.’
“是的，他在这里几乎写了一本关于劳动者与土地的自然条件的书，”卡塔瓦索夫说。 “我不是专家，但作为一个自然科学家，我很高兴他没有把人类视为生物规律之外的东西；相反，看到他对周围环境的依赖，并在这种依赖中寻求他发展的规律。

‘That’s very interesting,’ said Metrov.
“这非常有趣，”梅特罗夫说。

‘What I began precisely was to write a book on agriculture; but studying the chief instrument of agriculture, the laborer,’ said Levin, reddening, ‘I could not help coming to quite unexpected results.’
“我一开始就是写一本关于农业的书； “但研究农业的主要工具——劳动者，”莱文红着脸说道，“我不禁得出了相当意想不到的结果。”

And Levin began carefully, as it were, feeling his ground, to expound his views. He knew Metrov had written an article against the generally accepted theory of political economy, but to what extent he could reckon on his sympathy with his own new views he did not know and could not guess from the clever and serene face of the learned man.
莱文开始小心翼翼地阐述他的观点。他知道梅特洛夫写了一篇反对普遍接受的政治经济学理论的文章，​​但他能在多大程度上相信梅特洛夫对自己的新观点的同情，他不知道，也无法从这位学者聪明而平静的脸上猜出。

‘But in what do you see the special characteristics of the Russian laborer?’ said Metrov; ‘in his biological characteristics, so to speak, or in the condition in which he is placed?’
“但是你认为俄罗斯工人有什么特点呢？”梅特罗夫说道。 “可以这么说，是根据他的生物特征，还是根据他所处的状况？”

Levin saw that there was an idea underlying this question with which he did not agree. But he went on explaining his own idea that the Russian laborer has a quite special view of the land, different from that of other people; and to support this proposition he made haste to add that in his opinion this attitude of the Russian peasant was due to the consciousness of his vocation to people vast unoccupied expanses in the East.
莱文发现这个问题背后有一个他不同意的想法。但他继续解释自己的想法，即俄罗斯工人对土地有一种与其他人不同的非常特殊的看法；为了支持这一主张，他急忙补充说，在他看来，俄罗斯农民的这种态度是由于他意识到自己的使命是为东方广阔的无人居住的地区人民服务。

‘One may easily be led into error in basing any conclusion on the general vocation of a people,’ said Metrov, interrupting Levin. ‘The condition of the laborer will always depend on his relation to the land and to capital.’
“根据一个民族的普遍使命得出任何结论时，很容易犯错误，”梅特罗夫打断了莱文的话。 “劳动者的状况始终取决于他与土地和资本的关系。”

And without letting Levin finish explaining his idea, Metrov began expounding to him the special point of his own theory.
没等莱文把自己的想法解释完，梅特洛夫就开始向他阐述自己理论的特殊之处。

In what the point of his theory lay, Levin did not understand, because he did not take the trouble to understand. He saw that Metrov, like other people, in spite of his own article, in which he had attacked the current theory of political economy, looked at the position of the Russian peasant simply from the point of view of capital, wages, and rent. He would indeed have been obliged to admit that in the eastern—much the larger—part of Russia rent was as yet nil, that for nine-tenths of the eighty millions of the Russian peasants wages took the form simply of food provided for themselves, and that capital does not so far exist except in the form of the most primitive tools. Yet it was only from that point of view that he considered every laborer, though in many points he differed from the economists and had his own theory of the wage-fund, which he expounded to Levin.
莱文不明白他的理论的要点是什么，因为他没有花功夫去理解。他看到，梅特罗夫和其他人一样，尽管他自己的文章中攻击了当前的政治经济学理论，但他只是简单地从资本、工资和地租的角度来看待俄罗斯农民的处境。他确实不得不承认，在东部——俄罗斯的大部分地区——地租还为零，八千万俄罗斯农民中的十分之九的工资仅仅表现为自给自足的食物，迄今为止，除了以最原始的工具形式存在之外，资本还不存在。然而，他只是从这个角度来考虑每一个劳动者，尽管他在许多方面与经济学家不同，并且有自己的工资基金理论，并向莱文阐述了这一理论。

Levin listened reluctantly, and at first made objections. He would have liked to interrupt Metrov, to explain his own thought, which in his opinion would have rendered further exposition of Metrov’s theories superfluous. But later on, feeling convinced that they looked at the matter so differently, that they could never understand one another, he did not even oppose his statements, but simply listened. Although what Metrov was saying was by now utterly devoid of interest for him, he yet experienced a certain satisfaction in listening to him. It flattered his vanity that such a learned man should explain his ideas to him so eagerly, with such intensity and confidence in Levin’s understanding of the subject, sometimes with a mere hint referring him to a whole aspect of the subject. He put this down to his own credit, unaware that Metrov, who had already discussed his theory over and over again with all his intimate friends, talked of it with special eagerness to every new person, and in general was eager to talk to anyone of any subject that interested him, even if still obscure to himself.
莱文不情愿地听着，起初还提出了反对意见。他本想打断梅特洛夫，解释他自己的想法，在他看来，这会使梅特洛夫的理论的进一步阐述变得多余。但后来，他确信他们对此事的看法如此不同，永远无法理解彼此，他甚至没有反对他的说法，只是听着。虽然梅特罗夫现在说的话对他来说完全没有兴趣，但听他说话还是有一定的满足感。这样一个博学的人竟然如此热切地向他解释自己的想法，对莱文对这个主题的理解如此强烈和自信，有时甚至只是暗示他要了解这个主题的整个方面，这满足了他的虚荣心。他把这归咎于自己的功劳，没有意识到梅特罗夫已经和他所有的亲密朋友一遍又一遍地讨论过他的理论，他对每个新认识的人都特别热切地谈论它，而且总的来说，他也渴望与任何人谈论它。任何他感兴趣的主题，即使对他来说仍然晦涩难懂。

‘We are late though,’ said Katavasov, looking at his watch directly Metrov had finished his discourse.
“不过我们迟到了。”卡塔瓦索夫说完，梅特罗夫刚讲完话，他就看了看手表。

‘Yes, there’s a meeting of the Society of Amateurs today in commemoration of the jubilee of Svintitch,’ said Katavasov in answer to Levin’s inquiry. ‘Pyotr Ivanovitch and I were going. I’ve promised to deliver an address on his labors in zoology. Come along with us, it’s very interesting.’
卡塔瓦索夫在回答莱文的询问时说道：“是的，业余爱好者协会今天召开了一次会议，纪念斯温蒂奇的五十周年。” “彼得·伊万诺维奇和我要去。我答应就他在动物学方面的工作发表演讲。跟我们一起来吧，这很有趣。”

‘Yes, and indeed it’s time to start,’ said Metrov. ‘Come with us, and from there, if you care to, come to my place. I should very much like to hear your work.’
“是的，确实是时候开始了，”梅特罗夫说。 “跟我们走吧，如果你愿意的话，可以从那里到我这里来。”我非常想听听你的作品。

‘Oh, no! It’s no good yet, it’s unfinished. But I shall be very glad to go to the meeting.’
'不好了！还不好，还没完。但我会很高兴参加会议。

‘I say, friends, have you heard? He has handed in the separate report,’ Katavasov called from the other room, where he was putting on his frock coat.
‘我说，朋友们，你们听到了吗？他已经提交了单独的报告。”卡塔瓦索夫在另一个房间里喊道，当时他正在房间里穿礼服。

And a conversation sprang up upon the university question, which was a very important event that winter in Moscow. Three old professors in the council had not accepted the opinion of the younger professors. The young ones had registered a separate resolution. This, in the judgment of some people, was monstrous, in the judgment of others it was the simplest and most just thing to do, and the professors were split up into two parties.
就大学问题展开了一场谈话，这是那年冬天莫斯科的一件非常重要的事情。委员会中的三位老教授并没有接受年轻教授的意见。年轻人已经注册了一项单独的决议。这在一些人看来是骇人听闻的，但在另一些人看来却是最简单、最正义的事情，教授们分成了两派。

One party, to which Katavasov belonged, saw in the opposite party a scoundrelly betrayal and treachery, while the opposite party saw in them childishness and lack of respect for the authorities. Levin, though he did not belong to the university, had several times already during his stay in Moscow heard and talked about this matter, and had his own opinion on the subject. He took part in the conversation that was continued in the street, as they all three walked to the buildings of the old university.
卡塔瓦索夫所属的一方认为对方是无耻的背叛和背叛，而另一方则认为他们幼稚且缺乏对当局的尊重。莱文虽然不属于该大学，但他在莫斯科逗留期间已经多次听到和谈论过这件事，并对这个问题有自己的看法。当他们三个一起走向旧大学的建筑时，他参加了街上继续进行的谈话。

The meeting had already begun. Round the cloth-covered table, at which Katavasov and Metrov seated themselves, there were some half-dozen persons, and one of these was bending close over a manuscript, reading something aloud. Levin sat down in one of the empty chairs that were standing round the table, and in a whisper asked a student sitting near what was being read. The student, eyeing Levin with displeasure, said:
会议已经开始了。卡塔瓦索夫和梅特洛夫坐在一张铺着布的桌子周围，周围有六个人，其中一人正俯身在一份手稿上，大声朗读着什么。莱文在桌子周围的一把空椅子上坐下，低声询问坐在旁边正在读的内容的一名学生。学生不满地看着莱文，说道：

‘Biography.’
'传。'

Though Levin was not interested in the biography, he could not help listening, and learned some new and interesting facts about the life of the distinguished man of science.
尽管莱文对传记不感兴趣，但他还是忍不住去听，并了解了有关这位杰出科学家的生活的一些新的有趣的事实。

When the reader had finished, the chairman thanked him and read some verses of the poet Ment sent him on the jubilee, and said a few words by way of thanks to the poet. Then Katavasov in his loud, ringing voice read his address on the scientific labors of the man whose jubilee was being kept.
朗读者读完后，主席向他表示感谢，并朗读了诗人门特在禧年送给他的一些诗句，并对诗人说了几句话。然后卡塔瓦索夫用他响亮而响亮的声音宣读了他的讲话，内容是关于这位被纪念的人的科学工作。

When Katavasov had finished, Levin looked at his watch, saw it was past one, and thought that there would not be time before the concert to read Metrov his book, and indeed, he did not now care to do so. During the reading he had thought over their conversation. He saw distinctly now that though Metrov’s ideas might perhaps have value, his own ideas had a value too, and their ideas could only be made clear and lead to something if each worked separately in his chosen path, and that nothing would be gained by putting their ideas together. And having made up his mind to refuse Metrov’s invitation, Levin went up to him at the end of the meeting. Metrov introduced Levin to the chairman, with whom he was talking of the political news. Metrov told the chairman what he had already told Levin, and Levin made the same remarks on his news that he had already made that morning, but for the sake of variety he expressed also a new opinion which had only just struck him. After that the conversation turned again on the university question. As Levin had already heard it all, he made haste to tell Metrov that he was sorry he could not take advantage of his invitation, took leave, and drove to Lvov’s.
卡塔瓦索夫听完后，列文看了看表，发现已经过了一点，心想音乐会前应该没有时间读梅特洛夫的书了，事实上，他现在也不想这么做。在阅读的过程中，他思考了他们的谈话。他现在清楚地看到，虽然梅特洛夫的想法也许有价值，但他自己的想法也有价值，他们的想法只有在各自选择的道路上各自努力的情况下才能变得清晰并带来一些结果，而把任何东西都放在一起的话将一事无成。他们的想法结合在一起。莱文决定拒绝梅特洛夫的邀请，并在会议结束时走到他面前。梅特罗夫向主席介绍了莱文，当时他正与主席谈论政治新闻。梅特罗夫把他已经告诉莱文的话告诉了主席，莱文在他的新闻中也发表了他那天早上已经说过的同样的话，但为了多样化，他还表达了一个刚刚让他震惊的新观点。之后话题又转到了大学问题。莱文已经听到了这一切，他赶紧告诉梅特洛夫，他很抱歉不能利用他的邀请，然后告辞，开车去了利沃夫家。

Chapter 4
第4章

Lvov, the husband of Natalia, Kitty’s sister, had spent all his life in foreign capitals, where he had been educated, and had been in the diplomatic service.
利沃夫是基蒂妹妹纳塔利娅的丈夫，他一生都在外国首都度过，在那里他接受了教育，并一直在外交部门工作。

During the previous year he had left the diplomatic service, not owing to any ‘unpleasantness’ (he never had any ‘unpleasantness’ with anyone), and was transferred to the department of the court of the palace in Moscow, in order to give his two boys the best education possible.
去年，他离开外交部门，并不是因为任何“不愉快”（他从未与任何人发生过任何“不愉快”），并被调到莫斯科宫廷部门，以便给他两个男孩尽可能接受最好的教育。

In spite of the striking contrast in their habits and views and the fact that Lvov was older than Levin, they had seen a great deal of one another that winter, and had taken a great liking to each other.
尽管他们的习惯和观点截然不同，而且利沃夫比列文年长，但那年冬天他们还是见过很多面，彼此非常喜欢对方。

Lvov was at home, and Levin went in to him unannounced.
利沃夫在家，列文未经事先通知就走进了他家。

Lvov, in a house coat with a belt and in chamois leather shoes, was sitting in an armchair, and with a pince-nez with blue glasses he was reading a book that stood on a reading desk, while in his beautiful hand he held a half-burned cigarette daintily away from him.
利沃夫穿着一件系腰带的便服，脚踩麂皮皮鞋，坐在扶手椅上，戴着夹鼻眼镜，戴着蓝色眼镜，正在阅读书桌上的一本书，漂亮的手里拿着一本优雅地将半燃的香烟从他身边拿开。

His handsome, delicate, and still youthful-looking face, to which his curly, glistening silvery hair gave a still more aristocratic air, lighted up with a smile when he saw Levin.
他英俊、精致、依然年轻的脸庞，银光闪闪的卷发更显贵族气质，一看到莱文，脸上就绽放出笑容。

‘Capital! I was meaning to send to you. How’s Kitty? Sit here, it’s more comfortable.’ He got up and pushed up a rocking chair. ‘Have you read the last circular in the Journal de St. Petersbourg? I think it’s excellent,’ he said, with a slight French accent.
'首都！我本来想发给你的。凯蒂怎么样？坐在这里比较舒服。”他起身推开一张摇椅。 “你读过《圣彼得堡日报》上的最后一份通告了吗？我认为这非常棒，”他带着轻微的法国口音说道。

Levin told him what he had heard from Katavasov was being said in Petersburg, and after talking a little about politics, he told him of his interview with Metrov, and the learned society’s meeting. To Lvov it was very interesting.
莱文告诉他他从卡塔瓦索夫那里听到的在彼得堡所说的话，在谈论了一些政治之后，他告诉了他他对梅特罗夫的采访以及学会的会议。对于利沃夫来说，这非常有趣。

‘That’s what I envy you, that you are able to mix in these interesting scientific circles,’ he said. And as he talked, he passed as usual into French, which was easier to him. ‘It’s true I haven’t the time for it. My official work and the children leave me no time; and then I’m not ashamed to own that my education has been too defective.’
“这就是我羡慕你的地方，你能够融入这些有趣的科学圈子，”他说。当他说话时，他像往常一样转入法语，这对他来说更容易。 “确实，我没有时间。”我的公务和孩子让我没有时间；然后我并不羞于承认我的教育有太多缺陷。

‘That I don’t believe,’ said Levin with a smile, feeling, as he always did, touched at Lvov’s low opinion of himself, which was not in the least put on from a desire to seem or to be modest, but was absolutely sincere.
“我不相信，”列文微笑着说道，他像往常一样，感受到了利沃夫对自己的低评价，这绝不是因为想要显得谦虚或谦虚，而是出于对自己的评价。绝对真诚。

‘Oh, yes, indeed! I feel now how badly educated I am. To educate my children I positively have to look up a great deal, and in fact simply to study myself.
